HEADLINE: Some Insurers Halt Coverage for Vans Linkedto Rollovers 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
After deadly rollover crashes of 15-passenger vans that killed or injured young athletes, church choir members and summer campers, a growing number of colleges and churches are prohibiting or severely limiting the use of the vehicles, and some insurance companies are refusing to insure the vans as costly lawsuit settlements threaten to cut into their profits.
 Accidents involving athletes from Urbana University, Kenyon College, DePaul University, the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh and Prairie View A&M University within three months led federal officials to issue a well-publicized warning about the vans two years ago. 
 But the officials, from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, concluded that the vans, which are also commonly used by airport shuttle services and day care centers, were not inherently dangerous. Many of the problems, it said, are attributable to inexperienced drivers piloting fully loaded vehicles.
Last April the agency repeated its warning. The Marine Corps, which, like other military services, uses the vans widely, distributed the safety alert to all of those using the vehicles. Capt. Shawn Turner, a Marine spokesman at the Pentagon, said last night that the corps was considering limiting the use of the vans because of safety concerns. 
When carrying only a few passengers, the traffic agency said, the vans have a rollover rate that is similar to other light trucks and vans. But when fully loaded, the likelihood of a rollover is six times the usual. The insurers say the vans, even when lightly loaded, sometimes roll over if the steering wheel is jerked in an emergency maneuver.
The Ford Motor Company, which accounts for about 80 percent of the 21,000 15-passenger vans sold annually, acknowledges that its E350, Econline and Club Wagon models can be tricky to handle. But Carolyn Brown, a Ford spokeswoman, said: "If it is not overloaded and if it is driven properly, it is a very safe vehicle."
The problem with 15-passenger vans is similar to what Ford experienced two years ago with its Explorer sport utility vehicle. Both have high centers of gravity and thus can tip over more easily than cars if they have to negotiate sudden turns, as when a tire blows out.
Ford has been building similar vehicles for 40 years, Ms. Brown said, adding that sales were on the rise. "We would see no reason why an insurance company would not feel it was a worthy vehicle to insure," Ms. Brown said.
But the Colorado School Districts Self-Insurance Pool, the biggest insurer of public schools in that state, stopped issuing new coverage for the vans on July 1. And, on top of the average premium cost of $750 a vehicle, it imposed a $500 surcharge for customers with up to 10 of the vans.
GuideOne, a leading insurer of churches and their vehicles, announced last week that it had stopped selling new policies. Two other big church insurers, Church Mutual and Brotherhood Mutual, have issued safety advisories.
P. J. Crowley, a spokesman for the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group that represents major insurers including State Farm, said other companies were deciding case by case whether to insure the vans.
Fatal rollovers, however, have continued -- most recently in late June, when a Ford Econoline van carrying firefighters in Colorado crashed, killing five passengers. Between 1990 and 2000, the large, heavy vans were involved in 388 rollovers, killing 558 people, government records show. Comparable figures for other vehicles were not available.
Jeff Wigington, a lawyer in Corpus Christi, Tex., who has represented plaintiffs in half a dozen cases involving fatal crashes with the vans, says they ought to be recalled.
Other assessments have not gone that far, at least not publicly. But Jim Wallace, the chief executive of GuideOne, called the vehicles "inherently dangerous."
"Our underlying claims experience has been bad on these," he said. "We've had a number of heart-wrenching claims. They tend to be Sunday school classes going on retreat or on missions to help others. These things turn over, and a lot of people die or get injured."
GuideOne, based in West Des Moines, Iowa, said it would continue coverage on the 10,000 vans it already insures. But it is raising rates 20 percent to 25 percent and is trying to persuade van owners to replace them with small school buses.
Federal officials say they are powerless to recall a vehicle that may be difficult to handle but that has no specific mechanical defect.
"This is not a defect issue," Dr. Jeffrey Runge, the administrator of the federal agency, said through a spokesman. "It's a behavior issue with drivers and passengers."
The spokesman, Rae Tyson, added: "These vehicles don't handle like a passenger car, they handle more like a truck. And people who drive trucks understand you have to be particularly careful to avoid a situation that could lead to a rollover."
Critics of the traffic safety agency say it is as weak in response to the dangers of the 15-passenger vans as it was to the Ford Explorer problem.
Mr. Wigington called the agency's warnings in this case "merely a Band-Aid on a bleeding wound."
"With the Ford Explorer," he said, "it wasn't until many people died and there was a public outcry that the manufacturer took steps to redesign the vehicle."
The 15-passenger vans are popular in public school fleets because of their ample capacity and modest price -- usually less than $30,000 compared with $35,000 or more for a bus of similar size. Congress moved to ban them for public school use in 1974 because they were regarded as far less safe than standard school buses. But it left several loopholes that Representative Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, is trying to close with new legislation. His bill would also prohibit colleges and universities from using the vans.
"We're strongly with Congresssman Udall on this," said Wayne Scott, president of the American Association of Classified School Employees, a union that represents school drivers and other school employees except teachers in 40 states. "They're tremendously dangerous vehicles."
In Tennessee, the Department of Human Services, which oversees day care centers that use hundreds of the vans to transport small children, is imposing new requirements for drivers and by 2005 will ban the use of the vehicles. The University of Virginia has banned them, and the University of Texas athletic department has stopped using them while the university develops a systemwide program on their use, with some restrictions.
Dave Williams, who is in charge of insurance for the three vans of the First Baptist Church of Raytown, near Kansas City, Mo., said that until hearing from GuideOne he had had no inkling that the vans might be dangerous. "I was very grateful," he said, adding that he immediately made plans to replace the vans. He said that he was not surprised by the premium increase and that he planned to stay with GuideOne.
Eliminating a category of coverage is unusual for insurance companies. When claims begin rising, they usually simply increase premiums. In its 55-year history, for example, GuideOne has never eliminated a line of coverage for safety reasons. GuideOne and the Colorado insurer said they would stop issuing new policies out of concern for the safety of their customers and their own bottom lines. GuideOne said that of the crashes in which it paid out more than $100,000 in claims for injuries in the last five years, the cost for those involving 15-passenger vans averaged $492,000, compared with $350,000 for other vehicles.
But Cheryle Sullivan, the chief executive of the Colorado insurance pool, cited another reason. With such widespread notice of the dangers of the vehicles, she said, a court might determine that anyone using one was so reckless that the insurance would be nullified. GuideOne and the Colorado company both said that within a few years, they hope to have none of the vans on their books.
The national traffic safety agency, which began investigating the vans after several crashes involving college athletes, issued a warning to consumers in April 2001, focusing on the propensity of the vehicles to tip over. In that warning and a second one last April, the agency said only experienced drivers should operate the vans. It also stressed the use of seat belts. In another report on the vans, the agency said the overwhelming majority of the people who died in 15-passenger van crashes were not wearing seat belts.
After the government warning in April, Ford issued an advisory cautioning against "sharp turns, excessive speed and abrupt maneuvers."
In most states, people can drive these vans with a standard driver's license. But in January, GuideOne will require its customers either to get a commercial or a chauffeur's license or to pass a defensive driving course.
Richard Schaber, a spokesman for Church Mutual in Merrill, Wis., said his company felt an obligation to continue insuring the vans. "The 15-passenger van is the church vehicle of choice," he said. "So we need to insure them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The wreck of a 15-passenger van in which five firefighters from Oregon died this summer while on their way to battle forest fires south of Denver. From 1990 to 2000, the vans were involved in nearly 400 rollovers. (Associated Press)(pg. C14)

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Using Fiscal Tricks To Avoid Cuts, His Rivals Say 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki rode into office eight years ago as a fiscal conservative, railing about the fiscal gimmicks and spendthrift policies of his Democratic predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo.
 So it is no small irony that the two Democrats seeking to oppose him in this year's election -- one of them Governor Cuomo's son -- have leveled the same sort of charges against him. 
 The Democrats, Andrew M. Cuomo and H. Carl McCall, assert that the Republican governor cobbled together this year's budget with one-shot revenues and accounting tricks to avoid making cuts in an election year. They have also accused him of squandering the biggest surplus in state history by raising spending since 1998 instead of paying off debts. 
Mr. Pataki counters that New York, unlike most other states, avoided severe service cuts and tax increases this year because he had built up savings over his two terms. His aides say that the current budget is still on a sound footing, even taking into account weaker-than-expected revenues in the first third of the fiscal year.
It is too early to tell if the budget will fall apart right after the election, as Mr. Cuomo and some of the more pessimistic Albany lawmakers predict, budget analysts said. Yet the state's financial position could sharply worsen later this year unless the economy rebounds, they said.
What is certain is that the state will face an enormous budget shortfall next year of $5 billion to $7 billion, no matter who becomes governor, budget experts say. In essence, Mr. Pataki has pushed off painful cuts until next year by exhausting the state's reserves. "Because there were no real spending reductions here, it made next year's problem much worse," said E. J. McMahon, an analyst with the conservative Manhattan Institute.
In New York State, the governor proposes the budget for each fiscal year, beginning April 1. The Legislature can approve, strike out or reduce appropriations. Lawmakers can also add money for some programs, but the governor can veto those additions. A tradition of back-room budget negotiations has developed. The leaders refuse to pass the governor's budget until spending is passed for their priorities. This year was no different, despite the faltering economy, plummeting revenues and the fiscal fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks.
In January, Governor Pataki proposed a $88.6 billion budget, of which about $59 billion would come from state taxes and fees and the rest from federal grants. His proposal raised spending $4 billion and contained few major cuts aside from a freeze on education spending.
By early May, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders had agreed to add $600 million in spending, even as April tax revenues came in low. The final budget raised spending by 3 percent from the previous year, though budget officials were lowering predictions of income tax revenue by $2.5 billion, or 10 percent.
The only way for the governor and the Legislature to make ends meet was to spend down the state's savings and sweep out various pots of money earmarked for special purposes into the general fund. The budget spends about $3.1 billion in one-time revenues that will not be there next year, including savings. It leaves the state with a bare $710 million in reserves.
Since the budget passed, the revenue picture has not improved. Tax collections in the first four months of the fiscal year were $259 million below predictions, a drop the administration says owed more to the timing of payments than the economy. Mr. Pataki has stuck to his May prognosis that the state will collect about $40 billion in taxes this year, about $1 billion less than last year.
But the governor has carefully avoided saying what the budget gap will be next spring. In January, he predicted the state would have a $2.8 billion hole to fill.
That figure, however, does not take into account the spending added by the Legislature or the steep drop-off in income tax revenues the administration now predicts. When those are factored in, along with the one-shot revenues, the gap is likely to be at least $5 billion and could rise to $7 billion, several budget analysts said.
The Democratic candidates have tried to make the budget a campaign issue. Mr. McCall, who as state comptroller oversees spending, has criticized Mr. Pataki for raising the state's indebtedness during earlier economic expansion. He also has tried to pick away at Mr. Pataki's image as a fiscal conservative. "He squandered the biggest surplus in history," Mr. McCall said last week. "He didn't do the things I suggested, like paying down some of our existing debt or putting money in reserve."
For his part, Mr. Cuomo has painted the budget agreement between Mr. Pataki, the Assembly's Democratic leaders and the Senate's Republican majority as an election-year fraud. Casting himself as a reformer, Mr. Cuomo has tried to tar Mr. McCall with the same brush, charging he also is part of the "dysfunctional culture of Albany."
Mr. Pataki acknowledges that the state faces dire straits next year but denies that the budget is irresponsible. He points out that he came into office with a $5 billion deficit left by Governor Cuomo and has since presided over seven years of surpluses and four credit-rating upgrades.
Mr. Pataki cut the budget during his first two years in office and held spending flat in the third. Over the next four years, however, he raised state spending 16 percent higher than the inflation rate, with the largest jumps in election years. The red-hot economy of the 1990's made it possible for him to raise spending, cut taxes and still build up more than $3 billion in savings. Borrowing also rose about one-third, or $10 billion.
Michael McKeon, the governor's spokesman, dismissed Mr. McCall's criticisms as politically motivated and said Mr. Cuomo, who was in his father's administration, was being hypocritical. "I don't think the Cuomos have any standing," he said. "They left the cupboard empty."
But some budget watchers say tax collections are not improving and spending cuts may be needed in December. Income tax collections, the heart of the state's revenues, were especially sluggish from April through July, bringing in $2.1 billion -- or 23 percent -- less than in the same period last year. 
"It's hard to see how they meet their plan," said Elizabeth Lynam, a researcher with the Citizens Budget Commission. "Most of what they expected to lose for the entire year they already lost in the first quarter."

HEADLINE: The Case For Sanctions 

BYLINE:  By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank is a professor of economics at Cornell University's Johnson School of Management.

DATELINE: ITHACA, N. Y. 

 BODY:
From his approach to pollution abatement as governor of Texas to his approach to corporate malfeasance as president, George W. Bush has made voluntary compliance his motto. Explaining his initial opposition to strict criminal sanctions in the recently passed corporate fraud law, for example, he said that while tougher laws might help, "ultimately the ethics of American business depend on the conscience of America's business leaders."
 There are indeed limits to the law's ability to regulate human behavior. And public officials should try to nurture our inclination to do the right thing. But the downside to voluntary compliance is that it overlooks the critical role played by enforcement in society's efforts to curb self-interest for the common good. Granted, even laws and regulations with teeth might not be able to prevent offenses like the ones confessed this week by Michael J. Kopper, a former Enron financial executive. But without such enforcement measures, we are asking those who comply voluntarily to shoulder an unfair burden. 
 Consider the forces confronting honest executives as they weigh how to report their company's earnings. They know that many entries in the company's financial statements entail subjective judgments. Some, for instance, hinge on estimates and assumptions about the future, others on imperfect models for imputing monetary values to nonmarket assets. A broad range of earnings estimates could be defended as reasonable.
And therein lies the problem, because a company's ability to finance future growth depends strongly on how its reported earnings compare with those of its rivals. Indeed, this is how the capital markets decide which companies are most likely to succeed. Stock prices of corporations that report relatively low current earnings often fall sharply in the short run, increasing the risk of failure in the long run.
So it is difficult to see how even the most scrupulous executives could justify calculating their company's earnings on the basis of strictly neutral, let alone pessimistic, assumptions. On the plausible presumption that most other companies will report earnings near the optimistic end of the reasonable range, failure to do likewise would be to understate the company's relative prospects.
The problem is compounded by the fact that the standards defining acceptable accounting judgments depend on context. When almost all companies issue optimistic earnings reports, such reports come to be viewed as normal. Even the most cautious executives then feel pressure to report their earnings even more optimistically, in turn creating room for their more aggressive counterparts to push the envelope further.
Given this dynamic, and the enormous sums at stake in the battle for corporate survival, careful monitoring and stiff sanctions against violators are essential. It is one thing to ask people to forgo ill-gotten gains but quite another to ask them to commit economic suicide.
If we want people to restrain themselves for the common good, the sacrifices we demand must be made by everyone. This applies to areas outside of business as well. To ask athletes not to use steroids in the absence of effective sanctions is to penalize those who comply while rewarding those who don't. To ask people to be scrupulous in their tax filings in an audit-free environment is to reduce the effective tax rate for dishonest taxpayers while increasing it for honest ones.
Congress was wise to include criminal sanctions in its recent corporate fraud legislation. Major League Baseball would do well to include random testing and stiff penalties in the steroid ban under consideration. And President Bush should rethink the wisdom of the sharp cuts in the I.R.S.'s staff and budget, which have reduced the tax audit rate by more than half since 1996.
As Adam Smith himself was well aware, the invisible hand of the marketplace does not always produce the greatest good for all. When individual and social interests conflict, voluntary compliance must be supplemented by sanctions potent enough to matter. As President Ronald Reagan put it, "Trust, but verify."

HEADLINE: Talk-Show Tips for Bill Clinton 

BYLINE:  By Ben Stein; Ben Stein, a writer and actor, is the host of "Win Ben Stein's Money."

DATELINE: MALIBU, Calif. 

 BODY:
Dear Mr. Clinton,
I hear you might host a television talk show. Congratulations.
 But before you put on your lavaliere mike and your earpiece and slick back that roguish mane of gray hair, here's some advice I offer as a former host of a nighttime talk show, as the potential host of an upcoming daytime talker and as a former toiler in the White House. 
 First of all, on a "talk show," the host has to let someone else talk. Even an informed, lovable former president does not get to talk the whole time. Are you prepared to let the woman whose husband has left her for a younger man, the sex expert, the makeover stylist or the free-trade economist be the center of attention? That yearly salary of almost $50 million doesn't seem like so much now, does it? (It is, for the record, about 100 times more than what I am supposed to be paid for my daytime show, but then you are 100 times more famous and have about 100 times more hair than I do.)
Second, as the network has probably told you, daytime talk shows are aimed primarily at women. This means you provide these women with tips on their health and their looks and their finances. You make them feel as if you are their advocate, the way Phil Donahue did in years past and still does. You give them hope and information and a touch of excitement. But in general you do not get to spend time with them.
Third, on television, with a busy schedule of "gang taping" lots of shows far in advance so you can still be the headline act at those big-bucks real-estate seminars in Shanghai, you have to show up on time, not on B.C.T., Bill Clinton Time, which is two hours late. If you get the union crew into overtime and then double time and then "golden" time (something like triple overtime), you get into serious trouble. Do you really want to get into trouble with people who are paying you $50 million? (Not that I'm obsessed with this figure.)
If these problems don't faze you, you may be perfect for the job. After all, the essence of daytime talk is to feel the audience's pain, and we know you are the maestro there. A large part of this gig is just being a sexy and sympathetic man of a certain age, and you've got that locked up (until my show starts, that is). So you might want to think up some gimmicks. Start your own book club, for example. (Resist the temptation to assign "Earth in the Balance.")
I just want to warn you that once you start earning $50 million (did I mention that amount already?), you're going to start to wonder why you have to keep working at all. Trust me, you have to. So go for it. Your program may yet be the ultimate reality show about death and resurrection. Just please leave a few million viewers for me.

HEADLINE: Sustaining the Planet 

 BODY:
With the American president a conspicuous exception, leaders from nearly 100 nations will begin assembling next week in Johannesburg to address the future of life on this planet. At the heart of the conference is a formidable if now familiar challenge -- figuring out ways to bring economic well-being to billions of people now trapped in poverty without destroying the land, water, air and biodiversity required to sustain life itself.
 It will be the third such meeting in three decades, and if the past is any guide, the Johannesburg conclave -- known formally as the World Summit on Sustainable Development -- will be long on good intentions and short on specific solutions. Even so, it is a meeting well worth having. The Stockholm summit in 1972 inspired the industrialized nations to begin cleaning up their air and water. The Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992 produced treaties on global warming and biodiversity that, while vague, officially committed at least the industrialized nations to address two major environmental threats that had long gone unattended. In the last decade these challenges have not receded, while others have arisen. 
 President Bush's absence is regrettable, and reinforces his well-deserved reputation -- flowing in part from his rejection of the Kyoto Protocol on global warming -- for indifference to environmental problems and reflexive hostility to multilateral remedies. If anyone can dispel that impression, however, it is Secretary of State Colin Powell, who will lead the American delegation. Though his visit will be brief, Mr. Powell at least shares the view that environmental degradation and poverty can destabilize nations as surely as actual warfare. 
There is little doubt that current patterns of development are unsustainable over the long term. As the U.N. secretary general, Kofi Annan, recently observed, fish stocks continue to shrink, tropical rain forests (and associated species) continue to recede, and agricultural productivity declines while the number of mouths to feed grows. 
In 25 years, two-thirds of the world may be living without enough water. Meanwhile, use of fossil fuels means increased global warming. Millions die every year from tropical diseases, waterborne germs and parasites and the pollution that results from the unshielded indoor combustion of primitive fuels. Eliminating these diseases must be part of any development program.
Sustainable development may mean higher short-run costs. It can also generate longer-range savings. The Times has reported a large German insurance company's estimate that the consequences of global warming will cost as much as $300 billion annually by 2050. Health problems arising from poor sanitation, habitat destruction and loss of biodiversity also carry a high economic price. For these and other reasons, the conference's organizers have rejected the notion that nations must choose between economic growth and environmental protection. Both are indispensable. 
Mr. Bush's opposition to Kyoto means that global warming will not get the attention it did 10 years ago in Rio. However, Secretary Powell has generally expressed support for Mr. Annan's agenda, and is expected to announce a package of health, environmental and food programs aimed at helping Africa after he arrives. In the conference's aftermath, he needs to go further and lead an effort to reconfigure American foreign aid as a whole to underwrite sustainable development.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Steel Tariffs Put G.O.P. On the Spot In Campaigns

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
When President Bush set aside his free-trade principles in March and imposed steep new tariffs on imported steel, many critics said he had sacrificed sound economic policy to win political support in important electoral states like Pennsylvania and Ohio.
 That contention may or may not be valid, and White House officials say they had numerous good reasons for protecting a long-troubled industry. 
 But as became clear Thursday, when the administration backpedaled a bit by exempting 178 kinds of steel imports from the new tariffs, protectionism carries its own political risks.
Even though steel companies have benefited from the new tariffs, many American manufacturers have complained about sharply higher prices and difficulties in obtaining specialized kinds of steel that are available only from foreign suppliers. 
Thursday's partial reversal was an attempt to smooth over those competing interests, opening the path to the kinds of steel that are difficult or impossible to buy from American producers.
But instead of smoothing the waters, it provoked immediate protests from American steel producers, which had opposed more than half of the exemptions and said the effect of the benefits accrued from the original ruling would be sharply diluted.
For Republicans fighting to hold onto their tiny six-seat majority in the House and to win the one seat needed to reclaim the Senate, that poses a problem.
Pennsylvania alone has at least two hard-fought House races in areas that produce steel or have experienced the closing of big mills. Ohio and Indiana each have at least one serious election battle in a steel area, and voters throughout the region are anxious about imports of many types.
G.O.P. candidates, who normally pride themselves on their pro-business credentials, are already on the defensive about public anger over Enron and other corporate accounting scandals. Now lawmakers in steel states may have to confront accusations of not doing enough to support their home industry.
Representative Patrick J. Toomey, a Republican in the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania, is in a combative race against Ed O'Brien, a longtime local leader in the United Steelworkers of America. Bethlehem Steel has already shut its operations in the district, but tens of thousands of retired steel workers are still there.
"The steel industry is already gone," Mr. O'Brien said in a phone interview today. But, he added, the proliferation of new exclusions from the steel tariffs makes it easier to attack his opponents' credibility as an advocate for ordinary workers.
"My opinion from the get-go was: What is it they were really trying to do to save our industry? Was this just a pre-election plot to give candidates a chance to play as if they were on the side of workers?"
Representative Phil English, a Pennsylvania Republican who represents Erie and is chairman of the Congressional Steel Caucus, acknowledged that the Bush administration's most recent twist on steel had caused heartburn.
Today, one day after companies like U.S. Steel and Weirton Steel said they were "very disappointed" by the administration's latest move, Mr. English found himself defending the need to "balance" competing interests.
"We know that many people in the steel industry are concerned," Mr. English said, "but also recognize that the administration has some very difficult balancing to do in order to get the details right."
Indeed, he added, there is delicate political balance even with Pennsylvania. "The criticism I've been hearing from my district is more from steel consumers, who have been seeing the price of their supplies go up," he said.
There are ample reasons to complain. Many steel prices have jumped 35 percent to 60 percent since the tariffs were imposed, and many American manufacturing companies have complained loudly about being unable to obtain many kinds of steel that come only from foreign suppliers.
Few people dispute that the American steel industry is in dire trouble. More than 30 companies are in bankruptcy proceedings, and most others are running big losses.
But many experts say the industry's biggest problem is high "legacy costs" -- jargon for the costs of health and pension benefits for tens of thousands of retired workers, costs that are a hangover from the years before steel mills drastically reduced the employment levels.
For many, if not most, steel products, prices in the United States are higher than those in Europe and elsewhere. According to studies by the American Institute for International Steel, a lobbying group that represents steel importers, the spread between American and foreign steel prices has widened greatly since the tariffs were imposed.
To the extent that President Bush was hoping to bring the G.O.P. more blue-collar votes, the steel tariffs provide at best a mixed benefit.
All of the American carmakers have sought exemptions for steel imports they say they cannot acquire easily elsewhere. So have manufacturers of appliances and electrical equipment, and scores of smaller metal-forming companies that are themselves in steel-producing states.
The Bush administration's latest attempt to strike a balance cheered up many steel-using companies as well as leaders in Europe and Japan who are still bitterly fighting the American barriers.
But the puzzle of steel protection has hardly been resolved. Next week, the International Trade Commission is expected to decide on whether American producers of cold-rolled steel are being injured by imports and therefore need protection, too.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Cuomo in the Clinton Years

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN (NYT)

 BODY:
 Andrew M. Cuomo began running these two similar television advertisements on his record as the secretary of housing under President Clinton. One, "Real Results," will be broadcast upstate; "Real Resume" will be broadcast in the New York City area.

PRODUCER -- Squier, Knapp & Dunn

ON THE SCREEN -- Both commercials show dual screens against a dynamic blue-and-white background. Each screen flashes images of Mr. Cuomo. When the narration turns to his time as the head of housing and urban development, both screens show him with President Clinton.
As the male narrator touts Mr. Cuomo's accomplishments, official-looking citations appear on the screen: "Source: Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged." and "Source: the White House, Nov. 8, 1999."
Later, a blue lowercase "ny" appears on a white background, superimposed with the words "Andrew Cuomo for governor. Strong leadership. Real results. 

THE SCRIPT -- "Andrew Cuomo has a record of real results. He started a nonprofit that took 75,000 people off our streets and into jobs and housing." (In the downstate ad, the voiceover adds, "The New York Times labeled it 'a national housing model.' ")
"As President Clinton's secretary, Cuomo overhauled a $30 billion agency. He managed a $500 billion mortgage fund bringing home ownership to record highs." (In the upstate ad only: "Cuomo delivered $1.6 billion in economic development aid to upstate New York.") Both ads say his economic development programs created "300,000 new jobs nationwide."
"Andrew Cuomo. Strong leadership. Real results."

ACCURACY -- There are many claims in this ad, and there are many opinions on Mr. Cuomo's record at HUD. His other claims are equally difficult to sort out. During his tenure at HUD, government auditors criticized the agency for lack of financial controls, although they noted some improvement. One scandal that plagued the agency was the disclosure that 500 properties, many in Harlem, had been sold to real estate speculators and left undeveloped.

SCORECARD -- At 44, Mr. Cuomo has a far shorter resume than his rival in the Democratic primary, H. Carl McCall, but with this ad he makes the most of it, emphasizing his management experience even while it keeps Mr. Cuomo, who polls say tends to inspire dislike, from directly addressing the camera. The array of facts, figures and images might make viewers dizzy. SHAILA K. DEWAN (NYT)

HEADLINE: Back to Babbington 

BYLINE:  By Jennifer Reese; Jennifer Reese is a writer in San Francisco.

 BODY:
 INFLATING A DOG
The Story of Ella's
Lunch Launch.
By Eric Kraft.
Illustrated. 242 pp. New York:
Picador USA. $25.
 STARTING in the mid-1970's, Eric Kraft began publishing (initially self-publishing) a series of eccentric novels and stories about a winsome Long Island boy named Peter Leroy. Every few years since, he has provided another installment to this sprawling collection. Because the books aren't written in chronological order, they don't trace Peter's life so much as add more layers to it, moving freely back and forth from Peter's middle years to his childhood in the fictional town of Babbington, on Bolotomy Bay. They include photographs, diagrams, fragments of plays and other ephemera, forming an unpredictable, gentle and often charming literary collage.
"Inflating a Dog," the latest Peter Leroy volume, is a novel about physical and spiritual buoyancy. It's about keeping boats afloat and hopes aloft, and how, in one summer of Peter's adolescence, he manages to do both. It isn't Kraft's best work, but it has some lovely moments.
At 56, Peter is looking back at a period in his early teens when his mother, Ella, was losing faith in herself and life's possibilities. In an attempt to become something more than a bland housewife, Ella had started various crackpot businesses, from candy making to "high-heel-low-heel convertible shoes." None succeeded. "Most of the time," Peter observes, "there was a deadness in my mother's eyes, the blankness that comes with the expectation that nothing will make today different from yesterday or tomorrow different from today."
In 2002, we would label Ella "depressed," but in the wonderful invented idiom of the book she is "deflated." In the town of Babbington in the 1950's, Peter reports, teenagers had devised a very precise vocabulary to describe the phenomenon of enthusiasm and all its nuances. They had started with the phrase "blown up" -- or, more elegantly, "inflated" -- to capture the feeling of being filled with amazement, delight and inspiration, and had come up with ever more exact locutions: "When we suspected people of faking or exaggerating a response, we said that they were pumping themselves up. People who tried too hard, particularly those who wanted to make very sure that everyone saw how blown up they could get in the inflationary presence of art or nature, we called blimps or gas bags."
Over the course of the summer, Peter has two projects: to inflate his mother and to seduce Patti Fiorenza, a schoolmate of cartoonishly exaggerated sexual allure. The plot revolves around Ella's purchase of a leaky clam boat (clams are a recurring Kraft motif, his madeleines) and her plan to offer catered cruises. Peter believes it is essential that Ella never discover the seriousness of the boat's leak. "Hope," he explains, "is like a warm breeze that lifts and lofts and carries us on when we hardly have the will to carry on otherwise." Every night he sneaks away and pumps out the boat, so that his mother can proceed in ignorant bliss and, with luck, regain her zest for life. (The book's title comes from a mystifying episode in "Don Quixote" in which a madman inflates a dog, a difficult feat that is presented as the equivalent of keeping Ella's dream intact.)
NO one who has ever taken a creative writing course can have escaped the admonition to show, not tell. Well, so much for that old saw. Kraft does both, but his showing is far less effective than his telling. When he sets his characters in action, the book wobbles. The plot is undeniably original, but also far-fetched and haphazard; it's not particularly funny, just kooky. Kraft is unfailingly and refreshingly generous with his characters, but, perhaps because many have figured in earlier novels, they aren't richly developed here.
On the other hand, when he sits back and starts telling us, for example, about the invented language of 1950's Babbingtonians, we're hooked. Kraft's erudite asides and abstract musings are what make "Inflating a Dog" fascinating and sophisticated reading.

HEADLINE: Deep Six 

BYLINE:  By Garrett Epps; Garrett Epps teaches constitutional law at the University of Oregon. His latest book is "To an Unknown God: Religious Freedom on Trial."

 BODY:
 DESPERATELY SEEKING
CERTAINTY
The Misguided Quest
for Constitutional Foundations.
By Daniel A. Farber and Suzanna Sherry.
208 pp. Chicago:
University of Chicago Press. $30.
"WHAT you suggest may be all very well in practice," complained the apocryphal French philosopher, "but it will never work in theory." American law professors laugh uneasily. In recent years legal academe has been hungrily pursuing theoretical cachet. Law journals, once narrowly focused and written largely for judges and practicing lawyers, now feature work based on economics, history, philosophy and deconstructionist theory. Daniel A. Farber and Suzanna Sherry are concerned that the result -- in constitutional law, at least -- offers little help (and possible harm) to those who must argue or decide cases. Farber teaches at the University of Minnesota and Sherry at Vanderbilt. Their previous book, "Beyond All Reason," assailed the legal left for what they viewed as its relativism and sloppiness. In "Desperately Seeking Certainty," they rebuke six thinkers they see as shoehorning the Constitution into idiosyncratic theoretical pigeonholes.
The targets span the spectrum. Three -Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, the former judge Robert Bork and the University of Chicago professor Richard Epstein -- are distinctly on the right. Two others -- Bruce Ackerman of Yale and Ronald Dworkin of Oxford and New York University -- are old-fashioned liberals. The sixth, Akhil Reed Amar of Yale, defies easy characterization but is also on the left side of the spectrum. What all six share, the authors say, is "foundationalism" -- a belief that scholars can find one master key to interpreting the Constitution -- as well as "a penchant for novelty" that slights traditional approaches to constitutional interpretation. In particular, Farber and Sherry argue, these theorists devalue the common-law method of argumentation that builds on previous cases, and they pick each man apart in successive chapters that are lively and clear, but of somewhat uneven quality.
The unevenness arises because the six thinkers are not really comparable. Bork, for example, was once a brilliant academic, but in the years since the Senate rejected him for the Supreme Court, he has settled for lip-synching the current conservative line. The authors, in fact, are able to attribute a consistent theory to Bork ("originalism," or absolute commitment to the specific results supposedly intended by the Constitution's framers) only by ignoring much of his most recent book, "Slouching Towards Gomorrah," which argues against judicial review altogether. Scalia, who espouses a more nuanced form of originalism, is a first-class intellect -but as a judge on a nine-member court, he must decide concrete cases and win votes from colleagues, meaning that his work cannot attain perfect consistency.
Dworkin and Epstein discern their individual moral beliefs in the Constitution's general phrases. Dworkin, as a liberal philosopher of law, sees the document as requiring "equal concern" from government toward each citizen, and he instructs judges to apply this principle in accordance with the best moral reasoning available. Farber and Sherry point out that the plasticity of moral concepts means that in some ways Dworkin's position may not even be amenable to meaningful discussion.
Epstein, a libertarian thinker, sees property as the foundation of morals, and regards limits on its use as akin to robbery or trespass. This theory provides a clear prescription for judges -- strike down most economic regulation -- but it has little basis in history, case law or even most moral theory.
Ackerman contends that American history reveals recurrent periods of "higher lawmaking," when popular consent changed the meaning of the Constitution, even without formal amendment. But as Farber and Sherry note, he restricts this useful insight to three "constitutional moments," the founding, Reconstruction and the New Deal. It won't wash, they argue: "Constitutional change often occurs gradually and incrementally, not in momentous upheavals during which the People arise from their slumber."
Amar states that the Constitution and Bill of Rights were written largely to protect majority, not individual, rights. For example, he sees the First Amendment's protection of free speech as focused all but exclusively on popular assemblies, not the lonely dissenter.
AMAR calls his method "intertextualism." Simply put, an intertexualist examines how a term is used elsewhere in the Constitution, and provides an interpretation that makes the meaning consistent. Unfortunately, as the authors indicate, words often shift meanings in context. In addition, "Amar's history is too simplistic, too neat, and for that reason alone it is unlikely to be fully accurate." 
"Desperately Seeking Certainty" is at its best on the attack; the authors' criticisms are clear, sensitive and usually fair (though a certain well-known law school repeatedly evokes snideness, as in: "Perhaps, like Amar, Ackerman has been too long steeped in the rarefied atmosphere of the Yale Law School and too little exposed to what We the People have really been up to.") It is only a small disappointment -- and hardly a surprise -- that their solution is less cogent than their critique, and is also devoid of predictive or prescriptive value.
Farber and Sherry suggest that judges should use "the common law method that builds principles up from individual cases rather than down from abstract theories." But they provide little discussion of how that is properly done. They also argue for "legal pragmatism," which they define rather vaguely as "constitutional law as an evolving compromise." They might be a bit more forthright in noting that this definition of pragmatism offers little to constrain judges from enacting their policy preferences.
Farber and Sherry recognize that they have not provided a full explanation of how the Constitution should be interpreted. They promise a sequel that will set out "the implications of a pragmatist approach to constitutional adjudication." When it appears, of course, the authors' six targets will have their chance at revenge.

HEADLINE: Deoxyribonucleic Acid Trip 

BYLINE:  By Gina Maranto; Gina Maranto is the author of "Quest for Perfection: The Drive to Breed Better Human Beings."

 BODY:
 REDESIGNING HUMANS
Our Inevitable Genetic Future.
By Gregory Stock.
277 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company.
$24.
 GREGORY STOCK has written an enthusiastic book in support of germ-line manipulations -- that is, making genetic modifications to eggs, sperm and embryos that can be passed on to future generations. Like previous explorations of the subject by the ethicist Joseph F. Fletcher, the lawyer John Robertson and the biologist James Watson, among others, "Redesigning Humans: Our Inevitable Genetic Future" serves as an apologia for those scientists and physicians who are already edging toward such work in a piecemeal fashion in research labs and in vitro fertilization clinics around the world. It advocates the wholesale adoption of genetic manipulations with the purpose of finally taking control of human evolution. This, the author writes, "is the ultimate expression and realization of our humanity."
Because of the breadth of his scientific knowledge and his considerable flair as a writer, Stock -- who heads the program on medicine, technology and society at the School of Medicine of the University of California, Los Angeles -- is a forceful advocate. First and foremost, he says, such manipulations are inevitable -- an assertion he makes not only in his subtitle but repeatedly throughout his book. Stock may be correct, for many factors are driving genetic experimentation forward, including professional ambition, greed and the desperation of infertile couples who will submit to just about anything in order to have a child.
And it should be added that eugenic considerations have already entered into this enterprise (even though Stock states at one point that in the infertility field, no one "cares about such wild notions as human redesign"). Numerous practitioners of in vitro fertilization, starting with Robert Edwards of Baby Louise Brown fame, have discussed their goals for "improving" the species. Meanwhile, would-be parents readily buy into schemes to improve birth outcomes -- as they have done at least since the days of ancient Greece.
But to argue the inevitability of all this is to sidestep the paramount issue, which is how to balance the desires of researchers and of the potential consumers of laboratory technologies against the good of society. After all, scientists, when asked, will nearly always say that they would like to get on with their work unhampered by any sort of regulation.
However, unfettered science has not historically shown itself to be in the best interest of society, any more than unfettered government, religion or business have. The fact that biomedical tinkerings have brought benefits for some does not constitute a sufficient reason for concluding that the practitioners of the embryonic arts should have the right to pursue any and all lines of experiment. Nor is it an adequate argument to say that if banned, germ-line manipulations would simply move offshore or go to the black market. That may be true. But if the fact that people will seek to avoid the law were a reason not to have a law, we would have no laws at all.
Stock's overarching claim is that germ-line modifications will "write a new page in the history of life, allowing us to seize control of our evolutionary future," an echo of the classic eugenicist dream. New technologies will allow humans to make fundamental alterations to their individual genetic compositions and those of their children. The net effect, he says, will be to draw "reproduction into a highly selective social process that is far more rapid and effective at spreading successful genes than traditional sexual competition and mate selection." In the future, he claims, we will be "much more than simply human."
But Stock's assumptions regarding population biology and evolution are suspect. For example, he assures us that we needn't worry about any impact that germ-line alterations might have on the gene pool (like reducing genetic diversity) because the number of altered children would be quite small. But if the net effect of all those laboratory-engineered births is so negligible, how then can there be the major evolutionary changes he predicts? Moreover, while it is clearly possible to affect the genetic circumstances of small, reproductively isolated populations, most population geneticists would agree that the goal of bringing about substantial changes in a pool of six billion humans (and growing) is near to impossible, especially any time soon.
So the great collective enterprise Stock envisions will in all likelihood be limited only to the small percentage of people who can afford or gain access to these technologies. And then the issue becomes what these bermenschen might do with the rest of us.
STOCK frequently acknowledges problems with a particular line of experimentation, or impediments in the way of some of his predictions. But in each case, once he is done listing objections, he proceeds to a bold proclamation that effectively moots them all.
Nor do moral and ethical concerns slow him down for long. He declares, "If biological manipulation is indeed a slippery slope, then we are already sliding down that slope now and may as well enjoy the ride." The lesson he takes from history is that eugenics itself wasn't wrongheaded, just the nationalistic, totalitarian applications of it. "Given Hitler's appalling foray into racial purification," he writes, "European sensitivities are understandable, but they miss the bigger picture."
For Stock, this bigger picture is clear. The future is a time in which individuals will be able to go into a clinic and, through a simple procedure, obtain embryos fitted with chromosomal modules that will slow aging, eliminate disease and enhance personality, temperament, intellect and beauty. It's a pleasant enough fantasy. But even if evolution could be steered in a positive direction, why presume that humans have the wisdom to do so? "Redesigning Humans" is an act of both boosterism and reductionism. It admits but then ignores the enormous complexity of biological systems; it places biology firmly above social, ecological and economic considerations; and it reduces concepts like success in life to the purely physical, as if health and longevity were the only issues that mattered. Isn't it pretty to think so?

HEADLINE: COVER STORY; 
Women Seeking Men, None Too Carefully

BYLINE:  By Celestine Bohlen

 BODY:
Uma Thurman first saw "Hysterical Blindness," a bitter and funny play about women desperately seeking love in New Jersey, in 1997, the night before it closed Off Off Broadway. She had gone without expecting much but came away so moved and impressed that she decided to try her hand at producing and turn the play into a movie.
 "I found myself laughing and crying," Ms. Thurman said in a recent interview. "These characters were so familiar to me; I could see myself in them. It reflected life in both a secret and truthful way, and as a play about women -- I found it refreshing to have a view from the inside out, about how women feel about themselves." 
 Tonight on HBO, the characters who so captivated Ms. Thurman onstage five years ago will reappear in a film directed by Mira Nair ("Mississippi Masala," "Monsoon Wedding") and produced by Ms. Thurman, together with Jason Blum and Amy Israel. 
 In the film, which was the centerpiece of the Sundance Film Festival this year, Ms. Thurman plays the central character, Debby. "I think the responsibility falls very squarely on actresses these days to find good parts for themselves and others, at a time when cinema is not very actor-centered but concept- centered," she said over the telephone from Beijing, where she is filming "Kill Bill," a movie by Quentin Tarantino.
 At an Oscar party in Hollywood, Ms. Thurman asked Juliette Lewis, who had been nominated for an Academy Award for her supporting role in "Cape Fear," if she would be interested in playing Beth, a young single mother who is Debby's best friend.
 Debby is an intense, high-strung woman in her 20's who has a job as a warehouse clerk by day and at night stakes out the local bar, ready to pounce on any man who pays her the least attention. Beth, more easygoing, joins her in this continuing game of random, hope-filled flirtation, frequently leaving her 10-year-old daughter, Amber, at home alone. Meanwhile, Debby's mother, Virginia (Gena Rowlands), who has been single since Debby's father walked out on the two of them, is gingerly slipping into a new and kinder relationship with Nick, played by Ben Gazzara. Nick is an older man with honorable intentions but is instantly suspected by Debby, who is as suspicious as she is gullible, most of the time overlooking facts that are staring her in the face.
 The play, written by Laura Cahill, is set very specifically in 1987, in an era that has special meaning not only for Ms. Cahill, herself a Jersey girl who graduated from high school in Perth Amboy in the early 80's, but also for Ms. Thurman, who sees that decade as both poetic and tragic. "The 80's look like 'Happy Days' since Sept. 11," she said.
 In the film, the place is defined geographically as northern New Jersey -- Bayonne, to be precise -- where highways and bridges crop up in the background as a constant reminder of another, bigger world beyond the bars, the diners and the working-class neighborhoods that set the parameters of Debby's dreams.
 Ms. Cahill wrote "Hysterical Blindness" in 1994 and has since gone on to write more plays, including "Mercy," about single life on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, which was staged in 1998. But in adapting the script of "Hysterical Blindness" for the movie, she found herself exhilarated by the freedom that comes from working with a camera.
 "I had always wanted to go places with the script that you can't go onstage, so I was really happy to be able to do more," Ms. Cahill said. "It is not just about the emotions that were in the play, but it is also about what everything looks like -- the inside of the kitchens, the cars. In a movie you can do so much more."
 The proximity of New York City, where Ms. Cahill now lives, didn't figure in the stage version, but she said the shadow of the city was there for her growing up in New Jersey. "You are just over the bridge, and yet there are people I grew up with who would never come to New York," she said.
 That insularity has changed somewhat, she added, giving the movie the faint aura of a period piece. "I think the world is more open now than it was then," she said. "The economy got better since then, and people are a little more evolved."
 What attracted both Ms. Thurman and Ms. Lewis to the project was Ms. Cahill's unvarnished, unsentimental glimpse of the ways women deal with the opposite sex and with one another -- not just in North Jersey in the 80's, but in other places, at other times.
 "I don't think human nature is ever dated," said Ms. Thurman. "One of the great strengths of Laura's writing is that it is based on human observation."
 Those observations don't make for a very pretty picture: Debby and Beth are both self-centered and shortsighted, and the object of Debby's desire, a construction worker named Rick (Justin Chambers), has little to say for himself or to Debby, who has deluded herself into thinking that beneath his complete indifference is a man who cares. Rick and Debby don't have conversations; they have sex instead.
 "I had never seen this female point of view told so honestly -- the obsessiveness, the self-inflicted humiliation and people getting stuck in patterns of behavior that are passed on from generation to generation," said Ms. Lewis. "It was so honest, without artifice and without romanticizing. I love that."
 The difference between generations is shown through Virginia, Debby's mother, who is more patient than her daughter and more trusting in her relationship with Nick. "The way we approached men, the way we looked for love and relationships was so drastically different from our mothers," said Ms. Cahill. "We were probably too aggressive, and they were maybe too passive."
 But among themselves, the three generations of women, including the watchful and very perceptive Amber, are honest about what they want and what they are willing to do to get it. They have few secrets from one another, and that honesty and the affection that it generates is what keeps them close, and makes them real.
 "When I first started writing the play, I was just writing down the things that my friends and I were going around saying," Ms. Cahill said. "I really like to write what people say."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 8-25-02; 
Acceptance

BYLINE:  By Walter Kirn; Walter Kirn is the author, most recently, of "Up in the Air." He is a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
The news this year has offered Americans the chance to become connoisseurs of disillusionment. We've learned that high-level corruption, like fine wine, has an assortment of characteristic top notes, subtle accents and distinctive mouth feels that make for a range of tastes and aftertastes. Some scandals, like the priestly abuse of children, cause nausea. Others -- the big-money kind -- embitter. But just when the public must feel that it has sampled every vintage of deception, along comes the story of Princeton University's office of admission and its illicit visits to a Web site maintained by its counterparts at Yale to allow applicants to the freshman class to check whether they've been accepted. The staff poked through the files of several hopefuls, including that of Lauren Bush, the president's niece, who applied to both schools. 
 To what end, this bout of hacking? To gain some advantage in the competitive game of landing top talent and boosting the school's ratings in US News & World Report's next college guide? Or, as Princeton's own investigation of the incident suggests, were they merely testing the Yale site's security? (Or lack of it?) 
 Whatever the motives behind the furtive keystrokes, which Princeton promptly dealt with by reassigning and censuring the hackers, it seems unlikely to blight the school's prestige, either among those who dream of studying there or the parents who have mortgaged their homes to make this possible. This was a near-miss, as scandals go, an embarrassing unmasking that didn't quite happen. And yet it offers a chance to reconsider the peculiar mystique of the Ivy League itself, one of the last sacred national monuments still standing in this season of crumbling clay feet.
As the solemn doormen who guard the V.I.P. rooms of the American meritocracy, Ivy League admissions committees exist on a exalted social plane somewhere between Mount Olympus and the ozone layer. As inscrutable as the National Security Agency, as seemingly omniscient as the College of Cardinals and as secretive as the chemists at Coca-Cola, these obscure bureaucratic Magi decide, by means of esoteric formulas that you imagine are written in Aramaic and stashed in the subbasements of Gothic clock towers, precisely what combination of College Board scores, altruistic community involvement and ability to return a kickoff should qualify someone for a junior membership in the power elite. Their authority is intimidating and final, like the Federal Reserve's. They're the unmoved movers behind our human economy. 
The wonder is that, with all their influence, we agree to leave them alone in their maneuverings. While most other powerful social institutions, both public and private, must answer to an array of politicians, consumers, lawyers, inspectors general and organized pressure groups, the Ivies retain an aristocratic autonomy that the public seems loath to challenge or to second-guess. It's odd. Since who goes to Harvard this fall may substantially determine who runs the country 20 years from now, we all, in a sense, have an interest in Harvard's decisions -- and yet it's not an interest we pursue. Instead, we trust Harvard to come to its own judgments. Such blind faith just isn't like us. 
When so many Americans decline to exercise their right to be cynical, particularly nowadays, it can only be because there's something huge at stake -- a myth we sense we can't afford to tamper with. Here, it's the myth of the Ivy League degree as a real reflection of human excellence and as something for all young Americans to shoot for, even if it's assumed that most will miss and many others will give up before trying. It's a reason for immigrants' children to finish their homework. It's a reason for middle-class parents to buy savings bonds. Its intrinsic desirability and prestige are cultural counterweights to rather less noble but more relentless drives for money and fame and power for their own sakes. When the country loses its faith in C.E.O.'s, stock prices sink, but should it grow convinced that the system of meritocratic advancement itself is broken or corrupt, ambition and morale plunge. 
Our faith in any exclusive organization depends, of course, on how it has treated us personally. I'm a Princeton graduate myself, and for years I've harbored the self-serving belief that those who offered me a place there were indeed infallible judges of human potential who plugged my statistics into their patented formulas and sat back, stunned at the results. Had I been shown the door, I might think differently, but I doubt many people would have wanted to hear my gripes -- least of all those who were cramming for the College Boards that week or practicing jump shots from dawn to dinnertime. Sure, we suspect that the game is rigged at some level (Lauren Bush, best known to the public as a fashion model and a political relative, got yeses from both Yale and Princeton -- surprise!); but that's different from believing that it's a sham and that only a fool would would take his chances playing it. 
Princeton will be forgiven its little trespass, both because it appears that no harm was done to anyone and because when its new freshmen arrive for classes, their parents, younger siblings and high-school English teachers will want to -- will need to -- feel the trip was worth it. They, or someone they love and want the best for, may be dreaming of making it, too.

HEADLINE: A Main Artery of the 1800's 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KIRBY; DAVID KIRBY, who lives in Brooklyn, writes frequently for The Times.

 BODY:
NEVER did I imagine calling myself a canal nut, but that is what I became after researching and retracing the largely forgotten Delaware and Hudson Canal, an astounding feat of engineering performed in the 1820's to ferry coal from northeastern Pennsylvania to the Hudson River. Who knew that an old ditch could be so fascinating, and so beautiful?
 It turns out that thousands of inhabitants along the canal's route (and beyond) are equally enchanted by its story. I met many people who are passionately dedicated to preserving the memory of the canal, which closed in 1898 and now lies in ruins, and restoring the D & H to its place in American economic and social history. 
 The 160-mile journey from Carbondale, Pa., where anthracite coal was mined, to Kingston, N.Y., where it was loaded onto boats for New York City and elsewhere, is an odyssey into another America, when time was measured more in months than minutes, and when transportation technology was based largely on mules and gravity. 
I traveled on a cold weekend last April with my friend Jay, who lives in High Falls, N.Y., an important canal town about 20 miles northwest of Poughkeepsie. We made the trip in three days, driving about five hours a day on fine roads with endlessly scenic vistas. The journey is not just for history buffs. Many canal towns offer high-end dining, antiquing, shops and galleries with local artists. Between towns are hiking, biking, fishing, swimming, kayaking and birding. But it was the D & H we found the most beguiling.
Carbondale is the site of America's first underground anthracite mine, started not long after the end of the War of 1812 when "black diamonds" were mined here by two brothers from Philadelphia, William and Maurice Wurts. The war had ended with heavy restrictions on the export of British coal to America and, in 1824, the enterprising brothers brought anthracite to New York, where they heated a Wall Street coffeehouse with the newfangled fuel. Investors were so impressed, they bought out the million-dollar stock offer that day.
The company built an ingenious way to convey coal from mine to market. A "gravity railroad" was built to carry anthracite over Moosic Mountain and other ridges from Carbondale to Honesdale, Pa., where the canal began. Cars were hauled up a series of inclined planes by stationary steam engines at the head of each plane; they then were lowered down a series of planes on the other side of the mountain with an ingenious system of pulleys that brought the empty cars back up as the full ones glided into Honesdale.
In just three years, workers dug and blasted the 108-mile canal, lined it with clay, filled it with water to a depth of four feet, and built a berm, or towpath, for the pack mules to pull the barges along at one to three miles an hour. Engineers built 108 locks to lift and lower the barges.
Though the original source of the region's wealth, Carbondale today seems to be prospering the least. It's a somewhat sad, forgotten old company town with a bingo hall and thrift stores. Still, we loved its stoic beauty and faraway feel, its classical turn-of-the-century buildings and friendly residents.
Reminders of the D & H are displayed at the Carbondale Historical Society in City Hall, the remaining company office building (now a restaurant), and the forlorn monument in what's now called Gravity Park, on Route 6, where train cars got underway for Honesdale, 13 miles east.
Somehow, Honesdale escaped Carbondale's fate, and today is a vibrant town, its handsome Main Street lined with stately banks, antiques shops and homespun cafes. Old stone churches, some built on land donated by the D & H Company, grace the skyline. Even though the canal here was filled in long ago, Honesdale was its loading dock and served as an important link in the system, a badge it still wears proudly.
The Wayne County Historical Society is housed in an original D & H Company building in the center of town, near where coal was loaded onto barges. It includes a small, beautiful museum whose "Movin' Energy: The History of the D & H Canal" collection includes photos, maps, documents and other artifacts, a gravity railroad passenger car and a reproduction of the Stourbridge Lion, believed to be America's first commercial steam locomotive. Nearby, the Stourbridge Line, with old-fashioned cars, departs on excursions to surrounding attractions.
A 20-minute drive on Route 6 winds through deep woods and along the Lackawaxen River to Hawley, a lovely old canal hamlet. Antiques stores and architectural jewels, like the 1890 Presbyterian church, built in Queen Anne Stick style, abound. With 52 miles of shoreline, nearby Lake Wallenpaupack is the largest body of water in the Poconos and popular among anglers, boaters and campers.
Heading east on Route 590, we got our first glimpses of the D & H, with the canal on the left (partly filled in) and the river on the right. We realized we were actually driving on the old towpath.
A few miles on was Lock 31 and its canal house, a simple wooden two-story structure owned by the Rotary Club. Then the road forked and we followed the river on the right (at the "Woodlock Pines" sign). We stumbled upon rich remnants of the canal everywhere, including Kimbles, a canal stop now nearly deserted, and a cemetery with the graves of the Kimbles, the Rowlands and other families who operated the locks.
Lock 22 and its canal house are just down the road, and beyond, near Rowland, is Lock 19. Originally operated by the Rowland family, the locktender's cottage was purchased six years ago by Howard Leifman and Bill Voelkel, who are restoring the 1826 wood-and-stone house.
At Lackawaxen, five minutes farther by car, the canal met the Delaware River. In the 1800's the Delaware was slowed by a slack-water dam, allowing barges to be pulled across by rope. But timber-rafters on the river had to shoot rapids over the dam, and accidents were frequent. The canal company eventually hired Judge Thomas Ridgway to pay damage claims, and the stately Greek Revival house where he lived and worked is now the Roebling Inn on the Delaware, where we spent the night.
John Roebling, of Brooklyn Bridge fame, is the star architect of a major part of the D & H. When the canal was widened and upgraded in the 1840's, the company hired him to build aqueducts to traverse four different rivers, including the Delaware. (But the dam remained, as backup, and so did the accidents.)
Roebling's Delaware crossing, the country's oldest existing wire suspension bridge, was expertly restored by the National Park Service from 1985 to 1995, and includes a tiny but informative interpretive center in the tollhouse. The thought of coal barges crossing high above the river is astonishing.
The inn, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is run by Donald and JoAnn Jahn, who greet guests with warm smiles and expert local knowledge. Our comfortable room upstairs overlooked the river. Downstairs was a cozy parlor and dining nook, and outside, a sloping lawn to the pristine river, where beach chairs awaited summer.
We had dinner at Lackawaxen House, an old tavern and inn with stunning river views. The food was less than stunning, but not bad. Jay aptly labeled it "late 70's banquet hall cuisine."
Next morning, after a home-cooked breakfast at the Roebling Inn and a warm send-off, we crossed Roebling's bridge ( on the paved canal bed) to New York. The 21-mile drive south on Route 97, along the Delaware, is terrific, with many appealing stops for eating, fishing or canoeing, many with quirky names: Quicks Eddy, Pond Eddy, Sparrowbush.
Hawk's Nest is a spectacular stretch, reminiscent of the Rhine Valley, leading into historic Port Jervis, an important D & H town with rich canal heritage. The Minisink Valley Historical Society is housed here, adjacent to Fort Decker/St. John's Canal Hotel, a former tavern and trading post and now a fine little museum displaying artifacts from Colonial times through the canal era.
Much of the D & H in Port Jervis was filled in around 1900, after a drunken city elder supposedly toppled in and drowned. But accessible stretches of the canal bed and towpath remain, which the historical society is preserving as a public greenway.
Heading northeast on Route 209 to Cuddebackville, we stopped at the Neversink Valley Area Museum and D & H Canal Park. Roebling built another aqueduct here, across the Neversink River, and his stone abutments remain. The museum, which includes a full-size barge replica, was closed. But we walked the mile of fully restored towpath and water-filled canal, alone in the chill but entranced by the pastoral landscape.
The road north offers plenty of access to canal and towpaths, including the Basherkill wetlands and the Delaware and Hudson Canal Linear Park, a nearly completed 4.5-mile stretch of water and towpath, with wonderfully preserved locks and a drydock at Summitville. Other canal towns we visited included Wurtsboro (named for the brothers), Ellenville (whose library has a D & H collection) and Accord (formerly Port Jackson).
Arriving in High Falls, about 20 miles from Kingston, I checked into Locktender Cottage, a tiny, sagging but utterly appealing three-room, antique-filled B & B. It sits next to Lock 15 near another Roebling aqueduct ruin on Rondout Creek, its rusty ironworks visible in the stonework.
We dined at the 1797 Depuy Canal House, which owns the Locktender. The house is included in the National Register of Historic Places, and its interior is spectacular, with roaring fireplaces in every corner and Victorian cheer floating through the air. The service was warm, but the food, created by the owner and chef, John Novi, seemed a bit flashy and oddly overreaching for the setting. I had a lobster souffle appetizer with blue cheese and Pernod sauce ($16) and beef tenderloin ($37), which was good, but the $100-a-person tab (with wine, tax and tip) seemed excessive.
A delicious breakfast, at Chefs on Fire, a bistro in the Canal House's charming cellar, came with the room. We walked it off exploring Five Locks Walk. The locks here are deep and straight, their stonework mortarless and perfectly plumb, like Incan temples. There were several granite stumping posts, to which barges were once tied, and we traced our fingers along the polished rope burns left in the stone.
That afternoon we visited the splendid D & H Canal Historical Society and Museum in High Falls, with its working models of a lock and a gravity railroad, excellent photos and paintings, and canal artifacts.
Finally, we traced the remaining miles of canal. At charming Rosendale, we took Creek Locks Road, past more towpath and locks, until we hit Lock 1, in Eddyville. A tidal lock, it opened onto Rondout Creek, where barges completed the journey to Kingston, on the Hudson, with its still-vibrant waterfront and maritime museum.
Lock 1 marked the end of the canal, which closed when railroads rendered the mule barges obsolete. The lock stands as a final glorious ruin, a sentinel of a long-past marvel whose memory and remains so many still try to preserve.

Along the route where the coal was carried
 An excellent D & H Heritage Corridor map and guide was issued last June in coordination with the National Park Service. It is available from most visitor bureaus in the region, including the Pocono Mountains Vacation Bureau, (800) 762-6667, and Orange County (N.Y.) Tourism, (800) 762-8687.
