HEADLINE: FILM; 
At Play With Weirdly Morphing Images and Sounds

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
IN 1967 there appeared a 45-minute film called "Wavelength." It instantly made its director, Michael Snow, one of the most famous avant-garde filmmakers in the world. The archetype of cinematic Minimalism, the film was dominated by a continuous zoom shot that originated at the rear of a loft and closed in on a small photograph of waves placed between the loft's windows (a photo taken by Mr. Snow of the East River in Manhattan).
 At the time, Mr. Snow, who is from Toronto, had been living in New York for five years and had become an integral part of the downtown Minimalist scene; his peers included Steve Reich, Philip Glass, Richard Serra, Jonas Mekas and Donald Judd. 
 But by 1973, Mr. Snow had moved back to Toronto for good. Now 72, he has hardly disappeared. Always a multifaceted artist, one who approached film as a latecomer from the visual arts, he has continued to make art installations and photos and films, all with an ingenious, witty, often moving conceptual underpinning, and to play and record music -- and to see his work shown and heard in museums, film festivals and jazz and new-music clubs all over the world. (This year alone there have been three different shows and festivals of his work in Berlin).
But the films became increasingly infrequent, in part reflecting their swelling ambitions and, hence, budgets. Now he's back. His new film, "*Corpus Callosum," will open at the Film Forum on Wednesday in its United States premiere. He's been working on it -- not exclusively, but persistently -- for 21 years, and it ends with three minutes of never-before-seen animation that he did in 1956.
The title, in the words of Mr. Snow's program notes, refers to "a central region of tissue in the human brain which passes 'messages' between the two hemispheres." (Is it a trend that vanguard filmmakers title their works after obscure parts of the human body? Consider Matthew Barney's "Cremaster" series.) Mr. Snow's title refers to his interest in linking abstract image and sound, an effort common to all his films.
The film is 92 minutes long and has two principal settings, which alternate: an anonymous modern-day office and a surreal living room, in which a boy (Mr. Snow's son Aleck, then 12) sits watching television as his parents come and go, and objects clustered on the far wall are removed or rehung manually (by production assistants directed audibly by Mr. Snow from off camera) or digitally. Sometimes they explode.
With all due deference to hemispheric connectivity, the real subject of "*Corpus Callosum" is transformation, or metamorphosis. Not through narrative; Mr. Snow has always forsworn that. The transformations come most strikingly through digital effects: bodies or whole scenes twisted and stretched and squeezed and then returned to "normal." But there are all sorts of other playful transformations. Ten different couples appear and reappear and recombine as the same central pair, the parents of the boy: transformation through costume and substitution. A giant erection (animated). A pregnant woman (real). A photo of a muscle-woman on the living-room wall. The ever-shifting sounds of the film: electronic tones alternating with the everyday busywork of Mr. Snow's instructions to his actors and assistants.
Parts of the film have been seen over the last couple of years, especially in an extract called "The Living Room," and the whole thing received its world premiere at the vanguard Rotterdam International Film Festival earlier this year. Because of its cryptic allusions to his past works, early critical reaction has stressed its autobiographical nature. J. Hoberman, in The Village Voice, called it "continuously self-referential" and "almost a self-curated retrospective of Snow's career." Peter Kubelka, writing online, suggested that it was "a video catalogue raisonne of his greatest hits."
Speaking from a pay phone at the Stephenville airport in Newfoundland, a goodly drive from the summer cabin he shares with his wife, Peggy Gale, a curator, and their son, now 19, Mr. Snow innocently denied any self-referential intent.
"I only do stuff to make the film," he insisted. "Everything is calculated for its use in the film."
In his notes, Mr. Snow refers to the film, with some self-parodistic wit, as a "tragi-comedy of the cinematic variables." By that he presumably means a film that blends structural rigor with comic playfulness. In recalling "Wavelength," one should note that it wasn't just a continuous zoom, although that sticks in the mind; and it wasn't just a beautiful piece of conceptual art: a film shot in a raw urban setting ending with peaceful nature. All kinds of implied melodrama flitted through the film, hinting at a murder. (The "actors" were the critics Hollis Frampton and Amy Taubin.) All kinds of bizarre things happen in "*Corpus Callosum," too, front and center, but they are presented with a glacial impassivity that highlights or undercuts the humor, depending on your point of view.
"In all my films I've tried to concentrate on a specific possibility of the medium," Mr. Snow said. "Zoom, spherical movement of the camera, different links between image and sound." In "*Corpus Callosum," besides the acted and digitalized transformations, there is a continuous tracking shot through the office, with the same or different characters appearing and reappearing and being subjected to the peculiar distortions Mr. Snow visits upon them.
Mr. Snow said that he has always managed to support himself with his art, a source of considerable satisfaction to him. "I've been able to continue a number of different lines in my work, and I take them all seriously," he said. "I prefer not to teach or lecture, although occasionally I do."
One of his steady activities is his Toronto-based trio, CCMC -- the name means different things at different times, he said -- which played the Manhattan club Tonic in February. "It's totally free improvisation," he said, "but it's definitely our music: we build on what we've done before." "*Corpus Callosum," he added, "is totally scripted."
Despite his economic self-sufficiency, Mr. Snow had trouble getting "*Corpus Callosum" made, which is one reason the principal shooting didn't take place until 1997 and the film was only completed late last year. Part of the problem was the cost of digital animation, even though that cost has come down considerably since he first started thinking about such techniques in 1981.
"I kept running out of money," he said. "We used computer-graphics students and recent graduates, but there's a very active computer-graphics scene in Toronto, and people kept quitting to go to better-paying jobs and then we'd have to figure out what they'd been doing and sometimes have to start from scratch."
The result is a sometimes rough-looking film, one that doesn't really stand comparison with the slickness of up-to-the-minute Hollywood special effects. Mr. Snow is a little defensive about that.
"There were a lot of ideas I had before they could actually be done," he said. "I suppose that doesn't affect how you see the film, but it's a matter of personal pride for me."

*Corpus Callosum
Film Forum,
209 West Houston Street,
Wednesday through Sept. 10.

GRAPHIC: Photo: From Michael Snow's experimental work "*Corpus Callosum," which he filmed on and off for more than two decades. (Film Forum)

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Learning the Moves of Harlem, Circa 1930

BYLINE:  By BARRY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE lore of the rent party looms large in the legend of Harlem. Appropriately, it takes over the spotlight at one point in "Harlem Song," the musical revue at the Apollo Theater that traces the history of the neighborhood. 
 Depression-era Harlemites pushed back the furniture and made their rent money by inviting the neighborhood in to eat, drink and dance, for a price. "But rent parties also had a social purpose," said George C. Wolfe, who wrote and directed the show, which opened earlier this month. "They were not merely economic occasions. Rent parties gave that great wave of migration from the South then pouring into Harlem a chance to Harlemize." 
 It is this acclimatizing function (and "Saturday night functions" are how Harlem residents referred to rent parties) that Mr. Wolfe has captured in "Miss Linda Brown," a jiving song and dance number ingeniously choreographed by Ken Roberson as a virtual catalog of Lindy steps and other swing dance specialties. In his review in The New York Times, in which he described "Harlem Song" as "an adrenaline-laced valentine to a neighborhood," Ben Brantley called the number "the show's emotional center and most memorable moment."
The performers who ignite it -- DanaShavonne Rainey, 23, and Gabriel A. Croom, 26 -- acknowledge that the era is new to them. "There's so much about Harlem history I didn't know," Mr. Croom confessed over coffee recently in the company of Ms. Rainey, who nodded in agreement. 
Ms. Rainey added: "We've been challenged to try and be authentic. I couldn't be Dana circa 2002. So I started studying pictures and films. What were people's postures like? How did they move?"
The music for their scene, an eccentric rural blues from the 1930's by Alvis Cowens, was unearthed by Mr. Wolfe in the vaults of Sony Records. "That song really helped us feel the characters," Mr. Croom said. 
For Mr. Croom, who was born in Buffalo and has a bachelor's degree in musical theater from the State University of New York at Fredonia, this is not an entirely new experience. "I had done some swing dancing in other shows," he said, "and I've gone to the Manhattan dance club Swing 46 on occasion, to Lindy."
For Ms. Rainey, who arrived in New York 10 months ago, following some time in Europe but still fresh from her hometown of Cincinnati, the Lindy was entirely new. "It was really humbling," she said. "I felt like a little kid learning how to walk."
Ms. Rainey, who graduated from Hollins University in Roanoke, Va., with a bachelor's degree in dance, is one of only two cast members (out of 14) in "Harlem Song" who survived an open call to get the job. "I got to New York in October," she said, "and auditioned for the show in April. I saw the ad in Back Stage and thought, 'Why not?' I'd been to the Apollo once a long time ago, but I got kind of emotional this time walking on that stage -- 800 dancers and li'l ole me."
To hear Mr. Wolfe describe it, choosing Ms. Rainey was almost elemental. "I remember turning to Whoopi Goldberg" -- one of the producers of "Harlem Song" -- "and saying: 'See that girl dance? That's probably what Josephine Baker danced like. Can't move a finger without her whole body moving too. Complete abandon.' That's what I was after."
Ms. Rainey's dance with Mr. Croom wound up the hoofing equivalent of a jazz cutting contest, that ageless African-American ritual of can-you-top-this competitiveness updated by Mr. Wolfe and Savion Glover in their Broadway show "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk." The cutting contest in "Harlem Song," though, had to be of its time.
"I'm the Geechee Gal and Gabe's the Bama Boy," Ms. Rainey explained, "fresh off the train and very country, I mean, real rubes, at this rent party. And all he wants to do is to get me dancing."
Mr. Croom laughed. "Which I do."
To Mr. Wolfe, their interaction has a revealing duality. "They pretend a sophistication, the surface of which they've learned, but they really don't possess," he said. "Harlem is in their language and dress but their Southernness is in their bodies. When they dance, who they really are comes out. The steps tell their story."
The sequence seems invented on the spot. Of course, it is anything but. "The coupling is very structured because of all the close partnering," Mr. Croom said. "When we're dancing around each other, though, it's pretty wide open. There's room for us to bring stuff in -- within the realm of reason."
Ms. Rainey offered an example. "I saw this old movie and there was this woman dancer in it, I don't know her name, but at one point she did something I thought was so wonderful -- this move where she kicked her leg way up, to the side, froze in midair and just sort of wiped her foot off: 'Awww! Awww!' And I thought, 'Yeah, I've got to take that and use it.' "
Mr. Croom smiled. "She surprised me with that leg thing. And it boosted my energy level. I thought: 'Oh, yeah?' "
Ms. Rainey smiled too. "He's also surprised me. There are certain moments when I say to myself: 'I see. You bein' for real!' And it does give you that edge. 'All right,' you think. 'I'll outdo you!' "

Harlem Song
Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Theater's Memory Bank Expands

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN MANDELL; Jonathan Mandell, a former theater critic, is the editor of GothamGazette.com, a Web site about New York City.

 BODY:
DO not ask Philip S. Birsh, president and publisher of Playbill magazine, about "Kiss Me, Kate" or Swoosie Kurtz or Tony Kushner; he is more comfortable talking about his three Komori color printing presses. Mr. Birsh does not go to the theater that much.
 "I don't have time," he said recently as he walked through the Playbill printing plant in Woodside, Queens, overseeing another daily press run of about 60,000 Playbills, soon to increase to 80,000. "I'd like to see shows, but I have three children, and a company to run." 
 Some theatergoers and performers treat their Playbills as sacred objects, year after year collecting the only proof that they attended (or were involved in) a work of theater, something that by its nature cannot be saved or held. One Playbill staff member has been collecting copies of the magazine since 1937. But you need not have a job at Playbill to cherish the theater programs that have been distributed free in New York's legitimate theaters for the last 118 years. 
To the publisher, though, Playbill is a business -- "We're printers" -- and it has been a good one. In the eight years since he took over the company from his father, Arthur T. Birsh (who remains the chairman), the younger Mr. Birsh said, the magazine's circulation has increased some 350 percent, to 3.7 million copies a month.
In June, Playbill was given another opportunity to grow. Stagebill Media, Playbill's only national rival, announced that it was selling Stagebill magazine's publishing rights to Playbill. The program was, in effect, folding, after almost eight decades of publication.
The news alarmed representatives of performing arts centers around the country, 81 of which were clients of Stagebill or of Performing Arts magazine, a program that Stagebill Media had bought in 2001. Although Playbill has added a few new clients, many of the centers are scrambling to find a substitute means of obtaining programs. And the change has raised some questions: How will the end of Stagebill, and lack of competition, affect Playbill?
The program with the familiar yellow band across the top began in 1884, when an advertising man from Ohio named Frank Strauss came up with the idea of turning what for decades had been a simple handbill into a magazine that could serve as an advertising vehicle. Then as now, the company paid the theaters for the right to distribute its programs free to theatergoers, and made its money from the advertising.
Stagebill was started in the 1920's in Chicago. "New Yorkers don't realize that Stagebill dominated many markets outside New York, whether you go to Laguna Hills, Calif., or Dallas or Houston or Chicago," said Fred Tarter, who bought Stagebill from Primedia in 1998 and then ended his involvement two years later.
What Playbill purchased from Stagebill, Mr. Birsh said, was only its name, not the magazine, nor the contracts with its clients. So far it has picked up little more than a dozen of the theaters, auditoriums and concert halls that used Stagebill.
One of those not picked up is the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "We're still in the process of figuring out what we are going to do," said Jeff Levine, the academy's vice president of marketing and communications. "People will be showing up at BAM on Oct. 1, and they need to have a program in their hands."
Like many of the others, they are considering publishing their own programs, as they did until 1999. "Theater programs are very expensive," Mr. Levine said. "But they are also important. Our audiences are not one-time visitors. The program is the key tool to building up an ongoing dialogue with them." 
Mr. Birsh said his company will need time to decide who else it will pick up. "I'm sorry we can't afford to supply everybody," he said. 
The task of getting each Playbill into the hands of theatergoers every day is daunting, he explained, though it is worth it: the magazine has an automatic and affluent readership, attractive to advertisers.
Playbill is in effect simultaneously a daily, a weekly and a monthly. It must be printed and delivered six days a week, because the theaters in New York have no room to store it. In each issue, the middle pages, usually numbering 12, are devoted to a specific show, offering a list of scenes, a cast who's who and other information on the production. These pages (printed in Woodside along with the program's cover) are determined by the producer and, under a contract between the theater owners and Actors' Equity, must be printed anew every week to accommodate cast and other changes. The rest of the magazine (printed by outside contractors) is a monthly, and the articles in it are the same from one theater's Playbill to the next.
Publishing Playbill became more complicated when the Birshes expanded the program outside New York; for the first time, the magazine is being distributed in different editions to various cities, accounting for much of its increase in circulation. (It uses six printers throughout the country.) Several years ago, Playbill also created a classical arts division, which provides programs for performing arts centers like the Houston Grand Opera and Carnegie Hall.
The company has expanded in other ways as well: Playbill Online, a theater news service and discount club on the Internet (www.playbill .com); Playbill Broadcasting, a program on subscription satellite radio (a medium similar to cable television, though much newer); Playbill Books; and Playbill greeting cards and wrapping paper.
Before taking charge of Playbill, Mr. Birsh, 44, spent 12 years on Wall Street, in mergers and acquisitions. "It was soulless," he said. "What I like about working for Playbill is that we're in a community."
But he did learn a few things that have come in handy. "Acquisitions are a better source of growth than internal growth," he said. "Slowly, we've picked up a lot of publishing interests."
However this expansion works as a business strategy, it has left questions about its effect on the arts. "It was a very good thing for arts organizations that there was a competition between Stagebill and Playbill," said Carol Evans, a former editor in chief of Stagebill. Will the end of competition cause Playbill to act like a monopoly? 
"There is no monopoly in publishing," said Mr. Birsh, who noted that he has no plans to start charging theatergoers for the program. "Monopoly is not a good term anyway," he continued. "It implies abuse. I don't think there is a single incident in which we've acted in an abusive manner. We've basically survived; we're proudest of having remained profitable during these difficult economic times." Playbill is a private company, and Mr. Birsh declined to release figures about its revenues or profits. "We didn't put Stagebill out of business," Mr. Birsh said. "Their business practices put them out of business."
Martin Walker, head of Walker Communications, a magazine publishing consultant, agreed. "Stagebill closed because of inept management," said Mr. Walker, who had Stagebill as a client a decade ago during a previous ownership.
Scott Marshall, chief operating officer of Stagebill Media, would not comment, and Gerry Byrne, the chief executive officer, did not return several phone calls.
According to John Istel, the editor in chief of Stagebill until last December, there were five publishers in six years, a move to expensive new offices and a wrongheaded reorganizing of the sales staff. Yet Mr. Istel also said, "Once Playbill started bidding for the same accounts, it obviously drove the cost up."
Several years ago, when it inaugurated its classical arts division, hiring away Stagebill's senior editor, Cliff Tinder, to do so, Playbill began luring Stagebill clients like the Metropolitan Opera, Houston Grand Opera and Carnegie Hall to switch. "It became more and more expensive to compete," Mr. Istel said.
At the same time, some say, the editorial quality of Stagebill remained superior. "I think the performing arts patrons will miss Stagebill," said Mr. Tarter, the former owner. "Stagebill provided some extraordinary writers with a platform to do much more in-depth, long-form articles that were relevant to the performance. Playbill does sound-bite media, bits and pieces; their articles tend to be shorter." 
Whatever the relative merits of the writing, Mr. Levine of BAM said, "The real value that Stagebill brought to the performing arts was the customization." Each performing organization received a program designed specifically for it. "Every word in that program was about BAM, the current show or upcoming shows," Mr. Levine said. By contrast, except for the 12 center pages, Playbill's contents in New York City are the same. 
Will Playbill change its ways? 
"The New York City program will remain as it has for the past gazillion years," Mr. Birsh said. The Roundabout Theater Company and the Joseph Papp Public Theater, former Stagebill clients, for example, will now be distributing the standard Playbills that are offered in more than 70 theaters in New York, both on Broadway and off. (Playbill provides a variation, called Showbill, to the New Amsterdam Theater because the theater's owners, Disney, do not want a program with cigarette and liquor advertising, Mr. Birsh said.) Playbill began providing customized programs for performing arts centers several years ago, and, starting in the fall, it will produce individualized programs for a total of 16 of its clients, half of them new.
Mr. Birsh has heard the criticism dismissing the editorial contents of Playbill as mostly hype or pablum, without depth or context, pale cousin both to Stagebill and to theater programs in London. "Every so often, a member of the theater police criticizes us mightily," Mr. Birsh said. "We might not do the best job possible, but we do the best job we can."
He is unapologetic about his publication's promotional tone. "Playbill does not run negative articles about the theater," he said. "There are enough people hectoring theater. It's not fair for a producer to have to use a Playbill in his theater that has an article that is negative toward his production."
The publisher said he felt a responsibility to carry on a tradition of a program that has changed ownership only five times in 118 years. In 1974, Metromedia, a corporation better known for its television stations, was not happy with its investment in the then-ailing theater program, and was happy to sell it to its fifth owner, Arthur Birsh. Mr. Birsh, who had joined Playbill in 1961 and later oversaw it as a senior vice president at Metromedia, left Metromedia to run the magazine. 
"It's the best place to work," said Playbill's senior editor, Louis Botto, 78, the staff member who has been collecting the magazine since 1937, although he wasn't hired until 1978. 
"When I was 65," Mr. Botto said, "Arthur Birsh said: 'Remember, there's no retirement at Playbill. We expect you to die at your desk.' I said, 'I would prefer to die at an opening night.' He said: 'Please don't make it a Shubert opening. They wouldn't like that.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Playbill's publisher, Philip S. Birsh (second from left), with (from left) Robert, Patrick and Louis Cusanelli, the brothers who operate the magazine's printing plant in Woodside, Queens. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)(pg. 18); (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)(pg. 5)

HEADLINE: A Night at the Movies, Fresh Air Included 

BYLINE:  By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
MOVIE multiplexes have popped up everywhere and yet there are still those people who would rather pack a blanket, a couple of lawn chairs, and maybe a picnic, and head to one of the three remaining drive-in theaters in the state.
 In 1967, there were 42 drive-ins in Connecticut, according to statistics kept by the United Drive-In Theater Owners Association in Germantown, Md. But owners of the three remaining theaters say that business is thriving and that on Saturday nights they frequently have to turn people away. 
 On a recent night, despite stormy weather, car after car pulled into the Southington Drive-In. There were families with carloads of children there for "Stuart Little II," and at the second screen, teenagers, college students and adults of all ages settled in for two new releases. 
Southington can accommodate 1,000 cars at its two screens. Admission is $7 and $4 for those 10 and under.
At the Pleasant Valley Drive-In, with one screen and room for 250 cars, more families came for an evening of family films. There, admission is $6; $4 for children ages 6-11 and free for children under 5.
The Mansfield Drive-In, with three screens and a capacity for 900 cars, is especially busy on Wednesdays, which is family night. Admission is $7 and $4 for children under 12.
The environment is a little different at each location.
Pleasant Valley is in a rural spot on Route 181 off Route 44, in between New Hartford and Winsted. The Southington Drive-In is just down the Meriden-Waterbury Turnpike from a giant indoor theater, and the Mansfield Drive-In, situated on 40 wooded acres, is also home to the Mansfield Marketplace, a large indoor and outdoor flea market.
The drive-ins are frequented by fans who quickly become nostalgic as they talk about the old days of the drive-in movies and the good reasons for keeping them around today.
At Southington, Ariana Eaton of Bethany said she loved to take her daughter Tanner Eaton-Carberry to the drive-in. "I used to bring her here as a baby," Ms. Eaton said. "I love being outside in the summer."
Donna McGrane of Winsted, who owns the Pleasant Valley Drive-In, said she bought the business seven years ago because she had grown up there. "My mom worked here when I was little and I just used to spend my weekends here," Ms. McGrane said as she sold tickets from a tiny clapboard ticket booth. 
"We're the smallest drive-in ever built," Ms. McGrane added. "But it is absolutely viable as a business. The overhead is less and the work is less. I keep everything small, and the ticket prices as low as I can." 
Pleasant Valley is much the way it was when it was built in 1947. The projectors are old reel-to-reel Navy surplus. The concession stand and ticket booth are original. The only modernization is the lack of speakers on poles. Customers tune in to the movie, usually a second-run film, on their AM radios.
"People come from all over," Ms. McGrane said. "One man who comes from Hawaii for a month every summer always comes here. People like to bring their kids here because it's small, not blacktop, and it's just like they remember it. Everything's original here."
The Southington Drive-In gets a lot of repeat customers as well, according to the owner, Sperie Perakos of Orange. "A lot of people came as kids and they want their kids to have the same experience," he said. "It's also very economical entertainment and a wonderful opportunity to have some family time.
"One couple comes every weekend from Long Island, and another couple comes from New Jersey every time we change the movie."
Others travel from Vermont or Massachusetts on a regular basis.
Tracy Cegelka of Southington and her friend, Joe Rosas of Naugatuck, both of whom begin college this fall, said they returned to the Southington Drive-In every few weeks during the summer. "It's more comfortable than being in a theater," Ms. Cegelka said, "and we like to be outside. It's also cheaper than the movies."
Leslie Horner of Southington, a graduate student who works in the Southington ticket booth, said she loves it at the drive-in. This is her fourth summer on staff and the drive-in, she said, is where she spends her summer.
"There were 42 drive-ins in Connecticut and over 4,000 in the country at one time," said Mr. Perakos, chairman of the board and a former president of the Connecticut Association of Theater Owners. "The peak was in the 1950's and 1960's, with the numbers tapering off in the 1970's. The total number went down to 800 and is now back up to 1,000."
Not only have some drive-ins re-opened in the 1990's, there have been new ones built in other states. Many drive-ins, like the one in Mansfield, added extra screens.
For Mr. Perakos, tracking the growth trend is important. Southington Drive-In is a family business, opened in 1954 by his father, and now owned by himself and his brothers, John and Peter Perakos Jr.
The senior Mr. Perakos once had the largest drive-in theater circuit in Connecticut, mostly single screens, with four in New Britain. He also owned one of the first Nickelodeon theaters, opened in New Britain in 1906.
Mr. Perakos and his wife, Nikki, said they were hooked on the business. "Sperie's family has been in this business a long time," Ms. Perakos said. "It's hard to give it up even if you could do better somewhere else. We are real night people and love the business."
Mr. Perakos added: "The old motion picture managers lived for their work. There was a dedication, a camaraderie that existed."
"If it's in your blood, it sets you apart from other civilians," Ms. Perakos said.
Southington's manager, James DuBois, has been in the business for 32 years.
He supervises a part-time staff of 25 to 30 people, including those in the ticket booth, concession stand workers, and what are known as ramp boys, the workers who make sure every car is parked just right so passengers can view the screen but do not block anyone else's view. 
"Drive-in fans are just like Nascar fans," Mr. DuBois said. "We have die-hards and they get mad if we don't change the movies often enough."
All three drive-ins have full concessions, plus certain specialties like funnel cakes at Pleasant Valley and deli pickles and steak sandwiches at Southington, or "everything for dinner," said Michael Jungden, owner of the Mansfield Drive-In and Marketplace.
Mansfield has a playground for children. This drive-in also has speakers on poles, the old-fashioned way for nostalgia's sake, Mr. Jungden said. Customers can tune in on their car's FM radios or use the outside speakers. 
The Connecticut drive-ins try to show family films, rated G or PG. Pleasant Valley stays exclusively with family fare. "I try to always have something for families," Mr. Jungden said. "That's the bread-and-butter part of the crowd."
A night out at the drive-in can mean a bit of adventure for everyone. Because movies start at dusk, it is usually a late night, and then there are the variables of the weather.
"I remember when 'Psycho' came out," Mr. Perakos said. "We filled up the whole place, served lots of coffee, and kept the drive-in open and filled it up all over again when the first showing was done."
In the old days, he added, they had dusk to dawn showings of five movies.
At a Pleasant Valley showing of "Godzilla," lightning struck the junction box, leaving everyone in the dark. All but a few patrons gladly accepted vouchers to return and see the film another night, Ms. McGrane said. 
"We've really kept everything the way it was," she said. "This is why people like to come here. It's a little bit of nostalgia for them."

(Photographs by Mary Haggerty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch 

 BODY:
Cablevision Plans to Close 26 of Its 43 Wiz Stores
 The Cablevision Systems Corporation (NYSE: CVC) plans to close 26 of 43 branches of the Wiz, its consumer electronics chain, as part of its restructuring. On Long Island, six of eight stores will be closed: those in Bay Shore, Bohemia, Huntington, Lake Grove, Massapequa and Plainview. The stores in Carle Place and Valley Stream will remain open. 
 Industry analysts have cited the Wiz subsidiary as a drain on Cablevision's profitability. Cablevision, which is based in Bethpage, would not say how many jobs would be affected by the closings.

Losses Widen at Allied
The Allied Devices Corporation (Nasdaq: ALDV) of Hicksville has posted a loss of $1.2 million for its fiscal third quarter, after sales dropped to $4.9 million. Last year, the company reported a loss of $519,000 for the same quarter on sales of $5.9 million.
Mark Hopkinson, the company's chairman, said the company did not expect an improvement in sales and earnings before 2003. "The economy is fragile, and erratic booking patterns have prompted us to be cautious," he said. Allied Devices develops automation and robotic equipment.

No Fallout, Kimco Says
The Kimco Realty Corporation (NYSE: KIM) of New Hyde Park says that it does not believe the liquidation of Ames Department Stores will affect its earnings either this year or next.
Kimco, which owns and operates shopping centers throughout the United States and Canada, leases eight stores to Ames with a total of nearly 640,000 square feet. It is also a co-owner of a 101,749-square-foot store leased to Ames.

Global's Net Income Drops
Global Payment Technologies (Nasdaq: GPTX) of Hauppauge, a manufacturer of coin-operated mechanisms used in gambling and vending machines, has reported that pro forma net income for the fiscal third quarter dropped to $77,000, down from $181,000 during the same quarter last year. Net sales dropped to $6.5 million, down from $8.6 million in the same quarter last year.
Thomas McNeill, the company's chief financial officer, cited the soft economy as the cause of falling sales. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island; 
Hotels Sprout, Drawn by Mix of Potential Guests

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
WITH its stately pillars and curved driveway edged with white gas lamps, the 186,000-square-foot Inn at East Wind is a majestic sight along the rural tree-lined Route 25A in Wading River on the North Shore. 
 The 42-room hotel, which will have a 21,000-square-foot ballroom, is to open this fall at a time when some areas of Long Island have more hotel rooms than they can handle and others do not have enough. 
 Five of the eight new hotels that have opened since 1999 in Long Island excluding the East End opened this year, and more are under construction, according to Robert Lipper, president of Island-Metro Publications, which publishes the Long Island Lodging Guide quarterly and tracks the hotel industry on the Island.
The surge of new hotels, adding 722 rooms since January, helps to explain a drop in the occupancy rate to 68 percent in the first six months of this year from 72 percent a year earlier, Mr. Lipper said. 
"Most of the developers had made their plans two years ago when the market was good," he said. "Over two dozen more properties have been proposed, probably on the assumption that the economy will be on an upward trend."
Developers are optimistic because the Long Island hotel market has a "seven-day week, serving corporate travelers from Monday to Thursday, and on weekends, those attending social functions and tourist attractions," said Paul Fitzpatrick, senior managing director of Insignia/ESG Hotel Partners New York. It recently arranged the financing for a Hilton Garden Inn in Bohemia near MacArthur Airport.
Construction began in May on the 165-room $19.5 million hotel, which is being developed by Linchris Hotel Partners of Long Island, based in Hanover, Mass.
While the market appears to be saturated, there are still "underserved areas that can get away with new construction," Mr. Lipper said. "The town of Babylon has been desperately seeking a hotel for over a decade," he said, "and on the East End, Greenport, with its tourism, is an energy market and will have more demand." 
Of the five hotels that opened this year, two are in the town of Brookhaven. Because of an abundance of applications, the town, which has 26 lodgings and more in the planning stages, created a new zoning district classification last month to manage growth. Previously, lodging facilities were permitted on any property zoned for light industry. The new classification, which requires a hotel developer to get Town Board approval, includes restrictions like a minimum lot size of five acres and a maximum building height of 50 feet. 
"We don't want to control the market -- we're looking at it from a land-use perspective," said John Jay LaValle, Brookhaven's supervisor. "There are hundreds of acres of undeveloped land on our map zoned for light industry. We need it to attract jobs, not hotel development." 
In other areas, hotel projects are continuing. The Hauppauge-based Long Island Hotels expects to begin construction this year on a $20 million complex in Central Islip with a 170-room hotel and three restaurants. Melville Hospitality has proposed a 178-room Hilton Garden Inn and a 147-suite Homewood Suites next to each other in Melville, Mr. Fitzpatrick says. In Nassau, construction on a 120-room Hilton Garden Inn is about to begin in Westbury by the Briad Group of Florham Park, N.J.
To get customers, "most new hotels are taking them away from other hotels by their newness, with special opening rates and services," Mr. Lipper said.
The Inn at East Wind, owned by Kenn Barra of Wading River, has its own draw: a longstanding catering reputation and proximity to vineyards. The hotel is on 11 acres next to Mr. Barra's two existing catering halls, said to John Fields, the general manager. "The key attraction is the location, and our reputation as a caterer precedes us," he said. "We saw the need for hotel rooms for weddings and an upscale conference center on the East End." 
The catering company now serves at 16 weddings on a weekend, and "there has been a demand from corporations out west in Nassau looking to come for a country getaway," he said. 
The $15 million hotel is being built in several phases, beginning with the guest rooms, which will open this fall. The published prices for rooms will be $298 to $579 a night. Suites include Jacuzzis, and all rooms will have free high-speed Internet access. 
Construction has begun on the ballroom and a 100-seat pub with a lounge for entertainment, and they are expected to open in November. A full-service spa, four meeting rooms, two boardrooms, a restaurant and an indoor pool are scheduled for an opening in the spring of 2003.
"Even though the building is massive, we've tried to give it a quaint country inn atmosphere with the decor," which includes wood paneling and antique furnishings, Mr. Fields said. 
Site plans have been approved for a second hotel -- "but not as elaborate as East Wind country inn" -- about a mile west, he said. The proposed 50-room hotel will include a restaurant, tennis courts and an outdoor pool. 
Farther east, the village of Greenport, which has a historic main street and waterfront that attracts more than 500,000 tourists a year, needs more lodgings, said Audrey Wigley, director of the North Fork Promotion Council. The village has 150 hotel and motel rooms and 26 bed-and-breakfast rooms. "Every weekend during the summer we get numerous calls requesting lodging, and there is none," Ms. Wigley said. 
Construction is expected to begin in October on the 35-room Harborfront Inn, which will be the first newly built hotel in Greenport in 40 years. It is being built by KACE Development of Cutchogue and has been undergoing planning and zoning board reviews for the last eight months. 
According to the mayor, David Kapell, the "threshold issues have been resolved, including the controlling issue, which was the height." That has been cut to 35 feet from 47. KACE has volunteered to work with the village's historic review commission on the design of the hotel, he said.
Michael Kontokosta, who owns KACE with his brother, Dino, said rooms at the three-story hotel would range in area from 370 square feet to 900. Prices will average $185 a night. 
The hotel will be next to a newly built 3.5-acre waterfront park with a carousel and boardwalk. The park is on the site of the former Mitchell's Restaurant and Marina, which burned down more than 20 years ago. Its maintenance will be financed through a trust fund "in excess of $1 million" willed by Pauline Mitchell, according to Mr. Kapell.
The park is crucial to KACE's plans for the $3.5 million Harborfront Inn, Mr. Kontokosta said. "The location is perfect; we are capitalizing on the revitalization of Greenport, Mitchell Park and the waterfront's proposed 64-slip marina."
About 60 miles southwest in Babylon, there is an "obvious need for hotels," said Wayne Horsley, a town councilman. There are "some motels but no quality hotels in the town that would facilitate the business community or wedding guests," he said. 
He noted that on the Route 110 industrial corridor in Babylon and Huntington, Huntington has many hotels, "but the Babylon industry is underserviced." 
A commercial overlay district was created in Babylon three years ago that would increase the height limit for a hotel or office building in the 110 corridor to 55 feet from 35. Since then, a plan for one or two hotels at the state-owned Republic Airport, which is on Route 110, is being proposed by the Albany-based Republic Hospitality. 
"We're very excited," Mr. Horsley said. "This is our No. 1 economic issue."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 25 about new hotels on Long Island referred incorrectly to bed-and-breakfast accommodations in Greenport. There are 26 such establishments there, not 26 rooms.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Marketing Huntington to an Ever-Wider World

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
DENNIS SNEDEN works the phone, juggling calls from local merchants concerned with zoning issues and traffic problems on Main Street, while a caterer waits on hold to discuss plans for a fall festival in October.
 "Pretty much your typical local chamber stuff," said Mr. Sneden, 49, the chief executive of the Huntington Township Chamber of Commerce. But lately, more of the calls are originating from outside Huntington -- from Nassau County and Albany, and from as far away as China -- as Mr. Sneden moves forward in his quest to expand the chamber's reach well past the borders of the town to encompass all of Long Island. 
 Since taking over the top staff position at the chamber in March 1998, Mr. Sneden, a former real estate salesman with close ties to the town's Republican administration, has more than quadrupled the organization's membership, to 1,300. And he has done it despite a fire that left the chamber homeless in March 2001. 
By successfully marketing memberships throughout Nassau and Suffolk, by starting what Mr. Sneden calls "my China initiative," an ambitious and attention-getting plan to open a branch office in China intended to help members do business there, and by holding an economic conference attended by Governor Pataki, Mr. Sneden has extended the chamber's reach. 
"Dennis has a lot of chutzpah," said Ron Lazar, one of three vice chairmen of the chamber and the senior managing director at Schacker Realty in Melville.
The chamber has a staff of 13 and a yearly budget of about $530,000, most of it raised by membership fees, events and sponsorships. On Sept. 9, it plans to move from its temporary offices in downtown Huntington to a $640,000, 4,600-square-foot, three-story converted house on Main Street it bought earlier this month. When it does, it will start afresh with a new name, the Chamber of Commerce: Regional Business Partnership. The group's original name will be in small print, with the words "Huntington Township Chamber of Commerce" around the perimeter of the logo. 
Mr. Sneden (pronounced SNEE-den) said the chamber had not abandoned the interests of the small local companies that make up its traditional membership base. "We're still focused on our members, only now our members are increasingly coming from other parts of the county, from Nassau, and even New York City," Mr. Sneden said. About 75 percent of the membership comes from Suffolk, 20 percent from Nassau and 5 percent from New York City.
The chamber's rapid growth, its new emphasis on economic development and its assertion of a regional identity make it a rival to the Long Island Association, which like the Huntington chamber is also 76 years old this year.
"I am not concerned about competing with the L.I.A.," Mr. Sneden said. "The mission of our group is to support the day-to-day business activities of our members. I see the L.I.A. as more involved more with lobbying and shaping legislation."
Nevertheless, developments have lately moved the chamber away from its traditional roots. In June, the board selected William Davidson, the director of government affairs for the Long Island Power Authority, as its new chairman, who will serve a two-year term. Among the new directors installed was Carol MacKenzie, a Suffolk County District Court judge. Earlier this year, Mr. Sneden hired Frank Gargano, whose uncle is Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, to forge stronger ties with the governor's office.
He has also put into place plans to promote the organization more widely. Last December, he hired Gary Ciccerello, an advertising executive formerly with Foote, Cone & Belding in Manhattan, to assemble 60- and 30-second television commercials promoting the chamber and its members, along with other marketing tasks. These ads began running earlier this year on Channels 12 and 55, and the chamber is negotiating with Channel 4, the NBC affiliate, to broadcast the ads throughout the region.
Mr. Sneden has also wrung considerable publicity from the chamber's effort, finally successful, to win All-America City recognition for the Town of Huntington from the National Civic League. 
"Dennis is full of energy and ideas, but he also has the ability to follow through on those ideas and see that they're implemented," said Frank Petrone, the town supervisor. "Dennis gets things done by building partnerships and creating networks."
In 1995, Mr. Petrone gave Mr. Sneden his start in local government when he hired him as the director of economic development. At the time, Mr. Sneden, a former deputy director of the Suffolk County Girl Scouts, was helping run his wife's real estate business. In 1996, Mr. Petrone promoted him to deputy supervisor. 
The chamber has traditionally had strong representation from the ranks of the shopkeepers in Huntington village, one of Long Island's most dynamic retailing areas. By the mid-60's the character of the business community in the town had changed with an influx of large and midsize companies that had relocated to the Route 110 corridor, and many of the newcomers joined the chamber, too.
But by the mid-90's, membership in the chamber was shrinking and morale was low, said Mr. Lazar, the chamber's vice chairman. Several veteran chamber members who admired Mr. Sneden's performance at Town Hall recruited him as chief executive, Mr. Lazar said. 
From the start, Mr. Sneden's visionary plans and managerial competence have been admired and supported by the chamber's board, Mr. Lazar said. "Dennis came in just at the right time," he said. "We were small and getting smaller all the time."
Mr. Sneden, who tends to end sentences with exclamation marks, said "We were down to 300 companies -- shoot me now!" 
To expand the chamber's profile, Mr. Sneden has drawn on his extensive network of contacts, including connections he has made with other executives and prominent members of 42 other chambers in Suffolk County, who meet under the auspices of the Suffolk County Coalition of Chambers of Commerce, a group he formed in 1998 and continues to run as president. The coalition brings a focus to the traditionally disjointed economic development efforts of the county's individual chambers, he said.
Mr. Lazar, the group's vice chairman, said: "Looking back over where we've gone lately, I think the fire gave us a new start by destroying all the old stuff. I think the fire was the best thing that ever happened to the chamber."

HEADLINE: Places Where the Buck Doesn't Even Linger 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
ON a sparkling August morning that felt more like fall than summer, Dick and Pat Nicholas of Glastonbury packed up their three grandchildren and made their first trip to the Old New-Gate Prison in East Granby.
 "This is a treasure," Mr. Nicholas said as he stood on the grounds of the old prison, a national historic landmark where scores of Tories were imprisoned during the Revolutionary War. "I think it should stay open." 
 So did the employees of the Connecticut Historical Commission. But faced with a 44 percent budget cut, the commission's director, John W. Shannahan, announced in July that he would have to close all four of the commission's museums next month. 
The closings generated enough publicity to prompt state leaders to restore financing to keep the museums open and to avoid layoffs. But Mr. Shannahan was still left with a 17 percent budget reduction that means job openings in his agency will remain unfilled. Similar belt-tightening is occurring across Connecticut now that a struggling economy has left the state without a budget surplus for the first time in a decade and has also forced officials to make cuts. 
"It was a difficult year because people had to rethink the manner in which they handle the budget," said the Speaker of the House, Moira K. Lyons, a Democrat of Stamford. "In Connecticut, we had been used to not only surpluses but giving money back to taxpayers."
In response, tuition at state schools is on the rise, temporary court employees have been let go and the funnel of money to nonprofit arts organizations has been slowed. On the local level, though the state increased educational cost sharing grants to municipalities, nearly every city and town in the state raised property taxes this year in part because of a net decrease in state aid and cuts in money for items like special education and road repairs, said James J. Finley, associate director of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities.
"It's the worst municipal budget season we have seen in a decade," he said.
Judging by budget projections, it seems like the future may hold more of the same. 
"This is only the beginning of the problem," said State Senator Joseph J. Crisco Jr., a Democrat of Woodbridge who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee. Mr. Crisco said there could be budget deficits of $1 billion each in the 2004 and 2005 fiscal years.
Connecticut is not alone in facing troubling budget issues. Across the country, state governments are grappling with a downturn in the economy that has caused a drop in tax revenues from personal incomes, capital gains and retail sales. 
"Budget crises are influenced by two things: how much you are spending and how much revenue you are getting," said Mark Robbins, assistant professor of political science at the University of Connecticut. "I don't know how the spending has changed, but certainly there's been revenue shortfalls.
"Connecticut has an income tax and a sales tax and a capital gains tax so there's a lot of sources there, but you would expect all of those sources to decrease when economic activity decreases." 
In fact, according to a report from Comptroller Nancy Wyman, the state ended the 2002 fiscal year with a budget deficit of $812 million in large part because of a drop in income tax revenues, which were $561 million less than original estimates.
The downturn in the stock market had a major effect on capital gains tax revenue, said Marc S. Ryan, secretary of the Office of Policy and Management. 
"That's the one that really hurt us," he said. 
At the same time, Connecticut faces rising expenditures for items such as Medicaid. Together, the problems meant state officials had to find a way to close a nearly $1 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that ended June 30 and another $1 billion shortfall for the current fiscal year. After lengthy budget sessions, the General Assembly adopted a $13.2 billion budget on June 30, down from the $13.5 billion spending plan that was adopted a year ago.
To get there, the legislature cut several state agencies' budgets and increased taxes on items like cigarettes, diesel fuel and businesses. It also delayed cuts to the income tax, a sales tax exemption for computer services and the phase-out of the inheritance tax and the gift tax, Mr. Ryan said. 
Not many people were happy with the results. 
"There was a fine line and you had to get a balance," Mr. Crisco said. "As my grandmother always said, 'In life, if you want to be fair, you have to achieve balance.' " 
Consequently, it seems like people in all sectors are feeling the pinch.
At the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, a nearly 7 percent reduction in its programming budget meant the commission issued $1.2 million in grants for arts and cultural organizations, down from $1.6 million last year, said Kathleen DeMeo, communications specialist for the commission.
That in turn meant arts organizations like the National Theater of the Deaf, which typically receives about $35,000 from the state, did not receive anything this year.
"We understand the budget was a little bit less this year," said Pierre Patrick, a spokesman for the theater, which is appealing to the commission. "We thought we would get a little bit less, but we got zero." 
Mr. Patrick said the theater was counting on the money to help produce two major shows. Without the state money, the theater will probably cut back on the touring schedule of one of its productions, he said. 
"Really, throughout the years they have always been very, very supportive," he added. "Some organizations give less as years pass and we always expect that. It's just zero is a shock." 
At the Downtown Cabaret Theater of Bridgeport, the lack of any money from the commission means that plans to do the American debut of Ivor Novello's musical, "King's Rhapsody" are now on hold, said Richard Hallinan, the organization's executive producer.
At the Connecticut Grand Opera and Orchestra in Stamford, which did not receive any money from the commission, officials will be looking for new revenue sources, said Laurence Gilgore, general director and principal conductor of the Stamford organization.
"I think it's going to force companies like ours to be more clever, to never take anything for granted, to broaden as much as possible your funding sources," Mr. Gilgore said. "Individuals are going to have to reach deeper into their pockets. 
The same is true for students at the state's community-technical schools. Anticipating a tough budget year, the Board of Trustees of Community-Technical Colleges had imposed a tuition increase last year that would go into effect for the 2002-3 school year, said Mary Anne Cox, director of communications for the board. But the recent budget cuts prompted the board to impose additional fees of $2.25 per credit to help make up the shortfall, she said. That means a full-time student will be faced with a $2,034 bill compared with $1,888 for the 2001-2 school year.
That is bad news for Liane Dillard, an East Hampton mother of two who has been taking classes at Manchester Community College for nearly two years in an effort to obtain an associate's degree 
"I just think it's a shame," Ms. Dillard said. "It's going to put a lot more burden on me and my family." 
Still, even with the tuition increase, the community-technical colleges are by far the least expensive of any of the state schools, said Rifet Okugic of Newington, who dropped by the registration session at Manchester Community College on a recent morning.
"I have to pay for the tuition myself," he said. "It's much cheaper than the other schools."
In Storrs, the University of Connecticut experienced a 5 percent cut in its budget. In response, the school's trustees voted Aug. 13 to impose a midyear tuition increase that will raise the cost of classes for in-state undergraduates by $108 next spring, said Karen Grava, manager of media communications for UConn. That increase is in addition to the 3.9 percent increase in tuition the board had already adopted for the 2002-3 school year.
Also, the board raised undergraduate tuition for the 2003-4 school year by 8.72 percent to $5,260 for in-state students. In 2004-5 it will increase another 8.75 percent to $5,720, Ms. Grava said. 
In addition, the university is looking at other ways to cut costs at a time when the undergraduate student enrollment alone has grown from less than 20,000 to about 25,000 in the last five years.
"This is quite a challenge for us," Ms. Grava said. "We are growing and we need to supply students with classes and services, so it is a challenge to meet all the requirements we have to meet." 
The University of Connecticut Health Center had already been grappling with financial stresses because of pressures in the health care field, such as a reduction in federal reimbursements. But a $2 million cut in the $76.3 million it thought it would receive from the state prompted officials there to impose a hiring freeze as well as a managerial salary freeze, said James Walter, a spokesman for the health center. Layoffs are also under consideration, he said.
"Being in this environment over the past number of years with these financial pressures, we have adopted a course of action where we are constantly re-engineering our work force," he said. "We are cutting where we feel we need to. We are investing in our work force where we see opportunities to grow the health center and increase revenues, but we will be expecting layoffs at some point as a result of these cuts."
In the Judicial Branch, officials responded to the budget cuts by closing the adult drug courts in New Haven, Bridgeport and Waterbury as well as the juvenile drug court in Hartford, said Rhonda Stearley-Hebert, manager of communications for the Judicial Branch. Those courts tried to reduce substance-abuse recidivism among nonviolent drug offenders by offering a program that combined intensive judicial supervision with treatment, she said. The Judicial Branch expects it will save about $1 million by closing the courts. The branch will transfer offenders to other programs, she said.
In addition, judicial officials dismissed 62 temporary judicial marshals and 35 temporary assistant clerks last month, Ms. Stearley-Hebert said.
"There's going to be more work for less people, but we are not unlike any other state agency," she said. "We are going to do the best we can."

HEADLINE: Here, the Sandman Comes but Doesn't Leave 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY B. COHEN 

 BODY:
IT is a relaxing, four-day, four-night stay in a small New England city, complete with time for reading, movies and self-reflection. Management, after all, wants its guests to stay in bed until noon.
 But there are catches: no sunlight, no exercise, no visitors, no minibar, although the in-room movies are free. 
 You can make an occasional phone call, but receiving calls is not encouraged.
And those video cameras pointed at your bed? Just ignore them. 
Any takers?
The offer is from the sleep lab at Wesleyan University's Department of Psychology. People who sign up will be subjects in two four-day visits to the lab and be part of a two-year study to analyze how the external environment affects the internal biological clock. When completed, the research results may help those with irregular sleep cycles.
Mary Margaret Anderson, a 21-year-old Wesleyan student, got ready to take a four-day plunge at Wesleyan's Judd Hall in July. "Am I excited?" Ms. Anderson asked. "Well, I think it's going to be something different."
The objective of the study, run by Namni Goel, an assistant professor at Wesleyan University and financed in part by the National Institute of Health, is simple: to measure whether and how sound can affect human circadian rhythms (the 24-hour internal body clock).
"Normally our internal clock is in sync with the external environment," Dr. Goel said. But when the two are out of sync -- as with overnight workers or jet-lagged travelers -- the body clock says sleep, the sun says otherwise, and nobody's happy.
For her study, Dr. Goel does her best to remove the variable of the external clock altogether -- hence the "no sunlight" rule. Because the effects of light as a stimulus have been studied, Dr. Goel chose another variable: sound.
Her subjects spend four nights in the lab, and on two of those nights they listen to two hours of stimulus before or after going to bed, depending on the study. The stimulus is either bird song enhanced with music or sounds imperceptible to the human ear, Dr. Goel said.
"It's supposed to be relaxing so they don't get bored, because they have to listen to it for two hours," Dr. Goel said, explaining her choice.
But the stimulus was not nearly as stimulating as one subject, Mei Mei Chan, had hoped. "Oh my god, you have to sit there in this chair and it's like," she paused and stiffened, "music."
"You just sit there; it's craziness," she said, laughing.
Ms. Chan graduated from Wesleyan this year and said she figured this would be a good way to fill time and help the university. She also received $350 for participating.
On her first of two visits -- each subject must participate twice to make the data reliable -- Ms. Chan watched at least 10 movies in four days. The second time around, she brushed up on her foreign language skills, renting films in German and French, and read economics books. 
When she was in high school, Ms. Chan said she conducted her own psychology experiment. She sent out a questionnaire about the colors people dream. "But my drawback was I couldn't have people in a sleep lab and hook them up to see what color they dreamt in," she said. "So my sophistication was much lower than this."
But in this experiment, subjects enter the lab, and the first thing they do after getting settled is have electrodes placed around their heads with an adhesive paste, Dr. Goel said. The electrodes monitor sleep data every night, from brain EEG's to rapid eye movement to muscle movement in the chin.
Ms. Chan's first night was easy. She got no stimulus so that her normal sleep patterns could be gauged. But sleep on the second two nights was interrupted at 5:45 a.m. with just enough time left for Ms. Chan to don her dark glasses, go to the restroom (the eyes of the subjects cannot be exposed to the light in the bathroom) and freshen up, before taking her stimulus seat at 6 a.m.
Using body temperature readings, salivary tests for the sleep-related hormone melatonin, and the sleep data from the electrodes, Dr. Goel analyzes the effects of the stimulus on the subsequent nights. She found that the effects of sound on sleep are much like those of light. A two-hour dose of stimulus before bed (as in the first study) actually pushes the internal clock backward, while the same dose after sleep will likely push the clock forward.
Although Dr. Goel is more concerned with the psychological effects than a real-world application of her study's findings, her experiment does show that sleep patterns can be altered through sensory stimuli. What that may mean is that people who have trouble sleeping could possibly find a nondrug-induced way to snooze, such as listening to music.
"I know people who've had problems with sleeping pills," said Daniel Raimi, 21, a Wesleyan student and a subject.
For him, should a practical application be derived from the experiments, all the better. "I think it would be great for people to have a healthy alternative," he said.
But all of the benefits of science aside, being a subject in this type of study isn't exactly easy, Ms. Chan said.
"At the end of the four days, I just felt like, O.K., this is worse than being a prisoner," she said of her first tour. "You can do anything you want to do, but you can't see light, and there's only so many movies you can watch."
When she left the building after her first of two four-day sessions, Ms. Chan found a new appreciation for freedom. But when she left the building after her second four-day session, her opinion had changed. That is because beneath several of the electrodes on her face, Ms. Chan developed rashes.
Dr. Goel said it was probably because Ms. Chan had worn makeup and lotion one day, something Dr. Goel had told her not to do.
Ms. Chan said the rashes were actually worse behind her ears, where she applied no makeup. She left the study appreciating its goals but lamenting her experience. Dr. Goel said that Ms. Chan was the only subject out of more than 75 to develop a rash.
The subjects all agreed that the nicest part of participating was the isolation it provided, the refuge from daily college life and college friends.
"I'm living with a bunch of students, and I think it was good for me to have some time by myself," said Ms. Anderson, who spent a good deal of her time watching movies.
As for Mr. Raimi, he spent his time practicing guitar. But his guitar time and his earlier helping-out-the-sick rationale notwithstanding, there was still the cash payment to think of.
"We have jobs, but they're part-time and there's a lot of things we like to do," Mr. Raimi said. "We have to have beer money, we have to go to baseball games, we have to buy CD's."
For unemployed college students with nothing better to do, the payment is attractive, Ms. Chan concurred. "But it's really not attractive for somebody who has something going on in life," she said.
Most attractive of all, though, was leaving, Mr. Raimi said.
"That was pretty exciting," he said, sounding relieved. "We got to be pretty close with the people administering the study, but we were definitely happy to leave."

From left, a subject's brain waves are recorded during sleep, and a device used for brain imaging. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Another Home-Shopping Network

BYLINE:  By ELLEN L. ROSEN 

 BODY:
FUELED by new hobbies and a new generation, selling products at home remains a bright spot in the economy. While longstanding companies like Avon and Tupperware now sell in retail outlets as well as through individual consultants, other companies are finding profits in events that can resemble old-style coffee klatches. 
 One of the most successful party-plan companies, as they are called, is Pampered Chef, an Illinois-based cookware company. And one of its more successful consultants is Penney Parkes, a Fairfield, Conn., resident who also covers Westchester. She came upon the business by happenstance, when a friend invited her to a show. 
 It turns out that Mrs. Parkes had a natural affinity for her new business. Part comedian, part chef, she easily sold $1,000 in products at a recent gathering in the West Harrison home of Anna Gallo. 
Michele Costa of New Rochelle, a consultant for Creative Memories, products, not only sells its products like specialized scrapbooks, adhesives and marking pens, but also organizes gatherings so others can work on their books together.
She started keeping scrapbooks five years ago and says her involvement was highly personal. "I lost my mother before my daughter was born, and I didn't have anyone to ask the questions of what it was like to be pregnant, when did I take my first steps?" said Ms. Costa, who has been a consultant for more than a year. 
Cathy Parlitsis of Somers got hooked on a new hobby three years ago when she and an aunt attended a party sponsored by Stampin' Up!, one of the newer direct sales companies. "Once the host handed me the stamp, I was a goner," she said.
Her income last year, excluding trips and bonuses, was close to $30,000.
In contrast to other party-plan products, the three best-known clothing lines sold through the home -- Carlisle, Doncaster and Worth -- are not offered at large gatherings. Rather, representatives transform their homes with display fixtures and invite clients by appointment.
Kathryn Parter of Larchmont, for example, who has represented Doncaster for the last 10 years, keeps her quarterly shows low-key and personal, an approach that keeps her clients coming back. While shopping in someone's home is not for everyone, "it is by no means Loehmann's," said one longtime client, Betsy Cherkasky of Larchmont. 
Jori Wolfe of Scarsdale uses a similar style in selling clothes manufactured by Etcetera, a casual offshoot of Carlisle. Mrs. Wolfe, who worked in the garment industry for many years, signed on with Etcetera last year when her family business closed. Children's companies abound as well; Connecticut-based Big Enough, for example, has 20 representatives in Westchester.
Running just a few parties a month -- sometimes in the representatives' homes but more often in the homes of others -- can result in annual incomes of anywhere from $30,000 to more than $100,000, say company spokesmen and consultants alike. (The host of the party typically receives a few free items and discounts off any purchases). The representatives also get discounts on merchandise and all-expense paid trips as bonuses for attaining certain sales levels. Prices for products sold at home generally are no higher than retail prices for similar items.
Success depends directly on the efforts of the representative, both in terms of selling products and in attracting new consultants, an equally important part of the job. Although the compensation formulas vary, they each follow some form of multilevel marketing; earnings typically accrue from commissions on sales and a small percentage of the sales made by people recruited to join the business. 
Vivian Frerking of Ossining, for example, has sold candles and accessories made by PartyLite Gifts for five years, and now runs about three shows a week.
She has recruited approximately 50 people on her team, about half of whom are still active, and is now a group leader. As a result, not only does she earn a 32 percent commission on her direct sales, but also 7 percent on sales made by the people in her central unit, and 4 percent from the sales of two recruits who have subsequently created separate units of their own.
A physical therapist by training, Ms. Frerking says she earned approximately $50,000 last year. In the past because of her sales volume she has won vacations to places like Hawaii, Aruba and Paris.
The newer entrants in this segment of the direct sales market have not eclipsed the industry stalwarts. Westchester is home to four Mary Kay representatives who are successful enough to drive the company's signature pink Cadillac. (According to a company spokesman, Randall Oxford, 15 other Mary Kay representatives in Westchester drive more anonymous General Motors cars that were also bonuses for good work. Altogether, there are 920 cosmetic representatives countywide). Tupperware, which also offers autos to some of their consultants as well, has 95 representatives in the county; Avon has roughly 1,700.
The Shaklee Corporation, one of the oldest direct-sales companies, has its representatives in the county. Angela Nesbitt of Larchmont is one of about 1,000 Shaklee representatives in the county. A few years back she had risen to partner at a management consulting firm in Manhattan, but quit because her long workday kept her from her children. Looking for work that would require fewer hours, she investigated Shaklee, which specializes in nutritional supplements and environmentally friendly products. She studied the company's business model and also "tested all the products because I was convinced they weren't as good as the claims." She was soon convinced and signed on.
Party-plan companies comprise less than a third of all direct-sales businesses, yet they are the growth engine of the industry, said Joseph Mariano, the executive vice president of the Direct Selling Association, a Washington-based trade organization.
According to figures provided by the association, party plan businesses raked in more than $7 billion nationwide in 2000, an increase of $2.7 billion since 1996. Last year, The Pampered Chef's domestic sales totaled $750 million, said a spokeswoman, Jane Edwards. Shelli Gardner, the president of 14-year-old Stampin' Up!, said total sales reached $114 million in 2001, and this year the company's sales are 40 percent more than where they were one year ago.
Mrs. Parter said she sold twice as many clothes in her July show this year as she had last summer, despite high temperatures and a slow economy. She attributed sales of $30,000 to $40,000, roughly doubled from her show in July 2001, to additional clients coming from referrals. 
Although the field seems dominated by women, there are avenues for men as well, even at Mary Kay, although Mr. Oxford, a company spokesman said that fewer than 1 percent nationwide are men. Carol Brown, a Mary Kay sales director who lives in White Plains, said 3 of the 65 consultants in her sales group are men.
But for the most part, the men involved play supporting roles, including taking care of the children when gatherings are held at night or on the weekends.
Mrs. Parlitsis said her husband, George, initially did not like her new hobby-turned-business and would introduce himself as the president of "Stamp-Out Stampers." He changed his tune, however, when his wife was sidelined with a back injury. Although she couldn't work, a paycheck kept coming in, based on commissions from the sales made by her recruits. He was impressed, Mrs. Parlitsis said, and as a result, he resigned his post as president.
