HEADLINE: Dublin on the Thruway 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
McLEAN AVENUE meanders across Yonkers just above the Bronx border. While it winds and dips like an Irish country road, it is lined with so many pubs and other Irish businesses that one feels transported to Cork or Limerick. The local tongue is a lilting brogue.
 Irish immigrants first began settling here in the mid-1980's, and by 2000, the bars and sidewalks were teeming with young Irish people who had come for the jobs and the great craic, the Gaelic word for fun. The community seized claim to the unofficial title of Ireland's 33rd county. 
 But as the American economy has flagged and jobs have grown scarce, many Irish have returned home to look for work. Tighter restrictions on green cards and visas have kept others from replacing them. Things have grown quieter along the avenue that craic built. 
"Quite a few young people have gone back in the past couple of years, and the majority of them have stayed back," said Rory Dolan, a co-owner of Rory Dolan's, the most prominent bar on McLean Avenue.
There was fear, especially among merchants like Mr. Dolan, that the change would cause McLean Avenue to decline as as other short-lived Irish communities have But if anything, this bustling community along the New York State Thruway has grown stronger, residents say.
The area, which runs along McLean Avenue, roughly from the Saw Mill Parkway to the Bronx River Parkway, has become less of a rollicking party ground and more of a broad-based community. Swarms of Irish transplants are buying and renovating starter homes and establishing businesses, from construction companies to coffee shops.
What remains is a community with a strong middle-class backbone that no longer measures its vitality by the pint and the keg. Property values and rents have soared. More of the Irish who have remained here have steady jobs and legitimate immigrant status, and many are applying for United States citizenship.
In short, McLean Avenue seems to have reached trealbhaidh, a Gaelic term for maturation or coming of age.
"Especially for the young Irish, McLean Avenue has gotten to be the biggest Irish community in the New York area over the past decade," said Cait Moran, a spokeswoman for the Irish Consulate in Manhattan.
"Most Irish here have it in the back of their heads to maybe one day go back, and they're always watching closely to see how their friends and relations do when they return," she said. "But it's not seen as a depletion of the community. The neighborhood is strong enough to survive."
Adrian Flannelly, a popular Irish radio talk show host here, said the area had achieved a stability that other Irish communities in New York lacked.
"It used to be that you got off the plane and went straight to Inwood or Woodside or Woodlawn," he said. "Now the word on the street is that Irish have staked out McLean Avenue. If you want to move forward, to regularize your status, all roads lead there. It's an enclave with tremendous security and support. The stability of other Irish areas in New York is questionable, but look at McLean: You can't argue with success.
"It's not a passing thing," said Mr. Flannelly, chairman of Irish Radio Network USA and a board member of the Irish government's immigration task force. "The Irish community around McLean Avenue is here to stay. If you're looking for a 33rd county, this is the new one." 
Liam McLaughlin, who represents the area in the Yonkers City Council, said the community had developed strong political clout. Many of the Irish here are influential in the trade unions, he said, and the bar owners wield power in the larger business community. When Gerry Adams, leader of the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, visits the country, he always speaks at Rory Dolan's.
According to Mr. Flannelly, the politics and the troubles that have embroiled Northern Ireland, including differences between Catholics and Protestants, are not inflammatory issues in the community here, even though people here keep up with the peace process back home through Irish newspapers and news programs.
Northern Ireland politics just don't translate over here, he said, because people are coming over to make a better life for themselves. 
Mr. Dolan agreed. "Everyone lives together here," he said. "You have Catholics living next to Protestants. People don't care."
Mr. McLaughlin said the community is well-rounded now. "A lot of Irish have gone, but many have stayed too, and bought homes and settled in and taken root," he said. "You used to have young people tending bar and bouncing around the neighborhood, living in a house with four friends. Now they've met someone here and are buying homes of their own, fixing them up and settling here.
"Every time I drive by a house being worked on, it's seems to be someone of Irish descent, and not just on McLean Avenue, but they're moving up to the northwest and eastern parts of Yonkers."
There has been a strong Irish influence in Yonkers for more than a century. According to the 2000 census, of 196,086 documented Yonkers residents, 25,241, or 13 percent, claim to have Irish heritage. That is second only to Italians, who make up 18.8 percent.
The Irish neighborhoods in the New York area include Sunnyside and Woodside in Queens, Woodlawn and Bainbridge in the Bronx and Inwood in Manhattan.
After the decline of Bainbridge Avenue, an Irish hot spot of the 1980's and early 1990's, many Irish moved to Woodlawn and traveled up Katonah Avenue into Yonkers. Many of them, tired of living in apartment buildings were attracted to McLean Avenue with its affordable one-family houses.
The neighborhood, which was part Italian but with a sizable population of older Irish immigrants who settled here decades ago, was safe and convenient to Manhattan. Pubs began springing up, an essential foundation for any Irish neighborhood, and the Irish invasion into the area began. The community grew throughout the 1990's into a major destination for Irish arriving in New York. The American economy was booming and, even on weeknights, the bars were packed shoulder to shoulder. The sidewalks were so crowded with Irish people that it was often compared to Grafton Street, a busy thoroughfare in Dublin.
The area has not been without its problems. In the 1990's there were fears that McLean Avenue would become the next Bainbridge Avenue, which became affected by heavy night life, bar fights and police crackdowns. In 1996, to prevent over-saturation, the Yonkers City Council temporarily banned the construction of new bars along a stretch of McLean Avenue. And in 1999, there were problems with Irish immigrants using ecstasy and other recreational drugs.
But overall, the Irish influx has had a positive effect, said Lee Ellman, the planning director for Yonkers.
"You walk down McLean Avenue and you see a tremendous revitalization of the neighborhood," he said. "It has really become especially vibrant over the last 10 years, a tremendous upgrade. The storefronts had a 1950's look and were somewhat tired looking. Now there is a much more Irish aesthetic, a continental look to the facades."
One of those storefronts is Dympna Tully's business, Tully Travel, which has prospered since she opened it in May 1998.
"A lot of people have chosen to go back to Ireland for one reason or another," she said, "but a lot of young couples have also chosen to stay here and put their children in the schools.
"The area has taken on a lot better look and the stability has increased tremendously in the last few years. The housing prices have doubled, and it's impossible to find a house here. They're sold before they get put on the market."
In Westchester, ethnic enclaves can dilute quickly and recede into anonymity in residential neighborhoods. But it is hard to miss McLean Avenue. The area's picturesque pubs have names that could be set to a lively Irish reel. For starters, you have Mulligans, McGinn's, McGilligan's and McKeon's. Then there is the Well, the Lark's Nest, the Quays and the Snug. Add to that: Arthur Daly's, Ned Devine's, Burke's, Behan's, Bodhran's, Fagans, Fiona's, Cornyn's, Tara and Granuaile. For good measure, throw in: P. J. Clarke's, J. J. Mannion's, the Heritage, the Hibernian, the Leinster House and the Malt House.
Of course, there are also many successful businesses that do not traffic in Guinness Stout and Bushmill's whisky. For food, there is the Irish Coffee Shop, the Irish Country Kitchen, the Celtic Kitchen, Eileen's Country Kitchen and Katie's Cottage. There is Sean's Deli and the An Siopa Beag grocery. There are many Irish car services and law offices.
When the economy was better, even the many Irish immigrants without visas or green cards could find off-the-books work, assisted by the tight network of Irish businesses here. But now many who want to come to America cannot. In recent years, the United States government has made it harder for immigrants from many nations to get work visas and green cards, decreasing quotas and creating lotteries. After Sept. 11, immigration became even harder.
STILL, some young people from Ireland continue to come. And for any newcomer, a haven like McLean Avenue is vital.
"Having a support network is crucial to getting started," said Mary Tuohy, a director of the Aisling Irish Community Center on McLean Avenue, which provides cultural and outreach services.
The center, financed by community donations and a grant from the Irish government, offers everything from passport renewals to classes in yoga and Gaelic.
McLean Avenue is very unified, said Tom Riordan, another director of the center.
"It's actually tighter here than across the sea," Mr. Riordan said. "The Irish are clannish. At home, a Kerry man might help another Kerry man before a Donegal man. But here, Irish is Irish."
Mr. Riordan is a Killarney man and Ms. Tuohy is from Tipperary. 
They said, regardless of their home county, all Irish enjoy being able to get Irish products locally, like Irish newspapers or strong Irish tea. Irish foods can help stave off homesickness, and the small grocers along McLean Avenue stock bangers and rashers and pudding-style sausages. They have Batchelor's Baked Beans, Galtee bacon and kidney pies. Snacks like Tayto's chips and Cadbury chocolates are also on the shelves, as is Weetabix cereal, Jacob's Cream Crackers, and Oldlum's flour for making soda bread.
Besides food, the Irish import another touch-stone of home: sports. The Gaelic Athletic Association runs hurling and Gaelic football games on Sundays in Gaelic Park, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Gaelic football resembles rugby and hurling is something like field hockey for gladiators. For a $10 admission fee, there are four games and some of the world's best hurlers and footballers, most of whom play for teams named for the Irish counties they came from. The teams, financed by the local community, regularly pay for expert players from Ireland to fly here on weekends to play for them during the season, which runs from March through October.
"The teams are a starting point for a lot of Irish," said Tom Tuffy, president of the Sligo Supporters Club, which backs the Sligo team from New York.
"If you're a good footballer and a team picks you up, it will get you work and an apartment and get you moving in the right direction," said Mr. Tuffy, who moved here from Sligo in 1986 and started his own construction company in Manhattan. He soon bought himself a home a block north of McLean Avenue. "If they're footballers, they'll get work through the teams. A large percentage of people in the area come here and stay here because of their sporting abilities."
Danny Leavy, 32, who plays Gaelic football for the Westmeath team, came here nine years ago from the town of Rhode, in County Offaly, and got his job with the carpenters' union through the team. He bought a house just up from McLean Avenue two years ago.
He married an Irish woman here and they are undecided whether to start a family in Ireland or Yonkers. He bought his house for $276,000, he said, and now he can sell it for more than $400,000, but "I know I'll never earn as much working back home."
Inside the bar at Gaelic Park, Varina Carey drank beer with her teammates from the County Kildare Gaelic football team. Ms. Carey, 28, is from the town of Scotstown in Monaghan County. She came to New York in 1993 and headed straight to McLean Avenue. She has basically remained here since then, playing midfield for the team, working for a local accountant and hitting the pubs on the weekends. She said she is buying a condominium near McLean Avenue because "it's the handiest area for me."
Not only Irish immigrants enjoy McLean Avenue. Others are drawn to the neighborhood by Irish music festivals, live bar bands and Irish culture classes in small private schools and community centers.
The McNamaras, an Irish-American family in Tuckahoe, are regular visitors to the McLean Avenue area. The parents, Tom and Rosita McNamara, are constantly shuttling their five children a set of triplets, 11, and a set of twins, 17 to Yonkers for Irish dancing and music lessons. The twins, Elizabeth and Patricia, are world-class competitive step dancers who started at age 8 and have been to Ireland nine times for dancing events. The triplets are Maggie, Conor and Thomas. Maggie plays the tin whistle and dances, Thomas plays keyboard, and Conor plays the accordion.
It's the same with the Mahon family of Mount Vernon. Kathleen Mariah Mahon, 11, has taken step dance since she was 3. Her brother plays the tin whistle.
"Everything she knows about Irish culture, she learned from McLean Avenue, said her father, James M. Mahon. "We didn't even know what the tin whistle was, and now I'm spending $100 on one."
But for residents like Mr. Tuffy, this Dublin-on-the-Thruway is more than just a resource for Irish culture. It is home.
"You're 3,000 miles away from where you were born, yet you don't feel like you're that far away from home," he said. "In a way, it's our home away from home, but we're not going anywhere. We're here to stay."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Woodbridge, N.J.; 
Many Roads and Trains and 10 ZIP Codes

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
AT the intersection of the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike, Woodbridge is one of New Jersey's major crossroads.
 The Amtrak Boston-Washington line and New Jersey Transit's New York-Philadelphia train line meet at its Metropark station. Routes 1 and 9 join up just north of the giant 1.5-million-square-foot Woodbridge Center mall on Route 1. Routes 9 and 440 and the Parkway meet at the southern tip of the township in a spaghettilike snarl of overpasses, sending drivers north toward New York; south toward Philadelphia; west toward the giant Raritan Center Industrial Park, which is partially in Woodbridge; and east toward Staten Island. 
 The 27-square-mile municipality, which is in Middlesex County, includes 10 distinct, but unincorporated, sections and stretches across an equal number of ZIP codes. 
Each of the 10 sections -- Woodbridge, Avenel, Colonia, Sewaren, Iselin, Fords, Menlo Park Terrace, Keasbey, Port Reading and Hopelawn -- has its own central business district; and throughout the town, strip malls abound. Of the 10 areas, only Iselin, which is now a center for immigrants from India, has a specific ethnic flavor.
The town has seven major supermarkets and dozens of restaurants. Perhaps the best known is the Reo Diner on Amboy Avenue in the Woodbridge central business district, where generations of politicians and businessmen have gathered. 
Settled in 1664 and chartered by King Charles II of England in 1669, Woodbridge is New Jersey's oldest township. Among its earliest settlers was John Pike, ancestor of Zebulon M. Pike, who discovered the peak in Colorado that bears his name. The township is named for the Rev. John Woodbridge of Newbury, Mass., from which many of the original settlers came.
Among Woodbridge's claims to fame is that its former mayor, James E. McGreevey, is now New Jersey's governor. The current mayor, Frank G. Pelzman, said the Town Council had often discussed the notion of applying for city status, which would increase its eligibility for state aid, but had always rejected the idea.
"The word 'city' means 'massive,' " the mayor said. "And each of our areas wants to keep its individuality. However, they stay together as a township because of the economies of having one mayor, one police department and one school system." 
Although no major Revolutionary War battles were fought in Woodbridge, the Jersey Blues, a regiment that guarded the inner perimeter of Gen. George Washington's encampment in Valley Forge, Pa., was organized in the township. On April 22, 1789, General Washington stayed overnight at the Cross Keys Tavern -- now a private home -- in Woodbridge en route to his inauguration in New York City.
The town's only building on the National Register of Historic Places is the brownstone Barron Arts Center, which has stained glass windows and a clock tower. Built as a library in 1877, the center on Rahway Avenue holds art exhibits and concerts.
Fueled by low interest rates, the Woodbridge real estate market is very hot, with frequent bidding wars among prospective buyers, drawn in part by the town's excellent transportation system. 
"Recently, a split level in Colonia was listed at $209,900," said Ernie Dragos, owner of Dragos Sun Realty on Amboy Avenue. "Six agencies submitted contracts" on behalf of perspective purchasers, he continued. "A builder bought it at $212,500, updated the kitchen, installed new windows and did some other renovations, then relisted it three months later at $314,900. It sold at full price within 10 days."
Woodbridge has an extremely diverse housing stock. In Sewaren and Port Reading, along the Arthur Kill, some small Cape Cod or ranch houses go for as low as $170,000, and in the Estates neighborhood of Colonia, an enclave of large colonials on lots of an acre or more, houses can fetch more than $1 million, according to James J. Elek, owner of JJ Elek Realty on Main Street.
At the beginning of August, 204 homes were on the market in the Multiple Listing Service, ranging from $129,900 for a two-bedroom unit in a "half duplex" two-family house in the Woodbridge section up to $1.2 million for 5,000-square-foot custom colonial to be built on one acre in the Estates area. 
The majority of homes are 30 to 40 years old. Lately, however, builders have been tearing down existing homes on large lots and replacing them with several new homes. For example, on Trinity Place in Avenel, a builder recently purchased a small bungalow-type ranch for $145,000, knocked it down and is now building two four-bedroom homes on the site, with plans to list them for $325,000, Mr. Dragos said.
The town has 21 major condominium complexes, ranging in size to the 404-unit Wyndmoor development on Cricket Lane in the Woodbridge section. It also has 7,598 rental apartments in 69 complexes, the largest being the 802-unit Kensington Gardens in Fords. According to Mr. Dragos, town house condominiums range from about $170,000 for units with two bedrooms and two and a half baths in Woodbridge Commons off Gill Lane, within walking distance of the Metropark train station, up to about $270,000 for some three-bedroom, two-bath units with finished basements, decks and fireplaces off Highview Drive near Woodbridge center. 
Mr. Dragos lists his typical buyers as two-income families, including blue-collar couples, professionals seeking houses near their offices in Woodbridge and young couples who are drawn to the excellent transportation to Manhattan. Besides Metropark, the town has two other train stations in Woodbridge and in Avenel. 
Among those recently purchasing homes in Woodbridge were Martin A. Comiskey, a freelance photographer, and his wife, Barbara, who works as a supervisor at L'Oreal, the cosmetics company, in Cranbury, about 15 miles to the south. Two years ago, they moved from a mobile home in Avenel into a three-bedroom ranch on Lyman Avenue in the Woodbridge section. 
"We paid $154,900, and the day we started painting, someone offered us $20,000 more," Mr. Comiskey said. "Although we are only in this house two years, we wonder how we managed in a cramped two-bedroom mobile home."
He termed the area "very friendly," noting that neighbors had helped him put up Christmas lights and had helped his wife start a vegetable garden. Their son, Thomas, 20, attends Middlesex County College in neighboring Edison and their daughter, Barbara, 13, attends Woodbridge High School. Because the house is very close to Routes 1 and 9, Mr. Comiskey's main complaint concerns the heavy rush-hour traffic. "They are building more stores along Route 9, which will only make things worse," he said. 
The 13,250-student Woodbridge Public Schools system has 16 elementary, 5 middle and 3 high schools. The acting superintendent, Vincent Smith, complains that in each of the past 33 years except for 1991, voters have defeated the school budget, forcing the township and the school board to hammer out budgets.
"Failed budgets mean smaller budgets," Mr. Smith explained, "and we can't raise construction money through a bond referendum because the voters won't support it."
As a result, no new schools have been built since Colonia High was completed in 1967. Some of the schools are overcrowded, with the most severe problem at Colonia Middle School, where the average class size is 26, compared with a state average of 21. Although the media centers in the schools have Internet access, the classrooms do not, even though statewide 89 percent of classrooms are connected.
The district recently began an initiative called Technology 2000, supported by $1.5 million in district funds and $1 million in contributions from the township and the FedEx Corporation, to improve computer access throughout the district. 
In 2001, the last year for which the figures are available, students at all three high schools in Woodbridge scored below the state averages on both the verbal and mathematics portions of the College Board tests. Eighty-one percent of the graduates are going on to higher education. Each of the three high schools offers 11 or 12 advanced placement courses in the sciences, foreign languages, computers, history and English. 
"We are making too many tough choices," Mr. Smith said. "Our middle schools are cutting back on security officers; our heating systems, boilers and windows are shot; and our parking lots are full of patches. We need to get more parents involved and get our budgets passed."
Community United for Better Schools, a 50-member organization formed after the latest budget was defeated last April, has begun an information campaign to persuade voters to pass the next budget.
Woodbridge has 21 parks; the largest is the 179-acre Middlesex County-owned Merrill Park off the Middlesex-Essex Turnpike. It contains four tennis courts (two with lights), two basketball courts, three baseball diamonds, two softball diamonds, three gazebos, a soccer field, a football field, nine picnic groves, four playgrounds and a petting zoo.
The township has just completed the $16 million Woodbridge Community Center on Main Street. It contains meeting rooms, a full-sized hockey rink, a roller rink, a pool, a exercise room and a basketball court.

Some homeowners use them for basketball courts; others for driveways. They were poured as floors and foundations for some of the 110 buildings constructed in 1918 to serve as United States General Hospital No. 3, a military orthopedic hospital. The facility was built on 300 acres owned by Charles D. Freeman, a commodities trader. Mr. Freeman lent his estate to the Army after a discussion with another Colonia resident, Dr. Fred A. Albee, an orthopedic surgeon who had been asked to establish a hospital that would perform reconstructive surgery on wounded soldiers. The hospital received its first patient on July 5, 1918, and closed on Aug. 15, 1919. In its 13 months of existence, it treated about 6,000 wounded soldiers. The hospital was demolished in 1919, and the land was returned to Mr. Freeman. Map of New Jersey shows the location of Woodbridge.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
The Pros and Cons of Owning a Piece of the Dock

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: CROTON-ON-HUDSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Harvey Shaplow, who lives in this Hudson riverfront village, learned this spring that some of the only dockominiums in the state were for sale at Half Moon Bay Marina next door to where he lives, he bought two of them. Mr. Shaplow, who is not planning to use them himself, said he bought them as "a good investment in tough economic times." 
 "Maybe I'm not going to make a million dollars," Mr. Shaplow said, "but with the way things are these days, I'm doing a lot better than if I put the same money in the stock market." A 35-foot-long dockominium -- the dock and the land under it -- at the Half Moon Bay Marina costs $32,500, and Mr. Shaplow has already found renters who will pay him $3,150 a season for each one. 
 Moreover, the value of his two-bedroom condominium on the waterfront here is enhanced by the availability of a dockominium so close by, realtors say. On the other hand, recent history has shown that in hard times investors may flee from the marina business. 
Half Moon Bay Marina began converting its 173 slips to dockominiums this spring after the offering plan was accepted by the state in March. Almost half of the slips have already been sold. Marissa Piesman, an assistant attorney general, said that dockominiums fell under the same legal category as condominiums. Condos, dockominiums, co-ops and homeowners' associations must be registered with the state attorney general's office in New York.
David Plotkin, who owns the Half Moon Bay Marina, paid $715,000 for the property -- which includes nine underwater acres and less than an acre of shoreline -- at a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation auction in 1994. The property had been owned by James Harvey, the original developer of Half Moon Bay Condominiums next door. Mr. Harvey defaulted on his mortgages for the marina and the condos during the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, as did many real estate investors at that time.
The condo project, a separate business entity that has seen a number of development proposals in the last decade, is being completed by Spectrum Skanska of Valhalla as Discovery Cove at Half Moon Bay.
In the late 1990's, as the economy flourished again, the dockominium concept regained popularity, particularly in Florida, North Carolina and California. But in New York, the only other dockominium is the Anchorage Yacht Club in Babylon on Long Island. That one was formed in 1985, along with several others that subsequently failed, according to the attorney general's office.
Howard G. Sheldon, a financial specialist in Roanoke, Va., with First Union National Bank, which handles many mortgage applications for boat slips, predicted the dockominium concept would take off this time around -- "especially since we're only four or five years away from the baby boom retirement era."
"Boats are a great leisure time activity, people need places to keep them, and demand for slips is beginning to overtake supply," said Mr. Sheldon, who has received about 20 mortgage applications in the last six weeks from prospective dock owners at Half Moon Bay, many referred to First Union by the marina owners.
Another factor contributing to the growing popularity of dockominiums is the recent repeal of the federal tax on luxury boats, said Diane DeNardo, an owner of the Palmer Point Marina in Greenwich, Conn., which is the sales and service arm for River Club of Greenwich, a dockominium complex. "In the last two years, boats here started selling like crazy," Ms. DeNardo said. Palmer Point, which was started in the mid-1980's and struggled in its early years, has now sold all 110 of its dockominiums. 
"For a while, we couldn't give the slips away," Ms. DeNardo said. "Now we have waiting lists."
Dockominium buyers can apply for up to a 10-year mortgage -- with the same tax deductions that a conventional mortgage offers -- although interest rates of dockominium loans have been a bit higher lately than on first mortgages for houses, running about 7.9 percent in recent weeks, according to Mr. Sheldon of First Union. Many dockominium buyers like Mr. Shaplow, who own condos nearby, buy the boat slips to increase the value of their land-based property, he said.
BUT Mr. Shaplow, like several others interviewed, paid cash for his two dockominiums. 
And while some use them solely as an investment, others buy them instead of renting to make sure they have a place to keep their boat -- especially as waiting lists for rentals grow longer. Also, owning a dockominium allows a condo owner to sell both at the same time to a potential boat owner.
Like a landowners' condo group, a boat owners' dockominium association can be formed when 15 percent of the slips have been bought. Alan Rothschild, a White Plains lawyer who wrote the offering plan for Half Moon Bay Marina, said dockominium buyers owned the water space and the right to use a specific slip to dock a boat. The dock area, walkway and planks constitute the common area, much as the internal sidewalks, roadways and parking areas of a condo do.
"It's like buying a piece of the Hudson River and land under it, and the dock comes along with it," Mr. Plotkin said. He said monthly maintenance ran about $80 and covered insurance, electricity and maintenance, among other things. Each dockominium includes a hookup for electricity, water, telephone and cable television.
Dockominium owners, like condo owners, are responsible for taxes.
But why have dockominiums been popular elsewhere and so slow to catch on in New York? According to Ms. Piesman at the attorney general's office, few marina owners in the state also own the land under the water, and most have only an easement to the property. It is easier, she said, to become a co-op marina, with a corporation owning or leasing a strip of land, obtaining an easement for use of the water and selling shares to use the docks. Even so, there are only about a dozen of those registered in the state.
But even when they meet all the criteria to convert to dockominiums or a co-op, not all marina owners consider that a wise business decision.
Johanna Giacobbe, who owns the Imperial Yacht Club in New Rochelle, a family-run business with close to 100 slips, said: "We never wanted to convert because that would mean giving over control to someone else, to an association. For now, we're keeping things the way they are."
Also, in at least one state, the concept of private ownership of an area on a body of water is illegal. In Wisconsin, state judges halted a proposed dockominium complex on the basis that is would block public access to the water. The Public Trust Doctrine, a legal principle dating to the Roman Empire, guarantees the public access to the water, holding that air, sea and shore belong not to any one person but to the public at large. Waterfront owners have a right to use the shoreline and access the water, and to build docks and piers as long as the structures do not impede navigation of the river or lake.
MASSACHUSETTS outlawed the concept of dockominiums in 1990, but the state for now is allowing members-only marinas, where a boater pays a fixed amount to join a marina n return for a guaranteed spot to park his boat for 99 years. No ownership deeds are issued to members. Existing dockominiums have been grandfathered.
The future of the dockominium market in New York is difficult to predict, Ms. Piesman said. Clearly, the ability to create new dockominiums will be limited somewhat by the requirement that the land under the water be owned by the individual or company selling the boat slips, she said. "But anything can happen," she added. "Judging by other creative developments we've seen, real estate can sometimes enter the realm of the surreal."

HEADLINE: THE ARTS; 
Redefining Mall Culture

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: PARAMUS 

 BODY:
FIRST stop: the Gap for a new pair of jeans. Then on to Claire's Accessories, for makeup and earrings, and possibly a spin through B. Dalton Bookseller to check out the latest fiction. But before leaving the mall, you might want to head downstairs to view the works of a local watercolorist, or take in the Holocaust remembrance exhibition at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science.
 After years of operating out of makeshift county office space and relying on other venues to display its works, the Bergen Museum will soon have a home to call its own -- in the lower level of the Bergen Mall. 
 Maybe this what is meant by mall culture.
The idea of housing a museum inside a mall seems like an obvious choice for Paramus. After all, the American Association of Museums says that elsewhere in the country, there are only two children's museums, two museum satellite branches and one science and art museum situated in malls.
"Paramus doesn't have a town center," said Dorothy Nicklus, first vice president of the Bergen Museum. "Even City Hall and the main post office are off Route 17. So, like in many places, the mall is the town center."
The president of the museum's board, Peter Knipe, who has been pursuing the mall space for the last two years, admits the choice may seem a bit unusual but thinks it is not much different from having a movie theater in a mall.
"Of course, the mall won't have the same economic advantage if we were a movie theater, but the museum will attract people that might not otherwise come to the mall," said Mr. Knipe, who expects to remain at the mall for at least three years. "They can come do some shopping, have dinner and visit the museum."
Not unlike the bones of the two mastodons that are part of its collection, the Bergen Museum has been struggling to piece itself back together since December 1998, when Bergen County reclaimed the 10,000-square-foot space on East Ridgewood Avenue here that it had been providing the museum rent-free for nearly 40 years.
Since then, the museum has been a nomad, presenting occasional shows in municipal buildings, theaters and schools and mounting limited exhibitions in its fifth-floor office space in another county building in Hackensack. With no heating or air-conditioning in the evenings or on weekends, Ms. Nicklus said, it was particularly frustrating trying to get the public to attend shows there, since "the building's doors would lock at 5 p.m., and we would have to use walky-talkies to let people up."
In March, the museum even lost this less-than-desirable space after its lease with the county expired. And while the board was given enough notice to properly pack up the works in Hackensack, the bulk of the museum's 500-piece collection, which was still being stored in Paramus, was crated up by county workers with little care, said Rena Burg, one board trustee.
"They came in with no warning in March and loaded them off to a county storage facility without any attention to the conservation of art," said Ms. Burg.
While the Bergen County freeholder chairman, Anthony Cassano, blamed a communication mix-up for the premature packing, he said that he was "not aware of any major problem."
The museum will have a better idea of the condition of its collection when it begins moving it to the 2,800-square-foot mall space on Sept. 1. Board members do not expect to be ready to open to the public until late October, but the museum will be host to its first annual music and arts festival outside the mall on the weekend of Sept. 14 and 15, to let people know it is back in business and, it is hoped, to begin establishing a regular source of funds.
As a "museum without walls," the Bergen Museum has not been able to qualify for state art financing. And in March did not include any money for it in the current budget. 
Ever the optimist, Mr. Knipe said he hoped that in its new home, the museum -- which is operated with the help of volunteers -- will be able to sustain itself through private resources rather than public funds. Currently the museum has about 600 members, which Mr. Knipe said he expected to triple or quadruple in the next year.
Among its priorities, the museum board is eager to bring home its two mastodon skeletons. Discovered in 1962 during the construction of Route 80, the Hackensack Mastodon is currently on loan to Museum Village in Monroe, N.Y., while the Dwarskill Mastodon, which was discovered in 1973, is on display at the State Museum in Trenton. Mr. Knipe is hoping to display one or both of the partial skeletons at the mall, but because of their size, this might require spilling over into some of the mall's common space.
One other piece of unsettled business is the renowned mural by the Polish artist Stefan Knapp, which belongs to the Bergen Museum and is undoubtedly its most valuable piece. Believed to be the largest enamel mural in the world, the 184-by-50-foot Abstract Impressionist painting graced the side of Alexander's on Route 4 from 1965 until 1998, when the department store was razed. Since then, the mural has been in storage in Carlstadt. And while Mr. Knipe has had conversations with various parties, so far he has no takers for the mural. Among those he approached was Ikea, which is now negotiating building on the space once occupied by Alexander's, although representatives of the home furnishings store were "not very interested," Mr. Knipe said.
"Because it's a very important asset, we couldn't just give the mural away, and Ikea didn't recognize the value of it," he said. For now, the Bergen County icon is being appraised. 
Mr. Knapp's works are on display throughout the world, from the Tate Gallery in London to the Vatican Museum in Rome to the Museum of Modern Art in New York. But for anyone wishing to see the Bergen Museum's Knapp mural, they will have to settle for the picture on the museum's Web site, or the reproduction in a local Verizon yellow pages.

GRAPHIC: Photos: David Knipe, president of the Bergen County Museum, says relocating in the Paramus Mall may allow more people to see its works. (Photographs by Demetrius Balevski for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE ENVIRONMENT; 
Why Was the Spigot On in August?

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD 

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY'S on-again, off-again drought restrictions were on again last week with a statewide ban on all lawn watering and car washing, which left many people asking: Why was the ban lifted at all in a period that Bradley M. Campbell, the commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Protection, said was shaping up as the driest in the state's history?
 "Extraordinary events call for extraordinary actions," Mr. Campbell said last Wednesday when he announced the reimposition of the ban on lawn watering and car washing at home. Plants, shrubs and trees can be watered every other day. 
 The announcement gave a herky-jerky feel to the state's drought policies, which depend largely on the imprecise arts of weather forecasting and climatology. This year, rainfall levels declined drastically in the withering heat of July and August -- after the restrictions were eased following the relatively wet months of April, May and June. 
Yet another part of the drought policy is formed in response to the political and economic pressures faced by the region's elected officials.
In one way or another, all these factors have dogged the state throughout the year as Mr. Campbell has sought to come up with a balanced response to the vagaries of the rising tempers of spring and the rising temperatures of midsummer.
In 20-20 hindsight, it seems that all the indicators were there to dictate a clear, singular approach.
In March, Mr. Campbell, along with Governor McGreevey, declared a state drought emergency, noting that New Jerseyans were coming off the driest six-month period in the state's history since 1895.
But then in July, water consumption in the northeast part of the state increased a whopping 100 million gallons a day.
Faced with perilously low reservoir levels in the aftermath of a warm, dry winter -- a total ban was imposed on lawn watering in the northeast and a schedule was drawn up for the less arid central and coastal areas -- allowing households with odd-numbered addresses to water on odd-numbered dates and those with even-numbered addresses to water on even-numbered dates.
Restaurants were told not to provide patrons with water unless it was requested, and hot tubs and pools could only be topped off and not refilled. Car washing -- except for emergency vehicles -- was banned and only commercial car washes using recyclable water could operate.
Those who used more than 100,000 gallons of water a day -- like golf courses, nurseries, automobile plants and utilities -- had their allocations cut 50 percent. Then came an April, with average rainfall and a May and June with rainfall above average.
"There was a three-month period in which things were looking a lot better," said Jeffrey Tittel, executive director of the Sierra Club of New Jersey. "The grass was all green, the climatologists were saying summer would bring average rainfalls, and a lot of wishful thinking set in."
Keith Arnesen, a professor of meteorology at Rutgers University and the assistant state climatologist, said that long-range forecasting was "not very good."
"It is true that we had reached a period where rainfall had returned to normal, but weather doesn't have a memory which dictates that being normal for the last three months means that it will be normal rainfall for the next three," Mr. Arnesen said.
As it was, the three months of rain began just as Mr. Campbell started holding public hearings on what measures to take to ease the dropping water levels. At every stop, said Elaine Makatura, spokeswoman for the environmental agency, he faced angry representatives of the "green industry" -- landscapers, nursery operators and golf course operators -- who complained that their reduced allocations and threatened restrictions would present a financial hardship.
In June, the commissioner eased the restrictions, increasing the allotment of large water users to 80 percent from 50 percent, allowing weekend car washing and odd-even lawn watering statewide. Other restrictions -- like those on restaurants providing water, the filling of swimming pools and controls on other commercial water uses -- remained in place.
"It had everything to do with the fact that we had a period of above-average rainfall and a lot to do with the negative impact it was having on the nursery industry," Ms. Makatura insisted.
Throughout the drought emergency, the McGreevey Administration had shown an acute awareness of the connection between the drought and New Jersey's delicate economic state, said James Sinclair, an environmental expert with the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. Early on, Mr. Sinclair said, the environmental agency asked businesses to develop plans for a reduction in water use, and with the latest restrictions asked them to provide an analysis of the economic effect of the rollback.
"The drought is probably not as serious a threat to our state economy as the drought in the 70's was when we were more dependent on manufacturing for jobs," said Mr. Sinclair. "But to Brad Campbell's credit, he has been talking about this and has promised that he would track rainfall carefully in setting restrictions."
But Mr. Tittel of the Sierra Club said that the decision in June to increase commercial allotments was a bad call, running counter to the long-term indications showing the state in a prolonged drought that had persisted from 1998 to 1999, abated in 2000 with Hurricane Floyd, but roared back in 2001.
Still, he said, the McGreevey administration had been faced with the delicate job of juggling the psychology of water restrictions and a sagging economy.
"The McGreevey people have been doing the best that they can given the circumstances, and they probably should have tightened up the restrictions earlier, but that is 20-20 hindsight," said Mr. Tittel. "They are on the other hand trying the longer-term solutions to our water problems such as curbing growth and development and linking up the state's water resources."
Mr. Arnesen, the assistant state climatologist, conceded that there was a risk of "whipsawing people" with the revisions, but added that not to respond to the changes in the weather would have paved the way for even more serious problems.
At the least, the ban on lawn watering can provide quick results. According to Mr. Tittel, a lawn sprinkler running for two hours spouts out more than two inches, or 2,000 gallons, of water -- a significant amount.
In Ridgewood, for instance, the town's water storage last week plunged to 40 percent of normal, prompting town officials to institute a local lawn-watering ban. In just four days of relatively lax enforcement, said Frank Moritz, the town's water director, the amount of water stored doubled to 80 percent. The town had planned to lift its local ban, but the announcement of the statewide restrictions dashed those plans.
But Mr. Arnesen said that rising reservoir levels and increased water storage did not solve the more serious and long-term problem of coping with the drought. He likened the state to a sponge that has been just sprinkled with water, noting that while softness on the surface represented the reservoirs, the core of the sponge representing the subterranean aquifer remained hard and dry.
"Still, I think in this day and time letting your lawn go brown is actually performing a community service," Mr. Tittel said.
He might get an argument from Dan Schapiro, a Ridgewood homeowner who has lavished attention on his lush, green 50-by-100-foot lawn over the last months.
"It's upsetting after putting in all of the work I did since April," said Mr. Schapiro, a textile company owner whose lawn will soon become an expanse of withered browner. "The only consolation, I guess, is that the lawn can come back green as ever next year."
For Terry Bannon, the general manager of the Rancocas Golf Club in Willingboro, the drought restrictions that cut his water allotment by half have already "changed the way we do business." Even with the increased allotment in June, the club still watered only the greens, tees and fairways, leaving the rough to go brown. But the diminished allotment, along with the heat and scant rainfall -- is beginning to stress even the areas that they are watering.
"In other years they have imposed restrictions, but no one did much enforcement," he said. "This time its different, and the state regulators are all over us." --------------------

Utilities Barred from Cutting Service
NEWARK, (AP) -- State regulators last week barred utilities from shutting off delinquent customers' power when temperatures of 95 degrees or higher are forecast within 24 hours.
The emergency measure, effective for the next 60 days, is intended to guard the health of frail, elderly and other residents vulnerable to extreme heat, by ensuring that they can run their fans or air-conditioners even when they cannot pay their bills.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NONFICTION; 
Why New Yorkers Loved the Babe

 BODY:
YANKEES CENTURY: 100 Years Of New York Yankees Baseball
Text by Glenn Stout
Photographs edited by Richard A. Johnson
Houghton Mifflin
($35, hardcover)
 New York City was precisely the right place for Ruth. The dual tragedies of the war and the recent plague of Spanish influenza, which killed half a million Americans, had left the nation saddened and pessimistic. But now society was on the rebound, the postwar economy was booming, lifestyles were changing, and Americans were ready to cut loose and have some fun. 
 New York City emerged in the 1920's as the nation's commercial and cultural center. And Ruth was New York incarnate -- uncouth and raw, flamboyant and flashy, oversized, out of scale, and absolutely unstoppable. He towered over baseball like the Manhattan skyline. Compared to Ruth, all else was in shadow.
His doughy face, dark, broad features, and massive torso drew fans toward him. The simple fact that he was neither English nor Irish made it easy for fans of other ethnicities to identify with him, and New York City, more than ever before, was still a city of immigrants, a place they had made their own. Manhattan was more than Fifth Avenue and Wall Street. The heart of the city was where the people lived, in dozens of ethnic enclaves such as Little Italy, Hell's Kitchen and Chinatown.
Ruth was one of them, a street urchin raised in a Baltimore orphanage. His behavioral incorrigibility somehow made him even more endearing, because Ruth, despite his many personal faults, was never cruel. There was no malice in his behavior, simply unchecked enthusiasms run amuck.

RESCUING THE WORLD: The Life and Times Of Leo Cherne
By Andrew F. Smith
State University of New York Press
($26.50, hardcover)
Cherne's first year at New York University was actually spent in an annex at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building. He had no serious academic orientation, and he found the courses unstimulating with two exceptions. One was an English class, in which he was required to write a paper. At the time, Prohibition was still the law of the land, and Cherne noted that newspapers were filled with stories about deaths on the Bowery as a result of the illegal sale of "smoke," a mixture of wood alcohol and water, which had a smoky appearance. It sold for 15 cents a bottle -- sometimes just a dime. Every morning ambulances would arrive on the Bowery and cart away the bodies. Some victims needed medical treatment, but many died from alcohol poisoning. Cherne convinced Lillian Herlends, his English teacher, to give him credit to live for a month on the Bowery and write up the experience, provided that a newspaper agreed to publish his stories. The editors he approached at The Daily Mirror bought the idea.
Cherne lived on the Bowery disguised as a bum frequenting speakeasies. He reported daily the addresses of the places that sold smoke, which The Daily Mirror dutifully published. The police read the stories and raided the speakeasies identified in Cherne's articles. This had two results: the speakeasies threw comatose bodies into the alleys behind their establishments rather than out the front door, where they would have been visible; and every proprietor on the Bowery began looking for the informer. At first Cherne had been able to order smoke and spill it out without drinking it, but as things heated up, he had to drink what he ordered. He remained on the Bowery for 10 days, living in flophouses. One morning, he awoke to find himself piled with the others in the back of a speakeasy. He'd had enough. The Daily Mirror was happy with the results and his teacher gave him an A+.

MY LIFE IN THE NYPD: JIMMY THE WAGS
By James Wagner
With Patrick Picciarelli
Onyx
($5.99, paperback)
Ninth Precinct cops had a reputation for being wild men. More often than not, any high-crime command was a world unto itself. Rules generally didn't apply in precincts where walking to your radio car at the start of a tour could turn into a near-death experience. We made up our own rules as we went along.
Wild parties, drinking on duty, brutality, and a sloppy appearance were generally accepted in a ghetto command, as long as you got the job done. Parties were a safety valve to let off steam. Drinking on duty prepared us for the after-work parties. (Why waste valuable minutes getting a buzz on your own time?)
In the 70's it was commonplace -- indeed, accepted -- to slap around prisoners and other miscreants who gave us a hard time. The cops were greatly outnumbered, and if for one moment the street people thought you were soft, you'd pay the price with a garbage can thrown from a roof or a direct confrontation on the street. The tougher you were, the more respected you were in your sector. . . . 
Captain Baker was determined to change our image by implementing rules that would have met with resistance even from the Royal Guard at Windsor Castle.
"Men," he said at his first roll call, "from here on in every officer in this command will wear a hat when outside the radio car." I hadn't seen my hat in weeks. "Two, no smoking in uniform, no drinking in uniform, and above all, I want a greater amount of respect shown to the citizens of this command."
Citizens? I thought. I had recently locked up a 15-year-old kid for setting his parents on fire -- this shortly after someone tried to blow up my radio car with a homemade bomb. No, Captain Baker had to go, but first we had to find where he was most vulnerable.

FOR THE SINS OF MY FATHER: A Mafia Killer, His Son And the Legacy of a Mob Life
By Albert DeMeo
Broadway Books
($24.95, hardcover)
I already knew that there were two White Houses in America. One was the White House we talked about at school, where President Carter lived. Anybody could visit that place. The White House my father was taking me to was the place where Paul Castellano lived. Paul Castellano was ii capo di tutti cappi, the boss of bosses, godfather and chosen heir to Carlo Gambino. Big Paul was at least as powerful in the underworld as the president was in the world of international politics. The Castellano White House was a private place, and only the inner circle could go there. My father was now a part of that circle.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Rooting for a Recession in the East Village

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS; E-mail: jacobsa@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"CRASH! Crash! Crash!"
 That's the chant my cash-poor friends and I have been secretly invoking, a cynical, self-serving prayer aimed at the Big Guy in the Sky who holds sway over the stock market. You see, after a decade of depressing excess, we were hoping that a dive-bombing Dow would quell the soaring rents and boutique-ization that has turned our beloved East Village into an alcohol-soaked playland for dot-com millionaires, carousing N.Y.U. students and those who love them. We had a dream that the recession would bring back the cheap pirogi joints, $600 studios and the charming anarchy of Avenue B. 
 Fat chance. 
Rents dipped briefly after Sept. 11 but, like the markets, they're on the rise again, with subway-car-size flats in my neglected tenement going for $2,000. The New Theater Building, a luxury condominium that mockingly shadows its low-rise neighbors, was sold out even before the frosted windows obscured its guarded lobby. St. Marks, that chaotic jumble of tattoo parlors, secondhand CD shops and panhandling skinheads, will never be the same once a developer finishes renovating the blue elephant that once housed Andy Warhol's Electric Circus. Every week, it seems, another cherished merchant is replaced by the likes of Alpha Fine Foods, a purveyor of British muesli ($5 a bag) and strawberry Italian balsamic vinegar ($9) across from Tompkins Square Park, that former crucible of social tumult. The rest of the Lower East Side, increasingly pocked with mojito lounges and 50's furniture stores, is not far behind.
"The yuppies have wiped out a wonderful culture of artists and those with a political consciousness," said John Penley, a battle-scarred photojournalist who has lived there for two decades. 
Not that the changes have been all bad. For one thing, the East Village is cleaner and less menacing than it was in the late 1970's and 1980's, when my generation discovered a neighborhood that had been left for dead, its streets awash with crack addicts and homeless people. I'll be the first to admit that I patronize some of the new bistros that dot Alphabet City, although I do so with the requisite liberal guilt. 
But I still seethe at the changes, and try to fathom why moneyed folk want to live in these grimy fluorescent-lighted walkups. "Why?" asked Gene Martinez, a broker at the Corcoran Group, which sells million-dollar homes on Avenue D. "Because it's cool. It's about living on the edge, being Bohemian, but with lots of money." 
Mr. Martinez's hypothesis was partly borne out the other day as I walked past the boarded-up remains of Charas/El Bohio, the iconic cultural center on East Ninth Street that housed artists and activists until Mayor Giuliani sold it to a developer. Across the street, resting on the loading deck of their U-Haul, two weary newcomers explained why they had given up comfortable lives in Madison, Wis., for a cramped $1,925-a-month apartment on a block once famous for heroin outlets. "It's sexy, the drinks are cheaper and it's safe," said Ali Tonn, 26, whose hair was dyed a dull orange. "Everywhere else in the city seemed so boring." 
Both Ms. Tonn and her friend have already found work at a nonprofit arts group. But to make the rent, they'll both need supplemental waitress jobs. They may not be fiery socialist squatters, but in some ways, they are not unlike the earlier youthful strivers who brought color and creative buzz to the neighborhood. 
Last week's news that the Bloomberg administration will sell 11 buildings to a group of homesteaders is further proof that all is not lost. And as long as New York's rent laws remain in place, thousands of other old-timers -- aging hippies, undiscovered artists and assorted outcasts -- will help keep some intensity in the East Village.
Then there are the weekly protests each Saturday night at Avenue A and East Seventh Street, where the police and protesters clashed more than a decade ago. Organized by a hardy band of antiestablishment agitators, the Speak Outs, who have been drawing scores of people who sing ditties like "Die, Yuppie Scum" and shout unkind words at the diners at Leshko's, a retro-chic restaurant that appropriated the name and space of a treasured Ukrainian coffee shop. 
Now in their fourth week, the protests began after recent incidents in the park, including a police crackdown on quality-of-life offenses and the arrival of a Haagen-Dazs "sculptural pavilion" that sold $3 scoops of ice cream. Mr. Penley, an organizer, said he had been heartened by the turnout, but acknowledged that no amount of angry foot-stomping can kill the gentrification beast. 
"I guess our only hope," he said, "is that the stock market tanks."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
When Times Are Hard, Household Names Shine

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
COMPANIES that make basic consumer products like lipstick, shampoo and razor blades have been proving their worth as bedrock investments.
 Carol Warner Wilke, household products and cosmetics analyst at Merrill Lynch, talked last week about the outlook for the dozen companies she follows. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. How vulnerable are the companies you follow to turns in the economy?

A. For the most part, the current slowdown has not really had an impact on them. When they are challenged, it is more a company-specific sort of story. During the current slowdown, for example, Estee Lauder has seen a significant impact in its department store sales.

Q. A couple of years ago, when the economy, technology and telecom were booming, these stocks were getting slammed. Why?

A. A couple of years ago, this group was having a really tough time. Part of the problem was technology, which was very popular. But most of the challenges they were dealing with were company-specific.
There were management shake-ups at companies like Procter & Gamble, Avon and Gillette. Some acquisitions didn't work out. And some challenging external conditions made the problems well up. 
But over the past 9 to 12 months there has been a significant improvement in execution. Procter & Gamble's new chief executive has spent the last two years revamping the company, and earnings growth has beaten expectations three out of the last four quarters. 
Avon is another example. Andrea Jung took over there in November of 1999 and since then has refocused on the direct-selling business. Avon has met or exceeded expectations for 10 straight quarters.

Q. What shape are these companies in?

A. I am positive on the group. Cash flow and earnings are strong. The quality of earnings is high, balance sheets have improved significantly, the currency situation on the whole is positive and they are well positioned to pick up growth outside the United States. To me, that is pretty appealing.

Q. Historically, what sort of growth rates have these companies achieved?

A. On average, earnings tend to grow about 10 percent a year. Revenues tend to grow about 4 percent. They are not superfast growers. That is not what you buy these companies for.
The market is not concerned about superfast growth. It has shown it is more concerned about a company setting a realistic goal and meeting it. The market rewards steady, consistent growth.

Q. Are the stocks trading at historically high price-to-earnings multiples?

A. Through last Tuesday, on average, the stock price of the group was up 7 percent so far this year, versus quite a big decline for the major market averages. Every company is outperforming every index.
Typically, these stocks have traded at a premium to the Standard & Poor's 500 index. But right now almost every name is trading at a discount to its 5-year and 10-year price-to-earnings ratio. That is a function of the market. I don't assume the stocks will get back to their all-time-high price-to- earnings ratios, but back to their average. 

Q. At the moment, which company has the best new-product pipeline?

A. Looking at the whole universe, the company that has the most momentum in terms of new products and initiatives is Avon.
Estee Lauder always has a host of new products. Colgate-Palmolive has some big new products coming in the fall. Procter & Gamble has been very focused on new products in their big brands, like their Crest business. And a year ago they launched a new line of diapers and training pants in Europe.

Q. Which companies are your favorites, and which are you cautious about?

A. I don't own any of these companies, but the two stocks I like the most are Avon and Procter & Gamble.
Avon's top-line growth is at least twice the group average, and earnings have been very consistent and consistently higher. 
Procter is very much back on track. Their earnings quality has improved significantly, they have streamlined manufacturing and are getting higher utilization rates out of their existing plants. Their goal is to focus on health care and beauty care, which are higher-margin and less capital-intensive businesses. 
Clorox is a company I am not positive on and have rated a hold. The stock is fairly fully valued. Its challenge is the business in which it participates: home cleaning. They have lower top-line growth than the others in the group. They have done a great job of improving their balance sheet and cash flow, but my concerns have to do with what their growth can be, given their business mix.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for DEBRA L. DUNN; 
Why It's Worth Taking the Heat

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
THROUGH much of this week and next, a large group of politicians, professors, environmentalists, economists and such, representing developed and developing countries, will converge on the Earth Summit sponsored by the United Nations in Johannesburg to discuss how to protect natural resources while expanding economies.
 Also participating will be executives from dozens of big corporations. They'll be there ostensibly to see how their companies can best help advance the worldwide push toward "sustainable development," a catchphrase for raising incomes and standards of living without depleting resources or sullying the environment. If the past is any indication, advocates of environmental and social welfare causes will protest the practices of these same companies. 
 So why do the companies attend, subjecting themselves to such public criticism? Don't they have their hands full buoying their stock prices, calming their shareholders, holding on to their customers and otherwise hanging on in this turbulent economy?
Debra L. Dunn, senior vice president for corporate affairs at the Hewlett-Packard Company and one of its delegates to the conference, tried to explain. She spoke in a telephone interview last Thursday. CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

Q. Wouldn't it be easier to just avoid this event?

A. Not if you take a long-term view of success. You can either hide from criticism or engage in dialogue that will move things forward. We can give specific examples of projects we've done in places like India and Senegal, in which we use communications technology to promote literacy and create jobs. And we can learn what other companies and governments have done. It makes no sense to keep relearning from scratch things that others learned before you.

Q. Do you think the much-publicized corporate scandals of this year will be a cloud over the American delegates' heads?

A. It will certainly come up, and I think it's important that we all address it. We can provide some reassurance to the world that we have internal mechanisms in place that will avoid the kind of alleged surprises that happened at Enron. After all, they have a real stake in this -- if your company is the source of jobs and taxes and it implodes, you're creating a huge economic issue.

Q. But aren't you afraid you will come across as the ugly Americans, shoving technology and methods at other cultures in the guise of charity, paying low wages, taking profits out and leaving a trail of pollution in your wake?

A. We've always been careful to enlist local governments and agencies and even companies as co-sponsors of any project we do. We never say, "This is our philanthropic solution." We say, "How can we use our talents and technology to jointly solve a problem?" For example, we recently provided Internet access to some remote villages in India that are two hours away from our nearest plant, but their local governments were eager participants in the project.
And while we certainly do not pay U.S. wage rates in developing countries, we do pay fair wages for those areas. There's an important line between exploiting and bringing in jobs and paying taxes. And we are all making progress on solving environmental problems.

Q. What emerging markets are particularly important to you right now?

A. India, China and Brazil are high on our list, both as places to make products and to sell them. They have lots of people, of course, and particularly in India and China, they have a real thirst for technology.

Q. Can the statements that often come out of a forum like this really do anything to benefit those countries or to help you build a business in them?

A. Stating goals and policies can be important in terms of setting targets to shoot at. And you make connections with people at forums like this, so that you can leverage everyone's expertise and really boost the impact that communications technology has on economic development.

HEADLINE: F.Y.I. 

BYLINE:  By ED BOLAND Jr.; E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com

 BODY:
 New York, D.C.?

Q. To show support for New York after Sept. 11, Congress is meeting here on Sept. 6 for the first time since 1790, but why did it leave New York in the first place?

A. When the first Congress met at Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan in August 1789, one of its first orders of business was to find a new location. Southern states did not like having their country's capital in what Thomas Jefferson, a Virginian, once called "a cloacina of all the depravities of human nature."
 As far as they were concerned, the city was too concerned with wealth, too immoral and too British. But New Yorkers liked having their city as the nation's capital and were in no rush to move it. One New Yorker, Alexander Hamilton, saw the schism as his opportunity.
Hamilton wanted the states' Revolutionary debts assumed by the almost-bankrupt Federal government, as a way to establish its credit. Northern states, heavily in debt, supported the idea, while the Southern states, whose debts were smaller, opposed it.
Jefferson and Hamilton made a deal: Jefferson would support the debt takeover and get Southern representatives to follow, if Hamilton agreed to move the capital south to some swampland being developed on the Potomac River, after a layover in Philadelphia while the city was being built.
On Aug. 12, 1790, Congress met in New York for the last time, and the move set the stage for something not seen in the European motherlands: a country with two capitals, one political and one cultural and economic.
Abigail Adams, wife of Vice President John Adams, might have seen this coming. When informed of the new location of the capital she noted, "When all is done it will not be Broadway."

Library Leos

Q. I know the lions outside the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue are named Patience and Fortitude, but how did they get those names?

A. Actually, the lions have no official names at all, but they have gone through a few nicknames since they first took up their perch when the main New York Public Library was opened in 1911. In the 1930's, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia christened the lions with their best-known nicknames, Patience and Fortitude. Those were the qualities, Mayor La Guardia believed, that would enable New Yorkers to survive the Great Depression.
The lions were sculptured by Edward Clark Potter and sit outside the library's main entrance, Patience on the south side and Fortitude to the north. When the library opened, the lions were called Leo Astor and Leo Lenox after two library founders, John Jacob Astor and James Lenox. Those names eventually became Lord Astor and Lady Lenox before La Guardia provided the nicknames that have lasted until this day.
So synonymous are the lions with the library that they their image is a registered trademark of the New York Public Library.

Life-Saving Initials

Q. I've seen sealed buildings in New York with "R.O." painted on them. What does this marking mean?

A. The letters stand for "roof open," according to a Fire Department spokesman, Capt. William VanWart, and they are there to let firefighters know if there are any holes in the building's roof that would allow smoke to escape. The letters usually accompany a painted box, which also tells firefighters the conditions of the floors in the buildings.
 ED BOLAND Jr.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Cost-Cutting Can Start A Ruinous Circle

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IN Alice in Wonderland fashion, we talk of expansion and ignore the contraction all around us. We convince ourselves that out of cost-cutting will come prosperity. But while cost-cutting can lift a single company or two, when practiced widely enough it can pull down an economy. And that is happening today.
 Few economists acknowledge this dynamic. Corporate cost-cutting and labor-saving layoffs appear in the forecasts as the golden road to greater productivity and rising profits. Never mind that we have just fired the workers and extinguished the salaries that would have been spent on the merchandise and services to fatten the profits. With sales revenue failing to rise, we cut costs more. The process feeds on itself -- until there are not enough workers and salaries left to generate sales and profits. 
 There is hyperbole in this description, but not much. As a nation, we are caught in the strangest and perhaps most perilous recovery since the Depression -- featuring a dynamic that William Dudley, chief domestic economist at Goldman Sachs, characterizes as "the corporate paradox of thrift."
"If everyone tries to cut costs and save more, no one saves more," he said. "If you and everyone else cut costs, costs do indeed go down, but revenue also goes down, so profits eventually go down, too. Collectively, we can't cut our way to prosperity."
Individual companies -- defending themselves, not the economy -- have good reason to throw themselves into this behavior. In one profit report after another this summer, the story has been the same: Sales revenue was flat or barely rose in the second quarter, but don't worry, profits were up. Cost-cutting and labor-saving efficiencies fattened the bottom line, and revenue will soon rise as lower costs allow us to cut prices and take sales away from competitors. 
That is fine, for a while, for the winning company. But consider what happens in an imaginary country where Burger King and McDonald's are the entire business sector and the total national output -- 100 hamburgers a day, evenly divided between the companies -- matches the demand from this nation's consumers. Demand and sales revenue, however, stay flat. So Burger King lays off two workers and uses the saved wages partly to fatten profits and partly to discount prices by just enough to take sales and revenue away from McDonald's. And McDonald's responds in kind. 
But soon, the four laid-off workers, with little income, buy fewer hamburgers, and the nation's total consumption drops to 95 hamburgers a day. That sets off another round of cost-cutting and price discounting, and our imaginary nation sinks gradually into stagnation or deep recession not unlike America in the 1930's. 
Why isn't that danger uppermost in everyone's mind? Why are forecasters like James Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, so optimistic? In a nutshell, they expect an infusion of demand from somewhere that will reverse the cost-cutting and persuade companies to expand investment, production and hiring. Their main hopes are more tax cuts, more growth in federal spending and more interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. They also count on people to finance consumption by continuing to extract equity from their homes, which are still rising in value.
Mainly, though, it is stimulus from Washington that for Mr. Glassman will save the day. "If Washington cannot get us moving toward full employment within a year," he said, "then there will be more federal stimulus. We have learned a lot since the Depression about how to fix the economy." 
BUT perhaps not enough. Perhaps we have become too accustomed to the other post-World War II recoveries, which were so different. There were no excesses to overcome from a stock market bubble and an insane rush by business to expand far beyond demand. Instead, when consumption rose, there was shortage and rising prices. To control inflation, the Fed pushed up interest rates. In response, consumption subsided, provoking a recession -- until rates came down and pent-up demand reasserted itself. Business stepped up investment to keep output abreast of demand, and recovery was on its way.
In the current cycle, however, consumption -- particularly for cars, housing and appliances -- never tapered off from very high levels during the nine-month recession that started in January of last year. It has still not tapered off, but it is not rising, either, and that is a problem. Recovery requires increased consumption and business investment to make the economy grow. The danger today is that demand will decline instead, and recession will return -- or there will be prolonged stagnation. Unfortunately, Mr. Dudley's "corporate paradox of thrift" is pushing hard in that direction.

HEADLINE: The F-Cars, From A to Z28 

BYLINE:  By NORMAN S. MAYERSOHN

 BODY:
 HERE are highlights in the development of General Motors' F-body pony cars:

APRIL 17, 1964 -- Lee A. Iacocca, general manager of the Ford Division, introduces a small sporty car built largely with parts from the Falcon compact. "Mustang fever" grips the nation as a new automotive category, dubbed the pony car, is born. More than 400,000 Mustangs are sold within 12 months.

SEPT. 26, 1966 -- Chevrolet's answer to the Mustang, the Camaro, is introduced with a base price of $2,466.

FEB. 23, 1967 -- The Firebird, developed under John Z. DeLorean, Pontiac's general manager, goes on sale.

1968 -- A Camaro driven by Mark Donohue wins the Sports Car Club of America's Trans-Am championship.

1969 -- Chevrolet builds a short run of Camaros with aluminum-block 427 engines, but the $4,160 ZL-1 option more than doubles the car's price. Only 69 are built.

1969 -- The Firebird Trans Am makes its debut. Figuring on a limited appeal, Pontiac agrees to pay the S.C.C.A. $5 a car for rights to the name, a decision that ends up costing millions of dollars.

FEBRUARY 1970 -- The second generation of the F-cars comes to market. A legend is born when the Camaro Z28 is fitted with the 360-horsepower LT-1 engine.

1972 -- A 117-day strike strands 1,100 partly assembled vehicles at a plant in Ohio. The cars are unable to meet bumper regulations that took effect during the shutdown, and all are scrapped.

1973 -- After much internal debate, an eye-catching graphic spreads its wings across the Trans Am's hood. It quickly becomes known as the Thunder Chicken.

1974 -- The Camaro Z28, emasculated by emissions controls, is dropped.

1977-83 -- Popular Burt Reynolds movies showcase the Firebird, including "Hooper" and the "Smokey and the Bandit" series. Sales soar with each sequel.

1977 -- The Camaro Z28 returns, albeit with a dishrag rating of 185 horsepower.

1978 -- T-tops -- roofs with removable glass panels -- endear the F-cars to the "Saturday Night Fever" set.

1979 -- Combined Camaro and Firebird sales set a record: 494,025.

1980 -- "Rockford Files" ends its six-year NBC run. James Garner played a private eye; a gold Firebird was his sidekick.

1982 -- The F-cars are redesigned, and reach a performance nadir. A four-cylinder engine is offered for the first time, with just 90 -- count 'em -- horsepower.

1985 -- A deal to supply cars for the International Race of Champions series results in the IROC-Z Camaro package.

1987 -- KITT, bionic Firebird of "Knight Rider," is parked after five years of flexing its Super Pursuit Mode and Passive Laser Restraint System on TV.

1993 -- Fourth-generation F-cars arrive. Production shifts to Ste. Therese, Quebec.

1996 -- Performance options raise power levels past the 300 mark (on the Camaro SS and Firebird WS6 Ram Air) for the first time since the early 1970's.

1998 -- The Corvette's all-aluminum LS-1 engine makes its debut in the F-cars.

AUG. 28, 2002 -- The last of the Camaros and Firebirds are to roll off the line as G.M. puts the cars "on hiatus." The 325-horsepower finale delivers the performance of the early days but with respectable fuel economy of up to 28 m.p.g.
