HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
College Football's Catch-22

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
BIG-TIME college football is the last frontier of colonial-style race relations, where African-American athletes supply the labor but rarely get control.
 This is not a new story; in fact, it's a dreadfully old and tired story. 
 In September 1970, the University of Southern California played the University of Alabama in Birmingham. The crux of the story surrounding the game is how Alabama's crushing defeat helped accelerate athletics integration in the South. Thirty-two seasons after that game, the S.E.C. is represented by a phenomenal black presence on the playing field. Yet no university in the conference has hired an African-American head football coach. 
The S.E.C. is a symbol for a nationwide travesty: African-Americans can block and tackle and run and jump across our screens every Saturday afternoon, but they cannot become head coaches and athletic directors.
This season, only 4 of the 117 Division I-A coaches are black while about half of their scholarship football players are black. The percentage of black players is remarkably higher when you look only at the starting offensive and defensive units.
The colleges that field these semipro teams should look at the lack of black head football coaches as an educational issue; the enterprise is a public symbol of a great failure. For the last 25 years, top universities have turned out thousands of African-American football players. Yet in that same 25 years barely a handful of them have managed to become head football coaches or athletic directors. Black athletes play and leave while many of their white teammates are put on the coaching and administration track. 
Mike Slive, who became the S.E.C. commissioner this summer, has made hiring African-American head football coaches one of the priorities of the conference. He has had his staff compile a data bank of African-American N.F.L. assistant coaches.
"There's a lot to do, and I just started this job," he said. "But you've got to start somewhere."
The long-languishing Black Coaches Association took a first step toward applying pressure on Friday when it met in Lincoln, Neb., to discuss hiring. The objective was to help aspiring African-American head coaches crack the code of big-time college football: to provide knowledge, accountability and political and economic strategies to bring about change.
Why is football such a bastion of resistance? Floyd Keith, the executive director of the B.C.A., has a theory. Football is the primary source of income for most athletic departments. Coaches are expected to generate interest and revenue through winning, through fund-raising, schmoozing with boosters and speaking at alumni functions. Fund-raising is the foundation of college football, and athletic directors want to have coaches whom boosters feel comfortable with, he said. 
Hiring blacks became good business in basketball after programs like Georgetown, Temple and U.S.C. became successful with black coaches. "This is a big business and the color that matters most is green," Keith said. "As of now, presidents have not seen that hiring black head football coaches is good business."
Notre Dame's hiring of Tyrone Willingham, even though he was the second choice, was seen as good business. Chris Leak, one of the nation's top recruits, will be making his first official visit to Notre Dame, precisely because Willingham is the coach.
What is more phenomenal than the persistence of the low number of African-American coaches is the mentality of parents and guardians who continue to send their children to these schools.
I like the Kellen Winslow model. Winslow, a tight end, played at the University of Missouri in the late 70's, then enjoyed a splendid professional career with the San Diego Chargers. Winslow was inducted into Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1995. When his son, Kellen Jr., also a tight end, became one of the nation's most highly recruited players in 2000, Winslow decided that he would treat Kellen Jr. the way recruiters treated him: as a valuable natural resource. Winslow set conditions for his son's recruitment -- he would not consider a college that did not have an African-American assistant coach, and would seriously look at colleges with black head coaches. Michigan State, whose head coach, Bobby Williams, is African-American, was in Winslow's top three. 
Winslow discouraged his son from selecting the University of Washington because he felt Rick Neuheisel and his staff attempted to go around the father during the recruiting process. Winslow, a college football analyst with Fox, canceled a visit that had been made without his knowledge or permission. Kellen Jr. ultimately chose the University of Miami and was on Miami's national championship team last season. The Hurricanes' defensive coordinator, Randy Shannon, is African-American.
The B.C.A.'s challenge will be to get an economically and politically diverse black community excited about the issue of controlling its most precious commodity: black muscle.
In the 1950's and 60's, economic boycotts of selected businesses broke down segregation in the South and forced businesses in the North to hire black workers. The campaign slogan was, "Don't Buy Where You Can't Work."
Beginning this recruiting season, the motto for high school football recruits and their parents should be: Don't play where you can't coach.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tyrone Willingham, Notre Dame's coach. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Colombia Counters Rebels With Troops and Music 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: PATILLAL, Colombia, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
The music has returned to this picturesque town where the kidnapping and killing of a tireless promoter of the local folk music by rebels last September shocked the country.
 Patillal (pronounced pah-tee-YAL) and several other communities in this lawless region of northwest Colombia, sandwiched between two towering mountain ranges, are part of a government pilot program aimed at establishing order and rooting out leftist guerrillas. 
 Residents here have long been accustomed to kidnappings on the roads, to extortion demands on farm owners and rebel attacks against isolated police stations. 
Though common across the country, such violence is especially troubling here because major roads connecting the coast to Bogota, the capital, pass through this stark region. 
But just two weeks after Alvaro Uribe was inaugurated president, army patrols have returned and a police station is being planned to replace one destroyed by rebel guerrillas. A network of 1,100 civilian informants, who provide information on rebel movements to state security forces, has also been formed here in Cesar Province.
"The kidnapping rate by the guerrillas is very high, so the idea was to go into that zone before other zones," said Alfredo Rangel, a military expert in Bogota who is a consultant for the army. "It is an area crucial for the national economy."
Even before the kidnapping from a local road of Consuelo Araujo, a former culture minister and the promoter of the accordion-driven vallenato music, Colombia's decades-old civil conflict had driven out weekend homeowners and the folk musicians who made the region famous.
On a recent night, however, the musicians settled under a mango tree and played their ballads as if all were well here. Soon a crowd formed, clapping, singing along and drinking chirinchi, the local brew. 
It was the first time in months that musicians had spontaneously begun playing, though that had once been common in this town, known as the "cradle of the maestros." 
"For more than a year, we have not seen this in town," said one singer, Camal Mohales, 54, a lifelong resident of Patillal. "But now that the armed forces are back, we feel hopeful because the security has returned."
Mr. Uribe, who has strong American support for his aggressive effort to combat the rebels, has promised to replicate what is being done here nationwide. By decree, his government has already announced a new, one-time tax on assets worth at least $60,000 to collect $800 million to pay for training thousands of troops and police officers and to pay for the growing network of informers. The goal, in time, is to double the size of the security forces and to station police officers in 163 municipalities -- one of every seven in the country -- that have no police presence.
On Aug. 8, the day after Mr. Uribe was inaugurated in a ceremony marred by a rebel mortar attack in Bogota, the new president showed his resolve by visiting here to assess how plans were proceeding for the informants' network. 
The plan, which calls for civilians to be recruited and paid for offering information on the activities of armed groups, had begun taking shape in the weeks after Mr. Uribe won the election in May.
Earlier this week, he and other officials returned, and were informed by the army as well as local officials that road traffic had increased 43 percent in Cesar because of the informants and the increased security patrols.
Defense Minister Martha Lucia Ramirez, pleased with the report, said, "We are going to work so the public forces are present in all the national territory." 
It will not be easy. Analysts of Colombia's conflict, now in its 38th year, contend that Mr. Uribe lacks the resources or the manpower to bring about substantive changes to a country where wide swaths of territory are under the influence of leftist rebels or the right-wing paramilitary groups that have formed to fight them in some areas.
Some critics also believe that Mr. Uribe's plans -- among them a new proposal to recruit up to an additional 20,000 young peasants to create a military presence in their hometowns -- could lead to abuses or put people in harm's way.
Analysts also say that re-establishing a police presence in regions under rebel influence could take years and, even then, could fail because of the overwhelming strength of the guerrillas in some regions. Even here, where the news has been good, the roads remain dangerous, as evidenced by today's rebel kidnapping of a farmer.
"Even if you reopen the police stations, keeping them open is quite another challenge," said Adam Isacson, who analyzes Colombia's military for the Center for International Policy, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
But here, where people had been so tired of violence and lawlessness for so long, any action by the government is warmly welcomed.
"Uribe's plans have had excellent results," said Elias Ochoa, mayor of Valledupar, the provincial capital.
Indeed, in addition to the increased traffic, there have been other tangible results, local military officials said. On Tuesday, an anonymous caller reported some suspicious men lingering near a bridge. The army arrived, found four rebels placing dynamite under the structure and began firing. One rebel was killed, and the others fled.
"It all began with a call from someone who saw something suspicious," said Lt. Col. Hernan Mejia, commander of the local battalion.
One local informer, a man in his 30's code-named K-003, said he had decided to take part in Mr. Uribe's force because he was tired of the rebel presence in his hometown. 
The man, a farm worker, oversees a group of five other informers, and regularly reports rebel activities to his employer, who then contacts the army. Since he is considered a "control agent," overseeing others, he will in time be paid about $75 a week for his work, with more coming for useful information.
"It is dangerous, but I feel confident," the man said. "It is not the same fright I used to feel before, though. I feel like we are all collaborating." 
Local people who are closely following Mr. Uribe's proposals are perhaps most interested in seeing a positive outcome here in Patillal, a town that is symbolic because of its music and traditions.
Some of the greatest vallenato composers, household names like Rafael Escalona and Freddy Molina, were born here. Valledupar's middle classes had, before the conflict spiraled out of control, built weekend homes here.
"This is the place that has made the province important," said the local prefect, Elvis Diaz, 32. "Now, the town is quite happy. People have stood up to say, 'Let us take back the town.' It is like going back 20 years, when things were peaceful."

HEADLINE: To Be Hamlet (but Still Keep the Day Job) 

BYLINE:  By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
For years, Tim Martin, an executive at an antique-silver shop on East 57th Street, has dreamed about playing Hamlet. The desire came from a long run of theatergoing.
 Many of the plays were Off Off Broadway, many of them by Shakespeare, and he and his friend Dave Eisenbach would repeatedly leave a theater and agree that they could have done it better. Mr. Martin hoped to play Hamlet by the time he was 30, and it looks as if he will be only two years late. 
 Beginning Sept. 4, for five performances, he will star as Hamlet in a theater not far from Broadway. 
How did he do it? 
First, to cast the play, he placed an ad in Back Stage -- offering actors "possible pay." To his astonishment, more than 300 people replied, and he interviewed 160, many of them with acting credits and with far more experience than the man playing Hamlet. An octogenarian former baseball player auditioned for the role of Claudius and, without encouragement from Hamlet, a potential Ophelia stripped to her underwear before speaking her lines.
From the applicants, Mr. Martin gathered and rehearsed a cast of eager players, almost all professional actors with day jobs like office receptionist or waiter. Gertrude works at J. P. Morgan. The Player King is a computer consultant; the Gravedigger is a tailor; and Polonius is a professor of Shakespeare.
The response caused Mr. Martin to reflect: "You sit on the subway, and so many people look drab on a winter's day. They're going to their jobs, but for all you know, at night they're in a play or they're dancers. Everybody talks about how people in New York are obsessed with money and glory, and here's a massive group of people who answer an ad."
Mr. Martin is the producer and the show's sole backer -- for $7,500: an amount, he suggested, that he might have spent on a long summer vacation. He is also co-director with Mr. Eisenbach, who is playing Horatio. Another friend, Teige Carroll, is playing the Ghost.
From the beginning, he and Mr. Eisenbach hoped that the production might rise to the level of "pretty good," but they knew that "awful" was always a prospect. Even as rehearsals proceeded, Mr. Martin would make only one claim. Thinking of himself, at 6-foot-3, and his 6-foot-8-inch Ghost, among others, he said, "I've probably got the tallest cast ever assembled for a 'Hamlet.' "
Less than two weeks from his debut, Mr. Martin is of two minds. "It's fabulous," he said. "I hope people will come and get some pleasure out of it." Then he added, "In your imagination, you can do it much better than you can with your actual body."
Mr. Martin has not acted since college, but finally, prodded by Mr. Eisenbach, who is a Ph.D. candidate in American history at Columbia, he decided to go ahead with the project. He rented the Producers' Club II, an Off Off Broadway theater on Ninth Avenue between 43rd and 44th Streets, and drafted a budget. The initial outlay of $6,000 turned out to be less than what was needed.
The next step was casting. The ad in Back Stage read: "THM Productions will hold auditions for 'Hamlet' . . . Bring pix & resume, and prepare a speech and a Shakespeare sonnet, with a maximum length of five minutes. Callbacks will be next week. N.B.: Hamlet, the Ghost and Horatio are precast. Possible pay."
At first, he said, he thought they might have a complete "Hamlet" cast, but he soon became more practical. With some actors playing more than one role, the number needed shrinks to 14, so excluding those places reserved for Hamlet, Horatio and the Ghost, 11 actors were chosen.
He has taken as a role model Kenneth Branagh, an actor he greatly admires. In the early 1990's, Mr. Martin lined up at 4 a.m. to buy tickets to see him play Hamlet for the Royal Shakespeare Company, and thinks it was the finest Hamlet he has seen. (Of course, before Mr. Branagh did "Hamlet," he studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, and at 23 played Henry V.) 
On the positive side, Mr. Martin has never worried about learning his lines. "I always had a good memory, particularly for words," he said. "But I can't remember things that happen. That's a problem that many of my ex-girlfriends pointed out: 'You can remember all of "Hamlet," but you can't remember when we went to Italy for two weeks.' "
In June, he held auditions followed by callbacks, welcoming actors to his Gramercy Park apartment. One evening before the actors arrived, the floor of his living room was covered with head shots (with credits on the backs), as he and Mr. Eisenbach tried to decide which applicants to choose. First to read was an actor whom they had liked in an Off Off Broadway production of "Measure for Measure." On the basis of his reading, he might have had the role of Claudius, but later called to say he had accepted a different offer.
Next an actor came in to read for Polonius. "How do you want me to do it?" he asked, and added, "Do you want me to age?" After delivering a speech, he suggested, "I can do it differently." He seemed as amenable as Dustin Hoffman playing an unemployed actor auditioning in "Tootsie" ("I can be taller. I can be shorter. I can be different.") Polonius was followed by a breathless Ophelia and a Gertrude who seemed better suited to "Funny Girl." None of the three were offered parts.
Ophelia was one of the most difficult roles to cast. About 80 actresses auditioned, including one who besieged Mr. Martin with late-night calls and at her audition stripped to her underwear and did a monologue from "The Misanthrope." Frances Chewning, the actress who got the part, is the opposite. Mr. Martin said, "She is amazingly delicate, tall and thin with incredibly translucent skin, sort of like a Memling painting."
Several actors are members of Actors' Equity, some studied theater in graduate school and many have already done Shakespeare. Mr. Martin, a Columbia graduate and a student of Shakespeare, works for his stepfather, Eric Shrubsole, at S. J. Shrubsole, a leading silver dealer. His father, Dwight Martin, was an editor and writer at Newsweek.
Mr. Martin made it clear to the actors that he could pay only carfare. Because this is an Equity showcase production, tickets are held to $15. In a 99-seat house there can be no profit, but he said he might pass the hat and split the take among the actors. 
While meeting his actors, Mr. Martin faced his first crisis. He lost his Claudius. The problem began with the pronunciation of a line, "Colleagued with this dream of his advantage." Mr. Martin said the word should be pronounced in three syllables -- col-LEAGUE-ed, -- but the actor insisted that the accent was on the first of two syllables (COL-leagued). For proof, Mr. Martin deferred to various editions of the play and recordings of "Hamlet," one with John Gielgud. The actor acceded to the direction, but the next day called to say he was quitting to do "Jekyll and Hyde" in Rhode Island.
After Mr. Martin took out another ad in Back Stage, 15 prospective Claudiuses showed up, including an elderly man who said he had once played baseball for the New York Giants. He did Hamlet's soliloquy "O! What a rogue and peasant slave am I," and was, Mr. Martin said, "Absolutely fabulous." Boldly, the actor asked, "Do you think I'm going to get the part?" Mr. Martin replied that the audition was good, but that "you may be a little old." 
"How old do you think I am?" came the reply. "You must be 70, and Gertrude is pretty young." The actor said, proudly, "I'm 83," flexing his muscle to demonstrate his fitness. A younger actor was hired, and he read that crucial line correctly.
From the beginning, Mr. Martin made it clear that he planned a bare-bones production with minimal scenery, and with costumes suggested by the actors. The focus would be on the text. As host in his apartment, he made dinner, or rather, "slapped together whatever was in the fridge." Actors often discreetly announced, "I ate before I came here."
Rehearsals began this month in a Lower East Side studio, cheek by jowl with productions in the New York Fringe Festival. On a recent evening, the actors prepared to go through Act III. Everyone was ready. But where was the Player King? Hamlet got on his cellphone and learned that he was tied up with an emergency at Goldman Sachs. Another actor filled in.
A room in the castle. Enter King, Queen, Polonius, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. Then, Enter Hamlet with "To be, or not to be." Mr. Martin knew his lines but seemed to rush them. Soon he turned to Ophelia and said, "Get thee to a nunnery!" Then came the Dumb Show. The actor playing the Player Queen adjusted his long black wig, but the hair kept falling in his eyes.
Scene IV. The Queen's Closet. Gertrude forgot a line. The Ghost, sitting at a table waiting his turn, prompted her. On cue, Hamlet stabbed Polonius. The scene ended, with all lines accounted for. Mr. Eisenbach gave notes to the actors, beginning with Polonius, who took exception to the direction. The others were more receptive. Hamlet, in proper fashion, was highly self-critical. The conversation became a colloquy, with everyone participating. Then, it was back to the boards as rehearsals, and the learning process, continued.
Although Mr. Martin has the look of a leading man and has a clear, cultivated voice, he has no illusions -- well, maybe a few -- about being discovered and becoming an actor. He is not about to leave his day job. 
Before he started "Hamlet," Mr. Martin raised the question, "Am I being presumptuous?" The answer: Well, you're not doing "King Lear" -- yet. But if "Hamlet" works, he already has his eyes on "Julius Caesar" next summer. He wants to play Cassius, a second step for this lean and hungry Hamlet.

HEADLINE: In Race to Tap the Euphrates, The Upper Hand Is Upstream 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TELL AL-SAMEN, Syria 

 BODY:
The Euphrates River is close by, but the water does not reach Abdelrazak al-Aween. Here at the heart of the fertile crescent, he stares at dry fields.
 The Syrian government has promised water for Mr. Aween's tiny village. But upstream, in Turkey, and downstream, in Iraq, similar promises are being made. They add up to more water than the Euphrates holds. 
 So instead of irrigating his cotton and sugar beets, Mr. Aween must siphon drinking and washing water from a ditch 40 minutes away by tractor ride. Just across the border, meanwhile, Ahmet Demir, a Turkish farmer, stands ankle deep in mud, his crops soaking up all the water they need. 
It was here in ancient Mesopotamia, thousands of years ago, that the last all-out war over water was fought, between rival city-states in what is now southern Iraq. Now, across a widening swath of the world, more and more people are vying for less and less water, in conflicts more rancorous by the day.
From the searing plains of Mesopotamia to the steadily expanding deserts of northern China to the cotton fields of northwest Texas, the struggle for water is igniting social, economic and political tensions. 
The World Bank has said dwindling water supplies will be a major factor inhibiting economic growth, a subject being discussed at a weeklong international conference in South Africa starting Monday about balancing use of the world's resources against its economic needs.
Global warming, some experts suspect, may be adding to the strain. Droughts may be extended in already dry regions, including parts of the United States, even as wetter areas tend toward calamitous downpours and floods like those ravaging Europe and Asia this summer. In general, the world's climate may be more prone to extremes, with too much water in some areas and far too little in others.
Both the United Nations and the National Intelligence Council, an advisory group to the Central Intelligence Agency, have warned that the competition for water is likely to worsen. "As countries press against the limits of available water between now and 2015, the possibility of conflict will increase," the National Intelligence Council warned in a report last year.
By 2015, according to estimates from the United Nations and the United States government, at least 40 percent of the world's population, or about three billion people, will live in countries where it is difficult or impossible to get enough water to satisfy basic needs.
"The signs of unsustainability are widespread and spreading," said Sandra Postel, director of the Global Water Policy Project in Amherst, Mass. "If we're to have any hope of satisfying the food and water needs of the world's people in the years ahead, we will need a fundamental shift in how we use and manage water." 
An inescapable fact about the world's water supply is that it is finite. Less than 1 percent of it is fresh water that can be used for drinking or agriculture, and demand for that water is rising. 
Over the last 70 years, the world's population has tripled while water demand has increased sixfold, causing increasing strain especially in heavily populated areas where water is distant, is being depleted or is simply too polluted to use. 
Already, a little more than half of the world's available fresh water is being used each year, according to one rough but generally accepted estimate. That fraction could climb to 74 percent by 2025 based on population growth alone, and would hit 90 percent if people everywhere used as much water as the average American, one of the world's most gluttonous water consumers.
Water tables are falling on every continent, and experts warn that the situation is expected to worsen significantly in years to come. On top of the shortages that already exist, the outlook adds to the tensions and uncertainty for countries that share water sources, like Turkey and Syria, where Mr. Aween is among those still waiting and hoping for the Euphrates to be brought to his door.

A Few Miles' Difference
The stories of Mr. Aween and Mr. Demir illustrate how the growing fight for water can make or ruin lives.
Until last year, Mr. Demir, 42, a father of nine in Turkey, was living an itinerant life as a smuggler and a migrant laborer. But on a recent scorching afternoon, he stood sunburned and content, his striped pants rolled above his knees, bare feet squishing in Euphrates mud.
"It seems like we have all the water we need," Mr. Demir said, leaning on his shovel and running a hand through his close-cropped hair. What has changed in this swath of southern Turkey is the arrival of irrigation. It is part of one of the world's largest water projects, an audacious $30 billion plan by Turkey's government to spread the Euphrates' gifts across a vast and impoverished region of the country. 
By now, Mr. Aween, the Syrian, might have been celebrating, too. Under Syria's irrigation plan, ambitious in its own right, water from the Euphrates should have reached Mr. Aween's door, less than 50 miles from Mr. Demir's.
But strong doubts are emerging about whether the vast scope of Turkey's project will leave enough water for its neighbors downstream -- so much so that Syria appears to have put the brakes on its development plan.
"We're still waiting," Mr. Aween, 40, said on behalf of his 2 wives, 3 children, and 17 brothers and sisters, who all live in a hamlet that bears the family name. He wore a loose, Arab-style outer garment and cheap plastic sandals as he hitched a rusty tanker trailer to a sputtering tractor, his water bearers. "But the water hasn't come."
The trouble over the Euphrates can be expressed in a simple, untenable equation. 
As best as anyone can determine, the river, in an average year, holds 35 billion cubic meters of water. But the separate plans drawn up by Turkey, Syria and Iraq for building dams and irrigating fields would, taken together, consume nearly half again more water than the river holds.
Each country has acknowledged the impossibility of marrying their schemes. But none has shown any willingness to scale back. Trying to accommodate fast-growing populations and to head off a migration to the cities, each country is still clinging to its irrigation dreams.
On both sides of the Turkish-Syrian border, snapshots of those dreams still unfold on summer dawns, in fields that used to be good for little but grazing, but where new irrigation canals are now delivering Euphrates water in regular supply. 
Thirsty crops like cotton and sugar beets have begun to thrive. Farm incomes have tripled. Young women who turn out in sparkling dresses tend prized plants with special care, shepherding the water down each muddy row. Young boys cavort in irrigation ditches that provide relief from the intense midday heat.
Now that there is water, Mr. Demir said, it would not be such a bad thing if his four sons, ranging in age from 4 months to 22 years, decided to stay and work the land -- something he could not have imagined only a year ago when farming was far harder. 
But in a world in which so much depends on having water, he bristled at the idea of sharing it. "If I used any less, the others would use more," he said. "I use what I need, and as for the rest, it's their business."
That kind of thinking has not helped Mr. Aween's village, not far from Tell al-Samen, where the absence of water is almost equally on display. With his family, Mr. Aween raises scraggly goats and grows whatever barley and wheat he can coax from dry, unirrigated land. It is a far cry, he said, from the lush green crops he would grow with irrigation -- the difference between sustenance and comfort.
Syria and Turkey have been at odds since the late 1980's, when Turkey decided to proceed with its development project without consulting its neighbors.
To Turkey, the plan was an essential step in the country's development, a means of transforming an area that is home to six million people, including many restive Kurds, into a zone of greater economic and political stability. But to Syria, which depends on the Euphrates for half its fresh water, it continues to be seen as a major threat. Iraq, the far downstream neighbor, has been mostly a bystander because of its international isolation. 
The basic disputes between Turkey and Syria -- over water rights and allocations -- would be familiar to any landowner who has struggled over competing claims to a stream or a well. But the fact that the parties are nations, with large armies at their disposal and large populations at stake, has added to the weight of the clash.
Less powerful militarily than Turkey, Syria resorted through much of the 1990's to indirect pressure, by giving support to the terrorist leader Abdullah Ocalan, the No. 1 enemy of the Turkish government. In response, Turkish officials sometimes went so far as to warn that the flow of the Euphrates into Syria could be cut.
Such talk has cooled in the last three years since the arrest of Mr. Ocalan. But the potential for trouble lingers. 
Over the last year, as Turkey has completed many dams and has begun to extend its irrigation, the flow of Euphrates water into Syria has grown consistently smaller. The flow has fallen below levels allowed under Turkey's only existing commitment to Syria, an interim 1987 agreement intended for the period of dam construction.
Turkey has blamed drought and the overuse of the new, cheap water by farmers for the shortfall. The government says much of that can be reversed. But Turkish officials have also said they no longer see the 1987 deal as binding. The trend has raised deep concerns in Syria, which is already facing water shortages in Damascus, the capital.
Both countries say they are ready to strike a deal, but cannot imagine scaling back their development plans. "For half of Syria, the Euphrates is life," said Abdel Aziz al-Masri, a top official at Syria's Ministry of Irrigation.
Mumtaz Turfan, the director of Turkey's department of hydraulic works, echoed the sentiment. "Without our dams, life in Turkey would be impossible," he said.

Rising Tension, Dwindling Water
It has been a decade since Syria, Turkey and Iraq sat down to formal negotiations, and their positions remain as starkly opposed now as they were then.
Syria and Iraq want the water to be divided roughly in thirds. Turkey, on the other hand, claims more than half for itself. It says any sharing must take into account Turkey's status as the source of most Euphrates water and the home to a population that is half again as big as Iraq's and Syria's put together.
"I am sure that if we forget about borders, we can solve the problem," Mr. Turfan said. Over the last 30 years, he has presided over the construction of 700 dams in Turkey, and a map that stretches across his wall details plans for 500 more.
"I am providing water for 22 million people who take drinking water from our dams, and for 35 percent of our agriculture," he said. It would be a mistake, he suggested, for Turkey to accept less than the lion's share of the Euphrates. "Without irrigation, we can't do anything," he said. "We can't give it up and destroy our people."
Around the world, the question of water ownership has never seemed so divisive.
Despite efforts by the United Nations and others, the world has yet to come up with an accepted formula on how shared waters should be divided. That situation applies to nearly 300 rivers, including the Nile, the Danube, the Colorado and the Rio Grande, all subject to major disputes.
In 1997, a United Nations convention declared that international waterways should be divided reasonably and equitably, without causing unnecessary harm. But Turkey, along with China and Burundi, refused to sign the agreement, a sign of reluctance on the part of major upstream countries to cede their dominant positions.
Beyond current water shortages, one reason for the tension is a lack of optimism that pressures on the world's water supply might be eased.
Of course, some new technologies, including advanced irrigation techniques, innovative desalination methods and bold water-moving schemes, offer some hope.
But experts say the task of making fresh water available where there is none -- from seawater, from icebergs or by moving surface water long distances -- remains too costly to be widely adopted. Most easily accessible fresh water sources have already been tapped.
To those who would bend nature, there are many cautionary tales, including the Soviet-orchestrated drying up of the Aral Sea, an environmental catastrophe. Even for its project on the Euphrates, Turkey could not win World Bank support because of the plan's significant costs, including the submerging of an important archaeological site.
But sometimes, as in Turkey's case, the thirst for water is greater than any such opposition. Along the Euphrates, Turkey is paying its own way, despite the financial hardship and despite the uncertainty over how its plans will affect others.
In the dry heat of a Mesopotamian summer, how that tenacity is regarded depends on which way the water is flowing. 
In an office in Al Raqqa, a Syrian city on the banks of the Euphrates, Iliaz Dakal, a consultant to Syria's land development agency, was studying a map of his own. It depicted, in vivid green, the land that Syria is already irrigating along the river. Much more land, though, like the fields that are home to Mr. Aween, was crosshatched to show uncertainty -- its water and its fate now perhaps in Turkey's hands.
"For now, thank God, we have enough to grow the wheat we need," Mr. Dakal said. "But what about the future?"
Mr. Demir, in his muddy Turkish field, had an answer, saying he had come to see water as a byproduct of power.
"If Turkey is stronger," he said, "then I get to keep my water."

HEADLINE: Facing Death, Founder Fights for Labor Party's Life 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
Tony Mazzocchi, the driving force behind the nation's fledgling Labor Party, shocked thousands of the party's members when he recently wrote to them, "I am both afflicted with an incurable disease and blessed with an incurable optimism."
 Mr. Mazzocchi, 76, has pancreatic cancer, and although his doctors give him only a few weeks or maybe a few months to live, he continues to battle relentlessly in pursuit of his dream -- building a Labor Party that will someday move to center stage in American politics. 
 Gaunt from losing 25 pounds this year, he seems especially rueful that his health is failing at what he sees as an opportune time to reassert workers' interests and to hack away at corporate power. "For the first time in 20 years, corporate America is losing legitimacy," he wrote last month to party members, pointing to the Enron and WorldCom debacles. "It is cracking under the weight of its own greed. No longer can it play the goose that lays the golden eggs." 
The Labor Party has three main issues: single-payer national health insurance, as in Canada; free tuition for all college and graduate students at public colleges and universities; and labor law changes to make it easier for workers to join unions without employer intimidation. Mr. Mazzocchi complained that it was extremely difficult to unionize workers because trying to do so caused many employers to threaten to close their plants or move overseas.
Many political analysts say the Labor Party's program is unrealistic, exemplifying the sort of big-government approach that even Democrats long ago disowned. The party's proposals, they say, might be embraced in Europe, with its social democratic traditions, but are not likely to get far in the United States, with its emphasis on shrinking government and cutting spending.
The Labor Party has even come under heavy fire from some labor leaders, who say it is undermining the Democratic Party, which they see as the best vehicle to help workers. Conservatives denounce the Labor Party as a crude advocate of class warfare and soaking the rich.
But Mr. Mazzocchi (pronounced muh-ZOCK-key) insists that the party's wish list is not pie in the sky. He says one of the party's mottoes could be "Steal Our Program." 
"We're concentrating on issues that resonate," he said. "Right now the cost of tuition is so prohibitive, even at many state universities, that it's hurting many working-class students. Tuition for all these folks is $23 billion. That's nothing."
Although he dropped out of school in ninth grade, Mr. Mazzocchi is a seminal thinker and strategist for what remains of the American left. He spends his days, often in pain, at his modest town house here, where the second floor has been turned into a Labor Party office. 
Several unusual accomplishments have helped build his reputation. In 1954, as president of a union local at a Helena Rubenstein cosmetics factory on Long Island, he was one of the first labor leaders to win dental benefits. From the 1950's through the 1970's, he did more than any other union leader to forge ties with environmentalists and scientists while working on such issues as fighting nuclear testing and identifying toxic chemicals that endangered factory workers and residents nearby. 
In 1970, as legislative director of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union, he played a crucial role in securing passage of the Occupational Safety and Health Act, which is often called the most important pro-worker legislation of the last 50 years. 
"What's incredible," Mr. Mazzocchi said, "was the guy who was president then was Richard Nixon, which shows that when you build a big movement from down below, regardless of who's in the White House, you can bring about change."
In 1974, Mr. Mazzocchi was the union's main adviser to Karen Silkwood, an atomic plant worker from Oklahoma, before she died in a mysterious car accident while driving to meet a journalist to publicize safety problems at her plant.
When he speaks, Mr. Mazzocchi often uses the us-against-them, class-tinged speech of the 1930's. In his view, the main issues facing workers have changed little since then: they keep getting squeezed while corporations grow more powerful, and the gap between the rich and everybody else keeps growing. 
"Workers are worried today," he said. "They see decent-paying jobs fleeing overseas. They see that they will get the raw end of the stick whenever it comes to corporate restructuring. They understand instinctively and more than ever before that when the economy goes downhill, corporations don't care about their well-being."
Mr. Mazzocchi's childhood in Brooklyn shaped his politics. His father, a unionized worker at a suit factory, lost the family's home because of steep medical bills for his wife, who died of cancer when Mr. Mazzocchi was 6.
Mr. Mazzocchi founded the Labor Party in 1996 at a convention in Cleveland because he was convinced that corporate interests and wealthy donors dominated the Democratic and Republican parties. 
He does not see the party, at least now, electing candidates to office. Rather, he said, its focus should be pushing worker-friendly issues into the nation's discourse.
Asserting that Mr. Mazzocchi and his party have an obsolete leftist vision, many critics say it is not surprising that the party has grown slowly and gained little traction.
Mr. Mazzocchi acknowledges that the party has grown more slowly than he had hoped and has tailed off some from the 14,000 members it had four years ago. One reason, he said, is that his illness has sidelined him -- the party's main spokesman and booster. He has concentrated lately on signing up union locals rather than individual members, and has helped persuade 350 union locals to pay affiliation fees to show their support. If the party had more money, he said, it could easily double or triple the number of unions.
"When I get into a union hall and I'm able to talk to the members, our message resonates," he said. "American workers aren't going to sit still if things continue to come apart. If you look at the history of American workers, you'd think they're in a sleepy lagoon, and then all of a sudden there is an explosion."

HEADLINE: A Group That Makes Networking Its Business 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Not long ago, Louise Wise Services, the big foster care agency, leased space at 55 West 125th Street (now better known as Bill Clinton's building). The agency chose Lara Hullinghorst, an information technology expert, to oversee the high-tech aspects of the move. Ms. Hullinghorst, in turn, helped Martin Cohen land the contract for office supplies and recommended Barry Winter to handle the physical relocation.
 Mr. Winter, meanwhile, suggested to a company whose lease was running out that it ask Daniel S. Chillemi, a commercial real estate broker, to help them find bigger quarters. Mr. Chillemi is showing the company space around the city. Once it settles, he will tell Mr. Winter, who will probably handle the move. Both men will probably steer business to Ms. Hullinghorst or to Mr. Cohen. 
 Indeed, Mr. Chillemi is already mentally making connections. "They'll need an architect and an engineer, and of course a telephone person," he said.
What is the link between people in such disparate fields? They belong to an organized group of 40 or so people in complementary but noncompeting businesses that have turned networking into a fine science.
David Glickman, the network's sole electrical engineer, recommends Ms. Hullinghorst, who works for Business Technology Partners, to people looking for a technology engineer, and she sends potential clients to him. If Mr. Chillemi's clients at CB Richard Ellis need an architect, he gives Jeffrey Kleinberg of MKDA first crack at the job. They may move to Lower Manhattan? That calls for Salim Ismail, whose specialty is helping companies get incentives the city is offering to draw business back downtown. What if the client wants to publicize the move? Time to call in Bambe Levine, a public relations specialist who is one of the group's newest members.
"It's a snowballing concept that really works," Mr. Chillemi said.
It does so despite having no dues, no formal charter, not even a name. Members tend to refer to it as "our group" or "our network," and Mr. Cohen, who owns Leonard Martin Office Products and is the group's founder, sees no need to change that. "Why do we need a name, so people can sue us?" he asked.
The name is probably the only thing about the group that is unscripted. Every other Thursday at 8 a.m., its members file into a board room in the Chrysler Building, which they borrow from the law firm Parker Chapin, whose partners sometimes attend. Over coffee and bagels, they sit down and start the routine.
Members and guests -- there are always a couple wanting to join -- introduce themselves, and give thumbnail sketches of what they do. Then, two members, different ones each time, give talks about their businesses. People then thank those who gave them recent referrals. The group takes a few minutes to tie up loose ends and to discuss new business, and it's out the door.
"That agenda is geared toward just one thing, expanding everyone's revenue stream," said Gail Z. Koch, a new member who owns the executive recruiting firm Comsearch.
A lot more people are clamoring to join, Mr. Cohen said, and almost no one misses meetings these days. Besides business leads, there is a bit of group therapy involved. "The worse the economy gets, the more people want to huddle," Mr. Cohen said. The meetings themselves remain inexorably tuned to drumming up business instead of to commiseration and handing out succor. It is Mr. Cohen's way of differentiating his group from all the other networking groups he has joined over the years. "I got to a lot of nice parties," he said, "but I didn't get much business."
The problem, he came to think, was the way the groups were structured. Because they charged dues, they needed more members. As a result, they would accept direct competitors and novices. Their events were attended by so many people that it took a maximum amount of chatter to generate a minimum number of business leads. The people who ran the groups rarely cared much if members showed up, or generated leads, as long as their dues were paid.
Expenses in Mr. Cohen's group are minimal because each meeting's speakers pay for the refreshments and members get their companies or clients to donate meeting space; for now, it's Parker Chapin.
Any member who misses six meetings in a year without a reasonable excuse is booted out. So are members who do not generate business. And the rules are enforced. The group has ousted nearly 20 people in its five years of existence. It recently kicked out an accountant who ran a 50-member firm yet provided no leads. It rejected an architect whose area of expertise bumped up against that of another architect in the group. ("Everyone liked her," Mr. Glickman said. "It was a shame.")
Rules can be bent, though. Several members have withheld recommendations from members who seemed wrong for a particular job. "I won't jeopardize a relationship with a client just to make a referral," Ms. Hullinghorst said. And, while the group is ostensibly for small-business owners, it accepted Moshe Jacobs, a fund-raiser for the Jerusalem College of Technology and a self-described master networker. "I introduce people almost intuitively," he said.
Mr. Cohen reckons that he has gotten hundreds of thousands of dollars in referral business from the group, and figures that he has given out more than $1 million. Mr. Glickman, who joined less than three years ago, says the network has led him to $100,000 to $200,000 in business.
"A new client called me last week, and said he'd gotten my name from three people," Mr. Glickman said. "Two of them were in this group."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Martin Cohen, at the head of the table, runs the meetings of the networking group of about 40 people in disparate fields. It meets every other week and focuses on finding business and avoids being a social encounter. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mt. Sinai on a Path Away From the Past 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT with MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
It is hardly a secret that this has been a tumultuous year for Mount Sinai, the megaplex medical center on the cusp of East Harlem and the Upper East Side, long a source of everything from high-tech medicine to physician education to subsidized care for the poor. 
 But the replacement of the hospital's president last week was the clearest signal yet of the board's desire for a new direction. 
 In his many years at Mount Sinai, the former president, Barry R. Freedman, played a central role in the medical center's precipitously shifting fortunes, from ambitious building programs to the troubled merger with the New York University Medical Center. Now, struggling with an operating-budget deficit of more than $100 million for the hospital and the medical school combined, Mount Sinai is in the midst of a series of changes that its leaders say are intended to break with the recent past. 
In replacing Mr. Freedman with Dr. Larry Hollier, a senior vice president and chief of surgery, Mount Sinai's trustees said they were seeking to remake the hospital as more of a "physician-led institution." The details of the medical center's new direction will not be made public until next month, officials say. 
Still, that process has been gathering force -- although painfully and haltingly -- since the hiring of outside consultants and the arrival in April of a new chief executive for Mount Sinai Medical Center, Dr. Kenneth I. Berns. 
There have been a number of shifts in the leadership of the trustees and administration, including the appointment of a new chief financial officer. At the same time, armed with the consultants' 7,000-page report, Mount Sinai has begun to impose a new fiscal austerity -- closing outpatient clinics, laying off hundreds of workers, and adopting a tighter-fisted approach to physician and faculty pay. 
All of this comes amid a state investigation stemming from the worst blow to Mount Sinai's image in years: the death in January of a liver donor left, after major surgery, in the care of what the state Health Department said was an overworked, undersupervised and relatively inexperienced staff.
Administrators attribute the center's fiscal problems largely to changes in health care financing and reimbursement. Even so, some of them acknowledge that the fiscal crisis is at least partly of Mount Sinai's own making. The new economics have squeezed all of the nation's teaching hospitals, and especially those in New York. But the roughly $700 million in bonds that Mount Sinai Hospital and three of the N.Y.U. hospitals raised jointly are now considered of the lowest investment grade by two of three rating agencies. 
Some officials say that Mr. Freedman and other executives were slow to respond to early signs of trouble several years ago. At the time, they say, the leadership was distracted by the merger with N.Y.U., which many officials say has failed to produce the gains that had been expected and which would have come undone if not for the bonds held jointly by the two institutions. Then, these officials say, the departure of Mount Sinai's chief executive, Dr. John Rowe, followed by a lengthy interregnum, made it far harder to take decisive action to control growing losses. 
One indication of the trustees' concern comes from its decision to hire the outside consultants, the Hunter Group, known for coming in "when a management is in trouble with the board and the board is looking around for help," according to Gary I. Filerman, a professor of health care management at Georgetown University. 
Mr. Freedman had been associated with Mount Sinai for 25 years, many of them in top leadership positions. During his tenure, the hospital began an ambitious building program, increased patient admissions and, for a time, cut the average length of their stays, increasing revenues. Mr. Freedman was also one of the hospital executives who devised the merger with N.Y.U.
He did not have a lot of visibility, but within the health care economy, he was powerful. Since 1996, he has served on the board of Premier Inc., a privately held company that helps a quarter of the nation's hospitals -- including Mount Sinai -- buy billions of dollars' worth of hospital supplies each year. In 2000, Mr. Freedman became Premier's lead director, its second most powerful governing official after the chairman. 
In recent months, several federal agencies have begun examining, among other things, whether Premier and similar buying groups have effectively colluded with large medical-supply companies to eliminate competition in the hospital-supply market. In response to pressure from a Senate subcommittee, Premier recently promised to change the ways it does business.

Austerity vs. Executive Pay
 At Mount Sinai, the current climate of austerity casts an uncomfortable light on the medical center's executive compensation, especially given its nonprofit status. The salaries of its top executives, said Mr. Filerman of Georgetown, are considered among the highest in the nation's hospital industry. Also, Internal Revenue Service records show that most of the top tier of executives received substantial pay increases in 1999, as Mount Sinai was promising the public that the merger with N.Y.U. would improve its fiscal condition. 
For example, the former chief executive, Dr. Rowe, received $1.4 million in 1998, the year the merger was consummated. The next year, his last full year at Mount Sinai, he was paid $1.9 million. The federal records also show that he had an interest-free housing loan of $2.25 million. 
Mr. Freedman was paid $1.1 million in 1998, $1.3 million in 1999 and slightly less the next year, the most recent for which records were available. 
A Mount Sinai spokeswoman, Lucia Lee, said that while she could not provide specific numbers, "we're not the highest, as far as our salary goes" among medical centers in the New York area. Of the loan to Dr. Rowe, she said many medical schools offered them, to attract top talent. It has been paid back in full, she added. 
Mr. Freedman would not discuss his departure or his compensation.
The ascent of Dr. Hollier, who was already on the payroll, is likely to be a cost saving in itself. But more significantly, as with the hiring of the Hunter Group, the appointment of a physician is also intended to have political and symbolic value. 
An executive vice president of the medical center, Dr. Gary Rosenberg, said the importance of a physician-run structure "has to do with the nature of how one makes change with physicians." He suggested that it would be easier to convince reluctant physicians of the need for change if physicians were in charge. 
The current situation has only heightened the inherent tensions between Mount Sinai's fiscal imperatives and its diverse agenda of teaching, research and service. 
"Obviously, if you go broke, you can't fulfill any of those missions," Dr. Berns said in an interview early this summer. But behaving more like a business presents its own problems. "The challenge then becomes how you remember that you're supposed to be an academic institution," he said.

Consultant's findings
 As it seeks to balance those interests, Mount Sinai is being guided by recommendations of the Hunter Group, which called for changes in everything from how supplies are purchased to how doctors are paid. Officials declined to make the report public. But conversations with several people who have seen it make clear that more than a few things operated at less than optimum efficiency. For example, Mount Sinai had been losing $10 million a year in uncollected revenue because of inadequate billing, Dr. Rosenberg said. The hospital, he said, is changing that.
The hospital is also trying to rein in the cost, which it pays, of patients kept in the hospital longer than insurers allow. Its average length of stay is longer than most hospitals' -- partly because its patients tend to be sicker, but also because of inefficiencies that are common, some say inherent, in teaching hospitals. Administrators say they have made progress but want to cut the average by 10 percent more. 
At the same time, the emergency room, primary-care physician to many of the poor, is severely overtaxed. Built to handle 35,000 visits a year, it now receives twice that number, and the resulting congestion can mean unnecessarily long waits. 
Amid all the talk of cutbacks and efficiency, administrators say they are also trying to create new sources of revenue. Most notably, they recently spent what Dr. Berns described succinctly as "a bundle" to recruit a high-profile team of four heart surgeons from Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and build them new operating rooms. 
Still, economy is generally the order of the day. About 700 positions in the hospital and 150 in the medical school have been eliminated, Dr. Rosenberg said. (Because some were unfilled, he said, the actual drop in employees is less.) He said the positions were mostly in management and building service, along with a handful of nursing positions in ambulatory care. At least immediately after the layoffs, medical center administrators said that parts of the hospital -- although not patient rooms -- had become noticeably dirtier. Offices were being cleaned less often, and faculty members and executives were told to put their trash outside their offices for pickup.

Restructuring at Clinics
 Perhaps the most visible cuts and restructuring have involved a central element of Mount Sinai's community-service mission: the 165 outpatient clinics run by Mount Sinai faculty and staffed by doctors in training. Mostly based at the hospital, the clinics receive nearly 400,000 visits a year, largely from patients on Medicaid or with little or no insurance to cover the cost. The clinics have been hemorrhaging money. 
To begin cutting those losses, Mount Sinai shut down its Communication Disorders Center, which for nearly three decades had treated children and some adults with speech and language disorders. 
To try to reduce the costs of outpatient pediatric services, Mount Sinai is shifting as many as 5,000 low-income patients to community clinics in Harlem and the Bronx staffed by Mount Sinai doctors but run by the Children's Aid Society.
And the Mount Sinai Adolescent Health Center, with 100,000 visits a year and a staff of more than 100, was informed that the medical center could no longer cover its $5 million annual deficit. Dr. Angela Diaz, the center's director, has cut staff, increased doctors' caseloads, organized fund-raisers and lobbied legislators. She said the center was "pretty much breaking even."
While those programs serve mostly low-income patients, Mount Sinai also recently shut its Women's Health Program, a comprehensive health program that in many ways resembled a private group practice. Opened in 1994, it was targeted at the more lucrative middle- and upper-middle-class market. Yet it was never profitable. The hospital also recently closed its diabetes clinic.
Virtually all teaching hospitals are subject to a host of economic constraints -- increasingly tight limits on Medicare spending, the policies of managed care companies, labor shortages and rising pharmaceutical and malpractice insurance costs. 
But Mount Sinai administrators often point out that they face special burdens. Largely because of geography, a high percentage of its patients are underinsured or uninsured: 25 percent to 30 percent of all inpatients and, administrators say, virtually all who use its outpatient clinics. 
Furthermore, they say, the hospital is reimbursed for its Medicaid outpatient visits at a rate lower than that of some comparable hospitals and even some community clinics. A spokesman for the state Health Department said Mount Sinai's outpatient Medicaid reimbursement rate, like those of other hospitals, is based on a formula plus an estimate of current capital costs.

Death After Transplant
 Adding to the medical center's woes is the case of Mike Hurewitz, the 57-year-old man who died three days after donating part of his liver to his brother. The state Health Department imposed the maximum fine, $48,000, and banned the hospital from doing live-donor liver transplants for six months. 
Though Mount Sinai administrators and physicians say it remains unclear exactly how Mr. Hurewitz developed the infection that apparently led to his death, and though they say they do not believe the hospital could have prevented his death, they have increased the number of nurses on the transplant unit and changed their procedures on orders from the Health Department. 
The continuing state investigation has since expanded to 125 cases or confidential complaints made in the wake of Mr. Hurewitz's death. Most involve the liver transplant unit, though some involve other services. 
Asked about the case's impact on the hospital, Dr. Berns said recently, "I think it brought home the realization that a lot more attention had to be paid to patient care here."

 INTERNATIONAL 3-14

The Struggle for Water Is Causing Global Tensions
All across the world, the struggle for water is igniting social, economic and political tensions. The World Bank has said dwindling water supplies will be a major factor inhibiting economic growth, a subject being discussed at a weeklong international conference in South Africa starting tomorrow about balancing use of the world's resources against its economic needs. 1

U.S. Envoy Credits Pakistan
Assistant Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage concluded a round of talks with leaders from Pakistan and India and credited Pakistan with reducing the cross-border infiltrations by Muslim guerrillas that have increased tensions between the nuclear-armed rivals. 11

U.S. Aids Broad Drug Sweep
A broad narcotics sweep from June 10 to July 11 involving 25,000 law enforcement officers and coordinated by the Drug Enforcement Administration across 15 countries of Central Asia and the Balkans has resulted in the arrest or detention of thousands of suspects, federal officials said. 9

Change in Karzai's Guards
State Department security personnel will begin providing the inner ring of bodyguards for President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan in September, as they take over that job from American Special Operations forces, officials announced. 10

Afghanistan Aid Hopes Unmet
There is a growing sense of disappointment in Afghanistan that the outside world has yet to deliver fully on the promises made after the collapse of the Taliban. The government there estimates that only one-third of the $1.8 billion pledged this year has reached Afghanistan. 10

Malpractice Insurance Forcing Cuts at Hospitals
At least six hospitals around the country have closed obstetric wards, others have curtailed trauma services, and a string of rural clinics have been temporarily shuttered as a result of soaring costs for medical malpractice insurance. 1

Accused Priests Strike Back
Priests from several Roman Catholic dioceses around the country have filed defamation suits against those who have accused them of sexual misconduct. The cases are seen as a counteroffensive by some of the hundreds of priests who have been accused this year of sexual crimes. 1

Lines in the Sand in Malibu
The battle between property owners and beachgoers over public access to California's 1,160-mile shoreline has become particularly intense. 1

Paying for Immigrants' Care
The question of who is responsible for illegal immigrants who require extensive medical care but have no means to pay for it has become an increasing concern for health care providers, particularly in Florida and border states with growing numbers of illegal immigrants. 16

Smallpox Vaccinations on Hold
More than two months after a national advisory panel recommended vaccinating thousands of health care and emergency workers against smallpox, state and local health officials are waiting for the government to announce its official policy. 22

HEADLINE: Judge Changes Mind On Murder Case Costs 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: McARTHUR, Ohio, Aug. 24 

 BODY:
A judge is allowing prosecutors to seek the death penalty against a man accused of killing a college student, reversing his earlier judgment that it would be too expensive.
 The judge, Jeffrey L. Simmons of the Court of Common Pleas in Vinton County, ruled this month that financial considerations could compromise the due-process rights of the defendant, Gregory McKnight. 
But in a one-page ruling on Friday, Judge Simmons dismissed those concerns. 
 The judge ruled minutes after an appeals court dismissed the prosecutor's appeal of the decision. The prosecutor, Timothy Gleeson, had also asked Judge Simmons to reconsider.
Mr. Gleeson, referring to small counties, said he hoped "the legislature will find a solution to allow counties to prosecute such cases." 
Vinton, in southern Ohio, is the state's most sparsely populated county, with about 12,800 people. Its unemployment rate is usually double the state average.
Judge Simmons said in his earlier ruling that paying for Mr. McKnight's defense against the death penalty would deplete the county's $2.7 million general fund budget. A county commissioner, Michael Bledsoe, said the county would find the money.

HEADLINE: Must Speed Process Of Meeting Energy Needs 

 BODY:
 Despite the economic downturn, New York will still require more than 7,000 megawatts of additional power by 2005. To avert the threat of blackouts, we need to take decisive action now. 
The state needs to ensure we have a reliable electricity system by facilitating the development of sufficient power supply. The state is currently reviewing permits for many power projects throughout the New York. However, many of these projects are at risk of not being approved and constructed. This risk is a result of the state's cumbersome permitting process and of the growing challenges of the softer economy and the corresponding increased difficulty in financing such facilities. 
 At least one power generation facility on Long Island is successfully making its way through the state permitting process and has just received a recommendation from hearing officers presiding over the case. American National Power's proposed Brookhaven Energy Project, a 500-megawatt, natural gas-fired, combined cycle facility, would use state of the art technology and equipment, making it one of the most efficient and environmentally sound projects in New York.
The development of this and other highly efficient generation facilities will also lead to increased competition for electricity, driving down prices in a region with some of the highest electrical rates in the country.
In addition, electrical generators like the Brookhaven Energy project contribute significant local benefits, including local taxes and employment. The Brookhaven project alone is estimated to create 700 construction jobs during times of peak construction and about 25 full-time employees to run it.
I call on state officials to facilitate the development and construction of the Brookhaven Energy facility and other similar power generators.

JOHN M. KENNEDY
President
Building and Construction Trades
Council of Nassau and Suffolk
Counties
Hauppauge

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
For Job Seekers, an Edge (a Sharp One)

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
It is soooo tempting to make fun of Career Gear, at least at first. How else to respond to a charity with a new program to help the jobless by giving them (drumroll. ..) free haircuts.
 But the story behind the barbershop Bargain is actually rather poignant - and it offers some insights into the changing challenges fo assisting unemployed New Yorkers in the current economy. 
 More than three years ago, when Gary Field founded Career Gear in Manhattan, New York City's economy was booming. It is not much of an exaggeration to say that if you were breathing and could speak English, you could find work. 
 So perhaps it made sense that both the city goverment and nonprofit agencies concentrated their efforts on a small but important group of the unemployed: those on welfare or those with serious problems that made finding a job especially hard.
 This troubled group, of the male variety, makes up Mr. Field's clientele. Men who just got out of prison, men struggling with drugs or alcohol, men with various kinds of disabilities. Back then, jobs were out there for them; the tough part was getting them ready to do the work.
 One of the problems these men have is coming up with appropriate clothes to wear to an interview. "Some of them haven't worn a suit since they were five," Mr. Field said.
 He knows the problem, because he had to buy a used suit and a preworn pair of shoes when he started looking for a job more than a decade ago. He was 32, on public assistance and, he said, "my life was a mess." After waiting tables and working as a receptionist, he helped come up with a plan to help other men in the same straits.
 Social service agencies refer unemployed men who have been through job training and have an employment interview scheduled to Career Gear. The agency fits them with an appropriate ensemble, whether it is a suit from Brooks Brothers ( a big benefactor) or a more casual work outfit. Along the way, it als provides advice and counseling.
 "In the scheme of things, a haircut sounds kind of ridiculous," Mr. Field said. But it is just the newest part of a packcage to, as Oprah might say, boost self-esteem.
 These days, however, the unemployed need far more than just self-esteem. New York City has lost almost 84,000 jobs in the last 12 months, a fewer people have jobs now than they did at this time in 1999, Career Gear's first summer of operation.
 The unemployment rate shot up to 8 percent in May and June, from a low of 5.3 percent in March 2001, according to the New York State Department of Labor. And while the rate edged down a bit in July 2002, to 7.7 percent, economists say that is probably because some job seekers were so discouraged by bad economic news that they stopped looking for work, and so were no longer officially counted as unemployed.
 But there are still a lot of people - almost 300,000 - looking for work in New York City now, according to government estimates, maybe tens of thousands more than last year.
 What this means for Mr. Field's clients is that they have to compete for jobs with people who have college degrees and good work records, he said, adding. "The folks with less education, less of a chance, have even less of a chance now."
 In a tough economy, helping such people has become more of a challenge - but so has helping all unemployed New Yorkers, said Neil Scott Kleiman, director of the Center for an Urban Future, a research group, and an expert on the city's efforts to assist the unemployed.
 Furthermore, workforce development - making sure there are enough skilled workers to attract employers - has become crucial to the city as it struggles to keep businesses from leaving in the wake of Sept. 11. The Bloomberg administration is clearly rethinking the "get 'em off welfare" focus its predecessor, Mr. Kleiman said, but figuring out what to do will not be easy, in part because so many traditional job-training programs have not helped people find work.
 But if one thing stands out, Mr. Kleiman said, it is that education pays off. "It is impossible to get a well-paying job in New York without an associate's degree," he said.
 Education worked for Mr. Field, who now has a master's degree in social work. He was already in his 30's when he began attending the Borough of Manhattan Community College "with a million 18-year-olds," he said. "It was very humbling. But that is where I needed to start."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary Field of Career Gear, a nonprofit that speeds the road to employment for men just out of prison or struggling with other problems by providing them with interview attire. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
An L. L. Bean Life Style on a Wal-Mart Paycheck

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
WHEN your property taxes finally hit the five digits, as mine did recently, you know you have entered a whole new ballgame.
 A ballgame, perhaps, in which the other team has Derek Jeter and Jason Giambi and your infield just came by bus from Lodi. 
 New Jersey Policy Perspectives, a research organization, came out with a report this summer called Fiscal Stress, which basically concluded that the entire state will end up like Camden if it doesn't fix a tax structure that allows so many different town and county governments to replicate services, and that relies so heavily on local property taxes.
When I talked to Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspectives, he was hardly reassuring. 
Take my minuscule town of Glen Ridge, which to Mr. Shure's way of thinking is a classic example of a town that doesn't have a right to exist at all.
"You might have a house you like in a neighborhood you like," he said, "but your town's got fiscal stress and you've got fiscal stress trying to live there."
Tell me about it. And from what I can tell, I'm not alone but right in the middle of the once-comfortable middle class and being squeezed like the third person in the middle of a New Jersey Transit train seat.
Maybe life is expensive because you can't live an L. L. Bean life style on a Wal-Mart paycheck. In case you haven't noticed, New Jersey -- where people used to skulk off to if they couldn't afford Connecticut or Westchester or even parts of Long island -- isn't cheap anymore. The days of $7.50 Springsteen tickets are over. Heck, even Asbury Park isn't cheap; I just heard about someone who bought a loft there for $400,000, though I can't vouch for her mental state.
I mean, if you can't stand the price of sushi, maybe it's time to get back in the kitchen.
So while I wait for enlightened political leadership, I thought I'd follow the example of Charles B. Darrow, who invented Monopoly during the Depression while he was unemployed. My game is called Suburbopoly, New Jersey Edition.
OBJECT: Live in a leafy neighborhood with good schools and go on vacation at least two weeks a year.
EQUIPMENT: A board, dice, tokens, 32 houses and 2 bed-and-breakfasts. There are Chance and Community Chest cards and all the currency is credit-card-style plastic.
PROPERTY: The board starts with condominiums, works up through split levels, Colonials, Tudors, Victorians and McMansions and culminates in actual mansions in Rumson. Players who lose their property are forced to move in with their parents in Boca Raton. Game over.
PROPERTY TAXES: Start at $6,500 and go up by a couple thousand dollars every time you you pass Go.
UTILITIES: In addition to water (which you are not allowed to use) and electricity (which may not always be there at the flip of a switch), there is E-ZPass, Poland Spring, Gym Membership, High-Speed Internet Access, Cellphone, Landscape Service, Weekly Maid, Cable TV, HBO, Karate Lessons, Orthodontia and Car Insurance.
Every time you land on one of these utilities, except Car Insurance, you pay 10 times the amount of dice rolled. If you land on Car Insurance, you pay 20 times the amount rolled. Two speeding tickets and you are out of the game.
RAILROADS: There are only two railroads, Amtrak and New Jersey Transit. If you land on New Jersey Transit, you pay $6 for a ride from Metro Park to New York City. If you land on Amtrak, you pay $28 and everyone else is assessed $100.
SO SUE ME: There is no jail in Suburbopoly, only court. If you draw a So Sue Me card, you pay thousands of dollars in legal fees for the rest of the game.
CHANCE and COMMUNITY CHEST: These represent the little vagaries of life that make suburban living so much fun. For example, you are invited to an out-of-town wedding; pay $1,000. Swimming pool filter breaks; pay $1,000. Oil change and a few other things the dealer says need to be done to keep your warranty in effect; pay $400. Restoration Hardware catalog comes; pay $600. Your daughter marries: pay $30,000. Homestead Tax Rebate, collect $67.
FREE LUNCH: There is no free lunch, only cheese samples at Whole Foods.
THE PLAY: Players who refinance their mortgages, avoid speeding tickets, send their children to college and marry them off are eligible to sell their property. The first player to sell the house and move out of New Jersey wins.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Nancy Doniger)
