HEADLINE: ON THE GROUND: Newark; 
A Gateway to New York Is Enjoying a Renaissance

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA R. OLSEN 

 BODY:
Newark -- a 15-minute train ride from Manhattan -- is a leading gateway to New York. But this third-oldest major American city has been enjoying a renaissance, and there are several reasons to stay in town. Newark is aggressively fighting to eradicate its reputation for crime; in fact, crime has decreased more than 50 percent in the last six years. 
 In recent years there has also been an influx of businesses, including the IDT Corporation, MBNA and the SBLI USA Mutual Life Insurance Company, which join stalwarts like Verizon, PSE&G, Merrill Lynch and Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield. The city has begun an effort to revitalize its waterfront, with the Faneuil Hall area of Boston and South Street Seaport in Manhattan as models. The F.B.I. will become the first organization to establish a presence there when construction is completed on its new office building. 
 Just west of the business district is the University Heights Science Park, a collaborative program for economic and community development that offers technology businesses modern office space, research facilities and assistance. The International Center for Public Health, a research center, relocated to Newark from Brooklyn this year.
Surrounding highways are undergoing major improvements, and transportation connections are some of the best in the region. New Jersey Transit (800-626-7433) provides a shuttle bus to points of interest around town, including to and from evening performances at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. You can also take the train directly to Newark International Airport.
Gateway Center, the largest office complex, is connected by an elevated bridge to Penn Station, where you can catch a train to New York or an Amtrak train to more far-flung destinations.

HOTELS
The NEWARK AIRPORT MARRIOTT (973-623-0006, $170 to $200), the only hotel on the airport grounds, is convenient for holding interviews or conducting meetings. Besides a 24-hour health club, there's a new cigar bar and patio, a telescope to track air traffic and an airline monitor in the lobby to check flight schedules.
If you like new, the WYNDHAM NEWARK AIRPORT (908-436-4600, $129 to $238), one of the many chain hotels near the airport, is less than a year old. 
In town, the HILTON NEWARK GATEWAY (973-622-5000, $229) is in the heart of the business district and is directly connected to Penn Station and the Gateway Center. Amenities for the business traveler include a business-services center and executive lounge.
In the arts district, the ROBERT TREAT HOTEL (973-622-1000, $125 to $142) has been a landmark since 1916. Combining old-world charm with modern conference facilities, it is a favorite of the celebrities, like Harry Connick Jr., who appear at the arts center.

DINING OUT
In the arts district, ARTHUR'S DOWNTOWN (973-286-1700) is popular with the locals for business lunches. Its banquettes and Art Deco styling give it a club atmosphere, and the bar is a pleasant place to dine alone. Lunch for two, including tip but not wine, runs about $25.
The upscale MAIZE restaurant (973-639-1200, $70 for lunch for two with tip and wine) in the Robert Treat Hotel offers lunch at no charge if you're not out in an hour.
Consider yourself lucky if the company you are meeting with has a corporate membership at the NEWARK CLUB (973-242-0658). Gabriella Morris, president of the Prudential Foundation, likes to bring out-of-town guests here for lunch. "Not only is the food wonderful," she said, but the views of Manhattan and the Passaic River "satisfy your visual appetite as well."
The THEATER SQUARE GRILL (973-297-5872) in the arts center has a $45 prix fixe dinner (wine is extra).
Ethnic restaurants abound in Newark. For lunch, Ms. Morris recommends JE'S (973-623-8848; $40 for two, including wine and tip, for either lunch or dinner) for soul food. 
In the Ironbound District, so named because it is surrounded by railroad tracks and bordered by highways, FORNO'S OF SPAIN (973-589-4767, $75 for dinner for two with wine and tip) is a good bet. The Ironbound is known for its large Portuguese community, its many Portuguese restaurants and its flourishing Portuguese night life.

ENTERTAINMENT
The NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER (888-466-5722) is one of the best-known arts centers in the area. Although the free outdoor summer music series is over, regular events include jazz, classical music, pop stars, dance and theater.
At the Maize restaurant, the eclectic lounge is like a comfortable living room. Entertainment is provided Wednesday through Saturday nights in the fall.
PRONTO CENA RISTORANTE (973-824-8999) in the Legal Center across from Gateway Center, has a river view and jazz on Thursday nights.

ON YOUR OWN
If you have a couple of hours to spare, you might like to stroll through the NEWARK MUSEUM (973-596-6550). If you have children in tow, try the child-friendly interactive exhibit about the New Jersey Turnpike at the NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY (973-596-8500). After its move some time this fall, the ALJIRA, A CENTER FOR CONTEMPORARY ART (973-643-6877) will have its contemporary art exhibits on display again.

LOCAL LORE
Newark has a long history as a baseball town. Professional baseball dates back to 1902 with the formation of the Newark Indians, who later became the Newark Bears. Newark was also home to the Newark Eagles of the National Negro League.
Rick Cerone, former New York Yankee All-Star catcher and Newark native, helped to revitalize the Newark Bears franchise. The team plays at the three-year-old Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The view from a window of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Its schedule includes jazz, classical music, pop stars, dance and theater. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
MEMO PAD

BYLINE:  ByJOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
Losing Billions And Charging Less
The airlines continue to lose billions, and air travel continues to get cheaper. 
 Average domestic air fares declined 9.1 percent and average international air fares were down 1.3 percent in July, compared with the month a year earlier, according to the Air Transport Association, the airline industry trade group. 
 "In order to stimulate demand, airlines have reduced prices to levels not seen since 1988," said David A. Swierenga, the chief economist at the trade group.

Travel Demand Perks Up a Bit
Overall travel demand appears to be picking up at the end of the summer, according to a new survey done by Orbitz, the online booking site, for the Travel Business Roundtable, a travel industry group. 
Nearly 90 percent of Americans are now traveling at least at the same level as they were a year ago, according to the survey, whose conclusions were extrapolated from interviews with 700 Americans who have taken at least one airline trip of spent one night in a hotel in the last six months. 
Leisure travelers have led the way. Frequent business travelers are among the most reluctant to resume former robust travel patterns. 
"There is a clear lag in the resumption of business travel patterns," said Jeff Katz, the president and chief executive of Orbitz. "Among frequent business travelers, 17 percent say that they are traveling less now -- 5 percent more than the population at large," he said. 
Jonathan Tisch, the chairman of the Travel Business Roundtable and chairman and chief executive of Loews Hotels, said that besides economic constraints, the "hassle factor" associated with airport security was one reason for the lag. 
Among those surveyed, 79 percent of frequent business travelers reported being subjected to heightened security treatment, like pat-downs and orders to remove shoes. 
In addition, the survey found, more than one in 10 travelers said they had canceled flights or were flying less because of the "hassles" of airport security.
Among female business travelers who have reduced their level of flying because of security checkpoint experiences, 31 percent have done so because of what they described as a personal "intrusion from security." Of male business travelers who have reduced their travel, only 4 percent cited such intrusion as the reason.

Giving the Boot To Substandard Hotels
Hotel chain executives have a phrase to describe what happens to franchise holders drummed out of the chain. "Taking the flag down," they call it. 
Usually, it's a quiet process. Last week, however, the Cendant Corporation surprised the industry when it announced Project Restore, which it described as a campaign to "purge its systems of substandard quality hotels" and of franchise holders who do not pay their bills on time.
Hotels with a total of about 40,000 rooms -- about 7 percent of the company's capacity in about 6,600 properties -- may get the boot. Already, 300 hotels have received notice, the company said. 
Cendant's brands include Days Inn, Ramada, Super 8 Motel, Howard Johnson, Wingate Inn, Knights Inn, Travelodge, Villager Group and AmeriHost Inn. JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Set a Record Pace Last Month 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
Sales of new homes surged in July to the highest monthly level on record, and sales of previously owned homes also increased, two reports released today said.
 Sales of new homes climbed to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.02 million in July, a record monthly pace and a 6.7 percent increase from June, the Commerce Department reported. 
 Sales of existing homes rebounded in July, rising 4.5 percent from June, to a rate of 5.33 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. 
Home sales have been a bright spot of the economy, mostly because of low mortgage rates, which remain below levels of a year ago. Another factor motivating buyers, economists said, is the appreciation in housing values. 
In July, those factors offset negative ones, including eroding consumer confidence and a stagnant job market.
In June, sales of new homes fell 2.6 percent and existing-home sales dropped 11.1 percent as worries about jobs, the stock market and the economy seemed to weigh on prospective buyers. Even with the declines, sales remained healthy.
Both new-home and existing-home sales are expected to set records this year. David Seiders, economist at the National Association of Home Builders, predicted that new-home sales would reach 936,000. David Lereah, economist for the National Association of Realtors, is projecting existing-home sales to reach 5.44 million.
By region, new-home sales in July increased 16 percent in the Midwest, to a rate of 203,000, the highest level since December 1993. In the South, sales jumped 10.1 percent, to a rate of 470,000, the highest level since November.
In the Northeast, sales fell 9.1 percent, to a rate of 60,000, and in the West, they dipped 0.4 percent, to a rate of 284,000.
For existing homes, sales in July jumped 10.2 percent in the Midwest, to a rate of 1.19 million. 
In the South, sales rose 6.4 percent, to a pace of 2.17 million, and in the Northeast, they went up 4.9 percent, to a rate of 640,000.
But in the West, sales slipped 2.9 percent, to a rate of 1.33 million.

HEADLINE: More Get 9/11 Aid, but Distrust of U.S. Effort Lingers 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Since overhauling its programs in late June to assist New Yorkers devastated by the Sept. 11 attack, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has granted more money to nearly as many people needing help with their mortgage or rent as it did in the previous nine months.
 The agency has eased its eligibility criteria to include more New Yorkers, not just residents of Lower Manhattan. It has produced brochures in several languages, not just English. It has hired caseworkers who are from New York, not just far-flung states. 
 But for all the changes, FEMA is still plagued by many problems that community groups, Congressional leaders and residents worry may ultimately leave thousands of needy New Yorkers in the lurch. 
The critics say that the rules are still too arbitrary. That they focus too much on people who were previously rejected under much stricter criteria. That they are unfair to people outside Manhattan. And that they are onerous on low-income workers, who have trouble securing documents from landlords and employers.
But more than anything, there are concerns that thousands of people, already scarred by their dealings with FEMA, may not have the stomach to try again.
"Thousands of people have lost trust in the agency because of the prior rejections and false promises the first time around," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of Manhattan. "It's going to take more effort and stronger outreach from FEMA to convince those who are now so frustrated with the process that they haven't even considered applying for assistance under the new guidelines."
Helga Wong is leery of applying again. The first time around, it took Ms. Wong, who is the owner of Technorama, a technology company in TriBeCa, five or six weeks to send a complete fax to FEMA because the agency kept losing pages. When she didn't even get a response, she simply gave up in March and borrowed thousands of dollars from her brother.
Now, she is thinking of holding off on her mortgage payments so that she can receive formal notices from her bank to give FEMA incontrovertible proof of her hardship. But it is a big risk, she acknowledges.
"When you're emotionally battered," said Ms. Wong, "and you go to the people who are supposed to help you, and you get more emotionally battered by them, you have to say to yourself, 'Is this worth my sanity?' "
For their part, FEMA officials say that their programs are fairer, better and more inclusive than before. But they also acknowledge that the criticism has been humbling. "I wouldn't say that sometimes it's not painful, because all of us are in the business of helping people," said Brad Gair, FEMA's federal recovery officer in New York. "But whether it's demonstrations or letters from members of Congress or media reports, it makes all our programs better."
In the months after Sept. 11, people were particularly incensed about the agency's handling of one little-used program, the Mortgage and Rental Assistance Program, which covers up to 18 months of mortgage or rent payments for anyone who lost income "as a result" of a disaster. Until June, the application forms were printed only in English.
In theory, the program meshed well with the circumstances, since much of the damage to New York was economic, with 75,000 jobs and $4.5 billion in income lost. But for the Sept. 11 disaster, the agency, apparently fearing being overwhelmed by applications, changed its usual phrase "as a result" to "as a direct result," thereby raising the burden of proof.
The real result was a 70 percent rejection rate for applicants, which far outstripped the rate in other major relief efforts.
It did not help that FEMA evaluators -- two-thirds of whom were temporary workers -- were located in Texas, Virginia and elsewhere and sometimes misunderstood New York's geography and culture. One agency evaluator did not know that 1 Liberty Plaza was in Lower Manhattan, let alone adjacent to the World Trade Center. Another insisted that garment workers had been laid off because they were seasonal employees. Indeed, some New Yorkers have described the evaluators as condescending, rude and ill informed.
"If I heard someone from Texas, I would just keep dialing until I got the Virginia people," Ms. Wong said. "At least they said, 'Hi, can I help you?' "
After months of withering criticism, FEMA revamped the mortgage and rent program in June. Out went the question of what constituted "as a direct result"; in came a slew of guidelines driven largely by geography and income. The application deadline was extended, too, from September to January 2003.
Under the new guidelines, anyone who lives or works in Manhattan and suffered financially because of the attack may be eligible for assistance. Others in surrounding boroughs who worked for businesses that were economically reliant on Lower Manhattan may also be eligible. Prospective applicants can call the agency's special line, (800) 462-9029.
Some New Yorkers, previously rejected by FEMA, are now contacting groups like the New York Taxi Workers Alliance and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. So every day, Chaumtoli Huq, staff lawyer for the taxi group, opens her offices to a steady stream of taxi drivers grateful for another chance.
FEMA has tried to reach more immigrants through brochures in six languages and an advertising campaign in the ethnic press. It has worked more closely with community groups. It has formed a 15-member task force here, composed mostly of local caseworkers, to handle the toughest claims.
It has even arranged what Mr. Gair said was a "foreign exchange" between FEMA employees in Texas and New York to visit one another.
All told, 3,053 households have received $25.3 million since late June, compared with 3,585 households receiving $20.6 million from September to June. So far, the average monthly payment has been $1,140, and many of FEMA's toughest critics say that there has been a bureaucratic about-face.
"Before the changes, their attitude was more along the lines of, 'This is how we've done it before, and we're not going to change it,' " said Robert J. Hurst, chief executive of the 9/11 United Services Group, a nonprofit consortium of 13 charities. "Now, it feels like there's a much more flexible, much more thoughtful approach."
John Tolve, the principal of ResourceReservoir.com, a database development company, has his own tale of two FEMA's. At first, he was forced out of his apartment near Wall Street. He exhausted his credit line and was constantly late with his rent. And, to no one's surprise, rejected by FEMA.
But shortly after he called Assemblyman Sheldon Silver and a downtown business group, From the Ground Up, he got results. In fact, he discovered a few thousand dollars directly deposited to his bank account even before he received an approval letter.
"FEMA bailed me out because of my rent, and I'm going to be O.K. for the next couple months," Mr. Tolve said. "I really have to thank Shelly Silver for that."
And yet, therein lies part of the problem. Mr. Tolve and other residents felt so stymied that they needed to contact elected officials like Mr. Silver, Ms. Maloney and Representative Jerrold L. Nadler. That is not how the program was supposed to work. (Even some residents in the Washington area, frustrated that FEMA has distributed only $38,000 in mortgage and rental assistance, have contacted New York officials, too.)
So, two weeks ago, eight members of the New York Congressional delegation wrote to FEMA's director, Joseph M. Allbaugh, demanding that the agency loosen its financial requirements and reach out to more potential applicants. And on July 31, hundreds of New Yorkers and community groups marched on Washington to demand better treatment for low-income workers.
Of the 79,000 people in New York who contacted FEMA for help before the rule changes, 33,000 were deemed potentially eligible for the mortgage and rental assistance program under the old criteria. But of that group, only 11,000 finished their applications.
Of course, some people have managed to rebound economically. But a recent study by the 9/11 United Services Group found that more than 45,000 workers in Lower Manhattan continued to suffer an income loss of 25 percent or more, including 28,000 who were still unemployed. And those figures do not include the other boroughs or the suburbs.
As the rules are currently configured, someone who lives in Harlem and lost a job at La Guardia would qualify, but someone who lives in Astoria and lost the same job would not. Moreover, people who had to move out of their apartments -- perhaps because they were rejected by FEMA, perhaps because they were worried about the air quality in Lower Manhattan -- are now being told that they may not qualify, said Benjamin Ross, disaster relief coordinator of the New York Immigration Coalition.
"They've put me in a pickle," said Ariel Goodman, a business owner who relocated to Midtown after being forced out of her apartment in Battery Park City. "I think they're penny-wise and pound-foolish."
In response, Mr. Gair said that FEMA was trying to help as many people as possible, and that each case would be evaluated on its merits. "We're trying to be as creative as possible," he said. "We want to make sure no one prejudges their eligibility based on something they heard or read."
Many community groups also say that FEMA's lost-income threshold of 25 percent is too high, particularly for low-income workers. It is often difficult for low-income workers to provide supporting documents, especially when their employers and landlords deal only in cash and may be unwilling to furnish any official papers, said Wing Lam, executive director of the Chinese Staff and Workers Association.
As such, FEMA's reputation is so besmirched in many parts of New York that even when someone receives help, few people believe it.
When Mohammed M. Quadery, a taxi driver from Queens, received a brown envelope from FEMA last month, he assumed that it was a brochure, maybe an advertisement. It was a check for $1,662.82, two months' rent.
Bewildered, he called the New York Taxi Workers Alliance.
"I was wondering, 'Is this real? Is this a check I can cash?' " said Mr. Quadery, who lost up to 75 percent of his business after Sept. 11 and borrowed thousands of dollars from relatives to avoid eviction. "I didn't think that FEMA sent out checks. I thought they only sent rejection letters."

HEADLINE: To Rebuild Afghanistan 

 BODY:
A country that has suffered as long and as cruelly as Afghanistan needs sustained international help to restore the rudiments of normal life. Two decades of economic and political breakdown helped make Afghanistan an outlaw base for global terrorism. Unless the promises of long-term reconstruction assistance that followed last year's military defeat of the Taliban are kept, anarchy could return. 
 Last January donor nations promised $4.5 billion in economic aid over the next five years. Most of what has been delivered so far, however, has gone to immediate humanitarian needs. Far too little has yet been committed to reconstruction projects that will revive the war-shattered economy and allow hundreds of thousands of returning refugees to become self-sufficient. 
 Unlike many European countries, America has fully delivered the aid it promised. Washington should begin shifting its assistance from emergency relief to reconstruction. Regrettably, more than $150 million in badly needed funds for Afghanistan is now being delayed as part of the $5.1 billion spending package President Bush is holding up in his budget tussle with Congress.
In the first few months after the ouster of the Taliban, emergency aid saved many lives. Sixteen million of Afghanistan's 27 million people have benefited from some kind of international help since last October, mostly in the form of food shipments or money for refugee care and resettlement. In addition hundreds of schools, hospitals and clinics have been rebuilt and more than three million children have been returned to school. The shaky central government led by President Hamid Karzai would be weaker still without the foreign aid that provides 80 percent of its budget and pays civil servants' salaries.
What is needed now is aid directed at reviving agriculture and trade. Before the Soviet invasion in 1979, Afghanistan had a functioning economy. The war destroyed many of the irrigation canals that made agriculture possible in the parched countryside and forced farmers off their land and into refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran. Reclaiming that abandoned agricultural land would make Afghanistan less dependent on food relief shipments and would allow hundreds of thousands of returning refugees to resettle in the rural areas they left. Without such reclamation, many will drift back to cities where no work awaits them, while others will hire themselves out to warlords, a traditional outlet for young unemployed Afghan men. 
War also tore up the roads farmers need to transport goods to urban areas. With its road system rebuilt, Afghanistan could again reap commercial benefits from its location astride the crossroads of Central Asia. More money also needs to be channeled directly to the Kabul-based central government so that it can extend its authority throughout the country and control local warlords. 
With the security situation still fragile in much of rural Afghanistan, foreign donors have hesitated to involve themselves in road-building and land reclamation projects. But rebuilding roads and providing rural jobs will go far toward making the countryside more secure. 
Foreign donors were far too quick to abandon Afghanistan after Soviet troops left the country in 1989. This time they need to stay engaged until governmental authority is fully re-established and the economy begins to function again.

HEADLINE: Chinese Will Move Waters To Quench Thirst of Cities 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: DANJIANGKOU, China 

 BODY:
The booming cities of northern China are parched and constrained by a growing shortage of water. Yet in China's rainy south, the mighty Yangtze River pours vast volumes, unused, into the sea.
 So why not, Chinese leaders have long asked, cross the country with new canals, bringing that "wasted" water to where it is vitally needed for the country's progress? 
 In a world short of fresh water, one of the gravest challenges facing governments is that needs and supplies are often far apart. Now China, with water scarcity reaching the critical stage in sprawling showcase cities like Beijing and Tianjin, has embarked on one of history's great water-moving projects. 
At huge cost and great risk to the environment, the government plans to rechannel vast rivers of water from the Yangtze basin to the thirsty north, over three pathways of nearly 1,000 miles each. The official price tag of $58 billion, nearly half to be spent in the next eight years, is more than twice that of the Three Gorges Dam, China's most recent mega-project now nearing completion. 
Some officials speak of delivering new waters to a "green Beijing" in time for the 2008 Olympics, an indication of the political overtones of the project as well as the crash timetable. 
"We have to sacrifice so that people in Beijing can drink water," said Zhang Jize, a 32-year-old farmer and father of two daughters who is among 370,000 people the plan will uproot.
Such immense, centrally planned projects have been tried before, notably in Central Asia, where a Soviet-era plan has steadily drained the Aral Sea, turning what was one of the world's largest inland bodies of water into a salty desert and providing a vivid illustration of the dangers of bending nature to economic needs. 
But China, convinced of its future as a great power, believes the project is essential. Some have drawn parallels to the great water works of the United States, like the the Tennessee Valley Authority that spurred rural development beginning in the 1930's or, more appropriately, the canals that took northern waters to fuel fantastic growth in arid Southern California. But the Chinese project is on an even grander scale. 
Like China's construction of the Three Gorges Dam, which set off global debate, this latest venture raises a host of tough questions, including how to deliver clean water across one of the world's most polluted landscapes. 
Perhaps toughest of all, in a country where no good patch of land lies idle, is how to provide for those like Mr. Zhang and his family who will be moved.
For Mr. Zhang and many others who live around the Danjiangkou Reservoir -- a linchpin of the new project -- it is not the first time they are being displaced, and their travails parallel China's expanding ambition to meet its water needs. 
Some 30 years back, when Mr. Zhang was a toddler and the dam was first completed, he and his parents were sent from their fertile valley plot to a remote spot on the banks of the new lake, receiving little compensation for their troubles. 
"Life is too hard here," he recently told a visitor, gathering with his family in their house with walls of wood and packed earth, covered with old calendars and newspapers. 
As the government makes its plans for a new mass move, bitterness survives from those earlier rounds of resettlements. Party leaders know that the issue could be explosive if not handled with more care than during past projects, including the Three Gorges Dam project, which will eventually displace more than a million people.
Chinese officials have often glossed over the challenges in public, and most planning has taken place entirely behind closed doors. But they and their scientists are working feverishly on a host of issues as construction of two routes is expected to begin in the coming year. 
Northern cities have begun to raise water prices for consumers and reduce waste, vital steps if the project is to provide lasting solutions. Provinces, meanwhile, are already fighting over how the water will be shared, because some of the delivered waters will require expensive cleansing.
"If we're given smelly water and Beijing receives all the clean water, it will be bad for our image and our living standards," said a city engineer in Tianjin, a teeming city of 10 million that desperately needs new water but fears the expense.
The demand has become urgent throughout the densely populated north-central plains, home to metropolises like Tianjin and Beijing, with a population of 13 million, as well as dozens of smaller cities that are bursting with people and construction. 
Over-pumping of groundwater in the region has forced people to probe deeper for wells every year, and in some areas has caused disastrous sinking of land. Urban consumers take scarce water from farmers, while planners warn of smothering new restrictions on industry. 
Much of China's arid northwest, at the same time, is turning into a dust bowl, its land destroyed by drought and overuse and its residents caught in desperate poverty.

3 Routes and Numerous Detours
Each of the three routes envisioned to bring water to these thirsty areas has its own challenges. 
Of these, the western route is most tentative, with construction scheduled to start in 2010. It would channel water from upper tributaries of the Yangtze to China's arid, needy northwest. But as it takes water from Tibetan regions it may stir political controversy, and it poses severe engineering challenges and awesome costs. The current estimates are $36 billion for this spur alone. 
The eastern, coastal route is technically simple, though it will require 13 pumping stations, which will consume large amounts of electricity to lift water from near the mouth of the Yangtze to the higher north. It will save costs by following much of the same path as the ancient Grand Canal -- second only to the Great Wall as a wonder of Imperial China -- that once moved silk and rice from the south to Beijing. 
The main challenge is pollution. The route cuts across many of the world's most soiled river basins. Along the hundreds of miles of the canal that is still in use, it bustles with barges carrying sand, coal and other goods. Its shores are lined with primitive houseboats, home to hundreds of thousands of people who rely on the canal for work and waste disposal as well as living space. The waterway also receives untreated sewage from hundreds of nearby towns and villages and the effluence of thousands of factories.
"If you drink the water you get rashes and diarrhea," said Cui Xiao, 38, who had docked his sand barge at Pizhou, within sight of the waste of a chemical fertilizer factory that gushed into the stream. "You can't even use the canal water for washing."
Some scientists are quietly asking how the coastal route can ever affordably deliver water that will be safe enough even for industry, let alone drinking. 
The cleanup plans, to the extent they have been disclosed, stretch credibility. They include the forced closure of thousands of dirty factories that line the canal's route, many of which are owned by local governments that have evaded controls in the past. 
The government is also mobilizing to build sewage treatment plants in each of 119 counties along the canal, a leading water expert said, itself a mammoth undertaking in the hurried time frame. 
The people who live on the canal all expressed hope that the water project would give them an economic lift. But the government has not said what is to become of this decrepit flotilla and the multitudes who live on or near the canal.
Along the final, central route, officials say that pollution will not be a problem. But there are other challenges.
This plan calls for diverting water north from the Han River, a tributary of the Yangtze, by constructing a new canal. But to do so the Danjiangkou dam and reservoir will have to be raised, displacing about 300,000 villagers in Hubei and Henan Provinces, like Mr. Zhang, the farmer.
Even then, many engineers say, the reservoir will not hold enough water both to feed the north and to meet regional needs. Its waters will have to be replenished by a new feeder canal, built across mountains at enormous expense, to bring water from the new Three Gorges Dam -- in turn reducing its electrical capacity by 6 percent or more.

Waiting for Another Moving Day
Earlier this year, sign painters traveled along the banks of the Danjiangkou Reservoir and splashed a new slogan in big blue characters on village walls urging people to support "the project," alongside the usual appeals to limit births, trust in the Communist Party and pay taxes. 
Long aware of the water-transfer plans, hundreds of thousands of people near the reservoir have waited a decade or more in limbo, putting off home repairs or construction and sometimes postponing marriages. 
Now, with that day apparently approaching, many are fearful. 
Local television has carried announcements that people should prepare for orders to vacate homes, and county officials have taken a census of households and assessed property. But villagers still have heard nothing about the terms of the relocation.
There are not many options. The hilly region around the lake is badly overcrowded, and entire families live off less than an acre each. The new moves may cause destruction of forests and grasslands and will require costly efforts to bring safe drinking water, electricity and roads to those moved. 
In the 1970's, 270,000 people in rich valley lands had to make way for the reservoir as it was filled. Their compensation was paltry, if they received any at all. 
Many are still fuming. Rao Fumin, a 58-year-old man whose family was moved first in 1958 and then three more times, can hardly contain his fury. "We were moved around like prisoners," he said. 
His legs now crippled by arthritis, Mr. Rao lives with his sister near the foot of the Danjiangkou Dam itself, subsisting on a monthly $12 welfare payment. 
"We never see a cent of the resettlement money," he said. "All these city, county, town and village officials stuff the money into their own pockets." 
If he doesn't get more aid this year, he said, "I'll hang myself at the gateway of the Danjiangkou City Party Committee." 
The comments suggest the potential for fresh anger facing a government that in any case sees little choice but to push ahead with the plan. Even many of those who will be most affected, like Mr. Zhang, are resigned. 
"We don't know when or where we'll move, but we just hope we get some decent farmland," Mr. Zhang said, exchanging a nervous glance with his wife. "We're all just waiting to hear what will happen to us.
"This is central government policy," he added stoically, "so it must be a good thing for the country."

HEADLINE: Jackson Hole Outgrows Its Tiny, Busy Airport 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 26 

 BODY:
In the alpine splendor of the Teton range, where crickets flitter across the trails and fish splash around the Snake River, another, less natural, sound is never far away -- the mechanical buzz of airplanes ferrying people in and out of this enclave for the rich and famous.
 The Jackson Hole Airport is the only airport in the country entirely within a national park. It is high season here now, and that means that aircraft, from private seven-seaters to commercial 757's, are touching down at a regular clip. 
 Perhaps more than is the case in most cities, in Jackson, the airport is central to economic vitality. The town's spurt in growth parallels the introduction of jet service here in the early 1980's. Yet the airport, a low-slung affair with peaked roof lines evoking the jagged-edge mountains that stagger up behind it, remains one of the nation's tiniest. Experts say the runway, at 6,305 feet, is among the shortest in use at commercial airports. 
But because it is located within the Grand Teton National Park, the National Park Service has restricted the runway's extension. So while Jackson Hole, the valley that includes Jackson and covers much of the county, is growing and developing largely because of its airport, the airport cannot grow along with it.
That has caused tensions between the many residents whose livelihoods depend on tourists -- including some business owners who would welcome expansion -- and those who worry that the rapid growth could ruin the very appeal that draws people here in the first place. Already, the surge in affluence that the airport has made possible dramatizes the rift between the growing rich, many of whom own second homes here, and the local work force, who cannot afford to live here.
All this has not stopped the traffic. Private planes swarm the tarmac in a constant procession. Because Vice President Dick Cheney is vacationing at his home here for the month of August, Air Force Two is frequently in and out, backing up planes because the airspace must be secured.
Even more activity is promised by mid-December, as local businesses here start to subsidize several major airlines to the tune of $1.3 million to guarantee nonstop service from some of the country's biggest airports, including those that serve New York, Chicago and Atlanta. There is only limited nonstop service now. 
After hearing a presentation from George Larson, Jackson's airport manager, about new security measures that will require passengers to arrive two hours before their flights, Jerry DeFrance, president of the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce, was not terribly upset.
"Our problems are born of success, and those are a lot better than problems born of failure," he said. "A lot of communities would like to have our problems."
But there is rising concern here that unless these problems are managed, that success could turn sour.
"It raises questions when the community is pitching in $1.3 million to bring more people," said Carl Schneebech, a specialist in public land for the Jackson Hole Conservation Alliance. "At some point, are we killing the goose that is laying the golden egg?"
The boom here began in the mid-1980's, when jet service began. Since then, the population has doubled, to 18,000 in 2000, up from 9,000 in 1980.
The Chamber of Commerce has even produced a graph that shows a happy correlation between the per capita income of residents and the level of jet service. Per capita income was relatively steady in Jackson Hole until 1984. As more planes began arriving, it soared, from less than $20,000 in 1984 to more than $67,000 today -- more than triple the national average. Now, Teton County, which includes Jackson Hole, is the nation's richest, ahead of even Fairfield County, Conn., at $50,000.
Yet Jackson Hole's airfield, which began as an unpaved strip in 1930, remains modest. When Congress designated the surrounding Grand Tetons a national park in 1950, constraints were placed on the airfield, which was not paved until 1959. Pilots periodically overshoot the runway, as one did a few years ago in the middle of the night in a plane flying the actress Sandra Bullock.
While there has been talk over the years of extending the runway, a 50-year agreement struck in 1983 between the airport and the park restricts such expansions. In addition, many residents object to a longer runway, saying it would invite bigger jets, which would create more noise.
Could the airport move out of the park, to where its runway could be longer? That is not likely. Land values here are exorbitant. A full 97 percent of the land is in government hands, and the remaining 3 percent is tightly held.
To move the airport but keep it in Teton County would mean moving it farther south, away from the national park, but the valley becomes narrower and more populated, making air traffic more dangerous. This has led some to suggest moving it over the mountains to Idaho, but Jackson Hole is not about to let that happen. 
The real problem, to many here, is the abundance of private air service. Because of poor air service in the past, even the less-than-rich buy into time-shares on private jets. As recently as 1999, about 5,250 private planes landed here per year. By 2001, that number had climbed to 13,100.
Town leaders, unhappy about the noise, are irked at the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to regulate the private planes. There are no curfews on them, as there are on commercial jets, and no limit on their number or flight paths. 
The federal agency maintains that banning private aircraft would be discriminatory. 
Tony Jewett, director of the Northern Rockies regional office of the National Parks and Conservation Association, said owners of private airplanes represented a powerful lobby.
"The fact that Jackson is in this explosive growth stage and a huge number of people moving to Jackson are people of means and have fairly snapshot lifestyles where they have to get in and out of places quickly," Mr. Jewett said, "means there is a lot of economic pressure to accommodate them." 
He added, "But this means that anyone visiting the park has constant visual intrusions, with flight patterns right across the park, and noise intrusions, which interrupt one of the great park values, which is the natural sound-scape."
But even park officials recognize the value of the airport to the local economy as well as the necessity for safety. As a result, they have not objected to night lights and a small tower, which controls air traffic. 
Jonathan Schechter, executive director of the Charture Institute, which studies issues of growth and change in places of ecological significance, said there was no direct cause and effect between airplane business and income even though he created the graph comparing the two. But he said that better air service not only brought in more tourists but, combined with Wyoming's lack of an income tax, made Jackson Hole more attractive to people with the means to live anywhere.
Mr. Schechter said that their wealth has in turn made Jackson Hole less reliant on tourism. Over the last 10 years, white-collar jobs -- in finance, real estate, medicine and law -- have generated more income here than tourism. Financial services and investments account for more of residents' income than tourism and white-collar jobs combined.
But Bill Collins, director of planning and development for Teton County, said that two-thirds of the labor force made less than $30,000 a year, and most of these workers could not afford to live here. The median price of a single-family home is $560,000, twice the national average. "An economic polarization is occurring here," Mr. Collins said.
Still, many businesses here are built on tourism, and business owners say it is essential to attract more tourists, particularly as the ski industry consolidates and shrinks.
Jerry Blann, president of the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort, has been one of the main business organizers of the new contracts with the airlines, an arrangement found in other wealthy resorts, like Aspen and Vail. He is putting up $200,000 of the total $1.3 million to guarantee cash to Delta, United, Northwest and Continental to fly here nonstop. American is also servicing Jackson Hole but is doing so without a contract.
Mike Gierau, owner of Jedediah's restaurant, is putting up $1,800.
"There are 35 Realtors within a fork's throw of where we are now," Mr. Gierau said enthusiastically. "They're selling property to people who are buying plane tickets. And one reasons it's easier for them to sell property is because people can come here, especially if you have service from places like New York. Second-home-owners are going ga-ga over this."
Still, he has to compete for their business with his fellow restaurateurs. Because of that, he said, he is still hedging his bets.
"I give the pilots free breakfast," he said, laughing. "And many a time I've flown in and on final approach they'll say, 'Boy, if you get a chance, eat at Jedediah's. It's an awful nice place.' "

HEADLINE: 16 Banks Pledge Continued Commitment to Brazil 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Brazil's top economic officials persuaded 16 international banks yesterday to maintain their lending at current levels, a move that relieved some but hardly all the anxiety in that country's financial markets.
 The banks, including Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase of the United States as well as Deutsche Bank and Banco Santander Central Hispano of Europe, pledged to keep up their lending after meeting in Manhattan with Brazil's finance minister and the president of the Brazil's central bank. 
 What the banks left unsaid is that most had already cut back sharply on their lending as Brazil began edging closer to a financial meltdown. 
Earlier this month, the International Monetary Fund negotiated a $30 billion bailout with the Brazilian government. But that package is aimed only at avoiding a default by the government, and it did not solve the credit problems of Brazilian manufacturers and exporters.
Brazilian companies have $8 billion to $10 billion in debt coming due by the end of the year, and analysts estimate that only about 40 percent of the medium- and long-term loans have been rolled over or refinanced in recent months.
The situation affecting exporters, who play a pivotal role in shoring up Brazil's financial position, may be even tighter. Alexandre Schwartsman, an economist at BBA, a Brazilian bank in Sao Paulo, said anecdotal evidence suggested that only 30 percent of Brazilian export credits were being renewed earlier this summer.
In a statement after yesterday's meeting, the banks stressed their "continued support" for Brazil and vowed to "sustain their general level of business.
"The tone of the meeting was very positive," said William Rhodes, senior vice chairman of Citigroup, in an interview.
Amilio Fraga, president of Brazil's central bank, said the meeting was "better than we had expected."
Investors appeared encouraged, but not jubilant. Brazil's beleaguered currency, the real, climbed slightly when the news first came out but ended the day almost unchanged. The value of Brazilian bonds climbed slightly.
Mr. Schwartsman of BBA said the banks' cautious support might have been the most that was realistic to expect. 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 28, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about a pledge by 16 banks to continue lending to Brazil misstated the given name of the country's central bank president. He is Arminio Fraga, not Amilio.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
New York Waits For Decision By the U.S.O.C.

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
New York City's expensive campaign to become the host city for the 2012 Summer Olympics could advance today, or end quickly, when a United States Olympic Committee panel in Chicago chooses two finalists from a field of four to be the country's candidate.
 The process will conclude Nov. 3, and the International Olympic Committee will select the host city in 2005. 
 For New York, which has budgeted the most of any city, $13 million, to earn the U.S.O.C.'s favor, the desire to play host to the Olympics has taken on the force of official government policy: Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, founded NYC2012 in 1995 and is still its principal booster.
Jay Kriegel, the executive director of NYC2012, said little time was being spent worrying about losing to Houston, San Francisco or Washington, the other cities being considered in the United States. 
"We're very focused," he said. "We're doing what we can -- planning, talking to our team. We're taking nothing for granted.
"We feel terrific about our bid."
The plan features the use of athletic facilities that could be reached by ferries or by the railroad.
Dan Knise, the president of Washington DC 2012, said: "I think everybody's a little nervous. It's a big decision for our city and our region."
The four cities have submitted elaborate plans and have been visited twice by members of the U.S.O.C. task force. They then submitted revised plans or addenda. Washington and San Francisco each scaled back the geographic scope of their bids.
The 13 members of the task force have scored the cities on 14 criteria -- from the financial plans to transportation to arenas and the Olympic village -- but until today at 8 a.m. Central time, the group has never compared one city with the other. Only 10 members will vote. 
"We've done detailed numerical scores on each city, but right now, everyone is at par," Charles H. Moore, the chairman of the task force, said. He will lead the group through an analysis of the cities' scores, the cities' strengths and weaknesses and their international appeals.
"I spent time talking to the United States delegates to the I.O.C., and asked them what would you look for in a city, what would influence your vote?" Moore said.
Ultimately, Moore said, the U.S.O.C.'s choice will come down to which city is the most likely to win against foreign competitors, which include Moscow, Paris, Toronto, Rio de Janeiro, London, Milan and Tel Aviv. "The most important thing is the international appeal and strategy," Moore said.
Moore insisted that the task force could not make its decision until its scheduled seven-hour meeting today, and that any reports that it had already picked the two finalists were premature. 
Last week, the U.S.O.C. debunked a Washington Post report that claimed Washington and San Francisco were chosen.
New York, Washington and San Francisco are considered world cities with myriad tourist attractions and grand stories to tell. (Whether the terror attacks of Sept. 11 will create sympathy for New York and Washington is uncertain.) Despite Houston's size, it is viewed by Olympic observers as having a less compelling tale.
"The people deciding where to take the Olympics is the I.O.C., not the general public," said George DeMontrond III, the chairman of Houston 2012. "They're looking at what's best for the Olympic movement, like having a budget that would be profitable and having the most venues built."
Moore said: "If any member of the task force spoke out of turn, it's only one person's opinion and it wouldn't be the end of the world." But he added that it would not be definitive.
In their bids, the cities compete over financial surpluses and the housing and athletic facilities they would leave behind to the public. Or they boast of riverfront Olympic villages (like New York's, in Queens, opposite the United Nations) or those that need not be built, like the dormitories Washington DC 2012 would use at the University of Maryland. And of new stadiums, like Reliant Stadium and Minute Maid Field in Houston.
Houston's bid contemplates a $90 million overhaul of the Astrodome into an Olympic track and field stadium "that would be a one-of-a-kind facility that can be used to compete in all types of weather," DeMontrond said. 
For detractors who view Houston as another version of hot, humid Atlanta, which was the host to the 1996 Summer Games, he vowed that air conditioning would be plentiful.
"And our weather this summer has been no worse than New York's," he said.

HEADLINE: Uphill Climb to Sustainability 

 BODY:
 To the Editor:
Re "Managing Planet Earth": Developing sustainably will require the right market signals, nothing less than a new governance structure with new rules of trade, fair prices for commodities, elimination of unpayable debts plus new incentives -- funds, subsidies and tax breaks -- to foster farming diversity and selective forestry and to usher in alternative technologies.

DR. PAUL R. EPSTEIN
Boston

The writer is associate director of the Center for Health and the Global Environment at the Harvard Medical School.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Price Tag and Local Politics Damp Interest in Hershey

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Paging Willie Wonka. Interest in the auction for Hershey Foods may be waning.
 Some potential suitors for Hershey, which put itself up for sale last month despite a storm of protest from local officials and employees, appear to be balking at the company's high asking price and the controversy surrounding the auction. 
 Cadbury Schweppes has already told Hershey that it will probably not submit an offer, according to executives close to the discussions. Nestle and Kraft Foods, the two most interested remaining bidders, are wavering about whether they can afford to meet Hershey's asking price -- more than $11 billion -- without significantly diluting their earnings, the executives said. 
Some board members of the trust that controls Hershey are reconsidering the auction, too. Without a lucrative sale price, some board members have begun privately discussing possibly ending the auction and buying back stock instead. Indeed, according to one board member, the political controversy could offer an excuse for the trust to halt the auction without having to acknowledge publicly that it could not draw the asking price. 
Besides opposition from officials and employees, Hershey's sale is also being complicated by a rival auction that has not yet begun.
Pfizer plans to put its Adams confectionary unit, which makes Trident, Dentyne, Certs and Halls, up for sale this fall, hoping to receive bids from many of the potential buyers of Hershey.
Adams could bring $4 billion or more, so some suitors are considering whether to bid for Hershey now or wait to try to buy Adams. "We only have so much gun power," said an executive close to one company contemplating the options. "We've got to decide which is the right shot."
Pfizer had hoped to begin its auction this summer but decided to wait until after Hershey completed its sale. Indeed, Pfizer's Adams unit briefly considered bidding for pieces of Hershey but decided the price was too high and that such a deal would complicate selling itself later, executives close to Pfizer said.
Analysts said Cadbury might be holding back on a bid for Hershey so it could pursue Adams.
Meanwhile, Nestle and Kraft Foods, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, continue to negotiate with Hershey, according to the executives, though both have lowered their valuations after reviewing Hershey's books in the last several weeks.
Executives close to Nestle and Kraft said the economics of a deal for Hershey worked only if it was valued at $10 billion or less. USA Today reported yesterday that Nestle had made an $11.5 billion offer for Hershey, but a spokesman for Nestle called the report a "market fantasy." Shares of Hershey surged $1.77 on the report, to $76.80.
To be sure, the potential suitors for Hershey and Adams may just be posturing, hoping to reach a deal with a lower price. But one member of Hershey's controlling trust recently questioned whether a sale would happen at all.
"The board is not committed to sell," William H. Alexander, a board member, wrote in a letter to a friend that became public last week. "It is only one of several options being explored," he wrote, adding, "Once and for all we are going to find out if anyone exists who will pay a sufficient premium to justify a sale."
In the letter, Mr. Alexander said, "My best guess is that the supposed premium for control will be offset by discounts for the Kit Kat license and the social constraints." Under the licensing agreement that Hershey has with Nestle to sell its Kit Kat and Rolo brands in North America, those rights could revert to Nestle even if Hershey is sold to another company, cutting into Hershey's asking price.
The social constraints mentioned by Mr. Alexander refer to the political jockeying in Hershey, Pa., to prevent a deal. On Friday, Mike Fisher, the Republican attorney general now running for governor, filed a motion in Dauphin County with the Orphans' Court, which has jurisdiction over the state's charitable trusts, to issue a temporary restraining order to block the sale of Hershey.
"We think it's time the court put a halt to this sale," Mr. Fisher said in a written statement. "We are concerned about the speed in which the Hershey Trust seems to be moving forward with their plans."
Lawyers for the trust responded in court yesterday, questioning the attorney general's jurisdiction in the matter. While acknowledging that the state has jurisdiction over charitable trusts, the lawyers contend that it has much more limited oversight of Hershey Foods, which is incorporated in Delaware.
The lawyers said a temporary injunction against a sale could cause "gross and severe harm and injury" to the auction process, leading to a drop in the company's share price and harm to the trust's beneficiary, the Milton Hershey School.
The judge in the case scheduled arguments for Sept. 3 on Mr. Fisher's motion.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg News Apologizes To Top Singapore Officials 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
As an entrepreneur-turned-politician, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken pains to avoid being accused of conflicts of interest in the way he runs New York City. Now, the company that made him a billionaire is in trouble for accusing this city-state's politicians of conflicts of interest in the way they run business.
 Over the weekend, the news and financial information company Bloomberg L.P. issued a public apology and agreed to pay damages and legal costs to three top Singapore leaders for publishing what it admitted were defamatory statements about the appointment of the daughter-in-law of the former prime minister as head of a powerful government investment arm, Temasek Holdings. The offending remarks appeared in a column Bloomberg published earlier this month on its subscription-based information service and on its Web site. The column, by Patrick Smith, was about the role of Singapore's government in the country's biggest companies. 
 In Singapore, which adheres to the British common-law interpretation of libel in which a defendant journalist or publication has the burden of proving the truth of what has been reported, ruling politicians here have never been shy about suing for libel. But the latest case comes at an awkward time. Faced with declining competitiveness as a manufacturing center compared with countries like China, Singapore is trying to overturn its reputation as an intolerant, state-run economy where most fresh ideas come from the top.
Instead, Singapore aspires to become a center for innovation, arts and the media -- but not, apparently, if it comes at the expense of its reputation for clean government. "They're still thin-skinned on this," said David L. Cohen, director of macroeconomic analysis at Standard & Poor's MMS International.
Set up in the mid-1970's to manage the government's corporate investments, Temasek (pronounce teh-MAH-sek) wields enormous influence in Singapore's economy. The companies in its stable represent at least one-fifth of Singapore's market capitalization and it has controlling stakes in Singapore Airlines and Singapore Telecommunications.
In May, Temasek announced that a board member, Ho Ching, would become its executive director. Ms. Ho is married to Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, son of the founding prime minister and now senior minister, Lee Kuan Yew. In its apology, Bloomberg said its article had implied that Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong had put the Lee family's interests above the country's in allowing Ms. Ho's appointment, and that her husband and father-in-law were guilty of nepotism. Lawyers for the three men accused Bloomberg and Mr. Smith of acting maliciously. The article has been removed from Bloomberg's Web site and subscription service. A complete copy could not be obtained.
"We admit and acknowledge that these allegations are false and completely without foundation," Bloomberg wrote in its apology to Mr. Goh and the two Lees, which was issued on the company's subscription service and its Web site. Bloomberg acknowledged that the article, as written, could be understood to mean that Ms. Ho's appointment was made "not on merit, but in order to indulge the interests of the Lee family, or for some other corrupt motive."
The company has until Wednesday to propose a settlement acceptable to the three men or risk having the case brought before a Singapore court.
Christine Taylor, a spokeswoman for Bloomberg in New York, would not comment on the company's decision to publish the apology or agree to a settlement. She said Mayor Bloomberg would not be personally involved in coming up with a settlement figure. The mayor stepped down last year from his management role. With his own finances still under examination by New York's Conflicts of Interest Board, Mr. Bloomberg has recused his company from tax breaks intended to keep corporations from leaving Manhattan in the wake of Sept. 11. 
The editor of Bloomberg's news service, Matthew Winkler, is scheduled to visit Singapore Tuesday as part of a trip around Asia. Bloomberg has more than 30 journalists stationed in Singapore, where it has had an office since 1990.
Ms. Ho's appointment is controversial in Singapore, but not necessarily because of her relatives. When she was appointed, officials said her family connections played no part. An electrical engineer with a master's degree from Stanford University, Ms. Ho worked her way up through the ranks of Singapore's state-owned military conglomerate and was a board member there for 10 years before joining Temasek.
Instead, executives, economists and fund managers have expressed concern about Ms. Ho's announced intention to exert a greater role in Temasek's companies. While Ms. Ho has stressed the need to extract greater shareholder value, many executives had hoped Temasek would slowly withdraw, eventually privatizing its stakes.
Singapore's boardrooms, meanwhile, are full of former government figures, some of them relatives or associates of the Lee family. The government is seeking highly educated professionals from abroad. In the meantime, officials explain, Singapore's population of four million people leaves it with a limited pool of talent from which to draw.

HEADLINE: At the U.S. Open, a Mayoral Return 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Nixon went to China. Gorbachev visited the Statue of Liberty. And last night, Bloomberg took in a little tennis at the United States Open.
 The idea that a mayor would attend a major international sports event in his own backyard would not normally qualify as big news, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's trip to the Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens, reflected a policy change of sorts: his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, refused to attend the tournaments for eight years. 
 "It is my pleasure to welcome everyone to New York City, home of the highest attended annual sporting event: the U.S. Open," Mayor Bloomberg said at the opening ceremony. "This is always a terrific time in New York City, with the last grand slam of the tennis season kicking off right here in Flushing, Queens."
The Open, in fact, has been something of a political football, or tennis ball, around City Hall for nearly a decade. It all began when former Mayor David N. Dinkins, concerned about the threat of businesses and institutions leaving New York City, negotiated a deal to build a new stadium for the Open.
Many city officials and fiscal experts found that the tennis stadium agreement, which was financed without city money, was better for the city than the stadium deals it struck in the past with the Yankees and the Mets. Mr. Giuliani objected strenuously to one clause in the contract, though -- the provision holding the city liable for fines if airplanes should fly over the tennis center during matches and distract the players.
The city has never had to pay any such fines, but Mr. Giuliani, who was always more a Yankees fan than a tennis fan and was never a big fan of Mr. Dinkins, said the city should not be held liable and warned that the deal placed unnecessary demands on the already crowded airspace around the city's airports. So he stayed away.
Then Mr. Bloomberg succeeded Mr. Giuliani this year and found that the ball was in his court. Mr. Bloomberg appeared on Mr. Dinkins's radio show in March and proclaimed the tennis complex in Queens "the only good athletic sports stadium deal, not just in New York, but in the country," and declared that he would attend the Open if asked. 
Mr. Dinkins, an avid tennis fan, said yesterday that he was delighted by the change in mayoral tennis policy. "I'm ecstatic," he said.
The new mayor's sports allegiances are not exactly clear. 
He likes to play golf, and he even took part in a charity tournament the day the city missed its first budget deadline this June. From time to time he watches one of his daughters in an equestrian competition. During the election he survived a whispering campaign that he might be -- gasp -- a Red Sox fan, and now that the city is wooing the 2012 Olympics, he has become an avid sports booster, even donning a skin-tight yellow zip-up biker shirt to kick off a bike race in Lower Manhattan earlier this month. 
"He may not be a big tennis fan," Mr. Dinkins said of Mr. Bloomberg, "but he certainly knows the economic impact of the U.S. Open."

A subheading yesterday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's attendance at the United States Open tennis tournament misidentified the Queens neighborhood where it is being held. The stadium is in Flushing Meadows, not Forest Hills.

HEADLINE: World Development Forum Begins With a Rebuke 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of officials, environmentalists and advocates for the poor converged on this old mining city today to devise an ambitious blueprint to promote development while protecting natural resources. 
 Participants from all over the world flocked to the United Nations' World Summit on Sustainable Development in flowing African robes, Indian saris and pinstriped suits. They celebrated the spirit of global solidarity and vowed to hammer out a plan to protect rain forests, to clean polluted air and to help millions of people escape from poverty. 
 More than 100 presidents and prime ministers, including most European leaders, will attend this summit meeting to show their commitment to their new pledges. But many here are expressing doubts about the developed nations' sincerity and are especially critical of the fact that President Bush, the leader of the world's biggest economy and its largest polluter, has decided not to attend. 
American officials here today said they were committed to the meeting's agenda and would soon announce investments of more than $970 million in projects to provide access clean water to Africa and other developing nations. They said they want to focus on offering concrete support for specific projects instead of getting mired in debates about the targets and time frames for foreign aid that the developing nations are seeking.
But as participants gathered in the gleaming convention center here, nearly everyone was haunted by the failures of the past.
Ten years ago, the world's leaders left the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro with an ambitious agenda that is mostly remembered by the participants here as a string of broken promises and squandered opportunities. In his opening speech today, President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa said pointedly that the world had stood by and allowed environmental degradation and deepening poverty to threaten the future of the Earth.
Mr. Mbeki said leaders had failed to muster the political will to reduce poverty and to protect natural resources despite the promises made in Rio de Janeiro. He urged officials to develop a plan during this 10-day meeting to rescue a world increasingly characterized by dying lakes, retreating forests, global warming and desperately poor people.
"Poverty, underdevelopment, inequality within and among countries, together with the worsening global ecological crisis, sum up the dark shadow under which most of the world lives," Mr. Mbeki said in his speech. "It is no secret that the global community has, as yet, not demonstrated the will to implement the decisions it has freely adopted." 
"We need to take stock of the inertia of the past decade and agree on very clear and practical measures that will help us to deal decisively with all the challenges that we face," he added. "This is the central task of this summit."
The officials here applauded his words. But as the day wore on and negotiators huddled in the ballrooms, it was clear that coming up with a strong plan would be very difficult.
No new treaties will be signed here. Instead, negotiators are focusing on the link between poverty and environmental degradation and on how to spur growth in poor countries while protecting the environment. 
But there are deep disagreements between rich and poor nations about how to achieve those goals.
Poor countries say they need to improve their economies before they will be in a position to protect their natural resources. They want wealthy nations to provide aid to developing countries equal to 0.7 percent of the wealthy nations' gross national products. They also want the wealthy nations to reduce or eliminate tariffs on agricultural goods from poor countries and, by 2015, to reduce by half the number of people who lack access to sanitation. 
Officials from the United States and the European Union have refused to make commitments for time frames to eliminate agricultural subsidies, which protect their farmers from foreign competition. "We do not see Johannesburg as a place to have these negotiations," said Catherine Day of the European Union at a news conference today.
The European Union is willing to discuss setting targets for increasing foreign assistance to the poor and for converting to renewable energy sources, but the United States opposes such measures.
"I think goals are important, but they're only lofty rhetoric without the commitment of resources," said John F. Turner, the assistant secretary of state for oceans and international environmental and scientific affairs. 
"The opportunity here is for partners to start committing resources in these critical areas to reduce poverty and ensure a more sustainable future," Mr. Turner said. "That's what we ought to be focused on." 
But officials from developing nations said the wealthy countries were being inflexible. "What's in there for us?" asked one official, who supports specific targets for foreign aid. "We're not advancing at all." 
Nearly 25 percent of the summit meeting's action plan remained contested today. As diplomats scrambled for consensus, some officials warned that the meeting might produce little more than reaffirmations of old promises. 
Environmentalists and advocates for the poor are already vowing to march through the streets by the thousands on Saturday to ensure that the link between poverty and environmental decay remains high on the agenda. Much of their anger is directed at President Bush.
Last year, President Bush upset many leaders when he rejected a treaty negotiated in Kyoto, Japan, which set targets for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. 
Marcel Furtado, a Brazilian representative of the advocacy group Greenpeace, said both developing and developed countries were to blame for the failure of pledges made in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.
Mr. Furtado said many delegates had learned from the failures of the past. He said they resented the United States and the European Union, to some extent, for blocking efforts to infuse this meeting's action plan with new and concrete commitments. "We have a job to do, which is to deliver change," he said. "It looks like the real issues are not making it into the document."
Klaus Toepfer, the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, urged negotiators to strive for consensus, no matter how difficult the negotiations become. No one, he said, can afford to give up. 
"The eyes of the world are upon us here waiting for signs that we are able to bridge our differences," he said. "The time has come to translate our political commitment into action."

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-9

Cheney Says Nuclear Peril Justifies Attack on Iraq
Vice President Dick Cheney presented the administration's most forceful and comprehensive rationale for attacking Iraq, warning that Saddam Hussein would "fairly soon" have nuclear weapons. Administration officials said Mr. Cheney's views mirrored those of President Bush, and were part of an ongoing campaign to persuade the allies, Congress and the American public about the administration's plans for what it calls regime change in Iraq. The officials said Mr. Bush is expected to discuss Iraq in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 12. A1

The Defense Department is notifying more than 14,000 reservists that they may be required to extend their duty, a move seen as a contingency for possible action against Iraq. A8

Giant Water Project in China
China, with water scarcity reaching the critical stage in sprawling showcase cities like Beijing and Tianjin, has embarked on one of history's great water-moving projects. At huge cost -- $58 billion -- the government plans to rechannel water from the Yangtze basin to the thirsty north, over three pathways of nearly 1,000 miles each. A1

Forum Opens in Johannesburg
Thousand of people flocked to the United Nations' World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg to devise an ambitious blueprint to promote development while protecting natural resources. But doubts remain about the sincerity of the more than 100 world leaders who will attend, particularly because President Bush, the leader of the world's biggest economy and its largest polluter, will not attend. Push to Secede in Patagonia
There is an increasingly restive movement to detach the southernmost region of South America, rich in oil and minerals, from the economic disaster that is the rest of Argentina. A1

Pope Drops Philippine Trip
Pope John Paul II has decided not to make a trip to a religious meeting in the Philippines in January, primarily because of his health. A4

NATIONAL A10-14

U.S. Appeals Court Rules Secret Hearings Are Illegal
The federal appeals court in Cincinnati declared that the Bush administration acted illegally in holding hundreds of deportation hearings in secret based only on the government's assertion that the people involved may have links to terrorism. The decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit is the first major appellate ruling on the government's legal tactics in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. A1

New Tools in Anthrax Inquiry
The F.B.I. will re-enter a quarantined tabloid newspaper office in Boca Raton, Fla., where last year's anthrax attacks were first discovered, using fresh techniques to search for new clues. The anthrax is thought to have entered the building in a letter, but the letter was never found. A13

Blood Test for Weapons Expert
An offer by Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, a biological weapons expert, to provide a blood sample to the F.B.I. could bear strongly on his guilt or innocence in the anthrax attacks last year, but any results would probably not be conclusive. A13

DNA Proof Frees Detroit Man
A Detroit man who confessed to the rape and murder of a 16-year-old girl in 1984 was freed after DNA evidence proved he did not commit the crime. Mr. Loyd, who served more than 17 years in prison, is the 110th person to be exonerated because of DNA evidence. A10

Singer Inches Closer to Space
The singer Lance Bass of the group 'N Sync began a week of training at NASA's Johnson Space Center in a bid to become the first entertainer in space. He joined four astronauts -- three Russians and a Belgian -- for orientation training to board the International Space Station, even though his trip is not assured. A California entertainment company, Destiny Productions, has been lining up sponsors to pay for the estimated $20 million cost of his flight. A14

Replacing a Lost Spacecraft
NASA should replace a comet-exploring spacecraft apparently destroyed in a rocket-firing accident with a duplicate to continue the mission, project managers suggested. A14

Chancellor Adds Two Days To the Coming School Year
Chancellor Joel I. Klein, in his first attempt to improve instruction for New York City schoolchildren, has added two days to the coming school year. The last-minute change is on top of a decision made earlier this year to extend teacher workdays by 100 minutes a week. Under a new contract agreement, teachers will spend half of the additional time on training and half on instruction. A1

More Getting 9/11 FEMA Aid
Since late June, when it overhauled its programs to assist New Yorkers devastated by the Sept. 11 attack, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has granted more money to nearly as many people needing help with their mortgage or rent than it did in the previous nine months. The agency has eased its eligibility criteria, to include more New Yorkers outside of Lower Manhattan. B1

Bloomberg's trip to the Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens, reflects a policy change of sorts: his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, refused to attend the tournaments for eight years.
