HEADLINE: Next Big Health Debate: How to Help Uninsured 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Concerned that millions of workers are losing their health insurance coverage at a time when health costs are surging, employers and Congressional leaders say the next great health care debate will be over how to help the uninsured.
 Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, an influential moderate Democrat, and leaders of the nation's largest pension plans are trying to drum up support for universal health insurance, a proposal that has received little attention, except from labor unions and liberals, since the collapse of the Clintons' health plan. 
 The House Republican leaders -- Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Dick Armey, the majority leader, who is retiring -- have been working on a package of less sweeping measures, including tax credits for the uninsured, in hopes of defusing the issue before the Congressional elections this fall.
Kate Sullivan, health policy director of the United States Chamber of Commerce, predicts that the issue will heat up next month when the Census Bureau announces the number of uninsured for last year, which may climb above 40 million -- from 38.4 million in 2000 -- and when the Kaiser Family Foundation reports the latest double-digit increases in health costs.
On costs, "the 2003 and 2004 projections are going to be much worse than the 2002 projections," said Helen Darling, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, a group of large employers. 
One of the nation's largest purchasers of health care, the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, which covers 1.2 million people, recently agreed to 25 percent increases in health premiums for next year. The state's $1.58 billion in spending for the Calpers health budget is expected to double in three years, said William Crist, an economist who is president of Calpers. 
As retirees are forced to spend more of their funds, higher payments for health care "are essentially taking away pensions," he said. Mr. Crist, who said he was "trying to get support for coalitions working toward a political base for universal coverage," recently sent invitations to other big state pension plans to join the National Coalition on Health Care, a Washington-based group that favors universal insurance.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts Group Insurance Commission, the New York State Teachers' Retirement System and the New York employees retirement fund -- which is run by H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and candidate for governor -- have all joined the coalition.
Paying for the uninsured is making health care even more expensive for private employers and government programs. Corporations, consumers and taxpayers end up covering the escalating health costs of people who lost jobs in the economic slowdown or who risk going without expensive insurance. 
"The uninsured should be a big issue in the coming year," said Bruce E. Bradley, director of managed care plans at General Motors. 
Adding to the urgency, employers are passing along more of those costs to workers and retirees, and they are increasingly angry and frustrated about those costs.
"We need to do something about the coming meltdown in health care financing," said Larry Atkins, coordinator of the Corporate Health Care Coalition, which includes big companies that supported the Clinton health plan in 1994. "I think the issue is going to pop up in the 2002 elections."
At the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research center, Robert Moffett, a health policy expert, said: "The climate is increasingly ripe for a re-examination of old ideas about health insurance." Heritage is promoting its own longstanding proposal for universal coverage, to be financed by tax credits.
Lack of, or inadequate, coverage is cited along with problems with Medicare as the two "most important health care issues for government action" in a public opinion survey published on the Internet this month by Health Affairs, a policy journal. 
"These findings suggest that this issue may emerge as an important one in the post-2002 Congressional election term," said the survey director, Robert J. Blendon, a researcher at the Harvard School of Public Health. 
Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, said incremental or piecemeal measures still had the best chance of paring the numbers of uninsured. He suggested "a combination of something like medical savings accounts, tax incentives and refundable credits for individual insurance policies."
But Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader, said recently that "many of us have concluded that incremental approaches to health care are not the solution."
A Senate aide said Democrats were expected to work on "a dual track -- seeking to expand the Child Health Plus subsidies to parents," as New York and a few other states have done, as well as "laying down markers for a debate next year on universal coverage."
Labor unions, which have long supported universal coverage, are preparing for tough bargaining over health benefits in the coming months and possibly strikes, said Gerald Shea, assistant to the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney.
"Wages are being traded for continuing health coverage," Mr. Shea said. Union workers at Hershey Foods walked out for seven weeks in the spring over a demand by the company that employees pay more for their health benefits.
Rob McGarrah, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. senior policy aide, said, "Universal coverage is back on the table."
Senator Breaux, who headed a bipartisan commission on overhauling Medicare and is active in the politically charged debate over a Medicare prescription drug benefit, has been discussing approaches to universal coverage with a number of colleagues, including Mr. Grassley and Senator George V. Voinovich, a conservative Republican from Ohio. 
As Mr. Breaux noted, coverage is available now for the elderly in Medicare, for veterans from the Department of Veterans Affairs, for the poor under Medicaid and for millions of workers in employer-sponsored health plans. 
"As a nation, it is very important to have national insurance for everybody," he said in an interview. 
Each existing program has "its own bureaucracy and rules and regulations and duplication of the others," he said, adding: "We need to get a lot more younger and healthy people in the insurance pool, hopefully reduce the costs for the people who have insurance now."
Existing programs could be reorganized and continued, he suggested, with the government making sure that health care is "delivered properly and also that it is paid for." He mentioned subsidies for low-income people that would be adjusted according to income.
Both companies and their employees get tax advantages for their health costs, he noted, saying: "There is a lot of money in the system already. I think we can rearrange it and spend it more wisely."
Deductions for medical expenses reduce state and federal tax collections by $140 billion a year, Mr. Moffett of the Heritage Foundation said.
The White House and many Republicans, including Senator Grassley and Representative Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, want to provide tax credits, which they say would make insurance affordable for many uninsured people. 
Democrats in the Senate have opposed the credits. "Tax credits would undermine the good employment-based coverage on which most Americans depend, forcing them to rely on the often-volatile individual insurance market," Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said.
In a compromise within the recently passed trade bill, however, both House and Senate voted to include a modest tax credit measure and new federal money to help pay for health care for workers who lose jobs as a consequence of future trade pacts.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Opening Western Eyes to a View of Islam

BYLINE:  By DAVID SCHOENBAUM; David Schoenbaum is the author of "The United States and the State of Israel" and teaches history at the University of Iowa.

 BODY:
MILITANT ISLAM REACHES AMERICA
By Daniel Pipes
309 pages. W. W. Norton. $25.95.
 There was a time when America was actually rather popular in what we now call the Islamic world. But that was a time when America exported oil, few Americans had ever seen a Muslim and vice versa. 
 Then came World War II and the historical equivalent of continental drift. Europe receded, by choice and otherwise. Post-colonial nation builders jostled in the newly opened space. Israel was created. The cold war overflowed its European banks. Hot wars proliferated. Populations soared. Economies scrambled and failed to keep up. America ascended to megapower and learned to love imported oil. Globalization spread like kudzu.
Meanwhile America acquired an increasingly visible and audible Muslim minority, part diaspora from all over the Islamic world, part African-American in growing numbers. Then, out of a literally clear blue sky, came Sept. 11.
"Here and now begins a new era in world history, and you can say that you were there," said Goethe of the Battle of Valmy in 1792, the first important engagement in the French Revolutionary Wars. Millions of Americans think of Sept. 11 in much the same way.
Wrong, says Daniel Pipes in this anthology of random pieces going back to 1990. That Tuesday from hell was not the beginning, let alone the end of history. Nor should the hijackers, their shadowy handlers and Osama bin Laden be taken for the authentic voice of Islam, the religion and civilization, with 1.3 billion adherents and nearly 1,400 years of history. On the contrary, says Mr. Pipes. What hit us on Sept. 11 was Islamism, the ideology, a product of relatively recent civilizational discontents in a swath of the world where a glorious past has somehow led to a futureless present.
He estimates the ideology's hard core at 70,000 in some 50 countries. To this he adds a penumbra of fellow travelers, accounting for 10 to 15 percent of the world's Muslims.
As a professional historian and trained Arabist, he regards Islamism as a global menace. But he finds its zeal, animus, organization and technology thoroughly modern and familiar, despite the conspicuous display of beards, caftans and turbans.
For Mr. Pipes the Islamist version of Islam is just another modernizing anachronism. To him its churchlike hierarchy, quasi-papal ayatollahs, quasi-sabbatarian Friday, even unexpected hints of feminism, look remarkably like unacknowledged Westernisms. The real analogues of Islamism, in Mr. Pipes's view, are 20th-century products, too: the great totalitarian heresies, fascism and Communism.
One of the book's most interesting pieces compares Western responses to Islamism and Communism. Mr. Pipes makes a strong case that Left and Right have approached both with impressive consistency. But sturdy, well-connected neo-conservative that he is, he argues just as forthrightly that the Left has been consistently wrong.
His policy guidelines are accordingly simple. Respect and support the moderate Muslims, who are Islam's silent majority. Don't push democracy where Islamists are likely to win. Don't try to appease. It can't be done.
Well, maybe. But is it that simple? Did we do ourselves a favor during the Reagan and first Bush administrations by cozying up to secular Iraq during its war with clerical Iran, and looking away when a bankrupt Algerian military dictatorship canceled an election for fear of losing it, at a time when we were incidentally insisting on free elections in post-Communist Europe?
And aren't there a few self-fulfilling propositions here? Does one size really fit all? Or are we creating solidarity by denying differences between natural adversaries?
And hasn't Islamist success something to do with the failure of secularizing regimes, from liberal to fascist, in a variety of Arab and Muslim countries, going back at least a century? And if so, might not some of the hostility toward us have to do with our support for some of these regimes?
And haven't regimes we call moderate helped Islamists seize the oppositional high ground by stifling alternative opposition: for example, the disgraceful treatment of the Egyptian-American sociologist Saad Eddin Ibrahim by President Mubarak of Egypt, or of Malaysia's former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad?
On the other hand Mr. Pipes also notes that the "war on terror" is confusingly, even dangerously open-ended, when our war is really with radical, politicized Islamic fundamentalism; that we are not engaged in a "clash of civilizations," because Islamists are as dangerous to fellow Muslims as they are to us; and that the containment policy that served us so well in the cold war can work again.

HEADLINE: Australia Lowers Fees Involving Credit Cards 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Australia's central bank ordered sweeping changes in the way credit card businesses operate today. The bank said the changes would lower costs and promote competition.
 The proposal was made over the strong objections of the two main credit card brands, Visa International and MasterCard International. 
 The central bank ordered that the interchange fees that banks charge one another to process card transactions be cut by about 40 percent, to the range of 0.55 to 0.6 cents on the dollar, starting in July 2003. The savings are intended to be passed along to merchants, who pay banks to handle customers' charges.
The central bank also ordered that retailers be allowed to impose a surcharge on purchases made with credit and charge cards, to defray some of the cost of the bank fees. Visa and MasterCard oppose the policy because they say it penalizes card use. 
The central bank, which took over responsibility for regulating credit cards here in 1998, issued the new rules after a three-year inquiry into costs and competition in the industry. Its findings, summarized in an 80-page report published today, were supported by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
The two agencies have said they were concerned about secrecy and price fixing in the credit card industry. The central bank governor, Ian Macfarlane, said today that the new rules "will ensure a more transparent payment system and reduce the size of the transfer from card users to financial institutions," while leaving the basic system intact. "They will also promote genuine competition on credit card interest rates and service fees," he said.
The card issuers see it differently. "The new regulations are clearly not in the public interest, and are a bad outcome for consumers and small business," Gordon Wheaton, Visa's executive vice president for Australia, said today. A MasterCard senior vice president, Lee Clapman, called the new rules unfair.
Australia is a strong market for credit cards -- Visa alone has 13 million cards in use in a country of 19.3 million people, and credit card debt per capita has tripled since 1996, to about $1,200 a person. Retailers in larger markets like the United States and Britain have brought complaints of excessive fees and price fixing to regulators, and analysts said the move by the Australian central bank might set a precedent.
The central bank's order is subject to court review, and Visa, the market leader here, has indicated that it may appeal.

HEADLINE: An American Abdication 

BYLINE:  By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
At present there is much talk about the unparalleled strength of the United States on the world stage. Yet at this very moment the most powerful country in the world stands to forfeit much political capital, moral authority and international good will by dragging its feet on the next great global issue: the environment. Before long, the administration's apparent unwillingness to take a leadership role -- or, at the very least, to stop acting as a brake -- in fighting global environmental degradation will threaten the very basis of the American supremacy that many now seem to assume will last forever.
 American authority is already in some danger as a result of the Bush administration's decision to send a low-level delegation to the World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg -- low-level, that is, relative to America's share of both the world economy and global pollution. The absence of President Bush from Johannesburg symbolizes this decline in authority. 
 In recent weeks, newspapers around the world have been dominated by environmental headlines: In central Europe, flooding killed dozens, displaced tens of thousands and caused billions of dollars in damages. In South Asia, the United Nations reports a brown cloud of pollution that is responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths a year from respiratory disease. The pollution (80 percent man-made) also cuts sunlight penetration, thus reducing rainfall, affecting agriculture and otherwise altering the climate. Many other examples of environmental degradation, often related to the warming of the atmosphere, could be cited. What they all have in common is that they severely affect countries around the world and are fast becoming a chief concern for people everywhere.
Nobody is suggesting that these disasters are directly linked to anything the United States is doing. But when a country that emits 25 percent of the world's greenhouse gases acts as an uninterested, sometimes hostile bystander in the environmental debate, it looks like unbearable arrogance to many people abroad.
The administration seems to believe it is merely an observer -- that environmental issues are not its issues. But not doing anything amounts to ignoring a key source of world tension, and no superpower that wants to preserve its status can go on dismissing such a pivotal dimension of political and economic -- if not existential -- conflict.
In my view, there is a clear-cut price to be paid for ignoring the views of just about every other country in the world today. The United States is jettisoning its hard-won moral and intellectual authority and perhaps the strategic advantages that come with being a good steward of the international political order. The United States may no longer be viewed as a leader or reliable partner in policymaking: necessary, perhaps inevitable, but not desirable, as it has been for decades. All of this because America's current leaders are not willing to acknowledge the very real concerns of many people about global environmental issues.
No one can expect the United States to provide any quick fixes, but one would like to see America make a credible and sustained effort, along with other countries, to address global environmental problems. This should happen on two fronts. The first is at home in the United States, through more environmentally friendly policies, for example greater fuel-efficiency standards for cars and light trucks and better insulation for buildings. The second is international, through a more cooperative approach to multilateral attempts at safeguarding the environment. Simply rejecting international treaties (like the Kyoto Protocol) then failing to offer a better proposal cannot be an acceptable option for American policymakers.
Much of the world has come together to help the United States in the fight against terrorism, out of the realization that a common threat can only be beaten through a cooperative effort. It is high time for the United States, metaphorically speaking, to get out of its oversized, gas-guzzling S.U.V. -- and join the rest of the world in doing more to combat global warming and protecting the planet.

HEADLINE: Notably Mixed Signals From 2 Economic R eports 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Orders to factories for durable goods, including cars and computers, rose in July at the fastest rate in nine months, while another report released today showed that consumer confidence fell sharply in August. 
 The Commerce Department said that orders for costly durable goods, items expected to last at least three years, rebounded last month -- increasing by 8.7 percent after a 4.5 percent decline in June. 
 While that report provided good news about a struggling economic recovery, the Conference Board's survey of consumer confidence for August raised questions about the willingness of people to spend in the months ahead. 
The consumer confidence index fell to 93.5 in August, the lowest level since November, from a revised 97.4 in July. The showing was weaker than the 97 reading analysts had forecast. The index is used by economists to gauge consumers' future patterns -- spending that accounts for most American economic activity. 
Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's research center, said August's decline was "a strong signal that business conditions have yet to turn around."
Viewed over time, the board said, the index in August is at a level that points "to a continued, but slow, economic expansion."
The report showed no improvement in confidence about current economic conditions. Consumers rating current conditions as good fell to 16.6 percent in August from 20.2 percent in July, while those seeing conditions as bad was virtually unchanged at 22.3 percent in August from 22.1 percent in July, the Conference Board said.
The share of consumers who said jobs were hard to get remained unchanged at 23.9 percent, with those seeing jobs as plentiful falling to 17.2 percent in August from 18.8 percent.
Consumer expectations for the next six months were mixed. The share of those surveyed who expected an improvement in business conditions increased to 22.1 percent from 20.8 percent a month earlier, but a larger share of respondents held the contrary view.
The outlook for jobs also soured, with 18.1 percent of consumers saying they expected fewer jobs to open in the next six months, compared with 17 percent in the previous survey.
In the report on durable goods, the 8.7 percent increase in new orders was the largest since a 9.2 percent advance last October. July's performance was far stronger than the increase expected by analysts, which had ranged from 1.4 percent to 2.7 percent.
And this strength was broad based, with new orders rising in virtually every category surveyed except for electrical equipment and appliances. 
Orders for transportation equipment soared 20.8 percent, more than erasing a drop of 5.8 percent in June. Orders for cars, trucks and parts increased 7.5 percent after a 3 percent decline. Orders for commercial aircraft and parts jumped 121.6 percent in July after a decrease of 46.6 percent in June. 
Excluding transportation equipment, durable-goods orders rose by a solid 3.9 percent in July. And excluding orders for goods used by the military, durable goods rose even more steeply -- by a record 7.3 percent. 
Today's report may be a sign that the seeds are being sown for a turnaround in capital investment by businesses, a crucial ingredient in a full economic recovery. 
Orders for computers increased 13.9 percent in July after falling 9.8 percent in June. For communications equipment, orders rose 10.4 percent after a 15.3 percent decline. 
Orders for machinery were up a record 11.8 percent in July after a 8.3 percent decline in June. 
But orders for electrical equipment and appliances fell 1.6 percent in July after a 1.3 percent decline in June.

HEADLINE: US Airways Puts New Terms On NonrefundableTickets 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
US Airways said yesterday that it was imposing more stringent conditions on most of its nonrefundable tickets, including requiring passengers to buy another ticket if they miss their original flight and want to take a later one.
 Until yesterday, passengers could get on a later flight as long as seats were available and they paid a change fee. Now, on flights originating in the United States, the Caribbean and Canada, they will have to buy a new ticket. 
 The carrier becomes the latest to impose economy-class changes to try to stem losses. US Airways is operating under bankruptcy protection, and it has already said it is eliminating 200 daily flights, or 13 percent of its schedule.
US Airways also announced yesterday that it would bar passengers with most nonrefundable tickets from flying standby; that it would not count miles earned with such tickets toward elite status in the frequent-flier program; and that it would cut corporate discounts.
Passengers who bought tickets before yesterday will be able to fly under the original conditions of the tickets.
US Airways compared the new policy to buying tickets for a Broadway show or a sports event -- missing the event does not entitle the ticket holder to any form of credit.
"Since most people travel as originally ticketed, most customers will not be impacted by this change," B. Ben Baldanza, senior vice president for marketing at US Airways, said in a statement.
Unlike entertainment, however, a flight is generally considered a utilitarian service. In train and bus travel, travelers who miss a scheduled departure usually are allowed to leave later or receive some form of credit.
Passengers will not be able to fly standby. A change to an earlier flight with available seats, can still be done so as long as the passenger pays a change fee and any difference in the fare.
Starting Jan. 1, passengers who fly with most nonrefundable tickets will not have their miles count toward earning one of the three elite categories in the frequent-flier program.
Passengers will also be charged $25 for each paper ticket and will not be able to have alcoholic beverages in economy class on trans-Atlantic flights. 
"Clearly they are reducing the quality of service and reducing their costs, so that strategy is consistent with the low-cost, high-efficiency strategy," said Roland Rust, a professor of marketing at the University of Maryland School of Business. "But if the customer can't justify paying more, then there's no reason for them to fly on US Airways."
Professor Rust predicted that passengers accustomed to a certain level of service in economy class would start migrating to low-cost carriers like JetBlue, which competes with US Airways on several routes on the East Coast and has a simpler fare structure.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
New York Doesn't Need More Games

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
TO remain the center of the universe -- which New York is, of course -- you need an infrastructure. For example: the National Tennis Center in Queens is built upon the skeletons of past extravaganzas when New York played host to the world.
 Now, for better or quite likely for worse, it could happen again. Yesterday, New York was chosen as one of the two finalists for the one American bid to hold the 2012 Summer Games. 
 The big city does not exactly shy away from big events. We are reminded of that every late summer when Agassi is playing Sampras, or Williams is playing Williams, or a few years back when Jimmy Connors blatantly played to the street-fighting spirit of all New Yorkers. 
There are billions of reasons why New York does not need the traffic, the cost and the distractions of holding the Summer Games. But there is no denying that New York has a certain affinity for drama and struggle, survival and spectacle.
Yesterday, for example, a Russian, Marat Safin, and a German, Nicolas Kiefer, were lurching and staggering deep into a fifth set, with Kiefer cramping on every point and Safin threatening to destroy his entire kit of rackets, and the crowd egging them on.
 When Kiefer finally lost the tie breaker, he hobbled off for medical attention, but he paused to wave, opera-style, at the fairly large crowd in Ashe Stadium. "They were supporting me and him," Kiefer said, as Connors used to say. "It was great for both of us." 
Now there is a possibility that the expensive little playpen for the designer-outfit set would be used for the tennis site if New York were selected in 2005. (There is reason to think, maybe even hope, that the International Olympic Committee will not be ready for another American city that soon.) 
Under the elaborate plans, parkland and an artificial lake near the tennis center would also be used for Olympic rowing and canoeing. This is somewhat hallowed ground for world events. The Open can be traced directly to the World's Fair of 1939 (surely, everybody remembers the Trylon and the Perisphere) and the 1964 World's Fair (surely, everybody remembers the Spanish Pavilion).
When the fair folded up after its reprise in 1965, its remains began to sink into the mushy earth. According to legend, Slew Hester of the United States Tennis Association was seeking a new site for the Open and spotted a dinky little stadium while on final approach to La Guardia.
When Hester inquired about the joint, he was told it was something called the Singer Bowl that had held concerts in 1964-65. Skip quickly through the politics, the economics, the demographics, the protests, and you have the Open and its fabled trademark, the $10 hamburger.
Now New York and San Francisco are the two finalists of the United States Olympic Committee after a vote in Chicago yesterday. The New York organizers emphasized sites for future generations: an Olympic Stadium on the west side of Manhattan that would be used for football, presumably the Jets, as well as for major shows and conventions. And there would be assorted arenas and stadiums scattered around New York, connected by a network of trains, buses and ferries. If it added one more car to the Cross-Bronx Expressway, the city would grind to a halt.
Any way you look at it, spending billions to build and upgrade means ignoring other needs, including rebuilding from the evil attack of a year ago. Athens is struggling to complete some minimal portion of the roads and housing it promised. Montreal's debt from the 1976 Summer Games will outlast its baseball team. The recent World Cup in South Korea and Japan left behind 20 handsome new stadiums, not all of them with a resident soccer team.
There is no hard evidence that major sports events benefit their hosts. Building stadiums is often a Chamber of Commerce boondoggle, to put the Greatest Little Town in the World on the map.
Imagine how embarrassed New York would be right now if it had been stuck building new stadiums for the Mets and the Yankees only to have the blockhead owners and the dunderhead players stage a ruinous long layoff.
Sports have a close connection with bad civic values. There are high schools in New York spending money for football helmets while the city cannot provide enough textbooks to enhance the brains inside the helmets.
The organizers of the New York bid make a compelling case for building for the long run, but New York is already on the map. Ask the Russian and the German who met at the crossroads of Queens yesterday.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Pushes Companies To Disclose Data Faster 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission, responding to recent corporate scandals, adopted rules today requiring executives to be faster in disclosing important company information and their own stock trades.
 The agency also adopted a rule that would require top executives at domestic and foreign companies whose shares trade in American markets to certify regularly the accuracy of their company's financial reports. 
 Most of the rules were ordered by Congress as part of the corporate fraud and accounting legislation signed into law by President Bush four weeks ago. But the agency went further than the legislation by adopting a schedule that will require most publicly traded companies to be quicker in filing their annual and quarterly financial reports. 
For the first time since the end of the Clinton administration, the commission was at full strength today, with all five seats filled. The agency has been hobbled by a lack of adequate financing and manpower. Late last month, the Senate confirmed four members to the commission. Before those votes, the only confirmed member had been Harvey L. Pitt, the agency's chairman, who had been in office for almost a year.
The day's rule-making was the first in a long series of decisions confronting the agency as a result of the legislation sponsored by Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, and Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio. In the coming weeks, the commission will begin to set up an agency overseeing the accountants of publicly traded companies and re-examine many of the rules governing accountants.
"We are determined to give real teeth and meaning to the protections of the new law," Mr. Pitt said. The rules, he said, "reaffirm our commitment to restoring public confidence in the markets."
Harvey J. Goldschmid, a new member of the agency and a securities law expert from Columbia Law School, said that the adoption of the rules "marks an historic occasion," and that the new law was "the most important securities legislation since the New Deal."
The agency's focus today was limited primarily to issues of corporate disclosure. The collapse of Enron, in particular, highlighted the shortcomings of the requirements on executives to make public their trading in company stock, and their disclosures of important financial information.
Under the rules that were generally described in the legislation and adopted today in more detail, corporate executives and shareholders with more than 10 percent of a company's outstanding stock will have two days to disclose their sale or purchase of their stock. 
In most instances, this means that the public will know about any stock sales or purchases even before they are formally settled. The old rule required executives to file by the 10th day after the end of the month of the transaction, giving executives as many as 40 days to disclose.
"This will provide more information to investors faster," said Cynthia A. Glassman, a commissioner and former economist at the Federal Reserve.
The law requires executives to file the reports electronically to the commission and post them on corporate Web sites, beginning next summer. But Alan L. Beller, director of the agency's division on corporation finance, said he expected that the commission might propose requiring electronic filing sooner than the Congressional deadline.
Another rule adopted today will require most publicly traded companies to make their most important filings quicker. The rule, proposed earlier this year, drew significant criticism from companies that said it would be difficult to satisfy and predicted it could lead to less accurate filings.
Mr. Pitt said the rule reflected a "careful balance" between the needs of investors receiving quick information without "impairing the quality" of the reports.
The rule will be phased in over three years. By then, most public companies will have only 60 days to complete their annual reports, down from the current 90 days. And quarterly reports will be due within 35 days of the close of the quarter, down from 45 days required now.
The commission also adopted a rule ordered by Congress requiring the chief executive and chief financial officer of the largest companies to certify the accuracy of their quarterly and annual reports. 
Mr. Beller of the corporation finance division said the rule would not impose any new legal liability on executives, although he suggested it could make it easier for government officials to make fraud cases against executives found to have intentionally filed false certifications.
Roel C. Campos, one of the new commissioners, who was a Texas businessman and former prosecutor, described the new certification requirements more simply.
"What is being required," he said, "is that senior executive officials must say, 'You have my word that what I am saying is accurate, and I realize if I fib, I will be in a heap of trouble.' "

HEADLINE: Saving Water, U.S. Farmers Are Worried They'll Parch 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: PETERSBURG, Tex. 

 BODY:
Ronnie Hopper grows cotton, and he has learned firsthand that water is precious. The water that he pumps from underground costs him five times as much as it used to, so he does his best not to waste a drop. 
 He has installed new, high-efficiency center-pivot sprinklers, designed to eliminate losses to evaporation. He has cut back on his planting on his 2,000-acre farm to concentrate water on fields that can use it best. He is even considering drip irrigation, water by the trickle. 
 Mr. Hopper has reason to be parsimonious. Though he lives atop one of the world's largest aquifers, the Ogallala, which spans eight states, it is falling every day. Here in dry northwest Texas, the problem is particularly acute, with declines of at least three times the average. 
"Putting more wells in this particular ground would be like putting more straws in a glass," Mr. Hopper said, ruddy-faced in the Texas sun. 
People have warned of the threat to the aquifer, which supplies roughly a quarter of the United States' irrigated farmland, for more than 20 years, and it is still in danger. But the experience of farmers like Mr. Hopper offers reasons both for hope and caution for those struggling to save scarce water elsewhere, and to arrest drastic declines in other underground supplies in places like India and China. 
In a shift of much significance, per capita water use -- on the rise in most of the rest of the world -- is now declining in the United States. That retreat has been led by industrial users and farmers like Mr. Hopper, who began to save water through technology and conservation even before the recent years of drought, which this summer will affect more than a third of states. 
Now, however, after years of conservation, these users now worry that whatever savings are achieved will only be lost to competition from fast-growing American cities and suburbs. Despite America's overall decline in water consumption, these booming population centers are making greater demands than ever on limited water supplies. 
"We're coming to the reality that we may not have enough water to farm all of this land," Mr. Hopper said, in fields that stretched toward the pancake-flat horizon. "But we don't want anyone coming in and telling us that we don't know how to use it best." 
By global standards, the United States remains one of the world's most gluttonous water users. But Americans' water use declined more than 20 percent from 1980 to 1995, to about 1,500 gallons of water per person a day from 1,900, according to the most current data from the United States Geological Survey, which says the downward trend appears to be continuing. 
Today the depletion of the Ogallala -- beneath parts of Nebraska, South Dakota, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas -- has slowed to an extent not predicted by any forecasts. It is dropping by just a few inches a year on average, after averaging declines of about two feet a year since intensive irrigation began about 60 years ago. 
Still, it is the outlook beyond their fields that makes farmers almost as anxious as the falling water levels beneath them. 
In most of the country, farmers have primary water rights, ahead of suburbs and cities. But competition is intensifying. Texas, for instance, with rapid population growth and few restrictions on water use, is increasing its water consumption faster than any other state. 
By 2050, Texas water planners say the state's population will leap to 40 million people from nearly 21 million in 2000. By the same year, the board has warned, Texas' supply of water, from existing sources, will be 19 percent less than it is today.
Given that imbalance, the Texas water board said, it would be unrealistic to think that the Ogallala could be sustained into the indefinite future. The aquifer should be treated like a mine, it said, and plumbed until it runs out. But then what?

Doing More With Less
At 58, Mr. Hopper remembers when water was so plentiful and the Ogallala lay so near the surface that conservation and cost barely entered his mind. But cotton is a thirsty plant, and out where he lives, farming has always been a marginal business. 
On Mr. Hopper's farm, the aquifer, which stood 95 feet below the surface when he was a boy, now stands at 335 feet, with just 65 to go before it hits bottom. Now, he figures, his water bill (in electricity, for pumping from ever greater depths) accounts for a fifth of his overhead. Last year, he earned 52 cents an acre for his cotton, not enough to break even, and 20 cents of that came from the government. 
Environmentalists call it a waste twice over: the United States produces a surplus of cotton, and pays subsidies to its farmers, yet in places like Texas the water-intensive crop is draining a finite water supply. 
Still, water managers like those in Texas have resisted limiting farmers' water use -- and often do not even gauge it. 
"One of the goals, I think, of most of the producers here is to reduce the use of water," said Jim C. Conkwright, the general manager for the district based in Lubbock, which covers Mr. Hopper's farm. "But it's not something we can accomplish overnight." 
Most water experts say the most urgent task is to find ways to do more with less. "If you become more efficient within reason, we can improve the situation in many places around the world," said Ben Dziegielewski, executive director of the International Water Resources Association.
Mr. Hopper says that is what he and many other farmers have done. American farmers who withdrew 2.9 feet of water for every irrigated acre in 1980 were making do with 2.6 feet by 1995, government statistics show. 
The savings reflect efforts to eliminate losses from evaporation, wind and runoff, as Mr. Hopper has done by installing the center-point sprinklers. They deliver water closer to his cotton with about 95 percent efficiency, compared with about 50 percent for old-fashioned furrow irrigation. 
With the savings in pumping costs, Mr. Hoppers says he has paid for his investment in just a few years. "It all comes down to economics," he said. "I'll take as good care of the land as I can afford to do."
But even as farmers like Mr. Hopper try to conserve, thirsty cities and suburbs in the region have begun to look to the Ogallala to meet their expanding water needs. By 2050, planners in Texas expect municipal water use to rise by nearly 67 percent. 
The competition alarms farmers like Mr. Hopper, who argues that the cities have no claim on the aquifer at all. "Who are they to say that farming is not the most beneficial use?" Mr. Hopper asked.

Controlling Water's Use
In places like Petersburg, there is much talk these days about what is unfolding near Abilene, to the north, as a possible barometer of the future. There, the wealthy investor Boone Pickens and his company, Mesa Water Inc., own farmland, and their plan is to pump the water from underground and sell it to other parts of the state. 
Over a lunch of cheeseburgers and tater tots smothered in chili and cheese, Craig Heinrich, 38, who grows cotton himself, was among the local farmers who said he just did not know what to think of the plan.
"If they're going to pump all that water out of the aquifer, it's going to have a real impact on farming," he said. "But if they start telling him what he can and can't do with his water, they'll be telling us next."
Telling people how to use their water, something many see as a natural right, is a sensitive issue. In Texas and most other Ogallala states, landowners still have the final say over how and how much of the water beneath their land they should use. 
But in Nebraska, local water districts have taken the authority to limit how much water can be used for crops. 
"As we restrict the water supply, the irrigators are more or less required to use the water as efficiently as they can," said Bob Hipple, general manager of a water district in Nebraska's southwest. There, to supplement rainfall, farmers may use just 14.5 inches of underground water per acre per year, down from 22 inches a year in 1980, when the limits were first imposed.
But such restrictions have for the most part been left to states to apply. The federal government has mostly limited its own efforts to promote conservation to making grants available to help farmers switch to more efficient irrigation.
For now, states like Texas seem comfortable with the idea that conservation will more or less take care of itself. 
Over the next 50 years, Texas' water board expects rising pumping costs to push some farmers out of business. That, it hopes, will free up increasing amounts of Ogallala water. To water managers like Mr. Hipple in Nebraska, though, such projections seem optimistic and and misplaced. 
"When I was in Vietnam," he said, "we used to kid about the idea that we might as well live fast, die young and leave a good-looking corpse. An area can let everyone pump all the water they want, or it can say, perhaps it is better to live slower, live to be older and look as good as you can along the way."

HEADLINE: Dreaming of Stadiums and Souvenirs 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Daniel L. Doctoroff's eight-year quest to bring the Olympics to New York went from quixotic to quite possible yesterday. 
 The investment banker turned deputy mayor for economic development has long extolled the virtues of international sports competition, and the choice of New York to be one of two candidates for the 2012 Summer Games yesterday was one step toward that goal. More important than the competition, Mr. Doctoroff has said, is the lasting Olympic legacy of "more than a billion dollars worth of new and renovated parks and sports facilities in all five boroughs, as well as the revitalization of the East River waterfront and the Hudson Yards area on Manhattan's far West Side." 
 It would not even cost taxpayers very much, he said.
It sounded too good to be true to some critics. But he and the local committee, NYC2012, say they believe the city could reap as much as $11 billion from things like new construction jobs, restaurant meals and sales taxes on Olympics souvenirs. New subway lines and ferry terminals would have to be built to get tourists and contestants from a new Olympic Stadium on the West Side of Manhattan to an Olympic Village on the Queens waterfront, volleyball courts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and mountain bike trials and an equestrian complex in Staten Island.
He and others say that much of the cost would be covered by media revenues from Olympic events and millions of dollars in taxes from new residential and commercial development sparked by the stadium and subway on the West Side.
"The Olympics would reinforce New York's role as a premier international city," said Mitchell Moss, director of Urban Research Center at New York University. "It'll improve the recreational infrastructure for all New Yorkers and it's a terrific way to pump up our economy with much-needed public investments."
Not so fast, say some economists.
"The key to an economically successful Olympics," said Mark S. Rosentraub, dean of the College of Urban Affairs at Cleveland State University, "is building no more than one major facility."
"They lost money in Japan and Korea when they built a scad of facilities, none of which got much use afterward," he said. "If the proposal is going to take more money than you'll receive in television broadcast rights, you've taken the first step toward an unprofitable Olympics from the public sector's perspective."
The NYC2012 committee has a capital budget of $896 million and estimates that 60 percent of the sports venues it needs are already built or under construction. They said the stadium, which would become home to the New York Jets, and the $1.5 billion Olympic Village, with 4,300 apartments, would be built largely through private financing. Some critics have argued that New York will actually have to spend $4 billion on construction.
By contrast, San Francisco's capital budget is only $220 million, because, that city says, 80 percent of the fields, arenas and stadiums already exist.
Mr. Rosentraub said that tourists would flock to either city for the Games, but that their economic impact would be relatively small because restaurants, hotels, museums and other attractions in New York and San Francisco operate at capacity when the economy is in good shape. "You just replace one group of tourists with another," he said.
Mr. Doctoroff's Olympic quest began in 1994, nearly eight years after he attended the World Cup semi-finals at Giants Stadium in New Jersey. Almost single-handedly, he pulled together a bid for the 2008 Olympics and later the 2012 Games. Often, the most ardent skeptic was turned into a believer after a visit with the curly-haired Mr. Doctoroff, who picked up contributions from Merrill Lynch, AOL Time Warner, J. P. Morgan and many of the city's most powerful real estate tycoons. 
That enabled Mr. Doctoroff and the New York Olympic committee to raise and spend $11.5 million for work on the bid, more than double the amount spent by San Francisco.
In June, the city's Economic Development Corporation, which Mr. Doctoroff now oversees, signed $1.8 million in contracts to hire two teams of consultants to assess real estate revenues and urban design issues related to the development of the far West Side of Manhattan.
Still he faces opposition from community and civic groups, many of which favor the Olympics but oppose construction of a stadium over the rail yards on the West Side. These opponents say a stadium would worsen traffic congestion and destroy a working-class neighborhood. And some downtown landlords fear that the development effort will siphon off scarce state and city funds from the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan.
"The stadium is part of a much larger scam to tear down much of our neighborhood, making it impossible for normal people to live in New York City," said John Fisher, president of the Clinton Special District Coalition, a civic group. "The impact of the stadium would ripple through much of Manhattan."
Mr. Doctoroff fends off the criticism, saying the Olympics would be good for everyone. 
Much could happen between now and the International Olympic Committee's final decision in 2005 -- and it is still true that that decision rests not only on Mr. Doctoroff's efforts. Yet people who have seen him evangelize say his persuasive salesmanship can go a long way. 
Douglas Durst, whose family owns 10 skyscrapers in Midtown, contributed $45,000 to the effort. He said, "Dan Doctoroff is a very focused and persuasive person, as evidenced by his ability to extract large sums of money from the real estate industry for an event that will not occur for another 10 years."

HEADLINE: New York's Olympic Bid 

 BODY:
Starting from somewhere deep in the back of the pack, New York City has made the cut to stay in the race to be host to the 2012 Summer Olympic Games. The United States Olympic Committee announced yesterday that it had eliminated Houston and Washington from the competition. New York will now vie with San Francisco to become the American entry in the international competition to hold the Games. 
 With the potential of bringing billions of dollars to the host city's economy, the contest was and will continue to be hard fought. After the one American city is chosen in November, either New York or San Francisco will be thrust into more than two years of campaigning before the International Olympic Committee selects a winner in 2005. One erroneous news report this summer that New York had already been eliminated because it was overreaching with its proposal seemed an effort to psych out the city's bidders. 
 If not overreaching, its bid was arguably a stretch -- and that may turn out to be a strength rather than a weakness. New York no doubt won sentimental points, particularly as the anniversary of Sept. 11 draws near. But the city's size, diversity, transportation infrastructure and experience with security make it a natural contender anyway. And the bid stood on its own merits as audacious and daring, just the kind of qualities the Olympic Games reward.
The New York City plan calls for more than $4 billion in construction, including a $3.4 billion development of the area west of Midtown, now occupied by Hudson Yards, the largest chunk of undeveloped property in Manhattan. The result would be an Olympic stadium that could become a field for the New York Jets, an expanded Javits Center, a park and hundreds of new hotel rooms. A proposed extension of the No. 7 subway line would make it all accessible. But NYC2012, as the project to win the Olympics is called, envisions more, including a reborn waterfront and programs to encourage youngsters in schools to use the next decade to train for the home games.
To develop and promote the New York bid, some $13 million in private funding will be raised and spent, more than any of the three other candidates had budgeted. But that's chump change compared with the investment that would be required for a New York Olympics; billions of dollars will be needed to build the stadium, the subway extension and Javits expansion. While the developers say none of it will come out of the city or state operational budgets, any commitment of bonding capacity or future tax revenue could be dicey for local governments that are already reeling under heavy debt and shrinking revenues.
As people start taking the whole Olympics idea more seriously, controversy is going to heat up, too. Lower Manhattan boosters are going to look warily at any plan that seems to shift emphasis from development downtown to another part of Manhattan. Residents of Midtown and the West Side have not exactly been unanimously enthusiastic about the idea of a sports stadium in their backyards.
Still, with one hurdle out of the way, the prospect of a New York welcome for the world's greatest athletes is beginning to get exciting. After a long, difficult year, it's hard not to cheer about news that we're in the game.

HEADLINE: A Personality That Says Kennedy, In a Campaign by the Name of Cuomo 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
There are women whose last names are too famous to change when they marry, and others whose husbands have names too famous not to take. 
 And then there is Kerry Kennedy Cuomo, the seventh child of Robert F. Kennedy and wife of Andrew M. Cuomo, the son of a former governor who is now seeking that job for himself. 
 Ms. Kennedy Cuomo, who runs a human rights organization, uses both names when she campaigns for her husband, and the privilege and burden of each are lost on few.
"Are you apologizing?" cracked one elderly gentleman at an Upper East Side senior center after she introduced herself on a recent afternoon. 
"No, I am very proud," she replied, only slightly chagrined.
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo, 42, is more often met with something resembling adoring scrutiny, especially by older women, who seem to be searching for their own history in her face. 
Some of them proclaim that she is the image of her father, or that her pink suit resembles something her Aunt Jacqueline wore, or that they remember the day she and Mr. Cuomo were wed.
They listen patiently as she speaks on behalf of her husband, ticking off his accomplishments and making promises about lower drug costs while slipping in subtle comparisons between her husband and father. "Once again you have a young man running for office in New York," she recently told one group in Riverdale. 
It is almost jarring: she is a woman so unassuming that she sat in a Midtown Starbucks unrecognized for almost two hours last Friday and hid an event on her speaking schedule from a reporter so she "could practice first," according to her publicist. Yet she is also a woman who provides a living, moving memory of one of the nation's most painful periods as soon as she says who she is.
"You've got my vote, honey," said one woman to Ms. Kennedy Cuomo during a campaign stop. She was apparently unclear that Ms. Kennedy Cuomo was not the one running.
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo seems slightly exasperated by the suggestions that have been made since she married Andrew Cuomo in 1990 that theirs was the perfect political union. 
"When you are sitting there with your fella and he is buying you a glass of wine, you're thinking 'Wow, he's kind of cute,' not what his last name and what your last name is," she said.
And yet there is no escaping the political symmetry in the lives of Mr. Cuomo and his wife, who spent her childhood vacations on Indian reservations, once walked unnoticed through the most dangerous streets of Guatemala to ferret out children abused by the police, and who fell in love with Mr. Cuomo when he agreed to fast with her for three days to protest pesticide use on table grapes. 
She has devoted most of her adult life to human rights; he has been obsessed with homelessness and housing issues. Both families, while differing in their class backgrounds, are staunchly Roman Catholic and committed to public service under the umbrella of the Democratic Party.
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo has been a significant figure in Mr. Cuomo's campaign, partly by design, through her increased campaigning around the state. In part, she was thrust more into the campaign by Representative Charles E. Rangel, a supporter of H. Carl McCall, who is challenging her husband for the Democratic nomination for governor in the Sept. 10 primary.
Mr. Rangel, appearing on the New York cable channel NY1 last May, said of Ms. Kennedy Cuomo: "No one knows who she is. She is not like a Ted Kennedy or a Patrick Kennedy or one of the better-known Kennedys. These are professional politicians -- I'm talking about those who have stood for election. And they would know as Democrats that Carl McCall should be the candidate of the Democrats -- not their new in-law." Mr. Cuomo responded sharply at the time in defense of his wife and has since released a campaign ad decrying the McCall camp for taking potshots at his family.
Undaunted, Ms. Kennedy Cuomo, who has mastered the art of the gentle shoulder squeeze and the campaign tagline -- "The ancient Greeks say that the greatest gift the gods can give is a passion" -- is thought by many to be one of Mr. Cuomo's greatest assets on the campaign trail. Yesterday he took Ms. Kennedy Cuomo and their daughters -- 7-year-old twins, Mariah and Cara, and Michaela, who is 5 -- to the Mount Kisco, N.Y., Metro-North Railroad station near their home to greet commuters and pose for campaign photos.
"When they are together it is an extraordinary combination," said former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "Usually she speaks first, and she has to be careful not to overshadow him. 
"When Charlie Rangel made the mistake of insulting her on television, it was stupid and crude and I think a little bit out of fear," Mr. Cuomo continued. "He tried to diminish her not because he believed what he was saying, but because he believed just the opposite."
A Kennedy name, an undeniable charm and the three small daughters all work to soften Andrew Cuomo's image, one that many voters have complained is too brash, and her lifetime of human rights work has made her at times as much a political activist as her husband.
Some wonder if she brings as much, if not more, to the political future of both families, as Andrew Cuomo does.
"Kerry is the one they have to watch out for," said William T. Cunningham, who has run many political campaigns, including that of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whom he now serves as director of communications. 
"There is something about that family that makes them formidable political candidates," Mr. Cunningham said. "She has spent more time in the state of New York than her father did before he was elected to the Senate. That is not a knock. It is a statement of fact."
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo said one of her strongest childhood memories was sitting around her family's table discussing what every child in the family wanted to be when they grew up. "I said I wanted to be an Indian," she said, laughing, inspired by family vacations on Indian reservations. 
"My father when I was a kid was so deeply involved with Native Americans," she explained, "he used to bring home these extraordinary headdresses and pipes." His advocacy for that group seems to have inspired her interest in human rights issues.
After her sophomore year at Brown University, Ms. Kennedy Cuomo began work for Amnesty International in 1981, tracking abuses of immigrants by immigration officials. After receiving her law degree from Boston College, she decided to expand the work of the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial, a nonprofit organization that honors human rights workers, by establishing the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights to help support those workers.
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo has spent much of the last two decades visiting troubled nations and the people who defend abused women, children and others. Her work culminated in "Speak Truth to Power," a glossy coffee-table book of photos and stories of human rights workers around the world, from the Dalai Lama to Bruce Harris, who works with children in Guatemala.
"She has been a tremendous help to us on many different levels," Mr. Harris said in a telephone interview. "I have been with her with President Clinton, and in the streets of -- some of the dirtiest underbelly of the streets -- of Guatemala City where a lot of police in Guatemala fear to tread.
"On another level, obviously, politically she is well connected," Mr. Harris said. "She put me in touch with members of Congress and got in touch with her uncle, who called the State Department when I was up for trial in Guatemala. She helps people like myself who do not have access to power in the United States."
On a recent Friday, in between campaigning, she met with Guillaume Ngefa Atondoko, a human rights campaigner in Congo, to discuss female genital mutilation in Africa.
It is somehow wholly unsurprising that Ms. Kennedy Cuomo and Mr. Cuomo's first date was a visit to a transitional housing project that Mr. Cuomo established.
It was 1988, and they had met a dinner party. Ms. Kennedy Cuomo told her husband-to-be that she wanted to see the shelter, but that she was leaving for Boston the next morning. So he picked her up at her sister's apartment at 7:30 a.m. on his Harley-Davidson and took her to East New York to tour the project on the way to the airport. 
A shuttle romance ensued, but Mr. Cuomo sealed the deal by agreeing to fast with Ms. Kennedy Cuomo. The labor leader Cesar Chavez had been fasting for weeks and was very ill, so others, including Ms. Kennedy Cuomo, agreed to take on his fasting for three-day stretches. 
"I thought, 'Well, he builds housing for the homeless and he fasts for Cesar Chavez,' " Ms. Kennedy Cuomo said. "I was really taken with the work he was doing; well look, he was very handsome, very charming, very funny and he's brilliant and terrific in so many ways. It was a traditional crush."
It would seem that Ms. Kennedy Cuomo is still uncommonly smitten. She often tells anecdotes about her husband's work with underprivileged children, and seems completely convinced that he will win the Democratic primary, dismal polls notwithstanding.
"It is so clear that Andrew is the superior candidate," she said at one point. "And it is so clear that he will make by far the greatest governor." She added later, emphatically: "I don't think he's going to lose," and went on to tick off statistics about the upstate economy. 
Ms. Kennedy Cuomo, who attacks Gov. George E. Pataki on the campaign trail more than her husband does, was there when Mr. Cuomo told a bus filled with reporters that Mr. Pataki had "held the coat" of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani after the terrorist attacks. She had eagerly chimed in. "It is reflective of his lack of leadership across the state," she said, to which Mr. Cuomo had added, "I think that's exactly right."
She has come to see the coat statement as a mistake. "I wish he hadn't said that comment about 9/11, because I think it was taken so out of context," she said. "I think it really hurt people. It was very, very painful." 
Mostly, though, she has been shocked at the perception, she said, that her husband can be brash and mouthy, and wishes that the campaign had gotten him in front of more diverse audiences so they could see him the way she does. 
With three small children and a human rights agenda to further, Ms. Kennedy Cuomo said that running for office herself is out, at least for now. "I've thought about it," she said, fingering a small bracelet made of shells. "My husband is in politics and my kids are already a campaign organ for him and I really love being their mother. Maybe in 10 years, 15 years, if the place was right and the time was right."
Mario Cuomo pauses when considering it. "That is an interesting question. That is an interesting question. I don't know."

HEADLINE: New York Announces Details Of Greater 9/11 Business Aid 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
New York State and City gave details yesterday of their plans to increase aid to small businesses in Lower Manhattan that are suffering as a result of the terrorist attack last September.
 In the largest increase, small businesses that were in the World Trade Center or its immediate vicinity on the day of the attack are eligible for up to 25 days' worth of revenue losses, instead of up to 10 days' worth, as was previously the case. A $300,000 maximum for those businesses remains in place. 
 Lesser increases were announced for other sections of Lower Manhattan. Officials have said that businesses farther from the trade center were generally forced to close for shorter periods and thus their losses were smaller.
Nearly 8,800 businesses that have already received the maximum amount of money for which they were eligible under the former rules of the program, the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program, may now ask for more. First-time applicants will be subject to the new rules.
The increase came after many small businesses in Lower Manhattan, and some of their advocates, complained that the grants were inadequate. The increase was reported to be in the works last week.
Yesterday, one advocate called the increases "a welcome step." Referring to the trade center site and its immediate neighborhood, the advocate, Kevin Curnin, said: "The increase within the restricted zone reflects that this is where small businesses have been the most underserved. We hope this is a signal of more changes to come." Mr. Curnin is a lawyer for From the Ground Up, a group of nearly 300 small businesses in Lower Manhattan.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the New York economic development agency, which is one of the primary administrators of the federally funded program, denied that criticism had led to the changes.
"We were dealing with an unprecedented situation," he said of the trade center's destruction and the ensuing effort to fashion a meaningful aid program.
Over all, the program -- which aids businesses with up to 500 employees -- has awarded $242 million out of its $481 million. The application deadline is Dec. 31; businesses that have received aid and reapplied will be notified if they are eligible for more.
The increase in maximum days to 25 from 10 is effective in the area bounded by Chambers and Rector Streets, Broadway and the Hudson River.
In the rest of the area south of Canal Street, the maximum days rise to seven from five, with awards capped at $150,000. Between Canal Street and Houston Street, the maximum number of days rises to five from three, with a $100,000 maximum grant, and between Houston and 14th Streets, the maximum rises to three days from two, with a top amount of $50,000.
More information may be obtained by calling (800) 456-8369 or (866) 227-0458.

HEADLINE: Plan for Alexander Statue Too Great for Many Greeks 

BYLINE:  By ANTHEE CARASSAVA 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Alexander the Great was a megalomaniac. But not even he, based on what is known of his life, wanted the side of a mountain carved to depict his face.
 Now, 2,400 years after the epic warrior's death, an American-based foundation is bent on doing just that, beginning in November. But its plan to have a 240-foot-high likeness of Alexander carved into a craggy Greek cliff -- four times the size of the presidents of Mount Rushmore -- has appalled Greek classicists and conservationists. 
 "This isn't just a monstrosity," said Isidoros Kakouris, a leading archaeologist here. "It's the quintessential example of what Greek tradition is not about: big." Even the Parthenon, he said, "the largest shrine completed in ancient times, was built just big enough to house a 40-foot statue in honor of the goddess Athena."
The scheme is the brainchild of the Chicago-based Alexander the Great Foundation. Its members include influential Greek-Americans, to whom politicians in Athens traditionally turn in times of trouble with the State Department. It says it has pledges for the full $45 million cost.
The local authorities want to go ahead with the project, anticipating economic benefits from tourism, but the national Culture Ministry adamantly opposes it. In April it decreed the project unsuitable for Greece, which has a tradition of building monuments in proportion to human scale and the environment.
The ministry's general secretary, Lina Medoni, warned last week that if the sponsors went ahead with the project at the 2,000-foot Mount Kerdyllion, in the northern Greek region of Macedonia near the birthplace of Alexander, it could be "forcefully blocked."
But the backers do not intend to give up. "Support is pouring from all corners of the world, even from as far east as Jordan," said Tassos Papadopoulos, the Greek-American sculptor who conceived the idea six years ago.
"All I ask of the Greeks is to put me on the mountain," he said by phone from his Chicago home. "My pajamas are packed. I'm ready to start work."
The local authorities insist that they expect to have all permits in hand by next month, when a group of Greek-Americans championing the cause is to arrive here to tour the site. Their plan envisions other new facilities, including an open-air theater, museums and parking lots.
"We have assurances from ministers," said Angelos Frantzis, mayor of the sleepy seaside hamlet of Asprovalta, over which the stone portrait of Alexander would stare out to the Aegean Sea.
"We're open, though, to any suggestions and recommendation to ease opposition," Mr. Frantzis said. "But to pull the plug on the project -- that could cause more harm than the good."
Local environmental groups have threatened legal action to protect the pine-clad province from turning into a theme park.
Although it has clean beaches and classy resorts, northern Greece has borne the brunt of the country's decade-long decline in tourism, primarily because of the nearby Balkan wars.
Residents hope the project will bring back the tourists and revive the economy.
"Better yet," Mr. Franztis said, "the project will serve as the final stamp of authenticity for the Greekness of Alexander," who was born in Pella, then in the ancient kingdom of Macedonia but now part of Greece.
Archaeologists and politicians, including Haralmbos Bakirtzis, an authority on the Byzantine period, say such talk raises another potential problem: reviving tensions with the neighboring former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia over who has a right to Alexander's legacy.
If the neighboring country should decide to start a similar project, he said, "where would that lead?"
James Rigas, president of the United Hellenic American Congress, which supports the porject, said the planners were not seeking to cause political mischief. "This project is all about Greece expanding its vistas," he said, "being more flexible in its outlook as a modernizing Western state and boosting tourism, its primary source of income.
"Sure this is a huge project, but nothing is too small for Greek tradition."

(Alexander the Great Foundation, via Reuters) Map of Greece highlighting Mount Kerdyllion: Mount Kerdyllion is the proposed site of a Greek Mount Rushmore.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses After Sept. 11 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "$500 Million Left in 9/11 Aid, but Small Businesses Don't Ask" (news article, Aug. 26): 
 On March 19, I was joined by Speaker Gifford Miller in asking the state agencies responsible for distributing the federal relief aid for Lower Manhattan small businesses to speed through necessary assistance to those very small businesses most affected by the Sept. 11 attack. 
We proposed rent subsidies and the easing of program restrictions for mom and pop businesses, as well as a $50,000 per business grant for the few hundred underinsured retail subtenants and tenants of the World Trade Center buildings that remain shut down.
The program to reopen demolished businesses would cost less than $20 million. It was never financed.
I urge Gov. George E. Pataki to direct his agencies to provide these former World Trade Center tenants and other imperiled businesses in our area with this vital assistance immediately.

ALAN J. GERSON
New York, Aug. 26, 2002

The writer is chairman of the City Council's Select Committee on Lower Manhattan Redevelopment.

HEADLINE: 2 Labor Chiefs Laud McCall, But Don't Say 'Endorsement' 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Two powerful leaders of teachers' unions stood shoulder to shoulder with State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday and urged the state government to spend more money on schools, but both stopped short of endorsing him in his quest to become governor.
 The willingness of the union leaders, Sandra Feldman and Randi Weingarten, to appear with Mr. McCall on the campaign trail seemed calculated to send a signal of support for his candidacy without actually tying the fate of union members to his. 
Andrew M. Cuomo, Mr. McCall's rival for the Democratic nomination, proposed yesterday that businesses get a large 10-year tax break for every job they create as a way to spur the flagging state economy. 
Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, was in Brooklyn to sign legislation requiring insurance companies to pay for infertility tests and therapies.
But education was the motif for the McCall campaign during an appearance at a public school in Midtown Manhattan, as Ms. Feldman, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, praised Mr. McCall effusively for his tenure as the president of the city Board of Education in the early 1990's.
Ms. Weingarten, who succeeded Ms. Feldman as the president of the city's United Federation of Teachers, said she supported Mr. McCall's call for changing the state financing formula for schools, shifting more money to urban school districts, as a Manhattan judge ordered last year. The ruling was overturned on appeal.
Ms. Weingarten said she had no plans to campaign with Mr. Cuomo. She said her union's members had yet to decide if they would advocate that the umbrella group of teachers in the state endorse Mr. Pataki in the general election over Mr. McCall, though another union official said that option had not been ruled out.
"After the primary, we will make a decision about whether to endorse and, if so, who to endorse," Ms. Weingarten said. "But this is something that is so important to both Sandy and myself; the equity of money for kids is so important that we're going to stand with anyone who says that they are in favor of helping kids and creating equity."
Mr. Pataki has used the power of his office to win the support of several influential unions, prying them away from the Democrats they have traditionally supported.
In January, he pushed through legislation providing $1.8 billion more in Medicaid grants to pay for raises for hospital workers. The bill was fervently sought by Dennis Rivera, a Democrat and the president of the state's largest union of health care workers. The union later endorsed the governor.
Mr. Pataki also took care of the New York City teachers in this year's budget when he included $200 million to pay for raises in a new teachers' contract. That move complicated talks among labor leaders when the 480,000-member New York State United Teachers, the umbrella group, met two weeks ago to discuss endorsements, participants in the talks said.
Even though Mr. McCall enjoys strong support among teachers statewide, the delegates decided to put off an endorsement decision until after the Democratic primary, union officials said.
One reason was that Ms. Weingarten made it clear at the meetings that she and her 140,000-member group were unwilling to back Mr. McCall before the primary, and the rest of the union delegates were wary of endorsing him until the city teachers took a position. Mr. Cuomo was never in the running, these officials said.
A similar phenomenon has taken place in the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., where no candidate has enough support to swing the endorsement. Even though the labor federation has a tradition of supporting Democrats, Mr. Pataki has helped gain passage of several labor laws that the unions want, including a ban on using state money to discourage union organizing.
Because of this, the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. has also put off its decision on an endorsement until after the primary and may well end up endorsing Mr. Pataki, federation officials said.
"The governor has shown a willingness to work with the trade union movement and a understanding of the basic needs of the movement," said Denis M. Hughes, the president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.
For the city teachers, the relationship with the governor has been a two-edged sword. He financed their raises, but also successfully fought a court ruling last year that would have forced the state to spend more on educating urban students.
Mr. Pataki has advocated streamlining school aid formulas, but has never reached an agreement with legislative leaders. His spokesman, Michael McKeon, said Mr. Pataki "has a stellar record" on education.
