HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Baseball Commissioner And Consensus Builder

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The acting commissioner was seething. Taking a break from a baseball owners meeting that had taken an unexpected turn, Bud Selig walked down the hotel corridor gesturing as if he had a machine gun and was mowing down everything in sight.
 "I was not happy that day," Selig, now the commissioner, recalled the other day. "My language was bad. Let's say it was profane." 
 The subject of that meeting in September 1993 was Major League Baseball's proposed realignment into three divisions in each league, and the addition of a wild-card playoff team in each league. The plan encountered unexpected opposition, primarily from the managing partner of the Texas Rangers, who some years later would become president of the United States. 
Selig was irate because he had expected the vote on realignment to proceed smoothly. It was a unique moment. In Selig's 10 years as baseball's boss, that was the only time that he or anyone else could recall that he did not have the votes or know ahead of time what the vote would be.
Two days later Selig did have the votes, and three-division play and the wild card were born.
"It is amazing," John Harrington, the former chief executive of the Boston Red Sox, said of Selig's vote-getting ability. "It comes back to his persistence. There's a saying up on the wall in his office about persistence paying off. He wears on you. His persistence pays off."
With ultimate authority on the clubs' side, Selig is one of two men who will determine whether the players strike on Friday for the sixth time in three decades. The other is Donald Fehr, the executive director of the union. They are the leaders who will decide how far they are willing to go to reach a compromise on a new labor agreement and ensure that the rest of the season and the postseason will be played.
The players trust Fehr to make correct decisions for them because he has built on Marvin Miller's foundation and gained vast riches for them. The owners trust Selig to make the right decisions for them because he was one of them, knows their needs and serves as the consensus commissioner.
Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner from 1984 to 1989, did not talk to owners but told them what to do; Selig talks incessantly to owners and finds out what they want to do and sells them on what he thinks they should do.
Rob Manfred, the clubs' chief labor lawyer, has said more than once in recent weeks that Selig has the votes to approve a deal. Other officials have said that no bloc of owners exists that could block a deal.
That Selig's aides speak with such confidence is testimony to the way he operates.
"He is a master politician; he'd be at home in the U.S. Senate or the House of Parliament," Larry Lucchino, chief executive of the Boston Red Sox, said.
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' owner and a close friend of Selig's even though they often disagree on issues, said Selig works at building consensus. "He is constantly in touch with all of the people in the game," Wilpon said. "He is able to listen. He doesn't necessarily agree, but he's able to listen."

Lessons of Ownership
Selig, 68, traces his modus operandi to his baseball mentor, John Fetzer, who owned the Detroit Tigers when Selig came into baseball with the Milwaukee Brewers in 1970.
Only 35 at the time, Selig had been instrumental in bringing baseball back to his hometown. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin and serving two years in the armed forces, Selig went to work with his father in the automobile business. But when the Braves left Milwaukee after the 1965 season, Selig formed Teams Inc., and worked for four years before heading a group that bought the bankrupt Seattle Pilots and moved them to Milwaukee.
He recalled his first owners meeting, with Bowie Kuhn as a relatively new commissioner.
"Bowie puts me between Phil Wrigley and Gussie Busch," Selig recalled. "It was all about labor, and after two hours I wondered what I had gotten myself into. I remember riding back to Detroit with Mr. Fetzer, who was a very enlightened human being."
Fetzer, Selig said, "convinced me the best way to do things was to listen to everybody," adding: "Everybody needed to be heard, and if you're going to err, err on the side of trying to make people understand. I guess it just sort of evolved over a period of years. The names and faces change, but I've been able at least to get people to think about the problems and see what the solutions are."
Selig does not enjoy universal acclaim. The players and their union see him as public enemy No. 1, and he has suffered losses to them. He is the man who is blamed for canceling the World Series in 1994, even though it was the players who were on strike, and just last month he was seen as the man who ended the All-Star Game in a tie, even though it was the managers who created the impossible circumstance by using all the available pitchers.
And even though Selig has presided over the creation of the wild card, expanded the playoffs, instituted interleague play, increased revenue sharing among clubs and undertaken the consolidation of the league offices, his critics still ridicule him as Bud Lite.

An Ear for the Owners
When Selig retires -- his term as commissioner runs through 2006 -- the owners should give him not a gold watch but a gold telephone. He is famous for his telephone time, spending, by his estimate, seven or eight hours a day on the phone speaking with owners. 
"Selig is the best guy on the planet at returning phone calls," John Moores, the San Diego Padres' owner, said. "I've never known anyone to return calls as quickly as he does."
Explaining his penchant for listening, Selig said: "I thought early on in baseball there were a lot of owners who felt disenfranchised. They felt they weren't being heard. I don't know if they were right or not, but I'm very sensitive to that. It's their life, their money, their franchise. They have a right to be heard."
If there is any owner who does not feel he gets a full hearing from Selig, he has not talked about it publicly. But then no one dares to dissent because it would be futile. Selig, whom the owners rewarded with a three-year extension and a $5 million annual salary last November, has immense support in just about anything he wants to do.
"No one dares to question him," a former owner said, "because he has so much power."
Selig gains much of his support because of his efforts to enhance the game and improve the economic lot of the owners. His critics, perhaps not even a handful within baseball but many outside the game, say he has other ways of ensuring that owners are aligned with him. 
Peter Angelos is an example often cited. The owner of the Baltimore Orioles, Angelos opposed the owners' labor position during the last strike but is now a member of the negotiating team.
He has become a strong Selig ally, critics say, because he wants to do everything he can to dissuade Selig from allowing a team to move to the Washington area. Selig has taken advantage of that situation, they claim, to the extent that he has put Angelos at the bargaining table.
Selig and Angelos both deny that situation. "I've heard that many times," Selig said. "I have a great deal of affection and respect for Peter. I visited him and we talked. Did he or I talk about keeping a team out of Washington? We've never had that discussion."
Angelos said his position in 1994-95 was misunderstood. "I wasn't opposed to what the owners were doing," he said. "My disagreement was over the use of replacement players. I was also concerned with the termination of the Ripken streak."
The new Red Sox ownership is another strong Selig supporter. No wonder, Selig's critics say. He made sure John Henry and his group got the team when it was sold last winter.
"I know people have talked about the Boston ownership deal and the Mets deal," Selig said, referring also to Wilpon's recent purchase of Nelson Doubleday's 50 percent share of the Mets. "But so much of this is misunderstood. The owners of the Red Sox voted to sell to these people. But what commissioner wouldn't want each franchise in the best possible hands?"
Selig says he knows that people say he calls in chits when he needs to but responded: "That's just nonsense. Do I think there's any quid pro quo for that? No, I've never discussed any of that."

Not One to Give In
His critics have brought other charges, especially one about making decisions as commissioner that are in the best interests not of baseball but of the Brewers, who are now operated by his daughter, Wendy Selig-Prieb. He placed his share of the Brewers' ownership in trust when he officially became commissioner, a position he had said for six years that he did not want.
In fact, much of the time Selig was not expressing interest in the job, George W. Bush, then the managing partner of the Texas Rangers, was expressing interest and was only waiting for the nod from Selig. But the nod never came, and he ran for governor of Texas instead.
Selig's path to the position began when he and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox led a move to oust Fay Vincent in September 1992. Selig and Reinsdorf felt Vincent, who had been in office for three years, had become too chummy with the union; they did not want him around for the next round of negotiations.
For years, Vincent refrained from speaking out about baseball matters in general and Selig in particular, but he has recently become Selig's severest critic.
Speaking recently of Selig's long involvement in baseball's labor battles, Vincent said: "He can't give in. We had a tough time in '90 getting him to give in. He's psychologically incapable of giving in to Fehr and making a reasonable deal."
Selig was chairman of the owners' labor relations committee in 1990, when the owners locked the players out of spring training for the first month.
"In '90," Vincent recalled, "we had a vote in my office. People were saying should we do it. I said we can't win. This was just after collusion. Half the clubs were encouraging settlement. Bud couldn't make a decision. Bud had to walk around the block. He was in a terrible bind. He couldn't give in."
Selig is aware of the favoritism charges but strongly denies them.
*He became commissioner ignoring the obvious conflict he had as owner of the Brewers. "That's been the most painful part of the whole job," he said. "While I knew when I put my stock in trust there would always be the perception from some that there was an inherent conflict, I talked to every club about it at the time. I was really fastidious about it." 
*He went through the motions to realign the leagues just to get the Brewers into the National League. "We needed one team to move," he said. "I begged David Glass to move Kansas City because I worried about the conflict. David thought about it and turned it down. I was still agonizing over it when Larry Lucchino sent me a fax signed by 12 members of the committee beseeching me to do it." Lucchino labeled as "utter nonsense" the idea that Selig manipulated realignment. "He was in favor of a much broader realignment plan than was ultimately adopted," Lucchino said.
*He engineered contraction to eliminate the Minnesota Twins and open the upper Midwest for the Brewers. "The contraction process came from ownership," Selig said. "I knew contraction would be painful and bloody. But there was no question the owners wanted to contract." 
*The Brewers will benefit from the clubs' preferred method of distribution of revenue-sharing money. "I've heard people say that," Selig said. "Given the Brewers' current position, revenue sharing will benefit 15 or 16 clubs more than the Brewers. The thing that bothers me is on these perceived conflicts, people haven't taken the time to find out what the real story was. I say give me a real situation where you feel my past association with the Brewers is a conflict."
Perceived conflicts aside, Selig faces difficult decisions in the hours ahead. Another strike, another canceled World Series, could occur on his watch. The game's problems, which he is trying to solve, do not lie lightly on his shoulders. He has seen them grow for 32 years. No owner or official has been in baseball as long.
"I blame myself," he said. "This is as much a criticism of myself as anyone. We went many years without addressing any of our problems. What makes this all so difficult is we've come to a moment in history where we don't have that luxury anymore. The longer you don't solve your problems, the harder they become. They become more painful."

HEADLINE: National Briefing Washington: Tally For Charity 

BYLINE:  By Stephanie Strom (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The country's 1,400 United Way organizations raised an estimated total of $5 billion last year, an increase of 6.8 percent over the amount collected in 2000, the United Way of America said. Without the $501 million of contributions to the Sept. 11 Fund, which is jointly administered by the United Way of New York and the New York Community Trust, however, the total was $4.5 billion, a 4.2 percent decline over the previous year. Adjusted for inflation, giving to the annual workplace campaign fell 1.8 percent to $3.95 billion, or somewhat less than the 2.3 percent decline in philanthropic giving over all. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

HEADLINE: Sony to Offer PlayStation Games Online 

BYLINE:  By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
The battle for dominance in the multibillion-dollar video game industry flared yesterday as Sony Computer Entertainment America announced that its PlayStation 2 game console, the market leader, can now play selected games over the Internet. Sony also kept an earlier promise that it would not charge a fee to play its popular games online.
 The Microsoft Corporation, which entered the highly competitive video game arena last November with its moderately successful Xbox console, says that it will start an online gaming service, Xbox Live, on Nov. 15. The service is expected to be fee-based and sold through retail outlets in a $49.95 kit, which is to include a headset and one-year subscription. 
 Nintendo, whose GameCube sales are generally comparable to Xbox's, has announced that it will offer at least one online game this fall that will require a $34.95 adapter to play.
"We have to take this step," Molly Smith, a Sony spokeswoman, said of PlayStation 2's expansion to the Internet. "We have to invest in the future of this platform."
Ms. Smith said using PlayStation 2 as a means for providing online entertainment in the home was always part of Sony's core vision. But changes in the Internet economy and the generally slow adoption rates of broadband connections in North America caused Sony to rethink its always-on, broadband-based strategy, she said.
As a result, PlayStation 2 requires a network adapter that can be used with any Internet service provider, either broadband, like cable and D.S.L., or narrow-band dial-up.
The adapter, which went on sale yesterday, costs $39.99. Sony says it plans to ship 500,000 of the adapters to North America by the end of its fiscal year in March. Sony says five games are available for online play. One, Twisted Metal Black, is being offered free with a coupon included with the adapter.
Playing video games over the Internet has been popular for years among gaming enthusiasts who mostly use their personal computers to engage in vivid role-playing and shooter games with opponents as close as the same room or nations away. But the process of setting up games and playing them often proves confusing and cumbersome for more general players, game console makers say.
PlayStation 2, Ms. Smith said, has greatly simplified online gaming by permitting players to use their existing Internet service providers as well as use either broadband or narrow-band connections.
Xbox Live is being planned as an exclusively broadband service, a decision that may reduce its potential market. But the Xbox console is sold fully equipped for online play, without need for an adapter.
This is not the first time Sony appears to have outmaneuvered Microsoft to better position PlayStation 2, which has sold 33 million consoles compared with the 3.9 million consoles Microsoft reported in June. In May, Sony cut its price on PlayStation 2 in North America to $199 from $299 -- a day before Microsoft made a similar cut in its pricing of Xbox.

HEADLINE: Budget Office Forecasts Shift From Surplus To Big Deficits 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the federal government would run big budget deficits through 2005, and those estimates do not include the impact of President Bush's proposals for higher military spending and his ideas for additional tax cuts.
 The bipartisan office also estimated that tax revenues this year are about $131 billion, or 6.6 percent, lower than last year, the biggest one-year drop in nearly half a century. 
 The forecast is considerably more pessimistic than what the Bush administration has predicted, and it virtually wipes out the trillion-dollar surpluses that the White House and the Congress had foreseen over the next decade.
The new estimates point to a sharp reversal in the government's fiscal position, which shifted from a sizeable overall surplus last year to an even bigger overall deficit this year. 
They were immediately seized as fodder by Democrats and Republicans alike in the battle over extending the tax cuts that Mr. Bush pushed through Congress last year.
Democrats said Mr. Bush's tax cuts were the main culprit behind the abrupt lurch into the red, and they used today's report to attack the president's plan to make those tax cuts permanent.
"The president is taking us down the path of soaring budget deficits, and he wants to dig the hole even deeper," said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
But White House officials and Congressional Republicans argued that the new deficits merely reflected the recent economic slowdown, the price of the war in Afghanistan and the costs of beefing up domestic security against terrorism.
Dan L. Crippen, the director of the budget office, said the recession and the plunging stock markets appeared to have played a bigger role than the tax cuts in reducing tax revenues.
But Mr. Crippen also said that the magnitude of the drop remained somewhat of a mystery. Tax revenues have declined faster than the economy itself, and nobody knows why. 
Much of it may stem from huge stock-market losses, but it may also reflect deeper changes in tax-paying behavior that endure beyond today's bear market.
By law, the Congressional Budget Office cannot base its estimates on proposals by the White House or Congress. It assumes that the tax laws remain unchanged and that spending continues on the same trend over the next 10 years.
Inevitably, the forecasts diverge with reality as both the laws and the nation's economy evolve.
Perhaps the most striking trend in the latest forecast is the long string of deficits that would occur under almost any situation.
When excluding the "off-budget" surpluses accumulating in the Social Security trust funds, which are supposed to be reserved for the baby-boom generation's retirement, the new forecast estimates that the deficit will stretch until 2010 and be followed by small surpluses in the next two years.
But even those modest surpluses assume that Mr. Bush's tax cuts last year expire in 2010, as scheduled. The president is pushing hard for Congress to make them permanent.
If he is successful, then tax revenues would decline by an additional $350 billion in 2011 and 2012 and even the modest non-Social Security budget surpluses in 2011 and 2012 would evaporate.
The other element not included in today's forecast are Mr. Bush's ideas for some incremental tax cuts next year as well as large additional spending increases for the military and domestic security.
Republican analysts on the Senate Budget Committee said the combined impact of those changes would increase next year's total budget deficit to $180 billion.
All of that adds up to considerably higher deficits over the next several years than the White House Office of Management and Budget predicted in July. At that time, the administration said the total deficit would shrink to $71 billion next year and disappear in 2004.
In a historical perspective, the bickering about deficits over the next year or two is probably less important than the much longer-term outlook. Even the pessimistic plans envision a federal deficit that would be less than 2 percent of the American gross domestic product and would decline over the next few years.

HEADLINE: Windmills On Their Minds; 
Battle Lines Drawn Over a Source of Power That Some Say Obstructs a Gorgeous View

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A small but vocal band of preservationists is tilting at windmills here in this town of 1,270. 
 High-tech, 400-foot-tall wind towers, to be precise. The kind with 100-foot-high blades that cost $1 million apiece. With the encouragement of New York State, an entrepreneur wants to put as many as 27 windmills on a 1,900-foot-high ridge that is visible for miles. 
 Environmentalists might be expected to celebrate the scheme. If constructed, the Cherry Valley turbines could produce pollution-free, wind-generated electricity that, its proponents say, would help relieve power shortages and foster energy independence from Arab oil. 
And this cash-starved town should be jubilant at the arrival of a new industry. On Aug. 20, Gov. George E. Pataki announced that the Cherry Valley project would receive $2.5 million in state start-up funds, as part of a $17 million grant to develop 315 megawatts of electrical power at five wind farms in upstate New York. 
"Clean energy technologies like wind farms will help New York State and the nation accommodate the growing demand for electricity," the governor said, "in an environmentally responsible manner that avoids air pollution." 
But the windmills are hardly welcome everywhere in Cherry Valley. "This is green power on the surface, but when you scratch it, it's black underneath," said Roberta O'Neill Kieler, a Cherry Valley resident.
The newest manifestation of Nimby, or not in my backyard, requires a different acronym: not in my viewshed. Wind-farm opponents contend that, like a watershed, a viewshed, or public view, is the common property of those who share it, and must not be degraded unilaterally by any one property owner. 
The Cherry Valley windmills would be visible for miles in several local communities, and near Cooperstown from the Hyde Bay section of Otsego Lake, the model for the Glimmerglass of the James Fenimore Cooper novels.
Henry Cooper, a great-great-grandson of the writer, is president of Otsego 2000, a planning and historic preservation organization in Cooperstown next door.
"James Fenimore Cooper developed his strong feeling toward nature in this very landscape, at this very lake," he said. "This landscape is a historic source of modern American views of conservation and the environment. It would be ironic if a place that is deeply associated with our whole view of nature is now to be overrun."
Windmills have been tilted at before. A proposal to place a wind farm in the middle of Nantucket Sound has raised the ire of Cape Cod homeowners, yachting groups and fishermen. And a proposal to put wind turbines near Montauk Point on Long Island was halted after residents claimed that they would spoil the view.
In the Cherry Valley area, environmentalists have had to do much soul-searching in opposing the towers. "I am absolutely committed to wind power," said Paula DiPerna, a board member of Otsego 2000. But Ms. DiPerna, who worked for the environmentalist Jacques-Yves Cousteau for 18 years, paraphrased her onetime boss when she said, "Do we want to live in a world where everything is spoiled just a little bit?" 
Robert Loucks, the Cherry Valley town supervisor, is thinking of the money the wind turbines would bring. "We all use electric power, but a lot of people don't want it produced in their neighborhood," he said. "It is a selfish view to say that 'I support wind power if I don't have to look at where it comes from.' " 
A wind-prospecting company, Global Winds Harvest, has signed contracts with Cherry Valley landowners on a ridge called Cape Wykoff. The company hopes to build up to 27 wind towers producing as much as 40.5 megawatts, generating enough electricity for 13,500 households. The total cost would be $30 million to $35 million, including the construction of a power substation. 
Global Winds Harvest is a three-year-old American offshoot of a German wind-power firm that has installed about 300 towers in Europe. The company is involved in 10 other United States projects, none of which are up and running yet.
Jeff M. Peterson, program manager of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority in Albany, said that New York's wind-power push began three years ago, when the state set about "trying to develop a competitive utility marketplace, while trying to encourage companies to develop renewable energy resources."
Last year, Governor Pataki signed an executive order that set a goal for the state to supply 10 percent of its energy from renewable sources by 2005. 
Since 1999, Mr. Peterson's agency has provided $596,203 in seed money to six companies that are prospecting for wind sites, and an additional $7 million to build two wind farms. Generally, wind prospectors sell the completed project to power companies and other operators, then move on.
Green power has already come to the town of Madison, site of the first wind farm in the state, which is 48 miles west of Cherry Valley. The seven wind towers there generate 11.5 megawatts of electricity. Another 23 turbines are in Fenner, 18 miles northwest of Madison, generating 30 megawatts in the largest wind farm on the East Coast. 
Under New York State law, wind and solar power qualify for a tax exemption to encourage new development, so wind prospectors negotiate in-lieu payments to local boards. The company initially offered Cherry Valley $2,500 for each of the 50 turbines it originally hoped to build. (Each landowner was also offered $2,500 per tower.)
Since the project has been scaled down from 50 to 27 or fewer, "the amount is still being negotiated," said Erich Bachmeyer, project manager for Global Winds Harvest. 
Mr. Loucks said that the greatest benefit of the money would be to improve the town's 45 miles of road, 35 miles of which are unpaved. 
"As supervisor, I have to come up with new tax ideas," Mr. Loucks said.
Though wind power would not bring the town many jobs, several people would be paid to maintain the towers, Mr. Bachmeyer said. Regionally, the economic situation is grim and census statistics place Otsego County among the 10 poorest in New York. "I get calls from farmers who want to know if they can site wind turbines on their land," Mr. Peterson said. "That income could mean survival." 
Supporters trumpet the fact that the wind towers create no air, water or heat and therefore do not contribute to global climate change. The green-power mantra is that one megawatt of electricity generated from wind saves 5 pounds of sulfur dioxide, 2 pounds of nitrogen oxide and 1,000 pounds of carbon dioxide emissions from equivalent fossil fuel plants. 
Despite such green credentials, opposition to the towers is growing in Cherry Valley. "The whole thing seems to be about the bottom line, making money for a private sector company," said Mrs. Kieler, a director of Advocates for Cherry Valley, a group of 130 windmill opponents. Her farmhouse would overlook the wind towers that she opposes. 
Most residents said they knew nothing about the wind towers until last spring, when the process was fairly advanced. "There is no sharing of information," Mrs. Kieler said, "and they are being very elusive.
"Why should we give our commodity -- wind -- to the first low-ball bid we receive?" 
Mr. Loucks said that Global Winds Harvest presented its plans publicly at town board meetings for more than a year, and Mr. Bachmeyer of Global Winds said, "We never hid anything." 
Some preservationists, including Ms. DiPerna, the board member of Otsego 2000, are disturbed that "the beautiful idea of green energy all comes down to paying the lowest price to the least stringent community to make a profit for private developers." 
To which Larry Thompson, proprietor for the last 30 years of Larry's Barber Shop, said: "America was built on entrepreneurship and capitalism. I think there is plenty of room for another business to come into Cherry Valley." 
Adding much confusion to the debate, many residents said they believe that the power from the windmills would flow directly to Cherry Valley. But the electricity will go into the grid of the New York State power pool. It would be too expensive to put up a separate network of new power lines to Cherry Valley homes just to deliver wind-power electrons to their homes, Mr. Bachmeyer said. 
Opponents say the windmills make too much noise, can fling ice in winter and are dangerous to migrating birds. Supporters say these complaints are exaggerated. 
But though the opponents also reject the towers' required nighttime airplane warning strobes and red lights, the primary objection is the daytime visual impact of the 27 windmills.
"The 19th-century landscape we value would become an industrialized landscape," Ms. DiPerna said. 
Mr. Bachmeyer countered, "A lot of people say the towers are beautiful, they look like works of art."
He added, "Right now there are radio towers and cell towers on the hills around Cherry Valley, and I think those are uglier." 
Andy Minnig, a retired schoolteacher whose property faces an alternative Cherry Valley wind-turbine site, acknowledged that the towers "may be sculptural in small groups."
But, he added, "Once the towers dominate the features of the landscape, they are objectionable."
And opponents worry that future residents may be stuck with the towers forever, since they question the fundamental economics of wind power. According to energy analysts, electricity generated from wind power costs 1 to 2 cents per kilowatt hour more than the wholesale average cost of 3.5 cents from fossil fuels. Wind-power advocates are hoping to create "green energy" initiatives where environmentally minded consumers can pay slightly more on their utility bills for the privilege of using wind-generated electrons in their toaster ovens. 
Mr. Bachmeyer said the towers should recoup their investment during 20 years of operation. 
But opponents say the entrepreneurs do not have to post any bond for the wind towers' removal. So, Mrs. Kieler said, "We worry that we could be left with a hill of rusting hulks."
Mr. Bachmeyer said that even in case of a bankruptcy, the towers' electricity would have value and they would continue operating. Furthermore, he said the cost of wind-power electricity "is much cheaper than conventional energy when you consider its health costs, the costs of environmental degradation and climate change, and the military cost of protecting offshore power resources."
There is an urgency on the part of wind prospectors to get projects up and running, because a government subsidy -- a 1.8-cent-per-kilowatt-hour production tax credit that helps makes wind-tower operation profitable -- expires at the end of 2003. 
Yet at the same time, Cherry Valley opponents are pressing for a moratorium. If they fail, the next step would likely be a public hearing in mid-September, to be followed by a vote, and conceivably a robust round of lawsuits. 
Meanwhile, the resident-vs.-outsider debate in Cherry Valley has been intensifying. "Most of the people who live in our town year-round aren't against it," Mr. Loucks said, adding that a lot of the tower opponents live in New York City. 
One of them, Patrick Shearer, a 76-year-old retired manager for the ABC television network who lives in Manhattan, bought 65 acres on a Cherry Valley hilltop a decade ago. "I think the towers would make my property worthless," he said.
He sighed. "To see these giant towers near your house -- it would be like driving through oil derricks to get to your front door."

HEADLINE: Planned Bill Would Spur U.S. Sale of Diesel Cars 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Representative John D. Dingell plans to introduce a bill that would encourage the sale of diesel cars in the United States, a prospect strongly supported by the auto industry but opposed by environmental groups. 
 Industry executives have said in recent years that modern diesel engines are far less dirty and noisy than those of the 1970's and offer a relatively easy way to improve fuel economy and reduce global-warming emissions. 
 That argument has carried weight in Europe, where about one-third of light-duty vehicles sold each year are powered by diesel engines. But regulations in the United States have restricted diesel engines -- they are in fewer than 1 percent of new light-duty vehicles -- and Volkswagen is the only company selling diesel passenger cars here. 
Robert A. Lutz, the vice chairman of General Motors, said at an auto industry conference last month, "We should get diesels in the mix because it's one way we could get 10 to 15 percent fuel economy improvement while keeping the size mix that we have."
Mr. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who recently won a rare and hard-fought Democratic primary election, is the longest-serving member of the House and a staunch ally of the Big Three automakers. His spokeswoman on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Laura Sheehan, said that the bill was still being drafted but that "the goal of the legislation would be to enable this technology to have widespread clean-diesel usage."
She said it would involve tax credits for oil companies that produced diesel fuel with low sulfur content and possibly some incentives for the auto industry. The industry has previously lobbied for tax credits for consumers who buy cars with advanced diesel engines. Mr. Dingell's plan was reported today in The Detroit News. 
Diesels can be a third more fuel-efficient than a comparable gasoline-powered car. They can also cut emissions of carbon dioxide, linked by some scientists to global climate change, because such emissions are tied to fuel economy. Allen Schaeffer, executive director of the Diesel Tech Forum, a trade group that includes G.M. and diesel engine makers, said: "We have concerns about fuel economy and carbon dioxide. Diesel can provide ready-made solutions for both of those."
But diesel engines also have much higher emissions of particulates, or soot -- which can worsen asthma, according to some studies, and lead to cancer. They also emit more nitrogen oxide, a contributor to smog.
A new set of regulations related to the Clean Air Act will restrict these emissions, but even the new rules will allow diesel engines to emit more than twice the quantity of particulates of a gasoline-powered engine. The biggest challenge for the industry, though, will be developing a way to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxide.
Environmental groups in this country oppose the wider use of diesel-powered vehicles. One prominent group, the Union of Concerned Scientists, is preparing a report expressing skepticism about improvements made in diesel technology. The report also contends that diesels emit 40 chemical compounds that lead to various cancers, birth defects and other health problems. 
"We remain to be convinced," said Michelle Robinson, a senior advocate with the group, adding, "In terms of cancer risk and immune-system disorders, diesel is far and away more problematic than gasoline exhaust."
European standards are not so strict on emissions from diesel engines, and environmentalists in Europe have not been as strongly opposed.
"Our colleagues in Europe have not been as concerned with smog-forming pollutants," said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. 
"They are just as concerned as we are about global warming, but they are willing to make trade-offs we are not willing to make."
And not all automakers seem eager to push to bring the technology here. 
"We do get customers at our dealerships asking for hybrids, we don't get customers asking for diesels," said Ben Knight, vice president for automotive engineering at Honda R&D Americas, referring to cars with hybrid engines that combine gasoline and electric power. "They are intrigued by the superclean, superefficient gasoline hybrid with a fuel that's available."
Mr. Becker of the Sierra Club added that hybrid cars offered a technology that could also provide greater fuel efficiency without increased particulate or nitrogen oxide emissions.
Diesel also has a high sulfur content, and regulations in Europe and the United States will require that to be reduced later in the decade, a move supported by the industry.
"Sulfur does nothing good for fuel," said Greg Dana, vice president for environmental affairs at the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, an industry trade group. "It's simply a poison to catalysts and all the advanced control technologies in cars."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Trade Panel Rejects New Tariffs on Foreign Steel
A federal trade panel has rejected pleas by the steel industry to impose new tariffs on imports of cold-rolled steel. In a 4-to-1 vote, the International Trade Commission ruled that American producers were not being injured by imports from five countries.
 The ruling is a setback for integrated steel companies because it suggested that the producers were exhausting the government's patience in seeking ever-higher levels of protection against foreign competition. Page A1. 

S.E.C. Adopts Disclosure Rules
The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted rules covering corporate accountability, including one requiring executives to be faster in disclosing company information and stock trades. Most of the rules were part of the corporate fraud and accounting legislation signed by President Bush. C2.

Hewlett-Packard Reports Loss
Reporting its first quarterly results that included Compaq, Hewlett-Packard matched Wall Street's earnings estimates and fell a bit short on revenue. The company reported a loss of more than $2 billion. The figure included an after-tax charge of $2.4 billion for costs related to the merger. C4.

Nortel Networks will cut 7,000 more jobs this year, and the company said its third-quarter revenue would miss its forecast. C4.

US Airways Tightens Restrictions
US Airways plans to impose more stringent conditions on most of its nonrefundable tickets, including requiring passengers to buy another ticket if they miss their original flight. C2.

Earnings Drop 65% at Bombardier
Bombardier said that a slump in demand for jets contributed to a 65 percent decline in earnings. The company said net earnings in the quarter fell to $65.2 million from $185.1 million. Revenue increased 16 percent. C10.

Microsoft Will Update Windows XP
In an effort to comply with an antitrust agreement with the Justice Department, Microsoft said that it planned to distribute its first major update to the Windows XP operating system some time in the next 10 days. C4.

Sony has announced that its PlayStation 2 game console can now play selected games over the Internet. C4.

Australia Lowers Credit Card Fees
Australia's central bank has ordered changes in the way credit card businesses operates. The central bank lowered the fees that banks can charge one another to process a transaction and ordered that retailers be allowed to impose a surcharge on credit card use. World Business, Section W.

Indonesia's Corruption Assailed
In unusually blunt remarks, Mark Baird, left, the World Bank's representative in Indonesia, said that corruption was probably the country's biggest economic problem. Mr. Baird, known for sympathetic views of the country, said, "The pattern of outcomes from the courts is very hard to understand except in terms of corruption, and probably incompetence." World Business, Section W.

Markets Drop on Consumer News
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 94.60 points at 8,824.41 after reports of a sharp drop in consumer confidence. The Nasdaq fell 43.96 to 1,347.78. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 13.13 to 934.82. C10.

Orders for durable goods, including cars and computers, rose 8.7 percent in July. But a survey of consumer confidence fell to 93.5 in August, the lowest level since November. C10.

A Shift for Real Estate Projects
The role taken by Lend Lease Real Estate Investments, the manager of a pension fund that is the lead investor in a development in Bellevue, Wash., reflects the changes in real estate financing. Lend Lease says it is taking a mildly aggressive investment strategy, exerting more control while also assuming more risks. Commercial Real Estate. C8.

HEADLINE: New York City Makes a Cut In Olympic Bid 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR and CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
New York and San Francisco advanced today in their quests to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympics, winning selection as the United States' finalists in an international competition that will end in three years.
 The United States Olympic Committee's bid evaluation task force eliminated Houston and a joint Baltimore-Washington bid from consideration. On Nov. 3, the U.S.O.C. will choose one of the two finalists to compete against an all-star group of foreign cities vying for the International Olympic Committee's final designation in 2005. 
 "Washington and Houston did not fall down," said Charles H. Moore, the chairman of the task force and a gold medal hurdler in the 1952 Summer Olympics. "It was a question of riches from all four cities. It wasn't a unanimous vote, but it was a clear consensus." 
Upon hearing the choices, the leaders of New York's bid, Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, and Jay Kriegel, the executive director of NYC2012, sighed and shook hands without saying a word.
Mr. Doctoroff began his long-shot campaign to bring the Olympics to New York in 1994, almost single-handedly putting together a bid for the 2008 Olympics, and following that, for 2012, which he continued last year despite the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and fiscal problems that have mounted with the economic downturn. He stepped down last December as president of NYC2012 to become deputy mayor for economic development in the Bloomberg administration.
Mr. Doctoroff remained so closely identified with the effort that some critics referred to him as the deputy mayor for the Olympics, worrying that the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan and other economic development projects would lose out to his obsession. Mr. Doctoroff has maintained that New York can redevelop the West Side and downtown at the same time. Yesterday, however, the Olympics were front and center.
"The I.O.C. wants to build the Olympic brand and demonstrate the importance of the Olympics in the contemporary world," Mr. Doctoroff said. "Coming to New York would let them do that in multiple ways."
Mr. Moore and other task force members refused to explain in detail why New York and San Francisco emerged from a field of 75 in a process that began in 1997. Generally, Mr. Moore said New York's infrastructure and security plans impressed the panel, and San Francisco's international strategies and environmental plans were important considerations.
In a statement, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, "Bringing the Olympic Games to the 'World's Second Home' would celebrate our unequaled diversity and participants from every nation would feel welcome."
When asked about New York's rival, Mr. Bloomberg said, "San Francisco is a very nice small town."
The biggest things that New York needs to build, according to the bid, are a $1.5 billion stadium on the West Side of Manhattan; an extension of the No. 7 subway line at a cost of at least $1.5 billion; and the construction of 4,300 apartments in an Olympic Village at the Queens West project on the East River plus a number of smaller sites like a velodrome, a whitewater canoeing course and areas for equestrian sports, archery and beach volleyball.
The biggest construction projects for the San Francisco bid include a renovation of Stanford Stadium and an Olympic Village, as well as a velodrome. An extension of the Bay Area Rapid Transit system is also planned.
Even the best-laid plans of either New York or San Francisco could be undone by a location lottery in which the International Olympic Committee has tried to rotate the continent and location of the games every four years. Vancouver, British Columbia, for instance, is vying with Bern, Switzerland, and South Korea to be selected as host of the 2010 Winter Games, a decision that could work against New York and San Francisco. South Korea has little chance of winning because the 2008 Olympics are headed for Beijing.
"There are decisions being made that could determine New York's fate in 2012, without New York being part of those decisions," said Marc Ganis, president of SportsCorp, a marketing firm in Chicago.
"If the Winter Olympics go to Vancouver in 2010, it's unlikely that the Summer Games will come back to North America in 2012."
The task force started meeting this morning at the O'Hare Hilton, where for the first time it compared the cities based on the scores they were given during recent visits by members of the group. 
However, the scores, assessed on a 1 to 10 basis, in 14 categories, were not enough for two finalists to clearly emerge. Some of the scores from the 10 task force members displayed a preference for Washington and Houston.
But Mr. Moore said before the meeting that he expected the decision would come down to the cities' international appeal and how each would market its global allure. 
"Charlie said the international reputation would be a major factor," Mr. Kriegel said. "We anticipated that the technical foundation of our bid would be the central factor" -- which refers to the facilities, infrastructure and financial plans -- "but we worked to prove that New York had a strong international story to tell."
Anne Cribbs, the chief executive of San Francisco 2012, agreed that New York and San Francisco started with built-in advantages, as major cities that are meccas for international travelers.
"It's an easy thing to say that people love to visit San Francisco," Ms. Cribbs said. "But there's something mystical about the air, the cable cars, the bridges, but also the marriage of San Francisco and Silicon Valley. And there is the weather, the weather and the weather."
Mr. Moore said New York received no explicit consideration for the impact of the terrorist attacks at the World Trade Center. "Was anyone not sensitive to 9/11?" he said. "No. But it wasn't part of the process."
Now, New York and San Francisco must wait for the U.S.O.C.'s vote in Colorado Springs on Nov. 3 to learn which city will face an international field that might include Moscow, Paris, Toronto, Rio de Janeiro, London, Milan, Istanbul, Madrid and Tel Aviv. Those cities will begin declaring their intentions more clearly after the I.O.C. chooses a 2010 Winter Olympics site next July.

HEADLINE: Frankfurt Ballet Director Says He'll Leave in 2004 

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
William Forsythe, the American choreographer who has led the Frankfurt Ballet since 1984, announced this week that he would leave the company when his contract expired in 2004.
 Mr. Forsythe, 52, who has turned the Frankfurt Ballet into one of the most admired experimental dance companies in Europe, had been seeking guarantees of his artistic freedom from the city government in Frankfurt, which largely finances the troupe. He avoided pointing an accusatory finger at the municipal officials in announcing his decision. 
 "Simply said, I wish to pursue a more independent organizational path," he said in a statement late Tuesday. "I must admit, however, it is difficult to leave a body of work, my life's work, behind."
Mr. Forsythe, a Joffrey Ballet School graduate, indicated through a company spokeswoman today that he would not elaborate for the moment. "It's too early to speak of his future plans," the spokeswoman said. "He doesn't want to talk about it right now. But he wants to change, not to work in these kinds of organizations."
One implication is that Mr. Forsythe might prefer to work as a freelance choreographer or with small groups of dancers rather than to create a new company. In recent years his works have been frequently performed by major dance companies, including the New York City Ballet, the Paris Opera Ballet and the Royal Ballet in London.
The possibility that Mr. Forsythe might leave Frankfurt was first raised in late May, when he said he had learned privately that the city government had decided not to renew his contract and might replace the company with a classical ballet troupe. He also complained then that there had been "a smear campaign against me carried out insidiously by anonymous politicians saying I was burned out."
A few days later, after a meeting with the mayor of Frankfurt, Petra Roth, Mr. Forsythe said he had been assured that the city wanted the company to continue its work after 2004. He acknowledged, however, that the city government was experiencing a severe financial crisis. The city's $5.7 million annual subsidy represents 87 percent of the Frankfurt Ballet's budget.
The two sides then met to discuss whether satisfactory working conditions for the company could be assured beyond 2004. After Mr. Forsythe returned from vacation earlier this month, he had one further meeting with Hans-Bernhard Nordhoff, the director of the cultural department of Frankfurt, before deciding to leave the company. Mr. Nordhoff said on Tuesday that he regretted Mr. Forsythe's decision but would respect it.
In his statement Mr. Forsythe thanked Frankfurt for its "unwavering and generous support" over the last 18 years, adding that its commitment "has enabled the evolution of my thought-work to a degree which would have been difficult or even impossible to realize in a majority of metropolitan cultures in the world."
In explaining his decision, though, he opted for vague language to suggest that he found it impossible to run a dance company that was subject to the vagaries of politics.
"For the present," he said, "I feel strongly that my own methodological evolution would be best served if conducted in a context less integrated into a field of political practice that is, understandably, challenged by the task of establishing primary descriptive models of cultural policy that can be accurately represented by numbers."
He continued: "It is extremely difficult, perhaps impossible, to objectively translate or reduce intrinsic, multiple values as are typically embedded in art, into interest-maximizing numbers that explicate its relevance in political models of cultural well-being."
Mr. Forsythe's reference to numbers is puzzling because attendance for the Frankfurt Ballet is 96 percent of capacity in Frankfurt, and it invariably performs before full houses on its frequent tours around Europe.
In his statement he also implied that managing a dance company was limiting his artistic freedom. "Over the course of the last several years I have experienced a shift in my perception of the field in which I am operating," he said. "This has engendered a very specific professional intention which lacks adequate identity with my current position as director of a large municipal institution."
Neither Mr. Forsythe nor Frankfurt officials have indicated whether the troupe's 67 dancers and staff members will survive his departure. Mr. Forsythe, who also has a home in Vermont, has two more seasons left in Frankfurt. On Sept. 11 he will present a still unnamed new work there. Later that month he is scheduled to take his company to Paris, where he has a strong following.

HEADLINE: When the Cellphone Is the Home Phone 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
WHEN my wife and I moved recently from the Upper West Side of Manhattan to a larger apartment in Harlem, it was a short hop on the map. Technologically, however, it was a journey to the heart of the current turmoil in the telecommunications industry.
 Of all the troubles associated with a move, we expected phone service to be the least of them: a routine order for a telephone line and two jacks. But when I called Verizon Communications, our local phone company, I was told that it would take a week and a half to fulfill the request, at a cost of $250. 
 Other companies now offer local phone service, but they would need to have authorization from Verizon to make a connection to our apartment. So faced with unanticipated cost and delay, we took a step that would have been unthinkable just a few years ago: we decided to abandon conventional phone service altogether -- and we are not alone. 
In what may be the start of an alarming trend for the nation's largest telephone companies, the total number of business and residential telephone lines declined last year for the first time since the Depression -- to 192.3 million at year's end from 192.6 million a year earlier, according to the Federal Communications Commission.
Those who follow the industry attribute the land-line decline in small part to the general economic doldrums, while some consumers have dropped second lines as they switched to cable modem or D.S.L. for Internet access. But tellingly, a small but growing number of consumers, many of them students or recent college graduates, have abandoned land-line telephones altogether in favor of wireless service. Nearly 3 percent of telephone users have made wireless phones their primary telephone, according to the Yankee Group, a telecommunications consulting company in Boston. So far the shift is evolutionary rather than revolutionary, but that is likely to change, said Keith Mallinson, an analyst at the Yankee Group.
"It is more like gradual displacement than a complete eclipse," Mr. Mallinson said. "But the disruptive effect of substituting land lines is likely to become more far-reaching during the next few years."
Joel Kamm, a graphic designer in Waltham, Mass., uses a cable modem for his Internet connection and depends on a cellphone for the rest of his communication.
"I moved around so much in recent years, so getting a new phone line installed in each place was a hassle," said Mr. Kamm, 28, who gave up his conventional phone line two years ago. "This is the right solution for anyone that moves frequently."
One cellular company, Leap Wireless of San Diego, is at the forefront of this trend. Its Cricket service allows unlimited incoming and outgoing local wireless calls. Leap said last month that its customer research showed that a quarter of the 1.4 million Cricket subscribers did not have traditional phone lines at home.
Jennifer LeHockey, a 24-year-old Cricket customer in Westminster, Colo., said she had canceled her land line the day she got wireless service, cutting her monthly phone bills from about $90 to less than $50.
"I was just sick and tired of forking over so much money every month to Qwest," said Ms. LeHockey, a hair stylist. "As a single person, just having a cellphone was right for me."
Eric Rabe, a Verizon spokesman, said the decline in the number of land lines was no surprise. "The old telephone company measure of access lines is less accurate today as a measure of a company's health," Mr. Rabe said. Large local phone companies like Verizon are seeking to compensate for the decline in conventional phone lines by investing in the wireless and Internet access businesses, he said.
Still, the decline may be evidence of a fundamental change in the telecommunications landscape.
"It's a behavioral shift from the last hundred years in which we called a geographical place and got a person," said Jeff Kagan, an independent telecommunications analyst in Atlanta. "We're now moving to a model of calling a person -- regardless of geography. The consequences of such a change could be profound."
In my own case, there was confusion over the location of our apartment (vacant for several years before it was renovated, it had disappeared from Verizon's records) and a misunderstanding about how long it would take the company's technicians to install the line and jacks that my wife and I urgently needed, since we both work from home some of the time.
Both issues were later cleared up (a Verizon spokesman said the company would have listed our apartment in its computer system if we had ordered service; he also said the installation would most likely have taken three days, the average in Manhattan). But my wife and I could not afford to wait before settling our telephone service arrangements.
We decided to use our two wireless phones from Sprint for local and domestic long-distance calling. Time Warner Cable installed a high-speed Internet connection in two days. We make international calls using an Internet service, Net2Phone, whose rates are cheaper than what Verizon charged in our previous service plan. All told, we figure we're saving about $50 a month by not having a local telephone line, on top of the installation charge.
Relying on cellphones for voice communications has quirks both good and bad. My wife has her voice mail available on her cellphone instead of an answering machine or a voice mail system tethered to a land line at home. She no longer goes straight for the answering machine upon arriving home.
The divisions between home and work and nearly everywhere else we take our mobile phones are also blurred. Family or friends may now reach us in a supermarket or on the street, instead of in our apartment, which is quieter, and sometimes the background noise confuses the caller.
Cellphones, as nearly everyone who has one knows, are far from perfect in terms of service. Calls are impossible to make from areas known as dead zones, whereas service on a traditional line is almost always infallible.
There are other drawbacks. Wireless calls tend to drop more often than calls on land lines, as Tracie Jacobs, a customer service representative in Orlando, Fla., who gave up her land line two years ago, has experienced.
"Cellphones are not perfect, but it's worth the $90 we save each month," said Ms. Jacobs, 33. She and her husband had two traditional phone lines, one for a dial-up Internet connection, before disconnecting both to go with two cellphones and a cable modem connection.
For those whose wireless providers do not offer unlimited local calls, there is a risk that cellphone bills will be higher than those for conventional telephone service.
"Widespread unmetered local calling would really be the catalyst for wireless substitution to take off," said Paul Melton, an analyst at Telegeography in Washington.
For the time being, however, these imperfections are part of the give-and-take involved in severing dependence on a traditional phone line. Our apartment, minus two telephone jacks and land-line phone, is testimony to that.

What to Consider
Weighing Costs And Convenience
Why you might want to give up conventional phone service: 

COST -- If you already have a cellphone, your overall phone-service cost may be lower.

PORTABILITY -- There is no need for connecting and disconnecting land-line service for people who move frequently.

CONVENIENCE -- You can place and receive calls and retrieve voice-mail messages anywhere -- not just home, office or pay phone.

CHOICE -- Most consumers have many more options for wireless service than they do for land-line service.

Why you might not want to:

COST -- A realistic estimate of the number of calls you make and receive every month is essential. If you make frequent or lengthy local or long-distance calls, your bill could be higher, depending on your service plan. And with most wireless plans, you also pay for incoming calls.

STATIC -- Service quality of cellular systems does not yet approach that of land-line networks.

SECURITY -- Emergency 911 services are not as comprehensive for cellphones as they are for conventional telephones.

HEADLINE: Canadian Transit Giant Having Summer ofWoe 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
Robert E. Brown, the chief executive of Bombardier Inc., assumes that things are bound to go wrong occasionally in a company like his, which has delivered more than 100,000 railcars and 7,000 aircraft around the world, and bids on 225 new contracts each year.
 What makes Mr. Brown wince, however, is the intense interest being shown by politicians and the media in the latest crop of troubles experienced by Bombardier, which makes leisure boats as well as regional and corporate jets and rail equipment. 
 In late July, Bombardier was the loser in a widely publicized contest to build 1,700 cars for the New York subway, one of the world's largest transit contracts. Then, earlier this month, Amtrak temporarily idled the Acela high-speed trains supplied by Bombardier and its French partner, Alstom, after cracks were discovered in the locomotives' suspension system 
Capping its difficult summer, Bombardier surprised investors last week by saying it would miss its goal of increasing earnings by 10 percent this year, a target it had confirmed little more than a month previously. 
The company, which is based in Montreal, said today that its earnings fell to $65 million -- 101 million Canadian dollars, or 7 Canadian cents a share -- in the three months to July 31, from 287.9 million Canadian dollars, or 22 Canadian cents, a year earlier.
The company now projects earnings at 70 Canadian cents a share for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, 2003, down from its earlier estimate of 89 Canadian cents. Bombardier's stock has lost about two-thirds of its value over the last year.
"They're at the mercy of their end-markets right now," said Cameron Doerksen, an analyst at the Dlouhy Merchant Group, a Montreal brokerage firm. "They're being hit with three or four different things at once."
In an interview here today, Mr. Brown said that those who have pounced on the recent missteps have not given Bombardier enough credit for the diversity of its businesses.
Started more than half a century ago as a maker of snowmobiles in Quebec, Bombardier is now the world's biggest supplier of passenger railcars, regional aircraft and corporate jets.
The name comes from the company's founder, and the Bombardier family still owns 63 percent of the voting stock. Its products include the Learjet, Challenger and Global Express business jets and the CRJ regional jet.
Bombardier and Amtrak are suing each other over the Acela problems. "A technology of this kind that travels at this speed needs a certain quality of roadbed," Mr. Brown said. "Our feeling is that in the past there hasn't been enough investment in this area."
Scott Leonard, assistant director of the National Association of Railroad Passengers in Washington, said "there may be blame enough to go around on both sides." According to Mr. Leonard, "there was a tremendous amount of learning involved" in the introduction of the Acela.
Mr. Brown said that despite the lawsuits "we've got to keep our eye on the ball and make sure we deliver to the customer what we said we'd deliver."
As a short-term measure, Bombardier has repaired the defective parts and is testing the trains daily. In the meantime, it is designing new brackets in conjunction with Amtrak.
David Gunn, Amtrak's president, told The Globe and Mail last week, "I have to give the manufacturer really high marks for putting resources here and trying to fix the problem."
On the New York subway contract, Mr. Brown said he had no regrets about losing out to Kawasaki Rail Car Inc., the United States subsidiary of Kawasaki Heavy Industries of Japan. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York, in his view, "clearly went for the lowest price" and "I was determined not to lose money on this contract."
Bombardier's biggest headache now is its aerospace business, Mr. Brown said. Demand for business jets has collapsed, a situation that he attributes to the unexpected weakness being experienced by the American economy. The company delivered 21 corporate jets from April to June, down from 43 a year earlier. And eight orders were canceled in early August, six of them from North American customers.
The market for regional aircraft also shows signs of weakening, said Douglas Abbey, president of Avstat Associates, a Washington consulting firm.
Bombardier, whose CRJ's make up 59 percent of the 700 regional jets flying in the United States, received orders for 30 planes in the second quarter, down from 125 in the period last year.
US Airways, which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month, operates 110 Bombardier-built Dash 8 turboprops. Mr. Brown said that the airline was likely to seek lower lease payments on these aircraft, which could have a ripple effect on other operators.
Still, Mr. Brown said, regional airlines are doing well. "They're profitable," he said. "We see them adding routes." For example, United Airlines said this month that it would replace larger jets with a more frequent service using CRJ's between Colorado Springs and Chicago. 
The airline said it also planned to introduce CRJ's between Denver and Palm Springs, Calif. According to Innovata Data, an airline schedule manager based in Oakwood, Ga., 557 new regional jet routes have been added in the United States in the year ending in May 2002 and 294 in Europe.
Bombardier introduced a 70-seat version of the CRJ this year, and is scheduled to deliver its first 90-seat jet in early 2003. "We've been working full steam ahead," Mr. Brown said.

HEADLINE: Water for a Thirsty World 

 BODY:
Water is a vital resource for sustaining human life, growing crops and running many industrial activities. It is disturbing that in many areas of the world the demand for fresh water is rising faster than the supply, leaving about a billion people without access to clean drinking water. Regional water shortages have raised the specter of armed conflict, forced relatively affluent societies to finance huge water projects and left some of the world's most impoverished nations in deepening misery. 
 A four-part series in The Times this week illuminated some of the causes and effects of dwindling water supplies just as the United Nations conference on sustainable development in Johannesburg is beginning to grapple with how to mitigate the problems. Only a little more than half the world's available fresh water is used each year. But by 2015, according to U.N. estimates, at least 40 percent of the world's population will live in countries where it is difficult or impossible to get enough water to satisfy basic needs. It is imperative to accelerate programs that can remedy the shortfall. 
 The potential for conflict over water shows up forcefully in the Euphrates River Valley, where Turkey, with the advantage of an upstream position and a sturdy army, has commandeered much of the river's water through a $30 billion program for building dams and irrigating fields. That has forced downstream Syria to curtail its own water development plans and has left Iraq, even farther downstream, at risk as well. This conflict and similar disputes on other rivers crossing national boundaries underscore the need for a globally accepted formula on how to divide up the water from streams shared by many countries. 
Nations facing water crises have come up with many solutions, none of them ideal. China, whose urban and industrial belt in the north is desperate for water, is undertaking an enormous project to move water from the mighty Yangtze River Basin in the rainy south to parched northern areas. Keeping the water free of pollution will be a major problem, and the costs will be gigantic. Meanwhile, Argentina turned to private companies to overhaul and manage some of its water systems, only to encounter cost and technical problems. Privatization can work, but clearly it must be done carefully and with strict public oversight.
Although per capita water use in the United States has declined substantially since 1980 thanks to greater efficiency by farmers and industrial users, those gains could be threatened by the increasing thirst of fast-growing American cities and suburbs, particularly in arid regions of the West. As yesterday's concluding article pointed out, the Ogallala aquifer that spans eight Western states and supplies roughly a quarter of the nation's irrigated farmland continues to be depleted, albeit at a much slower rate than before. By 2050 the population of Texas is expected to double, while the available water there drops by a fifth. That could suck the aquifer dry quickly unless new conservation and efficiency measures are found to slow its depletion.

HEADLINE: Big Airlines Cut Service And Add Fees 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Desperate to trim costs and starving for new ways to make money, the nation's largest airlines are cutting service, tightening rules and charging extra fees to their low-fare passengers. But many travelers and industry experts say the strategies could backfire and drive customers away.
 Over the last two weeks, a domino effect has taken hold in the industry, with airlines announcing one after the other a host of restrictions: charging $10 to $25 for each paper ticket issued and $40 and up for each checked bag beyond the second one, levying a surcharge for oversized checked bags and not offering passengers in economy class full cans of soda or plastic knives at breakfast unless they ask for them. 
 The most extreme rule changes to date came on Tuesday, when US Airways announced strict new policies that include barring most passengers with nonrefundable tickets from flying standby or catching a later flight if they miss their original one. Travelers in those circumstances will have to buy a new ticket, perhaps at a walk-up fare that costs hundreds or thousands of dollars more than the original fare. Under the old rules, passengers could board a later flight if they paid a change fee and any fare difference, or received credit for the unused portion of the original ticket that they could apply toward another ticket within a year. 
US Airways also said miles flown on nonrefundable tickets would not count toward earning elite status in its frequent-flier program.
The airline compared the new standby rule to what happens when someone misses a Broadway show or sports event: no refund or credit, period. 
The major airlines operate under a follow-the-leader mentality, and some rivals are considering whether they should match the changes. 
Airlines say some changes are just attempts to enforce rules they had been waiving, and others are intended to encourage business travelers to buy more flexible full-fare tickets again. But the new policies are already stirring worry and resentment among passengers, and industry experts say the changes will make it harder for the largest airlines to distinguish their products from the low-cost carriers.
Many travelers are already saying they could soon start flying on a low-cost carrier like Southwest Airlines or JetBlue Airways, neither of which has imposed the kind of rules announced by US Airways. Passengers who miss a ticketed flight on Southwest can catch a later one or receive credit to apply to the purchase of another ticket within a year. Those who miss a JetBlue flight are put on a standby list. Southwest is known for its friendly workers; JetBlue has leather seats and real-time television. Both airlines have simpler fare structures than the full-service carriers. 
"These changes can backfire if the consumers perceive the airline is trying to nickel-and-dime them," said Michael Boyd, president of the Boyd Group, an airline consultation company based in Evergreen, Colo. "I really think the way to go in the future is to treat the customer as a friend, not say, 'Here's eight more rules you've got to follow.' This is not Marine boot camp. Enforcing rules like a papal edict is not smart."
Jim Corridore, an airline analyst at Standard & Poor's, said the most recent changes were "a negative for the industry because certainly they're not going to increase customer satisfaction."
"They're all scrounging for extra revenue," he added. "I think US Airways is going to see very quickly a drop-off in the passengers that they have."
US Airways is in a better position than many of its rivals to take a gamble because it has less to lose. It is operating under bankruptcy court protection and must show that it can carry out a stringent business plan if it is to obtain a $900 million loan guarantee from the federal government. Its new rules are intended to discourage business travelers from buying cheap tickets, which have become more and more popular among such passengers during the economic downturn.
"Our balance sheet will benefit a couple of ways," said B. Ben Baldanza, senior vice president for marketing at US Airways. "Some people will choose to pay more for the ticket to keep getting benefits. Other people won't, and we'll benefit from not having to give the perks to them."
Mr. Baldanza added that although most travelers would not be affected by the changes, he was "certainly concerned" about a defection to other airlines.
The new rules put out in the last two weeks -- all of which vary from airline to airline -- are sure to cause confusion.
At La Guardia Airport yesterday, few passengers flying on US Airways were even aware of the policies announced on Tuesday. One man who had heard of the changes, Charles Minor of Charlotte, N.C., said he was anxious because he wanted to leave on an earlier flight but had a discount ticket and was not sure whether the airline would let him fly standby.
"I'm not that thrilled with flying anymore, and these things nag on you," said Mr. Minor, a 53-year-old business consultant. "Their business will continue to deteriorate if they don't pay attention to the customers. Things like not refunding a discount ticket, that will just eat away at customer loyalty."
At O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, Anu Sing, a 32-year-old hotel manager from Washington, said that the changes by the traditional carriers were eliminating the positive differences between them and Southwest.
"You shop around for the best price, but you also take other things into consideration, like service," Mr. Sing said. "If you take that away, then they are all the same."
The new rules also complicate the jobs of flight attendants and ticket agents, who have to deliver news of the changes to customers.
Jeff Zack, a spokesman for the Association of Flight Attendants, which represents 50,000 workers in the industry, said attendants were finding it difficult to keep all the rule changes straight and that "when you're explaining reduction in service to a passenger, that's not a comfortable conversation."
The new rules could lead to a mad scramble among passengers to carefully scrutinize which airline will give them the most benefits for their money. Passengers who know they might not make their ticketed flight could very well shun US Airways or AirTran Airways, which has always had a similar no-credit policy on its low fares. But AirTran could attract customers who want to check more than two bags because it allows a third checked bag free, as does Southwest. Continental Airlines has attracted customers that want food on their flights as rivals have cut back, although that could soon cost extra as Continental rolls out more trims in the next several weeks.
Continental has said that it will charge additional fees for certain services to low-fare passengers, and it is thought to be looking at the same kinds of rules that US Airways just put in place. Continental said last week that it would charge low-fare travelers $80 for each checked bag beyond the second piece as well as not giving out full cans of soda or breakfast knives in coach class unless people ask for them.
Joe Elenteny, a 66-year-old passenger who arrived yesterday in Chicago on Continental, offered this view of the situation: "I'd be pretty ticked off if they told me I had to pay extra to bring my golf clubs. They would definitely lose my business. Why wouldn't you just go to Southwest?"
