HEADLINE: Morris Heights Journal; 
Youths Find Hope in Jobs Academy

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in the Bronx was 9.2 percent in June, the highest of any borough in New York. If a softball team were to take the field in Melrose, Clason Point or Bedford Park, the odds would be that someone in the lineup did not have a job.
 While this number may be striking, it does not give a complete picture. Government statistics tell part of the story, but they do not tell it all. 
 For that, it takes a man like Travis Greene. Mr. Greene is 19 and has no job. When he talks about himself, it is often to tell the tale of living in a group home through his boyhood and slipping on a bright blue set of beads each morning, which marked him as a member of a street gang, the Crips. 
In a dozen years, he went to a dozen schools -- in the Bronx and Brooklyn, in Queens and Manhattan -- but he always got kicked out. He has been handled by an endless string of principals and teachers, drug counselors, social workers, welfare agents and family-intervention teams. "I've been with the government all my life," he said.
These days, Mr. Greene is with the South Bronx Job Corps, living in its Gothic-style academy in Morris Heights as he prepares himself to find a job. He is studying fiber optics and learning how to function in the 9-to-5 world. Get an alarm clock. Open a bank account. Buy some khaki pants. And, while you're at it, cut your hair.
The Job Corps Academy is the only place in the borough where a young man or woman can go to learn all there is to know about getting and keeping a solid job. There are centers throughout the Bronx where jobs are listed and resume-building skills are taught, but the academy stands alone as a full-scale university of work.
The students take classes in computer networking, nursing care, security and the culinary arts. They live in dormitories and are taught that a clean home is a happy home -- that, in the future, after the workday is done and the bills are paid and the children fed, they must still find time to do their laundry and mop their dirty floors. 
In the evenings, there are fashion shows and poetry readings and trips to professional basketball games. There is also a good amount of plain, old-fashioned hanging out. 
Jason Gotay is 18. He came to the academy five months ago because, as he explained it, "I was bad."
He was selling drugs and running with a gang and attended Morris High School for a month or two but then dropped out. His mother did not stop him, so he closed his books and left. When he had a child of his own, however, his girlfriend had enough. 
"She told me if I didn't come here, we were through," he said last week. "At first, I didn't like it here -- it was boring and I felt locked up." 
Then he started reading books on CPR and decided that emergency medicine would be his field. "Now," he said, "I'm destined to succeed."
To be fair, the academy is not some Harvard for the jobless. There is no guarantee its students will leave and find good work. Nevertheless, nearly 80 percent of the 275 students who live there go on to earn a paycheck, its director said. And they are not flipping burgers, either. They are working for Time Warner and Verizon, for example. 
"When you've got broken homes with no supervision, these kids tend to look at the street and their friends as home," said Louis Joseph, the academy's social development director. "What we do is grab hold of them in a residential setting. We teach them skills, but even more, we teach them drive."
"Grab hold" may be the operative phrase, since discipline at the academy is strict. The students are fined $5 every time they break a rule. The rules are posted in the dormitory halls and each begins with "No." As in, no gambling, no abusive language, no ethnic agitation, no horseplay, no hitchhiking, no drinking, no drugs, no cutting lines.
Although the academy is part of the national Job Corps program, certain difficulties come with a South Bronx setting. Sixty percent of the students are high-school dropouts and many read no better than fifth or sixth graders do. There are students from Puerto Rico and Colombia. Often, they have problems writing Spanish and find writing English is twice as hard.
In every room, it seems, there is a student with another obstacle to overcome. In one room, it is a high-school drug arrest. In another, an absent father or parents who never worked. 
For Latoya James, it was the child she bore in her senior year of high school. She could not leave the child at home because her mother had a job. She worked as a drugstore clerk herself but could not afford the day care, so she quit. 
Now, at 20, she has enrolled in the academy to study nursing, while the child's father takes over. She knows the jobless rate is high, but she also knows she has no choice: the numbers might be bad, but she needs a job right now. "I think about it all the time," she said. "It's bad. Here, at least I'm on my own -- at least, I'm independent. Finally, I'm doing something just for me."

HEADLINE: Study Rates Bangladesh Most Corrupt Country 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
More than two thirds of the world's countries are rife with corruption, a problem that especially affects wide swaths of Latin America, Africa and the former Soviet republics, an international watchdog group said today.
 The group, Transparency International, which is based in Berlin, said that 70 percent of the 102 countries it surveyed for its 2002 Corruption Perceptions Index scored less than a 5 on an index in which 1 is the most corrupt and 10 is the least. The numbers were a sharp deterioration from the group's 2001 list. 
 The group rated Bangladesh as the most corrupt nation, with a score of 1.2. Nigeria, Paraguay, Madagascar, Angola, Kenya and Indonesia, in order, were the next most corrupt. Finland scored a 9.7 on the index, ranking as the least corrupt country for the second year in a row. It was followed by Denmark, New Zealand, Iceland, Singapore and Sweden.
The United States was ranked the 16th-least-corrupt country, with a score of 7.7.
Latin America in general has slipped down the rankings of perceived corruption of its politicians and public officials, the group said.
"In the past year, we have seen setbacks to the credibility of democratic rule. In parts of South America, the graft and misrule of political elites have drained confidence in the democratic structures that emerged after the end of military rule," said Peter Eigen, chairman of Transparency International. For example, Argentina, ranked 57th last year with a score of 3.5, dropped to 70th with a 2.8 rating this year.
Mr. Eigen, who spoke to a news conference before heading to the United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg, said corruption ruined a nation's chance to relieve poverty and heal the planet.
There were a few positive signs in former Communist nations. Slovenia showed improvement, climbing from 5.2 points to 6.0, although many nations of the former Soviet Union were still riddled with corruption.
Russia, for example, had improved. But it still scored below 3 points, as did many former Soviet republics like Uzbekistan, Georgia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Moldova and Azerbaijan.
Among the nations of the European Union and North America, Greece was the lowest-ranking country at 44th, at 4.2 points.

HEADLINE: Native New Yorkers (The Original Kind); 
American Indians of Many Tribes Work to Preserve Identity in City

BYLINE:  By JASON BEGAY 

 BODY:
The city with the largest American Indian population, according to the 2000 Census, is not Phoenix. Not Los Angeles. It is New York City.
 The news is a surprise even to some Indians living in the city. "You're kidding, right?" said Rosemary Richmond, the director of the American Indian Community House in Manhattan. 
 The census counted 41,289 American Indians and Alaska natives living in the city in 2000. And although the Census Bureau's form allowed people to claim more than one race, helping increase the numbers from previous years, when the census counted those people who claimed only some American Indian or Alaska native heritage, New York City was still No. 1, with 87,241. (Los Angeles and Phoenix ranked second and third in both population categories.)
One reason people do not realize how many Indians are in the city is that they are spread throughout the boroughs. "There's no concentration of a community, because there's such a diversity of tribes," said Michael A. Taylor, who works with the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers, and was the head male dancer in the annual Thunderbird Powwow in Queens last month. 
"And the diversity of percentage of blood, it's across the board."
There are more than 500 American Indian tribes in the country, and many are represented in New York City. Most tribes, Mr. Taylor said, have their own languages and religions.
The American Indian Community House in Lower Manhattan provides services to about 6,000 people a year, including a free lunch program, food and clothing banks, medical referrals and job and computer training. Some board members, however, say that the center, which was formed in 1969, is in need of expansion, both of its offices at 708 Broadway and of its services.
"One of our problems is that we are defined by our social problems," said Leota Lone Dog, an artist and board member, of the center's focus on helping the poor and the unemployed. 
"The people who are coming into the city don't have the same types of problems that this organization was built on."
One of the biggest problems now, says Louis Mofsie, the chairman of the center's board, is more intermarriage.
"As time goes on, we're going to have more and more Indian people in urban areas with less and less Indian blood," said Mr. Mofsie, who is Winnebago and Hopi and has spent all of his 65 years in and around New York City.
So even though the community house is the largest meeting place for American Indians in the city, with a solid flow of regulars who attend the monthly powwows and lunches for the elderly and youth council meetings, Mr. Mofsie said that he would like to see the center offer more social gatherings and events.
Perhaps, he reasons, that would make it easier for the city's American Indians to meet one another. Some have found that hard, and harder still to meet someone from the same tribe.
"I went through it myself; I did look for a Seneca husband," said Stephanie Betancourt, 48. "But you can't say who you're going to care about."
Mrs. Betancourt's husband is Puerto Rican. Their son Paul Betancourt married outside the tribe as well. Because tribal lineage is passed through the mother, his children will not be considered Senecas by the tribe, the Seneca Nation of Indians.
Mr. Betancourt, 25, was born on a reservation in western New York but has spent most of his life in the city, growing up in the Bronx and going to school in Harlem. 
He shares the passion of his tribe's history and culture that his mother tried to instill in all three of her children. He and his mother both now work at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, in Lower Manhattan 
Mrs. Betancourt tried to balance the Seneca and Puerto Rican cultures of her three children. But the tribal policy means that it will be hard to remain an Indian family.
"How much blood do you have to have to be an Indian?" Mrs. Betancourt asked.
Alyse Eggleston, a spokeswoman from the clerk's office at the Seneca Nation of Indians in western New York, said this tribally mandated rule was an extension of tribal history. "It's always been that women traditionally have more power," she said. 
This is little consolation to Mrs. Betancourt. "I think we live in times where we have to think about changing things," she said. "I don't think we're ever going to have a homogeneous race again."
Mr. Mofsie and Ms. Richmond do recall when there was an identifiable American Indian community in the city. Both talk fondly of the time in the 1960's, when Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, around Nevins Street was full of Mohawks who worked in steel. 
They also talk about a church on Pacific Street, where the pastor learned to speak Mohawk.
"We were there all the time," Mr. Mofsie said. The Rev. David Munroe Cory, the pastor, even allowed Mr. Mofsie's group of friends, who called themselves the Little Eagles, to use the church to sing and dance. That group eventually became the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers.
But even without a similar neighborhood now, Mr. Mofsie sees Indians working to hold on to their heritage, despite documentation disputes in the tribes. 
"I see the enthusiasm the people have in keeping the traditions alive," he said. "Being an Indian is becoming more a cultural than a blood issue."
There are already some groups in the city that have accepted this and are dedicated to continuing the cultures of their tribe, regardless of official tribal recognition.
Walter Red Eagle is a founder of the Cherokee Language and Cultural Circle. He is 58, a retired truck driver and walks with a cane wrapped in buckskin. His great-grandfather, he said, was Cherokee.
He is not enrolled in the tribe, and has no plans to be. "Why would I want to?" he asked. "They don't ask any other ethnic group to enroll or prove their heritage." 
Mr. Red Eagle learned to speak some Cherokee growing up in Radford, W. Va. He said he learned to speak fluently from a tribal elder he met in New Jersey in the early 1990's. Since 1997, he has met weekly with the circle, although many of the members are not enrolled in the tribe. 
Mr. Red Eagle's Cherokee heritage is a small portion of his ethnic background, but it is the part he feels bonded to. "It doesn't matter what mix of culture you have," he said. "What you were meant to be in life comes out."

HEADLINE: Iran's President Trying to Limit Power of Clergy 

BYLINE:  By NAZILA FATHI 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, said today that hard-line clerics had made it all but impossible for him to do his job and that he would propose legislation to adjust the balance of power so that he could pursue reforms.
 President Khatami's statement amounted to a clear expression of frustration with the clerics who hold most real levers of power and have thwarted a president elected twice on promises to open the economy and usher in greater civil liberties. 
 "I am announcing today that the president must have the power to perform his duties within the framework of the Constitution," he said at a news conference.
"We cannot speak of democracy if we are not ready to play by its rules," he added. "The main aspect of democracy is the right of people to change a government if they do not like it." 
The president acknowledged that dialogue with the hard-liners had proved fruitless so far, and his challenge today suggested a new willingness to confront them more forcefully. It seems certain to intensify a long power struggle in the country.
Mr. Khatami said he would seek to bolster his powers through Parliament, where his supporters hold a majority and his proposals seem certain to pass. 
But any such changes can be blocked by a religious panel called the Guardian Council, which has turned back reforms before, though never proposals so sweeping.
Among his statements today that are sure to infuriate opponents, Mr. Khatami said he was open to ties with the United States. "We haven't said there will never be a change in policy toward America," he said. 
But he said that "America's policies have created concern in the world" and that relations could change only if America treated Iran with the same respect that European nations did.
"We cannot engage in a dialogue in which the other side constantly uses an intimidating tone against us," Mr. Khatami said. "We are willing to have dialogue when we become confident that this situation has changed."
The United States severed ties with Iran in 1980 after the Islamic revolution in early 1979 and the subsequent seizure of the American Embassy here by students who took 52 Americans hostage. 
President Bush has labeled Iran part of an "axis of evil" along with North Korea and Iraq, against which the administration is openly considering war. "I hope the U.S. makes no mischief against Iran," Mr. Khatami said.
Mr. Khatami's election in 1997 and re-election last year seemed to offer opportunity for a thaw with the United States. But his achievements have been limited as hard-liners have retained control of the judiciary, security forces, army, large economic centers and the government-run television.
One of the most substantial obstacles to change is the religious panel called the Guardian Council. Members of the panel are appointed by the supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and are authorized to reject any legislation they consider counter to the Constitution or Islamic law.
Among its powers, the watchdog body is authorized to interpret the Constitution itself and has the right to disqualify candidates for elections.
Mr. Khatami said his government had already presented Parliament with a bill to limit the powers of the council, which has used its authority to prevent many politicians supporting reform from running for office.
The next election for Parliament is scheduled to take place within 18 months, and analysts say that without limiting the powers of the council, many reform candidates may be thwarted again.
In addition, Mr. Khatami said he would soon send Parliament a bill to restore presidential powers from the time when Ayatollah Khamenei held the office in the 1980's.
Those powers would allow the president to act as head of state, enforce the Constitution and protect citizen's rights.
Mr. Khatami noted that he had been the first president deprived of those powers.
In recent months some of the most serious political struggles have come between the president and the judiciary, which the hard-liners control and which has been backed by the Guardian Council.
The head of the judiciary, appointed by Ayatollah Khamenei, has shut down nearly 60 publications and jailed scores of reform activists and political opponents, including 33 members of a religious nationalist party who were sentenced to prison and lashes last month.
Mr. Khatami has tried to use the presidency to supervise the judiciary, which has conducted closed trials of political dissenters. 
Today, Mr. Khatami said the Guardian Council had vetoed that attempt.
But he insisted that the judiciary's performance remained unconstitutional. The fate of newspapers should be decided by a jury, he said, and trials should take place in open courts with the presence of a jury.
"But they have never listened," he said.
Mr. Khatami warned that public disaffection was rising in Iran, where a sluggish economy has spawned an unemployment rate of 14 percent. But he acknowledged that much of this dissatisfaction stemmed from his government's failure to bring citizen's greater freedoms. His own frustration was evident.
"The Guardian Council should not reject the bills," he said, "because they are logical and none of them are against the Constitution or the Islamic law, unless it intends to violate the Constitution."
The president insisted that he wanted to avoid any social unrest. But he also acknowledged that the faith and patience he had placed in dialogue with his opponents had worn thin.
"Unfortunately I have had no success," he said. "My warnings have been ignored, and the president's duties, which are clearly stated in the Constitution, have been suspended."
Chief among those duties, he said, was to enforce the Constitution, and he insisted that at a minimum he should have the power to do so.
"A president who cannot perform that role is no good," he warned, "and we will seek other alternatives if this fails."

Marketing Agency Opens in New York

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
 Turf, a brand marketing agency, is being opened in New York by Mark Trippetti, who will be president. The agency has 10 employees and clients like American Express Publishing and Chelsea Piers. HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Talks Are Feverish With Strike Due Tomorrow

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When Commissioner Bud Selig arrived at baseball's office on Park Avenue in Manhattan late yesterday afternoon, a fan was waiting outside the building. "Get the deal done," the fan said emphatically. "You're making me miserable."
 The negotiators for the owners and the players wanted a done deal, but despite their feverish efforts to accomplish their goal and avert a strike that is scheduled to begin after tonight's games, they seemed to be failing. 
 A person familiar with the talks said late last night that there was no reason for optimism. "Substantial differences remain in the area of the luxury tax," the person said.
Negotiators had one session during the day and four brief meetings in the evening. At the fourth evening session, the two sides learned that their attempt at progress was falling short. The brevity of the earlier sessions was not a bad omen. "The meetings are not unexpectedly brief," a negotiator said.
He meant that in exploring ways to solve the differences, the negotiators were delivering updates on their positions, then breaking for internal discussions before the next session, where more updates would be given.
The two sides reached agreement on a steroid-testing program on Tuesday, and yesterday they were working on the two key economic issues: revenue sharing and a luxury tax on payrolls. Some player representatives seemed to become more optimistic yesterday that an agreement could be reached.
"We feel like we can really see the end," Mike Stanton, the Yankees' player representative, said in Boston. "There is still work to be done. I don't want to give the impression it's all done and waiting for Bud's signature. But we're in the ballpark."
A union official suggested, however, that the player representatives' optimism came more from what they were hearing from their clubs than what they were hearing from the union.
Union officials and management representatives were basically silent on the subject of progress, however.
The negotiator who talked about the brief meetings, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that in past days negotiators had focused on structural elements of the luxury tax, such as the number of years it would be in effect.
"In the last few days, the focus has been on numbers and we don't have anything resolved in either area," he said. "But we're working at it."
Numbers, as in payroll thresholds and tax rates. Those numbers, along with the numbers of dollars that richer teams would contribute to poorer teams, will determine whether the season continues with a day game in Chicago tomorrow and 14 night games tomorrow night or whether the players will scatter to their homes at the start of baseball's sixth strike and ninth work stoppage in three decades.
Asked if there was time to avert a strike, Selig, who did not participate in the bargaining sessions, said in a telephone interview: "I hope so. I believe so. Time will tell. It's a tough situation to read."
A day earlier Selig had said that if a deal was not reached by midnight tonight or not long afterward, baseball would be "on dangerous ground." Last night he amended that view slightly.
"We have to stretch this out as far as we can," he said. "Hopefully, if we're making progress, you can go as long as you can."
Many teams delayed their charter flights for tomorrow's games. Teams customarily travel to a playing site the day before a game.
Union officials have instructed players not to report to parks for tomorrow's games if there is no deal. They do not want to have players walking out of parks, walking ducks for photographs that would certainly elicit scorn from fans.
In 1994, when games ended the night of Aug. 11, clubs and players faced no uncertainty about their destinations because they knew the strike was on. The two sides were far enough apart on the clubs' demand for a payroll cap that a strike was guaranteed.
In this instance, players today will most likely finish six day games and four night games not knowing whether they will walk out before tomorrow's games.
What they do know is that they will undergo testing for steroid use next spring training, if there is a spring training. Although some details must be worked out, the two sides agreed to a schedule of survey testing and unannounced, random testing.
The initial testing will be done as a survey. As long as tests show that fewer than 5 percent of the players use steroids, survey testing will continue. If in any year the tests show that more than 5 percent use steroids, a two-year program of random testing will begin.
Random testing will end if fewer than 2 1/2 percent of the players test positive. Survey testing would take its place. The two sides still have to work out whether that 2 1/2 percent would apply to the second year of random testing or both years.
Wherever players are in the program, random testing will not survive the labor agreement. The two sides will have to negotiate a new plan for the next agreement.
If random testing begins, a player will not be disciplined for testing positive the first time. A player instead will be placed in the joint drug program for treatment and for more frequent testing. 
Players will be disciplined for additional positive tests. The plan calls for six terms of progressive suspensions for second and third offenses, the discipline becoming more severe with each offense.
Paul Lo Duca, the Los Angeles Dodgers' player representative, was the first person to disclose the steroids agreement to reporters on Tuesday night, but he incorrectly said players had also agreed to testing for cocaine and marijuana. The players had agreed to continue testing only for cause, as has been in effect for years.
In the efforts to get agreements on the luxury tax and revenue sharing, negotiators had floated 50 to 100 ideas in the last few days, one of the negotiators estimated. 
One of those ideas, another negotiator said, dealt with an extra year in the agreement. Instead of having it run through the 2006 season, it could go through 2007. In that way, the clubs could get the four years of payroll taxes they want and the players could get the last year of the agreement tax-free, which they want.
But that idea did not survive, both negotiators said, and it is unlikely any agreement will run through 2007.

HEADLINE: France Mutes Its Criticism Of U.S. Stance Toward Iraq 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
The new center-right French government has decided to stop criticizing American war planning against Saddam Hussein and instead maximize its leverage with the United States by stressing areas of agreement, according to senior French officials.
 Under the previous center-left government, French-American relations were often poisonous, characterized by repeated spats over issues ranging from perceived American unilateralism to policy in the Middle East. 
 The decision reflects an important tactical shift. Its proponents, including the new foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, argue that a more conciliatory policy will avoid needless friction between the two longtime allies and allow the government of President Jacques Chirac to keep open its options in case the United States decides to wage war unilaterally against Iraq. 
The move may also help protect France's national interests in Iraq, including its oil trade, should the United States wage war and win, the officials said.
The tonal shift does not mean that France has suddenly embraced the American position that a military campaign to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq from power is justifiable and perhaps necessary.
Rather, Mr. Chirac and Mr. de Villepin have come to the conclusion that it is wiser to present France as an active, strategic partner of the United States and to keep quiet about specific policy differences.
"More and more at the highest levels people are saying, 'We don't like a military operation but there's likely to be one so what do we do,' " a senior French official said. "So the goal is to keep all our options open and not criticize, not to provoke a backlash. We feel that Washington is expecting us to react negatively and we have decided not to. It's a tactical choice."
Another senior official put it more bluntly, "We're driving the Pentagon crazy by keeping silent." 
The French shift leaves France and Germany in uncharacteristic positions. Germany, normally the most pliant of allies, has said it will not participate in an American "adventure" in Iraq. This tone has played well for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder as he campaigns for re-election next month. Meanwhile France, normally the most combative of allies, has been restrained.
French officials seem to be relieved, even amused, that it is now the Germans who have taken the lead in taking on the Bush administration for its Iraq policy
On Tuesday, Mr. Schroder described Washington's course as a "mistake" that undermines United Nations efforts to resume weapons inspections in Iraq. He has also said a war could wreck the international antiterror coalition, inflame the Middle East and hurt the world economy.
The French attitude towards the United States was reflected in a speech by Mr. Villepin that opened a conference of French ambassadors at the Foreign Ministry on Tuesday.
Unlike his predecessor, Hubert Vedrine, who seemed to relish any opportunity to criticize the United States, Mr. de Villepin, who lived and worked for years in Washington, stressed the positive. He spoke glowingly of American "dynamism, energy and exceptional enthusiasm," and the need for the United States and Europe to unite in a "new Euro-Atlantic partnership." 
As for Iraq, he branded it a regime that "defies international rules set by the Security Council, holds it people hostage and threatens security, particularly that of its neighbors. Such behavior is not acceptable. We Europeans, know too well the price of weakness in the face of dictatorship if we close our eyes and play a passive game."
The emerging French strategy is to take diplomatic cover by putting any talk of war in the context of the rule of international law. Indeed, in his speech, Mr. de Villepin said that the international community must demand the unconditional return of United Nations inspectors to the country, but did not say what should be the response if Iraq refused. As for waging war, he reiterated the French position that "no military action can be conducted without a decision of the Security Council."
In his speech, Mr. de Villepin did not say, as other French officials have said privately, that the Iraq problem can only be dealt with after the war between Israel and the Palestinians is resolved. 
The passage on Iraq was carefully negotiated for hours inside the Foreign Ministry and with the Elysee Palace. It will be reiterated by Mr. Chirac when he delivers a speech to the ambassadors at the Elysee Palace on Thursday, according to Catherine Colonna, Mr. Chirac's spokesman. 
"For the moment, the most useful position is to remind people of the obligations of Iraq and the role of the Security Council," Ms. Colonna said. 
Last evening, in a meeting with ambassadors assigned to the Middle East, Mr. Villepin was peppered with questions that underscore the delicacy of France's position. "It was a real brainstorming and shows how things are too hypothetical now to take a stand," one participant said. "People were asking, 'What do we do if the Americans come up with a U.N. resolution and we don't accept it? Do we take part in the drafting? Do we vote for it? If we vote for it, do we send troops?' " 
According to his aides, Mr. Villepin simply listened.

HEADLINE: At Development Talks, U.S. and Its Allies Clash Over Issues of Energy and Pollution 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
For days now, the battle between rich and poor nations has dominated the United Nations talks here on the environment and development, with marches and fiery debates over how to reduce poverty. 
 But one of the fiercest struggles has been raging behind the scenes as the United States and the European Union clash over strategies to preserve the planet. 
 The allies are battling over the question of targets and time frames for the conversion from oil and gas to windmills and solar panels, for the cleanup of garbage and hazardous pollutants and for the preservation of endangered plants and animals. 
The European Union says these talks must produce a strong plan with firm deadlines so the world's leaders can be held accountable for their actions. The United States opposes targets and deadlines, saying it would rather finance specific projects than support goals that might ultimately prove meaningless. 
The negotiators on both sides are still cordial. But everyone agrees that the dispute has aggravated tensions that have been simmering since President Bush angered his European colleagues last year by refusing to ratify an international treaty aimed at preventing global warming. Nowhere is that rift more visible than in the debate over renewable energy. 
Scientists say the industrialized nations are endangering the earth by using fossil fuels that contribute to global warming. Renewable energy sources like wind power and solar energy produce smaller and more expensive amounts of electricity than plants using traditional fuels, but renewable energy sources generate a tiny fraction of the carbon dioxide and gases that are believed to accelerate global warming. 
Under the plan favored by the European Union, nations would commit to ensuring that renewable energy sources account for 15 percent of the world's total energy production by 2010. The United States has rejected such proposals. Canada and Saudi Arabia, significant producers of fossil fuels, have also objected. With both sides digging in their heels today, the talks seemed deadlocked. 
"We have a range of issues -- renewable energy, sanitation, hazardous chemicals and the reversal of the decline in biodiversity," Yvon Slingenberg, a senior member of the European delegation, said in an interview. "On all of those issues, we have not managed to convince them." 
American officials dismissed such criticism. In the coming days, the United States will announce programs aimed at providing clean water and reliable electricity in developing countries. Action, they insist, matters more than words. 
"We have maintained consistently that targets alone will not deliver the energy services needed," said Griff Thompson, the director of the Office of Energy, Environment and Technology for the United States Agency for International Development. "It's not the words in and of themselves that will electrify classrooms." 
David Garman, an assistant secretary in the Department of Energy, said the United States was focusing on trying to reduce the costs of renewable energy, which is still more costly than coal or gas. "Renewable energy is great because it's clean," he said. "It also tends to be more expensive." 
But at the talks here, the United States has been repeatedly, and sharply, criticized for refusing to commit to concrete obligations. 
Today Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, and Jerry Brown, the Democratic mayor of Oakland, assailed the Bush administration's energy policy at a news conference here. They called for a new commitment to solar power and an end to fuel subsidies. 
"There are people in the administration who will say, 'We don't need to talk about timetables,' " Mr. Kucinich said. "But when scientists can show that over a period of time that global warming can, in fact, impact on the increase in world temperature, we better be talking about timetables." 
The debate, however, is more nuanced than some American critics suggest. 
The United Nations describes the United States as a pioneer in renewable energy; it is already one of the largest producers of wind energy in the world, even though the technology is still costly. Even the European Union has rejected proposals favored by environmentalists that would demand an even larger commitment to renewable energy. 
"You can't say that the Europeans are dashing around reducing emissions furiously," said Gordon Shepherd, the director of international policy at the World Wildlife Fund. "But they have acknowledged that they have to. They've sent a message that things must change." 
Mr. Shepherd said he believed the two sides would come to some sort of consensus, even if it meant horse trading on certain issues. But negotiators were not predicting an easy breakthrough. 
"We've not made any progress," an American official said of the negotiations today. Asked whether he thought the two sides could bridge the gap, he shook his head and said, "I'm not sure."

HEADLINE: Senior U.S. Official Underscores Bush's Criticism of North Korea 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
A senior American official today vigorously defended President Bush's inclusion of North Korea as part of an "axis of evil" -- along with Iran and Iraq -- saying the term was "more than a rhetorical flourish, it was factually correct."
 In a strongly worded speech, the official, John R. Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control, cited what he said was "a hard connection between these regimes -- an 'axis' along which flow dangerous weapons and dangerous technology." 
 Besides building weapons of mass destruction, Mr. Bolton said, "North Korea also is the world's foremost peddler of ballistic missile-related equipment, components, materials and technical expertise." There were, he said, "few if any signs of change" indicating that the North was heeding demands by the United States to 'get out of the business of proliferation." 
Mr. Bolton chose a important juncture in inter-Korean efforts for reconciliation to issue a broad warning to North Korea on the development of nuclear as well as chemical and biological weapons.
He spoke on the second day of the first working-level economic talks in nearly two years between North and South Korean officials. South Korean negotiators, hoping for a breakthrough in President Kim Dae Jung's efforts at reconciliation with the North in the final six months of his administration, said they would try to get the North to agree to a timetable for the completion of a railroad linking the two Koreas. Mr. Bolton reiterated the willingness of the United States to reopen dialogue with North Korea but focused on the dangers posed by North Korean weapons of mass destruction. South Korean officials feared that his reference to an "axis of evil" would undermine North-South dialogue and also jeopardize chances for meaningful talks between American and North Korean officials.
Mr. Bolton said he wanted "a little straight talk among friends" when he made the broadest American public policy statement heard here in recent years on the North Korean threat. The remark reflected what was perceived here as Washington's concern that Mr. Kim and some of his top aides are playing down the threat posed by North Korea.
Indeed, some Koreans who attended the speech said that Mr. Bolton wanted to talk publicly because he was having difficulty getting South Korean leaders to listen to what he had to say privately. 
Mr. Bolton placed less emphasis than did Richard L. Armitage, the deputy secretary of state, on the prospects for a visit to North Korea by a senior American official, probably James A. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs. Mr. Armitage, in Tokyo, said that North Korea had indicated its interest in such a visit and that Mr. Kelly might go there fairly soon.
Mr. Bolton said only that resumption of discussions between the United States and North Korea was "one of the Korean government's highest priorities." The United States, he said, would engage in "intense" discussion with South Korean officials "on all aspects of any consultations with the North."
While castigating the North for "continuing development of weapons of mass destruction and exporting the means to deliver them," Mr. Bolton sought to allay concerns that his remarks might provide a rationale for a pre-emptive strike. The United States, he said, still had "no intention to attack North Korea in any way, shape or form."

HEADLINE: TAKING THE CHILDREN; 
Looking to Catch a Wave (And Also Looking Good)

BYLINE:  By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
Blue Crush
Kate Bosworth, Michelle Rodriguez, Matthew Davis, Sanoe Lake, Mika Boorem, Faizon Love
Directed by John Stockwell
PG-13 109 minutes
 "The Girls Lay Pipe," reads a headline in a Hawaiian newspaper. That's surfer talk for rocketing through the curling overhang of a 20-foot wave on the north coast of Oahu. Fall off the board and you are driven into the bottom by tons of breaking water. Waivers signed by contestants on the beach before the big competition mention possible dismemberment. 
 Three years ago Anne Marie (Ms. Bosworth), a top surfer, bounced her head off a rock and almost drowned in these waves. Now she has to get back out there and compete against the No. 1 woman in the sport if she expects to land all those big product endorsements. Anne Marie isn't sure she wants to do this, although it could mean a major move up the economic ladder for her, her rebellious kid sister, Penny (Ms. Boorem), and her two friends and housemates (Ms. Rodriguez and Ms. Lake).
At the moment they barely scrape up rent for their scroungy beach bungalow by working as chambermaids at a resort hotel. There they get to mop up after vacationing professional football players with revolting hygiene. They're all great guys, though, and one of them, a quarterback named Matt (Mr. Davis), takes a shine to Anne Marie and vice versa.
Everybody urges her on for the coming tussle with the huge breakers. But Anne Marie is wave-shy. On competition day she falls a lot, taking a terrific bashing. The waves are coming in sets of four every 20 seconds. Here comes that really big one.

VIOLENCE -- Matt gets into a fistfight with some local surfers.
SEX -- Plenty of references to go with much bared flesh.
PROFANITY -- Off-color talk.

For Which Children?
UNDER AGE 8 -- The surfing could be a little scary for some small children, and the earthy tenor of things on shore is none too favorable.
AGES 8-10 -- Fine if parents agree. The movie leans to the obvious, but it has good things to say about fears and perseverance.
AGES 11 AND UP -- Sure.

Simone
Al Pacino, Catherine Keener, Evan Rachel Wood, Rachel Roberts, Winona Ryder, Pruitt Taylor Vince, Elias Koteas, Jay Mohr
Directed by Andrew Niccol
PG-13 100 minutes
Suppose you are the movie director Viktor Taransky (Mr. Pacino) and one day at the studio an unkempt man jumps out of the shadows and yells: "I licked the skin! I licked the hair! I licked all of it!"
Taransky hasn't been having an easy time lately. His new picture, "Sunrise Sunset," has just had the plug pulled after its hissy star (Ms. Ryder) quit in a rage over the cramped confines of her trailer, an Airstream 50-footer. Then the studio chief (Ms. Keener), who happens to be Taransky's former wife, fires him.
So there he is throwing his belongings into a car when he is accosted by this fellow, Hank Aleno (Mr. Koteas). Years earlier Aleno had proposed teaming with Taransky to develop an actor who was completely digital. Now Aleno has done it!
Simulation One (call her Simone) is perfect in every detail, absolutely indistinguishable from reality. Aleno begs Taransky to collaborate and adds that they had better hurry. All that staring at a computer screen has left Aleno with a tumor in his eye. He has a week to live.
Taransky says thanks, but no thanks. Later, though, he is willed Aleno's program. Some months after that, the world is astonished by the radiant Simone (Ms. Roberts) in "Sunrise Sunset." Instantly she becomes a sensation, adored by the public and clamored for by the media. Sharper at subterfuge than he is at moviemaking, Taransky quickly masters the rules of playing the game with a star like Simone. First he makes her a retiring, humble loner who makes Garbo look like a publicity addict. No offense to her fans or fellow actors, but on no account can an artist of such sensitivity come in contact with anyone other than Taransky, not even those she performs with in her movies. All awards ceremonies, all receptions that turn into riots at the very rumor that she might be present, are strictly absentee affairs.
Operating at a computer, Taransky gets through all situations and makes himself the artistic inspiration she refers to on all occasions. On a personal level, his former wife the studio boss wants him back. His daughter (Ms. Wood) adores him (as she always has). But then he realizes that he has had enough. It's time for Simone to die -- mysteriously, of course. Will she?

VIOLENCE -- A few riotous situations but no real violence in the purest sense.
SEX -- Some references.
PROFANITY -- Quite a bit.

For Which Children?
UNDER AGE 11 -- Not for them. This is a very long 100-minute movie, seeming to conclude only to resume just when this audience (and some of the rest of us) will be ready to throw in the towel.
AGES 11 AND UP -- Many will like this film. The technology is fun. Taransky and Simone are winning, as is Taransky's loyal young daughter. At the end we even have a little moral: it's fine to make something fake; just don't be a fake about it.

Serving Sara
Matthew Perry, Elizabeth Hurley, Vincent Pastore, Bruce Campbell, Cedric the Entertainer
Directed by Reginald Hudlin
PG-13 100 minutes
Barging into a gambling den, Joe Tyler (Mr. Perry) asks a mobster if he knows who he is. "You're the guy who's leaving in the trunk of my car," the man answers. Tyler is a process server, not a happy profession. His boss, Ray (Cedric the Entertainer), dispatches him and his obnoxious rival, Tony (Mr. Pastore), to hand out the bad news, provided they can catch up with the intended recipients.
Ray gives assignments, and fees, to the faster man, so Joe and Tony always try to throw each other off the scent. The quarry here is Sara Moore (Ms. Hurley), the beautiful wife of the Texas cattleman and genial cad Gordon Moore (Mr. Campbell). Wanting to be rid of his wife, Gordon and his lawyers hire Ray to serve Sara with divorce papers. After chasing her around a while, Joe is ready to accomplish the task. But surprisingly (not so surprising if there's to be a movie), they like each other. Then they get an idea. Serve Gordon before he serves Sara.
As the film has it, nailing a man in Texas is difficult because of conservative divorce laws and the fact that no judge in the state is still with his first wife. But Joe and Sara infiltrate the Moore spread and chase old Gordon clear to the Mexican border. Will they catch him before Tony catches Sara?

VIOLENCE -- Slapstick scuffles.
SEX -- To get on the Moore ranch, Joe poses as a veterinarian and is called on to stimulate an impotent bull, which he does by thrusting his arm fully inside the animal (it looks real). He and Sara wind up in the same bed at one point, but so anemic is the chemistry between Mr. Perry and Ms. Hurley that they might as well be in different buildings.
PROFANITY -- Much, and a lot of scruffy talk, too.

For Which Children?
UNDER AGE 11 -- No.
AGES 11 AND UP -- It's hard to imagine children crowding into this one. There are some laughs. Parents' decision.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Collectors With a Weakness for the Ornery

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Wasn't late-20th-century American art strange, with its insane variety, outlandish forms and outrageous ideas? I think so; that's why I love it. And I was reminded how strange it was when I visited an exhibition at the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College, where objects made 40 years ago felt every bit as resistant and hard to love as they must have the day they were made.
 The show is "From Pop to Now: Selections From the Sonnabend Collection," and the Sonnabends themselves, Ileana and Michael, did, of course, love these objects or at least found them intriguing enough to want to have around. And they bought many of them early, straight from the studio, before most people were aware that such irritating stuff even existed. 
 The Sonnabends had an inside track: they were dealers in contemporary art. More important, Ileana Sonnabend was, and remains, one of the pioneering figures in the aesthetic Big Bang that took place in the 1950's and 60's, and produced the expanding, centerless, diffuse art universe we know today. 
Born in Romania, she came to New York in 1941 with her husband, Leo Castelli. They opened a gallery and discovered, among other young artists, Jasper Johns. The new era began. Divorced from Castelli in 1960, she married Michael Sonnabend and moved to Paris, taking American talent -- Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein -- to Europe.
In the 1970's it was back to New York and to SoHo. There she had yet another gallery, this one in the same building as Castelli, and showed more Americans and artists she had encountered in Europe, like Christian Boltanski, Bernd and Hilla Becher, and the British duo Gilbert and George. And all along, she and Michael Sonnabend, who died last year at 100, collected art.
The exhibition at the Tang -- organized by Charles A. Stainback, the director of the young, very on-the-ball museum -- is a broad sampling of the Sonnabends' acquisitions, from small paintings to bulky installations. On the whole it's a one-work-per-artist affair, and for that reason, combined with the rapid-fire eclecticism of the postwar art itself, it has a disorientingly jumpy rhythm, as if many individual voices were clammering for attention at once.
And unlike the expensively packaged traveling exhibition "Jasper Johns to Jeff Koons: Four Decades of Art From the Broad Collection" now at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Sonnabend show doesn't have the heft and polish of a masterpiece presentation. Instead, it feels personal, happenstantial, like history in the making, almost anti-masterpiece. Individual works are awkward, messy, even ugly. Why on earth would anyone want such things in their home? Because collecting this really radical art required having a brain as much as an eye.
The first work in the first gallery, "Grand Poubelle" (1962) by the French-born artist Arman, is a preview of coming attractions. One of a series of plexiglass virtrines that the artist filled with trash from his New York studio, it is a 3-D collage, a time capsule of everyday life, a post-Dada joke and a monument to consumption and decay.
Some of these identities are picked up in the pieces around it. One is a funky 1962 Rauschenberg combine made of a free-hanging tarp with a stuck-on Coca-Cola sign. Another is smudgy, shop-signish 1959 Johns stencil painting of the numeral 8. A third is "Balcony," a 1961 easel-size painting by James Rosenquist that splices together bodily images -- a honey-blond bouffant hairdo, a cuff-linked sleeve -- and real mirrors.
None of these are grandstandingly important works, but each represents a shift in thinking for the artist or the collector. "Balcony" was among Mr. Rosenquist's first uses of applied objects. The Johns painting was one that Ms. Sonnabend bought early, then sold and later bought back.
From this core display of turning-point art, the show broadens out. In the second gallery, Pop assumes its classic empty-is-the-new-full form in Warhol's stacked Brillo boxes. And generations mix. Near Warhol is Haim Steinbach's neo-Pop "Ultra Red No. 1" (1986), with its shelf of digital clocks and lava lamps. On the wall is a sardonic 1992 paean to alcohol consumption by Ashley Bickerton, while an even more recent painting by the same artist further on pushes Pop's ambivalent social commentary in devastatingly explicit directions.
Then change again -- different look, different mood, different thoughts -- in a gallery of Minimimal and Conceptual pieces. They take a rarefied form in a rose-colored light piece by Dan Flavin, glowing like a stained glass window. But Robert Morris's vulva-shaped, draped-felt sculpture is one of the sexiest pieces in the show. And John Baldessari's 1968 Minimalist sendup is one of the funniest. For it, he hired a sign painter to write on an empty canvas "Everything is purged from this painting but art, no ideas have entered this work."
But there are ideas all over the place. They helped make the Pop-Minimal-Conceptual era one of the most intellectually challenging episodes in 20th-century Western art; no wonder we're still reworking and reliving it. The Sonnabend Gallery played a significant role in shaping it, in part by shaping an American market for European art, including the movement known as Arte Povera, highlighted on the Tang's second floor.
It evolved in Italy during a time of political unrest in the early 1960's. With the country's economy in a slump and students and workers on strike, a group of artists came up with an art that pointedly rejected both painting and consumer culture, then as now closely linked, in favor of work made from "poor," prosaic, often found materials like wood, wax, plaster and cloth.
America never knew quite what to do with this art, which lacked the incisiveness of Pop, the clean lines of Minimalism and the emphatic nothing-thereness of early Conceptualism. Instead it offered a bunch of conceptual opposites: hard-soft, old-new, sweet-sour, nature-culture embodied in scuffed-up, pieced-together objects that might have been invented by a child.
In "Wax and Rubber" (1966), for example, Mario Merz placed two hollow half-cylinders of translucent beeswax and thick black rubber end to end on the floor and put a lighted bulb inside. An untitled 1969 installation by Giovanni Anselmo has six bricks standing upright in a metal container of water. These works are, respectively, about illumination and evaporation.
Arte Povera can look a bit precious, with its discreetly utopian, post-hippie, metaphor-spinning sensibility. But it also has a daffy exoticism that feels refreshing now. This comes across particularly well in a historical survey of the movement, "Zero to Infinity: Arte Povera, 1962-72," now in Los Angeles and opening at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington in late October.
In the 1990's Ileana Sonnabend collected and exhibited a crop of young artists. Several of them -- Elger Esser, Candida Hofer, Clay Ketter, Matthew Weinstein -- are represented at the Tang. Thanks to their presence, the show is less like a valedictory gesture than like an up-to-now status report, as much about the present and future as about the past.
One gets the same salutary lift from an energetic new museum like the Tang. Under Mr. Stainback it has a lively, forward-looking exhibition program; solo shows by interesting young artists like Nayland Blake, Kara Walker and Fred Wilson are scheduled for the coming year. At the same time, with interdisciplinary ties to the academic community of which it is a part, it has its eye on history and how that works. In such an environment, the Sonnabend collection is right at home.

"From Pop to Now: Selections From the Sonnabend Collection" remains on view at the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery, Skidmore College, 815 North Broadway, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., (518) 580-8080, through Sept. 29. It then travels to the Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University (November to February) and the Milwaukee Art Museum (February to May).

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Figure 8" (1959), 20 by 15 inches, by Jasper Johns, at Skidmore. (Jasper Johns/VAGA, New York) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Every Which Way to Paint

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT'S amazing how much you can learn about one medium over the course of viewing a few focused, often modest and seemingly unrelated museum exhibitions. Take the five shows, spread among four museums, that I visited on a sultry summer day here. 
 The shows had so little in common that I felt I had been dropped down on a series of small, isolated islands; so much art-historical ground was covered so quickly that aesthetic jet lag seemed likely. Yet by the end of the day, I realized that the shows' different coordinates were more connected than they had seemed, and that the link was the meandering ways and means of painting. 
 In fact, the works in these shows come from three different continents, span about eight centuries and aren't necessarily on canvas, or even flat. But painting in one guise or another is their common ground and they have much to say about its evolution, persistence and variety. Looked at from these angles, these little islands of painting define a terrain much greater than the sum of their individual territories. 
I am not kidding about the lack of canvas or even flatness. Some of the best painterly effects in these shows appear on the pieces of furniture, ceramics and textiles included in "An American Vision: Henry Francis du Pont's Winterthur Museum" at the National Gallery of Art. 
Sometimes paint is altogether absent, as in Winterthur's superb examples of needlepoint, blankets and quilts. One standout is a veritable monument to crossfertilization: a quilt that was not simply inspired by the profuse floral designs of the woodblock-printed cotton exported from India to the American colonies, but was actually constructed from them. Its maker appropriated these designs directly, cutting leafy flower motifs from a piece of Indian cotton and then quilting them, together with homespun calicos, to create a tree of life. The lush blooms and the plainer calico leaves, bark and ground are delightfully at odds, but the undulating rhythms of the tree's sinuous form -- not so far removed from those of a multi-armed Indian goddess -- provide the unifying force. 
"An American Vision," which was organized by Wendy A. Cooper of Winterthur, also has several impressive works on canvas. There is a wonderfully awkward portrait of the four slightly stiff, very serious children of the Gore family, painted by John Singleton Copley in 1755, before his style was smoothed out by training in England. And an unknown artist's charming full-length portrayal of young Magdalena Douw, from around 1740, depicts the daughter of a wealthy Dutch family. (She later became Mrs. Harme Gansevoort.) She is shown in all her finery, including a blue brocade dress and bright-red shoes. It is a picture in which nearly every element has a life of its own, from the boldly bulbous table she stands beside to the blue and flamingo-pink clouds in the windows behind her. 
My interest in things pictorial should not distract anyone from the fact that everything in this exhibition is exceptional and attests to du Pont's extraordinary eye and passion for excellence. In addition, the show, which is often arranged in period groupings, provides an unusually clear-cut introduction to the different influences and styles -- European, Asian, American, folk, rococo and Neo-Classical -- evident in the American decorative arts before 1840. 
Painting is limited to traditional canvas in "Anne Vallayer-Coster: Painter to the Court of Marie Antoinette," a second exhibition at the National Gallery. This is the first retrospective accorded this French painter, who is known mostly to specialists but was well-established in late-18th-century Paris. It was initiated by the Dallas Museum of Art, where it was organized by Eik Kahng (now a curator at the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore); the show is going to Dallas in October and the Frick Collection in New York in January. 
The daughter of a goldsmith, who grew up around artists, Vallayer-Coster (1744-1818) was accepted into the French Academie at the age of 26. She was given an apartment at the Louvre (with the intervention of her patron, Queen Marie Antoinette) and her work was acquired by the most discerning collectors of her day. Diderot mentioned her favorably in his review of the Salon exhibition one year and other critics were similarly admiring, although none failed to mention that the artist was a woman. 
Vallayer-Coster excelled at still-life paintings, especially of flowers, which were her most popular subject. The National Gallery show begins with a room of nothing but flower pictures, and while they are breathtakingly exquisite they also seem fussy and rarely match the quiet straightforwardness of Chardin's flower still lifes, one of which is also displayed in the first gallery. 
After this slightly disappointing introduction, the show grows steadily stronger: by its end, with a gallery devoted to still lifes of plums and grapes, you may consider Vallayer-Coster nearly Chardin's equal. That she is a more daring colorist is confirmed by several large still lifes with seashells, coral, lobsters and other sea creatures, riven with pinks and reds, including one completed the year before she died.
The art historian Marianne Roland Michel, whose 1970 monograph on Vallayer-Coster is the only previous book devoted to the artist, has contributed to the catalog a finely detailed new study of her life that is a model of art-historical sleuthing and insight. Also included are essays by Colin B. Bailey, Claire Barry, Laurent Hugues, Melissa Hyde and Ms. Kahng, as well as a list of all the artist's known works -- a total of 159. It is a powerful experience simply to lay hands on this substantial, informative book and wonder how many more might be written about forgotten artists who happened to be women. 

Ron Mueck
Vallayer-Coster was less successful as a portraitist, but the National Gallery show includes a few and they are more than competent. It is interesting to keep her subjects' soft, translucent and vein-tinged complexions in mind as you walk into Ron Mueck's show at the Hirshhorn Museum. 
Mr. Mueck (the name rhymes with Buick) is an Australian-born but London-based sculptor known for making human figures that look startlingly real, except that they are always larger or smaller than human scale. But a great deal of the jaw-dropping effect of Mr. Mueck's art depends upon old-fashioned painting skills: that is, his astounding ability to paint the surfaces of his sculptures, which are made of molded fiberglass, to resemble, almost exactly, real skin -- young or old, smooth or callused, ruddy or pale, whiskered or bare. It is trompe l'oeil in the round, and it also connects Mr. Mueck to other flesh-obsessed English painters, especially Lucian Freud and Stanley Spencer.
This show, the artist's first in an American museum, consists of four sculptures: a giant, bald rotund man who sits in a corner as if sulking; an ancient, undersize woman asleep in bed; a wall sculpture of a smaller-than-life infant whose dangling legs and arms akimbo suggest that he is being lifted by invisible hands, perhaps from his bath; and, best of all, an enormous masklike self-portrait of the artist's sleeping face. Resting horizontally on a pedestal, it can make you feel like a Lilliputian standing next to Gulliver's pillow. 
Mr. Mueck's alterations of human scale distance his sculptures from the viewer. Yet his work creates a sharpened awareness of intimacy and its liberties by dramatizing the unsettling possessiveness and appetite of the gaze. Much of his sculpture's power comes from the way it simply allows us to stare, up close and to our heart's content, at another human being, another life, that isn't really alive and won't respond. It is the kind of intimacy that most of us have only with the bodies of lovers, parents or children; having it in a museum is unnerving. 

'The Adventures of Hamza'
As for painting on flat surfaces, the high point among these shows is the stunning "Adventures of Hamza" at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery. (Those who miss it in Washington will have another chance at the Brooklyn Museum of Art in November.) The show brings together 61 of the approximately 200 surviving folios from the 1,400-page "Hamzanama," or "Story of Hamza," including 28 from MAK (Austrian Museum of Applied Arts/Contemporary Art) in Vienna that have never been shown in this country.
Commissioned by the great Mogul emperor Akbar in 1557, and completed 15 years later, the "Hamzanama" manuscript set down on paper the daring feats of Hamza, a Muslim folk hero. It also combined Persian, European, Central Asian and Indian pictorial conventions to form one of the great turning points in Indian painting. The folios are relatively small and portable, although at about 26 by 20 inches they are large for Indian paintings. Still, measured in terms of Western painting, the exhibition is comparable to transporting Giotto's frescoes from the Arena Chapel in Padua to an American museum.
The show has been organized by Massumeh Farhad, associate curator of Islamic art at the Freer Gallery and the Sackler, and John Seyller, professor of art history at the University of Vermont. The catalog, by Mr. Seyller, includes contributions from Wheeler M. Thackston, Ebba Koch, Antoinette Owen and Rainald Franz. 
The paintings are almost excessively rich in color, pattern and action. Hamza and his allies do battle, make great escapes, confront demons and sea monsters, traverse stormy oceans, skulk around pinkish mountainsides and vanquish and often dismember their enemies. Almost always fabulously attired, they rendezvous with beautiful princesses and hold strategy meetings in lush gardens and ornate palaces.
Frequently they seem to do most of these things within the space of a single image. Needless to say, that space is amazing, dense as collage, yet pocketed, full of different, coexisting volumes and perspectives. I sought respite in the closest thing to openness -- those pinkish mountainsides and roiling seas, which are black and covered in delicate coils of white. This is an exhibition worth several carefully paced visits. 

'Sienese Painting'
In contrast with the visual overabundance of "Hamza," the Corcoran Gallery of Art's exhibition "Art and Economics: Sienese Painting From the Dawn of the Modern Financial Age" has a slightly paltry feeling. Those expecting to feast on great Sienese painting will be disappointed. This show is more like hors d'oeuvres, and the flavors are sometimes a little surprising. 
The display features roughly 50 examples of bicchernas, the small painted panels that the city of Siena began commissioning from local painters in 1257 to use as covers for civic documents, especially the city's accounting books. Recently cleaned and lent by Siena's city archives, the panels date from 1258 to the early 1600's. 
Dominated by images of bursars, their offices, desks and piles of coins, the panels, enhanced by use, tend toward an endearing crudeness. Some are still banded by the rough leather straps that originally held the documents together.
Especially in the 1300's and 1400's, the bicchernas reflect the changes triggered by the new naturalism of Giotto, and some are, or are thought to be, by artists who contributed to those changes, including Ambrogio Lorenzetti, Sano di Pietro and Giovanni di Paolo.
But names carry little weight in this exhibition, where some of the most engaging paintings are by unknown artists, for example, a blocky little image of the city's cathedral, its black and white marble walls flanked by its terra-cotta roof and piazza. Basically this exhibition gives a worm's-eye, unedited view of early Italian painting, showing us its artisanal roots, along with history's messy sprawl, and it is an oddly invigorating sight.

HEADLINE: Toyota and Chinese Carmaker in Venture 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation signed an agreement here today with China's largest automaker to begin large-scale production of a wide range of models, becoming the latest multinational to place a big bet on China's fast-growing car market.
 Toyota officials said that beginning next summer, the venture would produce about 100,000 minicars a year and 10,000 to 20,000 luxury sport utility vehicles. Toyota and its partner, First Automotive Works, will also build an assembly plant to begin turning out at least 50,000 midsize sedans a year in 2005. 
 Those plans are in addition to another joint venture that Toyota has already set up and that will begin manufacturing 30,000 compact cars a year, starting in October. First Automotive, known as F.A.W., also has an existing partnership, a venture with Volkswagen to build compact cars. 
Fujio Cho, Toyota's president, said at today's signing ceremony in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing that his company planned to build 300,000 to 400,000 vehicles a year in China by 2010, a volume equal to nearly half its current output in North America.
"As China joins the World Trade Organization and gets the Olympics, the economy of China will develop quickly and it will become one of the most important markets for Toyota," he said.
Automakers sold nearly 750,000 cars and 750,000 trucks last year in China, making each market almost a 10th the size of the American car and truck markets. But sales have been rising swiftly, especially lately, with car sales up 40 percent so far this year as China's entry into the trade group forced it to lower import tariffs on cars, bringing prices down sharply.
Auto industry experts said that Toyota's deal underlined the large scale of foreign automakers' investments in China, and they warned that the situation could result in the same overcapacity and disappearing profit margins that have afflicted the auto industry in many industrialized countries.
"I knew they had ambitious plans, but that's a huge plan" that Toyota unveiled, said Graeme P. Maxton, the managing director of Autopolis Asia, a consulting firm in Singapore. "This is yet another company with huge ambitions for China, which means there is half a dozen of them all saying the same thing, and they can't all do it.'
Volkswagen, Honda and General Motors have all announced production plans in China similar or close to those of Toyota, while Ford, DaimlerChrysler and BMW are pursuing somewhat smaller ventures.
Japanese automakers face an extra obstacle here: lingering resentment about Japanese atrocities during World War II, when the Japanese army occupied large areas of China. A Japanese court ruled on Tuesday that the army had conducted deadly biological experiments on Chinese civilians, involving the release of bubonic plague and other diseases. But the court decided that surviving victims and relatives of the deceased were not eligible for compensation because of peace treaties concluded at the end of the war, a decision that provoked indignation here.
If the Chinese market does not grow fast enough to absorb all the cars envisioned, some of them could be exported. Honda has said that it would like to export cars from a new factory it will build in Guangdong Province in southern China.
But auto manufacturing is a capital-intensive business in which low-income countries like China have seldom had much success. Assembly plants here still tend to be either fairly high-cost operations that rely heavily on imported parts for lack of domestic suppliers, or else low-cost, low-quality operations selling modest numbers of cars that do not meet international standards for reliability and defect-free appearance. Big American, European and Japanese auto parts companies are setting up operations here as well, however, which could make factories here more competitive by the end of the decade.
Under the agreement, Toyota will provide management expertise, technology, marketing assistance and cash while F.A.W. will provide workers and much of the factories and equipment. Toyota will not take an equity stake in F.A.W.
"The auto industry in China is not fully developed now, but the market is booming, so F.A.W. and Toyota need each other," said Zhu Yanfeng, F.A.W.'s president.
Mr. Cho of Toyota estimated that building or expanding factories to produce 400,000 cars a year would require an investment of 300 billion yen ($2.5 billion) in other countries, but he said the cost in China had not been calculated.
The compact cars, midsize cars and what Toyota officials described as minivehicles are all to be produced in Tianjin, where F.A.W. is in the process of acquiring a controlling stake in a local car maker. The officials refused to say whether the minivehicles would be cars or some other kind of automobile.
The luxury sport utility vehicles, both large and midsize, are to be made in F.A.W.'s home city of Changchun, where F.A.W. operates an extremely large truck factory.
F.A.W.'s main expertise lies in trucks, for which it is China's dominant producer and one of the world's largest manufacturers. But it has long sold cars as well and has close ties to China's leadership.
Mao Zedong signed one of the first F.A.W. cars while China's prime minister in the early 1970's, Zhou Enlai, sent company managers to Toyota on one of the first overseas trips by Chinese auto managers to learn how cars are built in a capitalist country. Deng Xiaoping used to tour troops on military parades in Tiananmen Square while standing in an open-roofed Red Banner limousine made by F.A.W. China's current president, Jiang Zemin, has visited the company's operations on at least three occasions.

HEADLINE: 2 New Economic Reports Show Signs of Weakness 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Two government reports released today showed that the economic recovery lost momentum in the second quarter and that new claims filed last week for unemployment benefits climbed to their highest level in nearly two months. 
 A Commerce Department report says that after growing at a rate of 5 percent in the first quarter, the economy stumbled in the spring, increasing at an annual rate of just 1.1 percent. 
 The department's latest reading on gross domestic product in the second quarter was unchanged from its initial estimate a month ago. The G.D.P. measures the total value of goods and services produced in the nation. 
In a second report, the Labor Department said that for a third consecutive week, more Americans filed new claims for unemployment insurance.
Although economists were expecting claims to go down, claims rose by 8,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 403,000, their highest point since July 6, when claims hit 407,000. That was also the last time claims exceeded 400,000, the level associated with a weak job market.
"Right now the economy is in desperate need of a labor market revival, and these data don't suggest that is in the cards," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Argus Research Corporation.
The number of unemployed people continuing to collect jobless benefits increased by 90,000, to 3.6 million, for the week ending Aug. 17, the most recent period for which the information is available. That suggested that employers were not doing a lot of hiring, economists said. 
The unemployment rate, now at 5.9 percent, could hit 6.3 or 6.5 percent by fall, they said. 
The G.D.P. report showed that after-tax profits of corporations rose at a rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, down slightly from a 2 percent growth rate in the first quarter. 
Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisors called the profits picture decent and said he hoped businesses would become more inclined to invest. 
"That will require a change in corporate attitudes," he said, "from the wait and see to the let's get going."
Consumer spending in the second quarter grew at a rate of 1.9 percent, down from a 3.1 percent growth rate in the first quarter. Businesses cut spending on plants, office buildings and other structures at a rate of 17.7 percent, a deeper cut than initially estimated. But investment in equipment and software, after six consecutive quarters of decline, increased at a rate of 3.1 percent in the second quarter.
