HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Bankers Have Cushion Should Games Stop

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Despite Major League Baseball's industrywide debt of more than $3 billion, several bankers said that reserve funds built into many of the outstanding loans provide a cushion against business lost to a possible players' strike.
 And they said they are unlikely to exert pressure on team owners to settle a strike quickly to guarantee the flow of uninterrupted interest payments. 
 "We've structured all our sports transactions in a way that minimizes risk," said Rob Tilliss, a managing director of J. P. Morgan Chase, which is part of Major League Baseball's $1.3 billion credit line and was the original lender of $170 million to the San Francisco Giants to build Pacific Bell Park. "Our preference is that it be resolved because it's good for our business." 
Sumitomo Mitsui Banking lent the Detroit Tigers $145 million to finance the construction of Comerica Park and is not worried that the team owner, Michael Ilitch, will not make his payments on the two-year-old ballpark, where attendance has fallen 20 percent this season.
"We have significant reserves built into the loan for as long as a strike can last," said Jim Weinstein, a senior vice president of Sumitomo, which is a lender with FleetBoston Financial on the Philadelphia Phillies' stadium, which is to open in 2004. "We've known and they've known for two or three years that this could happen, and we've built up the reserves."
He added: "We scratch our heads when we hear that we'd pressure them to pay if there's a strike. But we never pressure a client over how they do their business. But there's no question they have to pay on time and no question if they don't, they would be in default."
But he said there is no doubt that they will pay because of the reserve. And he sought to minimize how much Ilitch owes the bank in interest.
"They have $130 million outstanding," Weinstein said. "What's that, $8 million or $9 million a year? That's less than the Tigers will pay Bobby Higginson next year."
In a strike, owners will lose game and local television revenues but will not have to pay salaries.
The so-called "sinking funds" in loans like Sumitomo's require that the borrowers put money in reserve to cover interest if they cannot otherwise pay. As loan balances decrease, the reserve funds shrink.
"Most of the loans we've seen are structured to provide for unforeseen events," Dan Champeau, managing director of Fitch Ratings, a credit rating service that has reviewed more than $8 billion in debt in the four major sports leagues since 1990. "The industry standard includes reserve funds, but we haven't reviewed debt that's been used to pay player salaries."
The $170 million Pac Bell loan that J. P. Morgan sold in 1997 to a group of insurers led by the Teachers Insurance Annuity Association also contains reserves dedicated to paying interest.
"Teachers likes the long-term nature and stability of that kind of asset," Tilliss said at J. P. Morgan, which is also a lender to several teams.
The $1.3 billion credit line -- which is run by FleetBoston Bank -- is similarly protected and is secured by payments from baseball's national television deal with Fox Sports.
"The Fleet reserves are well in excess of $150 million," Weinstein said, and we expect another $100 million in November."
Fox must continue to pay baseball in the event of a strike, even if it causes the cancellation of the World Series. But within 12 months, baseball would have to repay Fox the estimated $300 million and possibly $230 million more when an arbitrator rules on damages to Fox.
As for what payment protection exists in borrowings for a recent purchase of a team, like that of the Boston Red Sox, the team's president, Larry Lucchino, would not comment. A group led by John Henry acquired the team, Fenway Park and an 80 percent interest in the New England Sports Network for $660 million earlier this year.
Marc Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Ltd., a sports finance consultant, said there is a level of comfort within baseball about teams being unable to pay debt through a strike. "Bankers led by Fleet have been in close contact with Selig, going back one or two years," he said.
Despite protections built into most loans, there are still financial risks posed by a strike. If a strike cancels the postseason and continues into next season, Champeau said that baseball risks the anger of national and local sponsors who may pull out of the sport or demand reductions in their fees. The next local and national TV deals could be slashed. 
Reduced revenues from those sources could slow the owners' cash flow, and they would have to find other sources to finance their working capital with so much money already dedicated to paying loans.
Sal Galatioto, who heads sports lending at Lehman Brothers, said: "The problem isn't loans to healthier teams, but loans or debt to marginal ones. The Tampa Bays have real trouble getting debt under any circumstances. So most teams will be fine, but one or two will have problems if the strike goes past the World Series. If the strike continues to opening day, and some loan reserves go away, lenders will get more nervous."

HEADLINE: Blunt Portrait Drawn of the U.S. Work Force in 2020 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Demographic changes threaten to hamstring economic growth and widen inequality in incomes in the next several decades, according to a report being released today by a nonpartisan group of leaders from government, universities and the private sector.
 In its report, the group, the Aspen Institute, offers some stark forecasts for the quality and quantity of the American work force. The report says that economic growth will be hampered by changes in the population and in education levels. 
 The next 20 years, the report says, will strike a sharp contrast with the last 20 years. For example, higher fertility rates and women working in greater numbers helped the labor force grow 50 percent from 1980 to 2000. Over the next 20 years, the labor force may grow as little as 16 percent, the report says, as fertility rates decline, women's participation in the work force levels off and baby boomers begin to retire. 
At the same time, the number of native-born workers from ages 25 to 54 will not grow at all in the next two decades. And although the share of workers with any post-high-school education rose 19 percentage points in the last two decades, it will probably increase only four percentage points by 2020, potentially curtailing growth in labor productivity.
David T. Ellwood, a professor of economics at Harvard University who directed the report, said the forecasts on native-born workers and education should be right on target. Those future workers have already been born, and many have finished their formal education. The combination of reduced growth in the work force in both numbers and education levels "suggest a very serious slowdown in economic growth," Mr. Ellwood said.
He declined to predict how much the economy's potential for growth could drop as a result of the changes in the work force. Standard estimates of labor's contribution to the economy suggest that the growth of gross domestic product could slow as much as a percentage point a year -- up to a third of annual growth -- absent any changes in policy.
In addition, Mr. Ellwood said, a rising premium on skilled workers could further polarize incomes. "Industry needs more skilled workers," he said, "and if the supply doesn't keep pace with that, wages become more disparate as skilled workers get paid more and less-skilled workers get paid less."
The gap between incomes already widened sharply from 1970 to 2000, according to census data tabulated for the report.
The wave of change in the labor force has been a long time coming, but the report may be the first to consider the broader economic effect. "Everyone understands that the aging of the population has really worrisome features for Social Security," Mr. Ellwood said, "but no one's thought through what it means for the larger economy."
On Wall Street, at least, that statement may ring true.
"We've looked at demographic questions, but we frankly haven't looked at this particular one," said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. The slowing growth of the labor force is not a surprise, he said, but the potential for slower productivity growth is a concern. He noted, however, that on-the-job training could sometimes substitute for formal education in promoting productivity gains.
Members of the committee sponsoring the report acknowledged that warnings of labor scarcity might not attract much attention in a slowdown but that the tight labor markets of the 1990's could soon return.
"Before the current economy, you were experiencing all those shortages," said James E. Oesterreicher, a member of the committee, who retired as chairman and chief executive of J. C. Penney in 2000. "Now they've lessened a little bit, but they're going to come back. There's going to be a scarcity both in quantity and in skill level."
Mr. Oesterreicher said the labor and skills shortages could hit medicine, nursing and high technology the hardest. His former field, retailing, is already having problems, he added.
The report points out that only immigration and later retirements will be able to swell the ranks of America's workers in the years ahead. From 1996 to 2001, foreign-born workers accounted for 89 percent of the growth in workers from ages 25 to 54 and for 53 percent of the growth in workers with doctoral or professional degrees, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
To keep skill levels improving and productivity growing, the report suggests enlarging government training programs and strengthening their links to employers. The Labor Department, said Sue Hensley, a spokeswoman, is working with businesses to ensure that its programs develop useful skills and that jobs await workers who finish the programs. About 669,000 Americans participated in major training initiatives financed by the department in 2001.
Mr. McKelvey suggested that companies might respond by intensifying their own training programs and by seeking skilled workers abroad. Foreign workers no longer have to leave their homes, he noted, to work for American companies.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Extends Lease of a Renamed Newark Airport 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved the terms of a lease yesterday to extend its operation of Newark International Airport to 2065, and agreed to rename the airport Newark Liberty International in honor of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack.
 The lease approval will also cover the extension of the port agency's operation of Port Newark, one of the maritime ports on Newark Bay through which the region's container cargo passes. All that remains, said officials of both Newark and the Port Authority, is the final drafting of the leases. 
 The authority's payments to the city will include a $165 million cash settlement for longstanding disputes -- money that could provide Newark with financing to help build a long-sought arena for the New Jersey Nets and Devils.
The proposal for the $355 million arena has been hung up in the Legislature under three governors as South Jersey and suburban lawmakers have balked at any state support for the urban arena or assistance to the wealthy owners of sports teams. It now appears possible that Newark can close the deal with the teams' owner, YankeeNets, to build the arena without needing legislative approval. 
The extension of the current airport lease, which is due to expire in 2031, would make it easier for the authority to borrow about $3.8 billion over the long term for improvements and other investments at Newark International, the region's busiest airport. Jack G. Sinagra, chairman of the Port Authority, said the agreement "is fair and equitable and it allows the Port Authority to plan future investments at the airport that will not only improve service but also strengthen the region's economy."
But just as important, agency officials said privately, is the hope that the increased rent to Newark and up-front payments to end the disputes will serve as a template for lease extensions at New York's La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports. 
Those leases, which had been the subject of dispute and rancor between the authority and the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, will expire in 2015. The agency has already encountered problems in financing projects there because of the uncertainty whether the city will take over the airports' operations, as it had threatened to do.
The authority's approval of the lease terms comes nearly a week after Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and members of his City Council, faced with a budget gap, unanimously approved the same terms. That settlement would increase the annual rent that the city receives from the port agency from $35 million last year to a base of $65 million. The increase will allow the city to close gaping holes in its budget this year as well as insulate property owners from the impact of a long-delayed revaluation of their property.
The amount would be reviewed every five years and increase as gross revenues of the airport rise.
In addition there would be a cash windfall of $165 million and it is that amount that many expect will be used to help finance a proposed arena in the city for the New Jersey Nets and Devils.
Last week Gov. James E. McGreevey and Gov. George E. Pataki first announced that they would seek to rename the airport Liberty International, to honor the victims of Sept. 11 terrorism. But as opposition grew to the elimination of the city's name, Mayor James negotiated the compromise name of Newark Liberty International Airport as part of the lease talks.

HEADLINE: Improvement, Albeit Slight, Is Noted in Indian Point Safety 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Federal regulators announced yesterday that the new owner of the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant has made improvements there significant enough to raise the plant's dismal safety rating, if only slightly.
 The plant, on the Hudson River in Buchanan, Westchester County, had the worst safety rating of the country's 103 commercial nuclear power plants. But in a report released yesterday by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Indian Point 2 was listed among the six worst in terms of safety. 
Still, the report was mostly positive, and it provides a timely boost to the image of Indian Point, which the Entergy Corporation bought from Consolidated Edison in September. While Entergy officials hailed the report as a milestone, opponents dismissed it as insignificant. 
Especially after Sept. 11, many environmentalists and politicians have called to have the plant closed, warning that a terrorist attack or a plant malfunction could be catastrophic, spewing radiation many miles around the plant, which is 30 miles from Manhattan.
But that opposition seems to have lost some momentum this summer. Almost a year after Sept. 11, public apprehension about another attack has lessened, and the fear of Indian Point's being a terrorist target has become a less effective rallying cry for the plant's opponents.
Meanwhile, Entergy has been campaigning to convince the public that the plant is safe. The company has mounted a public relations drive that includes broadcast ads referring to Indian Point 2 as an "energy center" rather than a nuclear plant and repeating its new slogan, "Safe, Secure, Vital." The company has encouraged the plant's 1,460 employees to attest publicly to its safety.
Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy, called the report crucial in notifying the public about the plant's safety. "People can start feeling better about Indian Point because it's a safe place," he said. "The federal regulator has said so itself, and that's important to us and the community. We feel we can improve further and be one of the best-rated plants in the country."
But foes of the plant dismissed much of the report. Kelly MacMillan, a spokeswoman for Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, whose district includes Buchanan, warned that "we can't lose sight of the fact that this is still an unsafe plant with an evacuation plan that cannot protect the public health and safety."
She added, "Going from the worst-rated plant in the nation to just one of worst rated in the nation isn't cause to feel there has been a great victory for the safety of the people, economy and natural resources surrounding the plant." 
According to the report, eight federal inspectors spent a month studying Indian Point 2 this summer and concluded that Entergy had operated the plant safely and made progress in addressing its "underlying performance issues," including equipment operation, engineering methods and oversight by senior management.
The report commended Entergy for addressing weaknesses that had led to two major malfunctions: a steam generator tube failure in February 2000 and an unexpected reactor shutdown in August 1999. These two incidents led to the poor rating.
The biggest current flaw cited in the report was weakness in a wall intended to protect the plant's central control room in case of fire.
Alex Matthiessen, executive director of the environmental group Riverkeeper, said: "The report does nothing to address the fact that Indian Point is a potential terrorist target and poses an enormous risk to the 21 million people living in the New York metropolitan area."
While the report makes no specific mention of how the plant would withstand a terrorist attack, Mr. Steets, the company spokesman, said that breaking through the reactor was virtually impossible, especially with recent security improvements.

HEADLINE: Growth Up in Japan in Quarter, But Pace Already Seems to Fade 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
Japan's economy grew moderately in the April-June quarter, the first expansion in more than a year, thanks to rising exports and an increase in consumer spending, but the tepid figures suggest the country's mild recovery is already losing momentum. 
 The figures, the first to be calculated using a new method that the government said would improve their precision, show that Japan remains dependent for its economic health on growth in its export markets, especially the United States. 
 With many of those markets flagging Japan's six-month-old economic expansion risks collapse. 
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is under pressure to find ways to increase growth at home and limit the country's vulnerability to any slowing of exports. So far, his efforts have been complicated by infighting between politicians who want more public-works spending and ministry officials who want to reduce the budget deficit and pay down debt. Analysts say the jumble of tax cuts being considered has little chance of spurring new growth. 
Instead, Japan will probably trundle anemically along until either growth gathers steam overseas, or a banking crisis or other internally generated calamity sends the economy into a tailspin. 
In the three months to June, the economy expanded just 0.5 percent, or 1.9 percent at an annual rate. Net exports and consumer spending rose while capital spending and government outlays declined. When the new formula for calculating national accounts, which uses additional data on spending and reduces the emphasis on production, was applied retroactively to the first quarter of 2002, government statisticians found less growth than had been reported earlier. Instead of expanding at a 5.7 percent annual rate, the economy stood still in the period, under the new reckoning.
Another crucial gauge of the health of manufacturers, industrial production, slipped 0.4 percent in July from June, the government said.
The economy's tepid performance has been made worse by falling prices, which erode profits and make debts more burdensome. Five years of deflation have highlighted what economists here call the three excesses plaguing Japanese companies: too many workers, too many assets and too much debt. To raise cash to pay creditors, companies are closing factories and eliminating jobs, and even companies earning solid profits, like Toyota Motor, are freezing wages.
As unemployment rises -- it stood at a near-record 5.4 percent in July, the government reported separately today -- consumers, in turn, are closing their wallets. Retail sales fell 5.7 percent in July from July 2001 as household incomes fell 4 percent.
"How can you spend money when salaries are going down and unemployment is going up?" asked Akio Makabe, a senior economist at the Mizuho Research Institute. "Exports are the only thing supporting the economy these days."
Mr. Makabe expects these conditions to continue for another year or two at least. Other analysts estimate that companies still need to eliminate about two million more jobs, or 5 percent of the work force, to reach efficient levels. Under such conditions, employers are doing little new recruiting -- the number of workers hired has fallen for 10 consecutive months -- and college graduates and other new entrants to the work force are left to scramble for lower-paying part-time jobs.
Managers are also reducing their capital spending plans. Over all, companies spent 0.5 percent less on factories, equipment and other capital goods in the quarter ended June 30 than in the quarter of 2001. Even exporters enjoying strong overseas demand, like automakers and electronics manufacturers, find sales at home muted. And primary industries like steel and chemicals are running at well below capacity.
Many of these industrial companies are also swimming in debt. On Thursday, Moody's Investors Service lowered the credit ratings of four of the country's largest machinery makers. Moody's cited heavy debt loads and shrinking demand for the ships, power plants and other heavy machinery they build.
Currency shifts also present a challenge. Japanese exporters have been hurt by a rise of almost 12 percent since March in the value of the yen, making their products less competitive and their foreign sales less lucrative. Recently, the yen has nearly reached 115 to the dollar, a common break-even point for automakers and electronics companies that earn the bulk of their profits overseas. The government has spent trillions of yen intervening to keep the exchange rate from breaching that level.
The threat that a strong yen poses to the profits of exporters has also helped take the shine off the Japanese stock market, which earlier this year had been rallying. Worries about the yen and about a looming slowdown in the United States helped send the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down on Thursday to 9,620.14, just 200 points above the post-bubble low it set in February.
With stocks so weak, huge losses may loom for the country's banks, which must revalue their portfolios to reflect market prices when the first half of the Japanese fiscal year ends Sept. 30. Banks are trying to compensate for these expected losses by charging more for loans and cutting off delinquent borrowers. The policy has led to a surge in bankruptcy filings in a country where, for decades, banks habitually propped up teetering borrowers as long as possible.
"The problems in the banking system affect the entire economy," said Rieko McCarthy, a credit analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities. Noting that some 22 percent of bank loans are nonperforming, he said, "Unfortunately, the country doesn't have the tools to withstand it." 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about economic growth in Japan referred incorrectly to a credit analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities who discussed the country's problems with nonperforming bank loans. The analyst, Rieko McCarthy, is a woman.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Boeing Declines to Resume Talks With Its Machinists
With 25,000 machinists ready to walk out on Monday, Boeing has rebuffed a request to resume negotiations that a mediator made in the hope of averting a strike. The mediator had asked Boeing and the union to meet because he had "determined that any job action threatens" to disrupt commerce.
 Negotiators with the International Association of Machinists agreed to resume talks and said the union would postpone a strike for 30 days. But Boeing surprised the union by declining. "There is nothing left to negotiate," the company said. Page A12. 

Signs of Weakness in Economy
Two reports showed that the economic recovery lost momentum in the second quarter. A Commerce Department report says that gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 1.1 percent. A Labor Department report said the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance last week rose to its highest point since July 6. C4.

The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 23.10 points, at 8,670.99. The Nasdaq rose 21.39 points, to 1,335.77. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dipped 0.07 point, to 917.80. C6.

Report Sees Changes in Work Force
A report by a nonpartisan group offers some stark forecasts for the quality and quantity of the work force. The report says that economic growth will be hampered by changes in the population and in education levels. C4.

United Asks Workers for Pay Cuts
United Airlines has asked its employees for $1.5 billion in annual concessions over six years as part of its restructuring plan. The concessions would be the bulk of the $2.5 billion in savings that the airline hopes to obtain. United also said that it was tightening rules on upgrades and fare discounts and was raising the fee for issuing paper tickets to $20. C2.

Mechanics at US Airways have voted to reject pay concessions and said they would fight any attempt by the airline to win wage and benefit concessions through bankruptcy court. C2.

Winning Viewers and Ballgames
Sports and media experts say the growing number of media companies that own teams has increased the gap between rich ball clubs and poor ones -- an issue that has been at the heart of baseball's labor talks. Teams owned by media companies have often been willing to pay more for marquee players. D4.

Eddie Bauer Tries for a New Look
Eddie Bauer is revamping its clothing line and will introduce a $12 million marketing campaign next week to restore its image as a retailer of rugged outdoor wear. The campaign includes the first national advertising since 1999 by Bauer. Advertising. C4.

Toyota in a Venture in China
Toyota has signed an agreement with China's largest automaker to begin production of a wide range of models. Fujio Cho, Toyota's president, left, said his company planned to build 300,000 to 400,000 vehicles a year in China by 2010, a volume that is equal to nearly half its current output in North America. World Business, Section W.

Utilities Selling Brazilian Units
Several energy companies are putting their Brazilian assets up for sale and are preparing to leave. World Business, Section W.

Reinsurers Hit Hard by Flooding
The leading reinsurers -- Munich Re and Swiss Re -- and Allianz, the major German insurance company, have estimated that they face losses of more than $1 billion from the recent flooding in Central Europe. C6.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
It's Game 7, Ninth Inning For Baseball

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Operating in a bargaining mode 180 degrees from their last labor confrontation, negotiators for baseball's owners and players struggled all day yesterday to work out their economic differences and avert a strike that threatens games beginning with today's schedule.
 In 1994, the two sides were so far apart and the situation was so hopeless that negotiators did not even meet the day before the players walked out. But yesterday the series of bargaining sessions conducted at the offices of both Major League Baseball and the union in Midtown Manhattan produced movement on the key issue of a tax on the biggest payrolls. 
 "Both sides have moved toward each other," a baseball official said early last evening. But one negotiator acknowledged minutes later that the two sides were moving like snails. 
Gene Orza, the union's No. 2 official, was mobbed by reporters and forced into the street when he emerged shortly after 8 p.m. from the Park Avenue building that houses the commissioner's office.
"I don't want to mislead anybody," he said. "We're doing O.K., but we still have significant differences."
Asked if any potential deal-breaking issues were on the table, he said: "Oh sure, potentially. But they are not the kind of differences that if there's a will to make an agreement, they would stop the talks."
The negotiators had no precise time against which they were working. The first game on today's schedule is between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Cubs in Chicago, beginning at 3:20 p.m. Eastern time. The union has not set a time by which a deal would have to be reached for that game to be played, but it would have to be at least a few hours before game time.
The union has instructed players not to go to Wrigley Field, or any other ballpark, unless there is an agreement.
Negotiators, who continued to talk past midnight, were expected to meet through the night and into the morning in an effort to play that game and the 14 other games that are on tonight's schedule.
"We're just going to keep working," said Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief operating officer and lead negotiator. "I've been prepared to stay for the night all week."
Before taking part in a late-night union conference call, Mike Stanton, the Yankees' player representative, said: "They're going to stay there as long as it takes. Hopefully, we'll be able to avoid tomorrow."
For most of the recent bargaining sessions, including those held yesterday morning and afternoon, two-member teams met with each other. But just before 9:30 p.m. last night, Donald Fehr, the union chief, led a six-member contingent, including two players, Tom Glavine and B. J. Surhoff, to the commissioner's office.
Before that bargaining session began, with three people from each side, Fehr and the players met with Commissioner Bud Selig for five or 10 minutes. Selig later said it was a social visit. "It was nice," he said.
Asked what he thought about the chances for an agreement, Selig said: "We'll see. I don't know. I really don't. I'm hopeful."
Earlier, Selig had a conference call with the owners' executive council, and a club official who was not on the call said he had been told that some of those on the call sensed that the commissioner would let the negotiations run through the night, then conclude a deal.
The remaining 31 days and 438 games of the season plus the playoffs and the World Series were at stake in the talks. The players' strike in 1994 wiped out the last 52 days and 669 games, the playoffs and the World Series, then shortened the 1995 season, too, by 23 days and 252 games.
The danger inherent in a walkout is that after each side has given more than either wanted to give, bargaining positions could harden.
"If there is a strike," said one person who is involved in the talks, "we won't talk for a long time, maybe longer than '94."
In 1994, the owners' attempt to get a cap on payrolls prompted the players to strike. On the day before that strike, when reports circulated that the owners might back off their cap position, a management official vehemently denied any such intention.
"Players have a choice," Fehr, the union leader then and now, told a news conference the day before the last day of games that year. "Take a salary-cap proposal now, take it after the season because they impose it, or strike. The owners have very deliberately left the players no choices at all."
That was not the case yesterday. The union began the negotiations not wanting a tax on payrolls, known as a luxury tax, saying that in combination with the revenue-sharing plan it could serve as a payroll cap of its own. Management has acknowledged wanting the tax as a means of retarding salaries.
The union has come to accept the idea of a luxury tax and has also lowered the threshold that would trigger the tax. When yesterday's bargaining sessions began, the union was at $120 million for the first year of a luxury tax, the clubs at $112 million. As the day progressed, a person familiar with developments said, the two sides moved closer with their thresholds.
The movement came after the two sides hit a snag Wednesday night that prompted one negotiator to say at the time that there was no reason for optimism. However, the negotiators apparently overcame the problem yesterday.
The two sides had also been far apart on tax rates for a luxury tax. They agreed that clubs would be charged a higher tax each time they exceeded the threshold and that the tax would be assessed on the portions of payrolls over the threshold, but they had vastly different ideas of how steep the taxes should be.
"We're talking about different structures, different grids," a management official said of the rates.
The sides also differed on a luxury tax in the fourth year of a new agreement. The clubs said they had to have it; the union said they had to have the year without a tax. But the management official said the union had begun discussing the possibility of agreeing to a tax in the fourth and final year of the agreement.
Based on this season's payrolls, as computed for a luxury tax, the Yankees ($171.2 million) would pay the tax under either side's plan. The clubs had wanted the clubs with the seven highest payrolls to have to pay the tax, but as they inched upward with their threshold, they figured to lose one or two teams.
Negotiators also had to complete their bargaining on the plan under which poorer teams would receive a percentage of the local revenue of richer teams. The clubs were seeking an annual average of $252 million to $258 million to be transferred, and it was very likely they would get it, or at least come close to it, if a final settlement on the luxury tax were closer to the union's liking.
Also at issue was the owners' contraction plan. An arbitrator has held off ruling on the union's grievance challenging the owners' attempt to eliminate two teams, and the two sides have been trying to resolve that dispute through negotiation.
The White House had no plans to become involved. "This is something the players and owners need to resolve," said Scott McClellan, the White House deputy press secretary.
Later, after speaking with President Bush, the former managing partner of the Texas Rangers, McClellan said, "The owners and players need to keep in mind not only what a strike would do to the future of baseball, but also what it would to America during a time of national unity and national spirit."

HEADLINE: Environmentalists vs. the Poor? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 If, as Bjorn Lomborg asserts (Op-Ed, Aug. 26), for the same amount the Kyoto climate treaty would have cost just the United States every year "we could provide every person in the world with access to basic health, education, family planning and water and sanitation services," what is our excuse for not doing exactly that since we have not signed on to this treaty? 
 Until we see action in this area of humanitarianism, let's not talk about the United States' "moral high ground."

LORRAINE T. SHERMAN
Yonkers, Aug. 26, 2002

HEADLINE: Environmentalists vs. the Poor? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 How did Bjorn Lomborg (Op-Ed, Aug. 26) tally the cost of climate change? Did he add in the cost of the increased droughts, fires and hurricanes that we're likely to see? How about lost crops, fish migration, the disruption of breeding grounds, the death of coral reefs? How did he value a nice view, a river that is safe to swim in? 
 It's a mistake to regard the term "global warming" as the end-all of environmental consequence. It's about much more than average global temperatures. Let's use "regional fluctuations from the norm, with increasing magnitude and frequency." Then we've introduced a whole host of other issues.

JIM POSS
Marblehead, Mass., Aug. 26, 2002

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: THE DETROIT CONNECTION; 
Informer Is Cited as the Key To Unlocking a Terrorist Cell

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
For nearly a year, the three foreigners picked up at an apartment here a week after the Sept. 11 attacks seemed like just another group of Arab men caught up in the government dragnet. They languished in prison while facing charges that seemed minor; federal agents had actually been looking for the previous occupant when they raided the apartment.
 But at least one thing appears to have separated the Detroit trio from hundreds of other Arabs swept up by the government in the last year: a cooperative witness. A fourth Arab man who once lived with the men and who had been charged in the case appears to have become a witness against the other three and is playing a critical role in the government's case. 
 The picture painted by the indictment issued on Wednesday by a federal grand jury is of a busy terrorist cell working hard to avert suspicion. The men used fake names to open post office boxes and had phony visas so authentic-looking that one veteran investigator of visa frauds said he could not tell the visas were bogus, and they even enlisted a "mentally unstable man" to disguise their notes, federal court filings show. 
Much of this evidence comes from an apartment on Norman Street in Detroit which was once the residence of Nabil al-Marabh, who the government believed had ties to Al Qaeda. It was Mr. al-Marabh, 35, that federal agents were looking for when they raided the apartment on Sept. 17. His name was still on the mailbox.
Instead, they found the three men who were indicted on Wednesday as being part of a terrorist conspiracy: Karim Koubriti, 24, and Ahmed Hannan, 34, both Moroccans, and Farouk Ali-Haimoud, 22, an Algerian. A fourth man from Chicago and known as Abdella was also indicted. He is still at large.
The Detroit case has been aggressively investigated by federal authorities since last September when the men were first arrested. The case has stirred debate within the government, government officials said. Some officials have hinted that they suspected the men had ties to Al Qaeda, but others have said that no evidence has emerged to show any definitive connection. 
The indictment paints the men as operating a terrorist cell, though no definitive connections to Al Qaeda are revealed. None of the men are now suspected of knowing in advance of the Sept. 11 attacks, government officials said. 
While the men are regarded by counterterrorism officials as low-level operatives, the charges against them are serious, particularly an accusation that they conspired to provide material support for terrorism against the United States. 
Some officials said today that the case was important but not a breakthrough in understanding terror operations in the United States. The indictment provides little information about the nature of the terror operation that the men are accused of supporting, nor does it indicate how far plans for an attack had progressed.
Investigators did find in the Norman Street apartment a cache of material they considered suspicious, including audiotapes that preached jihad, notes suggesting a plot against William S. Cohen, the former secretary of defense, and a cache of phony ID documents. The indictment said investigators also found a videotape that had surveillance footage of the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.
It remains unclear whether the material belonged to the three men or to Mr. al-Marabh.
Mr. Koubriti, one of the three men, implicated a fifth man, Youssef Hmimssa, whose picture was found among forged identity documents. Mr. Koubriti said that a day planner that contained notation in Arabic referring to an American airbase in Turkey, the American foreign minister and an airport in Jordan, belonged to Mr. Hmimssa. 
Mr. Koubriti and Mr. Hmimssa had lived together in Dearborn. Mr. Hmimssa was arrested shortly after the first raid, on Sept. 28, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. 
Kevin Ernst, a lawyer for Mr. Ali-Haimoud, said in an interview on Wednesday that Mr. Hmimssa was cooperating with the government. 
"The only difference between October of last year, when the government dismissed the charges against my client because there was no evidence, and today, when they issued the superseding indictments, is one snitch," Mr. Ernst said referring to Mr. Hmimssa.
Mr. Hmimssa's lawyer, Stephen Rabaut, did not return calls. Government officials would not say whether he was an informer.
Jim Thomas, a lawyer for Mr. Hannan, said his client had been held since Sept. 17 without a bond. "He is still, in the face of these very serious charges, presumed to be innocent," Mr Thomas said. "The trial will be scheduled hopefully for some time in January and at that time we expect to have a full and fair hearing in front of impartial jury."
While the case against the three men in Detroit has grown more serious, the case against Mr. al-Marabh, the initial target, appears to be winding down. Mr. al-Marabh, who is being held at a prison in Batavia, N.Y., is likely to be deported to Algeria after pleading guilty to illegally entering the country.
"We brought an immigration violation charge against him; that charge does not contain any evidence linking him terrorism," Bryan Sierra, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said. 
In the indictment against the other men, the government says they were part of a terrorist cell that provided support to other operatives, recruited members, collected intelligence on potential targets and cased the Detroit Metropolitan Airport while all three worked there. 
Part of the men's intent was to "cause economic harm to U.S. businesses," the indictment said, and previous documents said they planned an "economic jihad."
The men went to some length to conceal their plan, it said. They used a "mentally unstable man" to try to disguise their writings in a notebook. They used the man, who is not identified in the indictment, to write his name and personal information on some of the notebook pages found in the apartment, which contained plans and sketches of an American airbase in Turkey and a Jordanian hospital. They also had the man temporarily hold on to the notebooks.
It appears that they also had high-quality false ID documents. 
Edward Seitz, a special agent for the State Department who has investigated visa fraud for 14 years, testified at an April hearing that one of the visas was so authentic looking that he had to check the agency's database to find out if it was fraudulent.
"It was of such a quality that to the naked eye it would have probably passed," Mr. Seitz said. "It would have passed me."

HEADLINE: China Expected to Sell Stakes To Foreign Companies 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
The Chinese government is likely to allow the sale of government stakes in publicly traded state-controlled enterprises to foreign companies, a senior regulator said here today, signaling what could be the next big step in China's movement toward a market economy.
 Wang Jianxi, assistant chairman for international policy, futures trading and accounting at the China Securities Regulatory Commission, also said in an interview at his office today that China would give permission to multinational corporations to sell shares in their Chinese operations to Chinese citizens. 
 Taken together, the two measures outlined by Mr. Wang would draw China more into the global economy and give the country's securities markets a considerably greater role in bringing Western investment and management practices to businesses. 
As China's leaders prepare for the 16th Communist Party Congress early in November, when many current leaders are expected to retire, high-level expressions of interest in international investment like Mr. Wang's are also a sign that this country remains committed to a market-directed economy.
Dennis Zhu, managing director of investment banking in China for J. P. Morgan Chase, said that while there was little interest yet by multinationals in selling stock in China, the sale of government stakes in state-controlled enterprises would have "tremendous" effects. Although the government had given no hint until today that it was ready for such sales, foreign companies have been evaluating many state-controlled enterprises anyway, he said.
"Based on the inquiries, we've got, you will see quite wide interest," Mr. Zhu added.
While some of China's largest state-controlled enterprises are traded on stock exchanges in New York and Hong Kong, where foreigners can buy shares, more than 1,000 are traded only on the A-share stock markets in Shanghai and Shenzhen, in which foreigners are not allowed to invest. These include large companies like Baoshan Iron and Steel, Xugong Science and Technology and Shanghai Automotive.
The total value of the shares in these businesses is about $450 billion. A third of the shares, or $150 billion worth, is held by Chinese citizens and can be traded. The government holds the remaining two-thirds, worth some $300 billion, which are designated "nontradable." 
The Beijing authorities -- faced with a large budget deficit, a shaky banking system and a public pension system with virtually no reserves -- have been looking for a way to sell some of the government-owned shares to raise money.
But the domestic stock markets have fallen steeply in the last year, giving up huge previous gains that may have been created in part by speculators' market manipulation. So, regulators reluctantly promised early this summer not to sell any more government-owned shares on the exchanges for fear of driving stock prices down even further.
Mr. Wang said today that the government was "likely" to allow the sale of such stakes instead to the Chinese subsidiaries and to joint ventures of international companies.
China's State Council -- effectively the nation's cabinet and the highest level of the government, though subject to being superseded by the Communist Party leadership -- now bans foreign companies and individuals from owning stakes in Chinese companies traded on the A-share markets. The authorities are still reviewing whether to lift the ban but are likely to do so, Mr. Wang said.
"We should allow the foreign-funded companies here to acquire nontradable, state-owned shares," he said.
The securities commission fills the roles here that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission together serve in the United States. Within the Chinese bureaucracy, the commission has tended to support greater foreign investment in China. But officials in this country are usually wary of predicting that something is likely to happen unless the idea has already attracted broad official support.
China is expected to sell only minority stakes in the publicly traded state-controlled enterprises to foreigners, and would most likely require that the stakes be held for long periods as strategic investments, although the rules for any such sales have not yet been drafted. 
It already allows foreign companies to buy stakes in state-owned enterprises that are not publicly traded, or that are traded on the very small B-share markets, which are open to foreign investors. But many state-owned enterprises that are not listed on exchanges have not issued shares because they are either small or, in many cases, virtually bankrupt -- making them unattractive to investors.
A few are in good shape, however, and Shenzhen's municipal government coincidentally announced on Wednesday that it would sell stakes in five local nontraded companies by tender to international investors.
While there are some struggling state-controlled enterprises on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, the exchanges also list many of the country's healthiest enterprises. With China's economy growing at 7 percent a year, these businesses, often with nationally known brand names and excellent distribution networks, have drawn hungry looks from executives of multinational corporations.
Investment bankers and economists said that the toughest part of selling nontradable shares could lie in deciding how much to charge for them. The A shares in Chinese companies typically sell at a steep multiple to corporate earnings, in part because of the scarcity created by the government's ownership of two-thirds of the shares. Foreign investors may balk at paying such a premium, but if they are offered a discount, then the Chinese investors might object.
Selling nontradable shares to foreign investors could also depress China's domestic markets, though not as much as a direct sale of extra shares on those markets. Western experts say that some foreign businesses have managed to buy a small number of A shares by supplying the money to individual Chinese or companies who then buy the shares. This source of investment, while apparently modest, could dry up if foreign enterprises are allowed to acquire shares directly from the government.
Mr. Zhu said that the government might also be reluctant to sell shares in companies in strategic sectors, like energy, even if these companies were especially attractive to foreign investors.
The Chinese officials' willingness to let multinational companies sell stock here also shows a philosophical change by financial regulators, even if the multinationals are not actually lining up to do so. Until the last year or two, regulators here mostly thought that domestic savings should be invested in domestic enterprises.
Mr. Wang said that multinationals should be interested in selling stock in China in their Chinese operations because this would allow them to raise money in the local currency, the renminbi, instead of exposing themselves to the exchange-rate risks inherent in financing domestic operations with fully tradable foreign currencies.
He added that a consumer goods multinational with a listing here would also receive widespread media coverage that would serve as free advertising, saying he hoped that the first foreign company would list on a Chinese market by the end of the year.
But Pauline Dan, director of I.G. Investment Management (Hong Kong), a large fund management business, said that foreign companies would be wary of going to the trouble and the risk of listing in China. 
"They do not want to expose to competitors their operations and the profit margins they're earning in China," she said.

HEADLINE: Cuomo, Calling His Own TV Ads Ineffective, Intensifies Attack on McCall 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Andrew M. Cuomo intensified his attacks against H. Carl McCall today in the third debate of the Democratic gubernatorial campaign, raising familiar complaints about Mr. McCall's performance as state comptroller but using stronger language than he has on the campaign trail.
 Mr. Cuomo's assault came amid some signs of disarray in his campaign, 11 days before the Sept. 10 primary. For the first time, he criticized his own tactics, saying his television commercials have not been effective. But he declined to detail any impending change. 
 "I believe my advertisement has not communicated the message of the campaign well enough," Mr. Cuomo said after the debate when asked to elaborate on similar comments that appeared today in The New York Post.
Mr. McCall generally did not reply in kind, and acted the front-runner that polls suggest he is. Adding to his confidence, Mr. McCall received an endorsement today from the editorial board of The Daily News, the first major newspaper to weigh in on the primary race.
Mr. McCall's supporters are already looking beyond the primary, with one key advocate, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, calling on Mr. Cuomo and his choice for lieutenant governor, Charlie King, to get out of the race now. Mr. Rangel, in an interview, said such a move would allow Mr. McCall to conserve resources he will need in the general election.
"They don't want to be remembered for having derailed Carl McCall by having him spending all this money on television that he needs in the general election," Mr. Rangel said. "If they believe that they should be concerned about the general election, and if they believe that they should become heroes instead of villains," then they should get out of the race, he said.
But during the debate both candidates seemed engaged in the race, although on different tracks.
True to form, Mr. McCall reserved most of his criticism for George E. Pataki, the Republican governor who is seeking a third term, and dismissed Mr. Cuomo's attacks.
"I don't think there's really any need to take him on," Mr. McCall said at public television station WXXI after the debate, which was sponsored by WXXI, WORK, the ABC station here, and The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle and broadcast on PBS and ABC affiliates statewide.
But on the eve of the pivotal Labor Day weekend, when campaigns often ratchet up, Mr. Cuomo seemed eager to take on Mr. McCall during the hourlong discussion.
Time and again, he said Mr. McCall had not done enough as manager of the state's pension funds to invest that money in causes like upstate economic development or affordable housing. And whenever Mr. McCall criticized Mr. Pataki's record on education, budgeting, campaign finance reform or the Rockefeller-era drug laws, Mr. Cuomo turned that into an attack on the comptroller.
"When you listen to the comptroller speak, it sounds like he hasn't been in Albany the last nine years," said Mr. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary. At one point, addressing Mr. McCall directly, he said: "Stop the excuses. Stop the reasons why you couldn't do anything for nine years. You were there."
Later, he said: "My opponents, both Governor Pataki and Comptroller McCall, were there for the past eight years. If they didn't do it over the past eight years, what makes you think they're going to do it over the next four years?"
When Mr. McCall raised other issues, like his experience as president of New York City's Board of Education, Mr. Cuomo seized on them, too.
"The comptroller was the head of the Board of Education in New York City, and look what happened," he said. "Scores went down in all 32 districts and class size went up." In truth, test scores were mixed during Mr. McCall's 1991-1993 tenure, with some grades improving and others falling behind.
Mr. Cuomo's aides said the criticism of his own ads reflected his frustration at the campaign's attempts to soften his aggressive image, a strategy that has precluded him from taking on Mr. McCall more forcefully.
It was not the only potential point of frustration for his campaign.
Douglas Harriman Kennedy, a son of Robert F. Kennedy and a brother of Mr. Cuomo's wife, Kerry Kennedy Cuomo, said in an interview that he believed his father would have discouraged Mr. Cuomo from running.
"I think Carl McCall's story would have moved my father greatly," said Mr. Kennedy, 35, a reporter for Fox television in New York. "I think the mix between his political and business experience was everything my father advocated. And I think Carl McCall's story would have touched him in his heart."
Mr. Kennedy, who had first voiced his opinions to Mr. Rangel, added: 'I believe that if my father were alive, he would have asked Andrew not to run."

HEADLINE: Panel Advises Bloomberg To Sell Stock 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The city's Conflicts of Interest Board yesterday urged Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to sell all of his stocks, along with his interests in a hedge fund, within 90 days because the holdings -- valued at possibly tens of millions of dollars or more -- violated a provision of the City Charter.
 The board spent more than eight months studying the unusually thorny ethical issues that have arisen over the holdings of Mr. Bloomberg, one of the world's wealthiest businessmen and mayor of one of the world's most complex cities. 
 The board's 13-page advisory opinion outlined a series of areas in which Mr. Bloomberg should withdraw participation from the selection of the city's bond underwriters, so as not to appear to favor Merrill Lynch, which owns 20 percent of his firm, Bloomberg L. P., to making decisions about cable television franchises, so as not to appear to favor Bloomberg Television. But its most immediate recommendation was its call for the mayor to sell all of his stock. 
Mr. Bloomberg's aides said he would comply. "As the mayor has said and demonstrated repeatedly, he's very sensitive to conflicts of interest, and he's going to abide by the ruling of the Conflicts of Interest Board," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor. 
In a sign of just how many potential pitfalls can arise when a rich man is elected mayor, there was even a potential conflict with a member of the conflicts board. One of the four members of the board, Benito Romano, withdrew from participating in the decision because his law firm, Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher, has represented Mr. Bloomberg's company.
It was unclear just how much money Mr. Bloomberg's stock was worth, partly because Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire, does not release his tax returns to the public the way that most mayors have. But limited financial data that he disclosed in June indicated that he owned at least $51 million in stock in 2001, and possibly more. 
When Mr. Bloomberg was a candidate for mayor his aides said that he had divested himself of all of his stock holdings so as not to pose any conflicts, but added at the time that they could not say if he was buying new stocks. Aides have now explained that he sold off his portfolio and then hired private money managers to buy and sell stocks for him without his knowledge, so he would not know what stocks he held.
But the conflicts board found that the arrangement did not go far enough. It ruled that the mayor's holdings violated a section of the City Charter that bans public servants from having an interest in firms engaged in business dealings with the agency they work for "because Mr. Bloomberg owns his stock directly and not, for example, through a mutual fund, because many of the firms in his portfolio have business dealings with the city's executive branch, and because of the size of his holdings."
The mayor's limited financial disclosure showed that he owned more than half a million dollars in stock in Waste Management, which controls nearly a third of the city's out-of-state trash transport system, as well as in several large financial firms that are important players in the city and big retailers seeking to expand in the city.
Mr. Bloomberg's aides said that he would sell the stock, and possibly donate some of the money to charity, and invest the proceeds in mutual funds and exchange-traded funds. In giving Mr. Bloomberg 90 days to sell his stock, the ruling could cost the mayor some money. Some stocks may have declined in value; others that rose in value may be subject to higher taxes because he has not held them long enough to qualify as long-term capital gains.
The ruling also touched on Mr. Bloomberg's ownership of government bonds. To avoid the possible appearance that the mayor could take actions that would financially benefit himself as the owner of municipal bonds, the board prohibited the mayor from selling city and state bonds, saying that it would make exceptions only under unforeseen circumstances. The board ruled that the mayor could continue to buy bonds, though.
And, with the city refinancing much of its debt, the board ruled that the mayor should not participate in decisions about which bonds can be retired or called.
The board outlined a number of ways in which Mr. Bloomberg could avoid conflicts stemming from his ownership of Bloomberg L. P., a financial information and media company that he founded in 1981.
Mr. Bloomberg resigned his position and stepped down from making day-to-day decisions there, but wanted to remain involved in large business matters, such as any potential sale of the company; the sale or purchase of any major assets; any major borrowings; and any big changes in the company's salary structure. The board advised Mr. Bloomberg to seek its guidance before getting involved in such matters.
The board also weighed the mayor's dealings with Merrill Lynch, which owns 20 percent of his firm, and frequently underwrites the issuance of city bonds and manages assets for the city's pension funds. The report noted that Mr. Bloomberg has agreed not to participate in Merrill Lynch's dealings with the city, whether in terms of selecting bond underwriters or making decisions about Economic Development Corporation job-retention benefits or grants from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation grants.
But the report made no mention of the fact that Mr. Bloomberg selected E. Stanley O'Neal, the chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch, as one of his four appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the reconstruction of downtown Manhattan. When he made the selection in April, Mr. Bloomberg said that there was no conflict of interest.
The report also called on Mr. Bloomberg to be absent from all decisions involving cable television, because Bloomberg Television is distributed by cable systems that obtain their franchises through the city's Franchise and Concession Review Committee, on which the mayor serves. 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about an advisory opinion by New York City's Conflict of Interests Board that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should sell his stock holdings misspelled the name of a law firm that represents his company. It is Willkie Farr & Gallagher, not Wilkie.

HEADLINE: U.S. BACKS INCREASE IN PEACEKEEPERS FOR AFGHANISTAN 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Pentagon officials who long opposed expanding the international security force in Afghanistan now say that enlarging it and placing its troops outside Kabul may help secure the country and allow American troops to leave sooner, senior Bush administration officials said today. 
 The shift, officials said, may be necessary because of the lingering difficulties in rebuilding the country and establishing law and order in a nation still wracked by banditry, warlords and renegade Taliban fighters. 
 One senior Bush administration official described the shift as a "mid-course correction." 
The change in the Pentagon's thinking is an important precondition for other nations to contribute troops for a peacekeeping effort that would extend beyond the Afghan capital, Kabul. 
Foreign nations have been reluctant to consider such a venture until the Pentagon agrees to help with logistics, command and control and intelligence, and promises to withdraw the peacekeepers if they are endangered. 
American officials said that steps to enlarge the peacekeeping force might not come for months and that finding nations to contribute the forces would not be easy. 
Even if the force is expanded, it is likely to be more modest than the one proposed by the Afghan leader, Hamid Karzai, blunting but probably not ending the debate over whether the Bush administration has done enough to rebuild Afghanistan.
American officials say a number of ideas are under consideration, all of which would involve American support, but not troops. They include setting up a mobile group of peacekeepers, which could be whisked from Kabul to trouble spots.
Another idea is to place peacekeepers in several cities outside Kabul, like Mazar-i-Sharif, where there are tensions between rival warlords. 
A sizable deployment of peacekeeping forces in all the major Afghan cities is the least likely possibility, American officials say. The Bush administration itself has not offered to place American peacekeepers in Afghanistan.
It has also had a tough time finding another nation to lead the force once Turkey's command expires this year. 
One of the first hints of the Pentagon's shift came early this week when Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the head of the United States Central Command, discussed expanding the peacekeeping force. 
"There are in fact views and a number of places that would indicate the desirability of expanding the International Security Assistance Force," he said at Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul.
The deputy defense secretary, Paul D. Wolfowitz, also signaled a new receptivity to expanding the force in an interview with the British Daily Telegraph. 
"We are looking very seriously at what might be done if we get more contributions to ISAF," Mr. Wolfowitz said. "At the moment the issue is sustaining ISAF first. Expanding it is valuable, but it cannot be the first priority." 
Expanding the force beyond Kabul has been a contentious issue within the administration. President Karzai has urged an extension to Mazar-i-Sharif in the north, Kandahar in the south, Herat in the west and Jalalabad in the east. 
State Department officials were generally supportive. Richard N. Haass, the director of the State Department Office of Policy Planning, told the World Economic Forum in February that the force might be expanded to as many as 25,000 troops spread around Afghanistan. Foreign Secretary Jack Straw of Britain said Mr. Karzai had made a persuasive case for expanding beyond Kabul.
But Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his aides resisted the idea, fearing it would tie down American forces and extend the stay of American troops in Afghanistan, even though American troops would be cast largely in a supporting role. 
Mr. Rumsfeld pushed for setting up an Afghan army as the solution to the country's security problems, saying that would enable the Afghans to become more self sufficient. American Special Forces in Afghanistan and United States Civil Affairs teams were also asked to use their influence with local warlords to bring calm in the country.
"The question is, Do you want to put your time and effort and money into the International Security Assistance Force -- go take it from, say, 5,000 to 20,000 people?" Mr. Rumsfeld said in February. "Another school of thought, which is where my brain is, is that why put all the time and money and effort in that? Why not put it into helping them develop a national army so that they can look out for themselves over time?" 
But the establishment of the Afghan army has gone slowly. The Pentagon says that army will number only 3,000 to 4,000 soldiers by the end of this year. Meanwhile, local warlords have continued to erode the authority of the central government in Kabul. 
Problems in restoring order and delays in providing money from international donors have slowed efforts to rebuild the country, develop the economy and establish the rule of law. As a result, reconstruction has fallen well behind the pace in Kosovo after NATO's confrontation with Serbia. 
"The creation of the Afghan army is a distant prospect," said James Dobbins, who served as the Bush administration envoy for Afghanistan and is now a senior official at the Rand Corporation, a government-financed research center. "There has not been a high enough level of security outside of Kabul to allow reconstruction outside the capital." 
The slow pace has not been lost on the Pentagon, where officials are well aware that it will be harder for American forces to leave the country unless the economy develops, Mr. Karzai's authority is reinforced and warlords are reined in.
As these efforts have lagged, Mr. Rumsfeld has sought to rebut criticism that the Pentagon has not been doing enough.
Earlier this month, he asserted that he had no objection to enlarging the peacekeeping force if other nations were willing to contribute the troops. 
But he did not offer to provide the logistical support and security guarantees that foreign nations say would be needed to encourage them to contribute more peacekeepers or to take an active role in organizing an expansion of the force.
The main problem, Mr. Rumsfeld said, was that foreign nations have provided relatively little of the $4.5 billion in aid they promised to rebuild the country. At the State Department today, a senior official said European nations had failed to contribute the necessary food aid. 
"The U.S is the champion and the predominate financial supporter of the multilateral relief and recovery program in Afghanistan," said Gene Dewey, the assistant secretary of state for population, refugees and migration. "We desperately need our flagging, all too unilateralist allies, especially from Europe, to join the multilateral bandwagon and come up to their fair share."

HEADLINE: Just Trust Us 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The story so far:
 Summer 2000: Candidate George W. Bush assures voters that his tax cut is affordable. He illustrates his point with four $1 bills. One bill, he says, represents the tax cut; one represents new programs, such as prescription drug coverage; the other two are funds set aside to pay down debt, strengthening Social Security. He pledges, without qualification, not to dip into the Social Security surplus. 
 Spring 2001: The Bush administration pushes its tax cut through Congress. Officials dismiss concerns that projections of a huge surplus may be excessively optimistic, assuring Congressmen that the projections are actually on the low side. Mr. Bush also claims that his budget includes a trillion-dollar reserve, enough to deal with any contingency. 
Summer 2001: Just weeks after the tax cut passes, officials reveal that tax receipts have been coming in far below expectations. Budget projections are revised sharply downward, but the administration still claims that it will run an overall surplus greater than the Social Security surplus, that is, more than $150 billion per year. The administration also claims that the tax cut, conceived at a time of runaway boom, is exactly the right medicine for an ailing economy. 
October 2001: "Lucky me: I hit the trifecta." So remarks Mr. Bush, claiming that recession, national emergency and war have let him off the hook on his budget promises. Though some think that it's in bad taste, the trifecta joke becomes part of Mr. Bush's standard stump speech. He claims to have made this exception to his budget pledges during the 2000 campaign, but there is no record of his having done so.
November 2001: Budget director Mitch Daniels admits that the overall budget -- not just the budget outside Social Security -- will actually be in deficit for fiscal 2002.
July 2002: The White House admits that the deficit for fiscal 2002, which ends in September, will be $165 billion -- a non-Social-Security deficit of $322 billion. But it still says that the budget will be back in surplus by 2004.
August 2002: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office issues a much grimmer projection, with a 2003 deficit twice that predicted by the administration, and deficits persisting until 2006. Moreover, the C.B.O. is required by law to make unrealistic assumptions that cause it to understate future deficits. A new analysis by Goldman Sachs, which is not under these constraints, predicts deficits well over $100 billion each year for the rest of the decade. 
This $7 trillion reversal of fiscal fortune has received remarkably little public attention; it has been crowded off the front page by talk of war. But its consequences will be immense. 
Where did the surplus go? The "trifecta" is not the main story; recessions have only a small impact on long-run projections, and the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities calculates that increases in military and homeland security spending account for only 16 percent of the 10-year deterioration in the C.B.O. projection. In fact, it's clear that we would be facing large deficits outside Social Security, and probably significant deficits in the budget as a whole, even if neither the recession nor Sept. 11 had happened.
The two main culprits are the tax cut and "technical changes" in the estimates: perhaps because of the end of the bull market, a given level of G.D.P. is yielding much less revenue than it did during the late 1990's. Or to put it another way, our brief era of big surpluses seems to have been a fluke.
Despite assurances that the tax cut would promote recovery, the economy seems to be sputtering. Early indications are that the administration will propose another round of tax cuts, all of them aimed at stock market investors. It's important to notice that such measures as increased deductions for capital losses provide no benefit to those whose investment takes place through 401(k) plans; so these tax breaks are mainly for the very affluent. A careful analysis by William Gale and Peter Orszag -- experts at Brookings who have consistently, and correctly, warned that administration budget projections were overoptimistic -- shows that these measures will be ineffective as stimulus, and will further worsen the budget outlook.
Of course, administration officials will brush this aside, assuring us that their proposals are just what the nation needs. Can anyone think of a reason not to trust them?

HEADLINE: As Bush Campaigns, Cheney Talks of Iraq 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
President Bush traveled to Oklahoma and Arkansas today to raise $1.1 million for Republican candidates, and he joined a back-to-school event to press his education agenda, even as his vice president was talking about whether the country needed to go to war.
 Mr. Bush repeated standard lines about the fight against terrorism at all his stops, his only public events this week, but he never mentioned Iraq or Saddam Hussein. 
 Vice President Dick Cheney, in contrast, used a meeting of Korean War veterans in San Antonio to repeat the arguments he made on Monday that Mr. Hussein could acquire nuclear weapons "fairly soon" and that American forces might be called on to prevent that.
As the debate over Iraq grows, Mr. Bush shows no sign of letting it distract him from helping Republicans try to recapture the Senate and maintain control of the House. He is planning two to three campaign-related trips a week from now to the November election.
Most of the trips focus on tight races like the one here in Arkansas, where Mr. Bush spoke tonight at a fund-raiser for Senator Tim Hutchinson, who is being challenged by Mark Pryor, the Democratic attorney general of Arkansas. The Senate contest here is considered one of the most crucial of the year, and Mr. Bush was raising $600,000 this evening at a $500-a-plate dinner in the shadow of the Capitol, where Bill Clinton began his political career.
Mr. Bush has raised more than $100 million this year, appearing at roughly 50 fund-raisers, a record that puts him well ahead of Mr. Clinton at an equivalent moment in his presidency. The White House is determined to avoid the position Mr. Clinton found himself in two years into his presidency when his party lost control of both houses of Congress.
But that has left to the vice president the job of making the administration's public case on Iraq. Tonight, the president alluded to the issue, mentioning speculation in the press about what his next step would be in the fight against terrorism, but he did not specifically mention Iraq.
Mr. Bush had not been seen in public since last Saturday, and today's appearance will be his only one this week. He is to return to Washington on Sunday and make a quick Labor Day trip to Pittsburgh on Monday to talk about the economy.
Mr. Bush began the day in Oklahoma City at a luncheon for Steve Largent, the former professional football player who is the Republican candidate for governor. The current governor, Frank Keating, also a Republican, could not run because of term limits. Mr. Largent appears ahead in the race. The lunch, which also benefited Senator James M. Inhofe, raised about $500,000, and Mr. Bush used a 30-minute speech to talk about worker compensation, energy, prescription drugs and defense spending.
Then Mr. Bush came to Little Rock, stopping at the Parkview Arts and Science Magnet High School to announce that Arkansas would be among a small group of states in a new program to encourage high school students to take more rigorous courses. The program is based on one in Texas when Mr. Bush was governor. But announcing the program here also served another purpose: whenever the president travels to deliver a noncampaign message, the federal government pays for much of the trip.
