HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
To Some Owners, TV Money Comes First

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Baseball strike or no strike, many sports and media experts say that the growing number of media companies that own teams has increased the economic gap between rich ball clubs and poor ones -- an issue that has been at the heart of baseball's labor negotiations.
 Teams owned by media companies have often been willing to pay more for players than their competitors because marquee players not only attract more fans to the ballpark, but they also attract more viewers and advertisers to the broadcasts. For many of the most successful teams, stadiums have increasingly become television backdrops. 
 "What it has done is exacerbate the competitive balance problem because the teams are being run as software or programming for the media companies," Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who writes about sports, said in an interview. "The teams are subordinated to the profit-maximizing schemes for the media operations." 
Two decades ago, Ted Turner (who owned the Atlanta Braves) and the Tribune Company (which owned the Chicago Cubs) were the only major media players with baseball in their stables. (The Yankees were owned by CBS before the team was acquired by George Steinbrenner's group in 1973.)
Now, the major media companies that own baseball teams outright are AOL Time Warner (the Braves), the Walt Disney Company (the Anaheim Angels), the News Corporation (the Los Angeles Dodgers), Rogers Communications (the Toronto Blue Jays) and Tribune (the Cubs). Then there are the media companies that own stakes in teams, like Cox Enterprises (the San Francisco Giants) and The New York Times Company (the Boston Red Sox).
Individuals with major media holdings also own teams, including Lawrence Dolan of Cablevision (the Cleveland Indians) and Tom Hicks of the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst (the Texas Rangers). Although the Yankees are not owned by a media company per se, the team's success in attracting television money and in spinning off the YES Network has been perhaps the most powerful testament to the dominating role of TV revenue in sports these days (despite Cablevision's refusal to carry the network). 
"Traditional owners used to run their business to build the asset value of the club itself," said one executive at a media company that owns a baseball team, speaking on condition of anonymity. "For us, it's all about building the asset value of the television contract using the team."
The desire for viewers and television dollars as well as fan loyalty and individual team profitability explains many of the key financial decisions in baseball in recent years.
It explains why in 1998, when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation was trying to build Fox Sports West and prevent Disney from starting an ESPN West cable channel, Murdoch made Kevin Brown baseball's first $100 million player, with a $105 million contract with the Dodgers. It explains why two years ago, when Hicks was trying to make television syndication deals for the Rangers, he gave Alex Rodriguez the richest contract in sports, a $252 million deal.
Teams that do not control their own television deals may not be able to compete.
"Few of these companies, if any, view the overall profitability of the various sports teams as meaningful in their overall operations," said Christopher Dixon, a media analyst in New York for UBS Warburg. "The money is all on the television side."
That is one reason media companies that own teams have generally taken a softer line in the recent labor negotiations. They have the most to lose in a strike: not only gate receipts, but also advertising sales; not only merchandising opportunities, but also cable television contracts.
"The media companies do tend to be more conciliatory and closer to the players' point of view," Zimbalist, the sports economist, said.
A spokesman for Major League Baseball declined to comment.
Murdoch's News Corporation has appeared particularly fearful of a strike. Of all of the media companies that own baseball teams, the News Corporation has the most to lose -- even if many of the company's explicit financial losses would be reimbursed by Major League Baseball and individual teams.
Besides owning the Dodgers, the News Corporation is in the middle of a six-year, $2.5 billion television contract with baseball. The vast majority of the contract is associated with Fox's rights to baseball's playoffs, which would be jeopardized by a strike. In all, baseball's contract with Fox could force the league to essentially refund about $520 million if there is a strike.
Some analysts believe that the News Corporation has actually been preferring a strike because, in addition to the refund, a strike would almost surely mean that future baseball contracts would be cheaper. Publicly, however, the News Corporation and Fox appear to be taking a softer line toward the players and are urging a settlement.
"If there is a long-term strike that stops play for any length of time at all, it is going to fundamentally damage baseball," said David Hill, president of Fox Sports. "It could be the death knell for the sport, or if not the death knell, it would take a long time to get over."
Also, even though Fox would be reimbursed in the event of a strike, the network would lose the ability to promote its other programs during baseball's playoffs.
In the end, television matters far more to the News Corporation than whether the Dodgers are profitable.
At first, AOL Time Warner might appear to be in a similar position. AOL Time Warner distributes Braves games on its TBS cable and satellite channel. But with the company's stock struggling and with pressure on the company to improve its financial performance, the company has taken a hard line against the players in the labor talks, according to baseball executives and people close to the company.
A spokeswoman for AOL Time Warner declined to comment.

HEADLINE: New Jobs For Labor Unions 

BYLINE:  By Samuel Leiken; Samuel Leiken is a consultant on work-force development strategy and a former union shop steward.

DATELINE: CHEVY CHASE, Md. 

 BODY:
In today's economy, rare is the worker who will spend his entire career in the same job. People are likely to have many employers, perhaps even several careers. Yet the labor movement remains attached to a 20th-century notion of its role: protecting members' employment, wages and benefits through collective bargaining.
 If labor unions are to flourish in the 21st century, however, they will have to reach workers who no longer have long-term ties to one employer -- or even to a single industry. These new circumstances present unions with an opportunity to expand their membership. Today's workers need to continually improve their employability through better education and training, and unions are uniquely qualified to help. 
 Going to college is not what it used to be. Higher education has evolved to a marketplace where companies even offer their own "degrees"; Microsoft now offers training and certification for computer programmers and engineers. The result is a kaleidoscope of career options accompanied by a complex array of educational choices. In the face of these changes, labor's continued focus on collective bargaining is a little like the proverbial French generals preparing for the last war.
But unions can help workers make their way through the tangle of educational and career choices. They have a well-organized communications network. In addition, they enjoy credibility within the network. Union members rely on shop stewards and local officials to represent them in conflicts with employers; to help them get confidential treatment of alcohol and drug addiction problems; and, in case of layoffs, to provide information on services and benefits for which they are eligible. Unions already provide members with information about pensions and health care, in some cases providing these services themselves. Why not do the same in education?
Survey data indicate that roughly 42 million workers want an organization focused on information, career assistance or consultation with management -- but still independent of management. That represents an enormous untapped market for unions; currently, there are only 13.5 million unionized workers in America. By offering learning services on their Web sites and expanding access to nonmembers, unions could bring millions into their network.
The labor movement is already reaching out to the wider work force by developing various projects, like low-interest credit cards, to recruit "associate members." But a union-sponsored credit card is not the same as a union card. It does not authorize the union to speak for you.
Union members and nonmembers alike benefit from a voice that can demand their rights and express their needs to schools and the government. For example, adults are excluded from federal student loans unless they attend classes at least half-time. Such a schedule is almost impossible for working mothers or fathers. When they relocate, they need to be assured that credits from one institution will be accepted elsewhere. And how can workers who want to enroll get credit for college-level learning acquired on the job?
This approach challenges existing notions of organized labor's role and purpose. Unions would still represent the interests of certain members in negotiations with particular employers, of course. But they must also begin reaching out to workers in nonunion shops or sectors. Unions may not be able to bargain for these workers, but attracting such workers is critical to the labor movement's growth and success. 
With their tradition of involvement in education -- apprenticeships, tuition-assistance grants and loans, joint labor-management training programs -- unions are ideally poised to lead the American worker into a new era. But for their leadership to have an impact, they must be able to speak for all workers, not just the 9 percent of the private-sector work force they currently represent. Expanding union membership will require extending membership rights to individuals independent of their workplaces.
Serving the learning needs of members and nonmembers alike could rescue unions from the decline in membership they have been suffering for the last several decades. A greater focus on education will also serve the needs of society.

PERSON: Mark Shuttleworth 

HEADLINE: THE SATURDAY PROFILE; 
The First 'Afronaut' Plans a Mission Back Home

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
PERHAPS the most obvious question to ask Mark Shuttleworth is this: after making half a billion dollars from the Internet bubble at the age of 26 and, two years later, buying a $20 million ride in space to become what Nelson Mandela called the first "Afronaut," what do you do for an encore?
 The response from this unassuming, South African-born entrepreneur is unexpected. Having achieved in a few years what most would not achieve in a lifetime, Mr. Shuttleworth, 28, said he did not want to try to re-create the intensity of his experiences in space or in business, despite having the personal wealth to try almost anything. 
 Passing his days in a spacious apartment in a chic part of London, Mr. Shuttleworth has resolved to invert his personal telescope, exchanging the celestial visions of space or the dizzying deals of high finance for a view of life from the narrow end, from the perspective of the penniless and the earthbound who will -- if his calculations are borne out -- fuel a new revolution in his native continent. 
"I'm not going to try and top either of these things in the same way," he said, "I'm not going to try and do a bigger business deal. I'm not going to fly again for flying's sake."
Rather, he said, he plans a road show in South Africa in September and October, taking models of the Soyuz space capsule he flew in and a rocket booster to 100 of the remote, rural schools where the country's greatest poverty is most evident. His goal is to fire up young South Africans with the same enthusiasm for science and math that underpinned his own success story. He tried to accomplish the same result with ham radio and Internet linkups to South African schools during his space flight with Russian cosmonauts in April and May.
He has set up a philanthropic foundation to promote the desire for schooling in a land where young people once boycotted classes to protest apartheid (one of its first pro-math campaigns is called Hip 2 B Square). Suffusing that effort is a belief that, as he put it, Africa is set for a half century of rapid growth, fueled by a surge of democracy and freedoms, that will make it far more interesting for an entrepreneur than the United States or Europe.
"If I do believe that the next 50 years are going to be more dynamic, I do need to get hands on, walk the streets, get the feel of it," he said. 
ON the way, Mr. Shuttleworth is also seeking to transcend the stereotypes of race and class and establish his credentials as an African. 
He had the kind of early life and education in one of Cape Town's top private schools that came with privilege. He was born too late to experience the ravages of apartheid firsthand -- while he was in his teens, segregationist legislation was being dismantled, and his high school was open to all races. By the time he graduated from college, in 1995, South Africa had already held the elections that gave Nelson Mandela the presidency.
At a private dinner recently at the home of Lindiwe Mabuza, South Africa's high commissioner, or ambassador, in London, Mr. Shuttleworth enthralled a table of senior African diplomats from Senegal, Ghana and Mozambique with tales from his space flight.
He spoke of the fear that comes before but not during the terrifying moments of blastoff and re-entry; he spoke of observing the earth's fragility as he spun through space. But as the son of an English-born father with only a half-generation of African roots, as a multimillionaire from a continent of paupers, he also spoke of wanting to become a diplomat for Africa. Most critically for him, he said later that he felt that his credentials had been accepted.
In an era when radical figures like Robert Mugabe in Zimbabwe and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya rail against intruders into the continent, the welcoming mood around the dinner table offered a poignant counterpoint.
As a youthful entrepreneur challenging global business giants, Mr. Shuttleworth was lauded as the Bill Gates of South Africa. But when he left two years ago to set up base in London, he was condemned for abandoning the country. That changed only after the space trip, which led to him being celebrated as a national hero. "I have been lionized and vilified," he said.
MR. SHUTTLEWORTH agreed to be interviewed in his new apartment, which is simply furnished and comfortable, and includes a work area littered with unpacked boxes of computer gear. The walls of the living room are decorated more with large, flat television screens tuned to 24-hour news channels than with art or books.
His smile is open and untroubled. As is the custom in South Africa, Mr. Shuttleworth received a guest without formal ceremony, serving an impromptu lunch of bread and cheese with lime marmalade -- one of his favorite combinations.
The conversation ranged over his school years when, having no great liking for rugby or cricket in a sports-crazy white world, he excelled academically. After graduating first in his class, he went on to the University of Cape Town, where his grades suffered after he found himself locking horns with teachers over the looming importance of the Internet.
His startup company, a consultancy called Thawte, began in what has become the time-honored way -- in his mother's garage, where he developed a system to certify the authenticity of Web sites used in e-commerce. He sold the company in December 1999 to an American rival, VeriSign Inc., in an all-stock deal worth about $575 million.
Contractual restrictions prevented him from selling the acquired VeriSign stock quickly, and he watched in frustration, he said, as the market first soared -- making him a paper billionaire -- and then began to fall. When he finally sold his stake, he discovered that South Africa's currency laws made it hard to move his fortune overseas, even as its value fell with the seesawing South African rand. Those financial considerations, in part, were behind his move to London.
If he was a prophet in his own land, then his stature could only soar farther with his Soyuz flight from April 25 to May 5. As the second fare-paying space traveler after Dennis Tito, an American, Mr. Shuttleworth spent eight months training for the flight, determined to be viewed as a cosmonaut rather than a space tourist. He conducted stem cell and human embryo experiments during the flight, and spoke by ham radio and the Internet to South African schoolchildren.
These days, he likes to depict his apartment as a retreat where he can read and think about the shape of Africa and the world and how he can best "position" himself for the future. He leaves others to manage his money and his South African venture capital company, HBD (short for "Here Be Dragons"). He would rather listen to unknown people than high-flying gurus of business.
"I'm a lot less fussed about the way things pan out in life than when I first went to Russia," he said, adding that he had not checked his financial portfolio for two months.

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 792 words

HEADLINE: Consumers Praised, or Blamed, for Aiding Recovery 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Though the economy took a pummeling in the second quarter, consumers struck a modest blow for the recovery at the beginning of the third. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that personal spending in July jumped 1 percent, to $7.35 trillion -- the biggest increase in nine months -- thanks largely to low interest rates.
 Consumers managed to spend more even though their total incomes did not change. Mortgage refinancing and lower income-tax rates helped to put more of consumers' existing income at their disposal. In addition, saving as a share of disposable income dropped to 3.4 percent from 4.2 percent in June. 
 The rise in spending did little to comfort an established Wall Street pessimist, Stephen S. Roach, chief economist of Morgan Stanley. "You have to ask yourself, 'How long can consumers go into debt, draw down savings and keep spending?' " Mr. Roach said. "This denial that consumers are steeped in is going to crack later."
Most of the overall increase in spending came from a 3.9 percent rise in purchases of big-ticket items, defined as those expected to last at least three years. Consumers reacted to lower interest rates by snapping up cars, appliances and other items, which they often buy on credit, said Christopher J. Wiegand, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney.
Two other reports yesterday offered little indication, taken together, of the economy's direction. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said its index of business activity in the Midwest rose to 54.9 from 51.5 in July. The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment fell slightly, to 87.6 from 88.1 in July. The predictive power of that index is strongest several months into the future.
The figures were still better than economic data released on Thursday that showed increased claims for unemployment benefits last week and anemic economic growth in the second quarter.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, did not comment on the current economic situation in his remarks yesterday to central bankers at a conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
Consumers have taken advantage of the Fed's leaving short-term interest rates low, a stance that is helping to keep 30-year mortgage rates under 6.3 percent.
"Refinancing activity, both in the form of lowering monthly mortgage payments and undertaking cash-outs, is definitely padding consumer spending," Mr. Wiegand said. He estimated that refinancing would add $50 billion to consumers' purchasing power in the second half of this year.
Consumers' direct borrowing from banks actually slipped a bit in July, according to figures the Fed published last week, but credit card debt could also be used for spending. "Some consumers are very responsive" to changes in rates, said David B. Gross, a senior economist at Lexecon, an economic consulting firm. Rates on fixed-rate credit cards dropped steadily this year until June and have stayed low since then, according to Bankrate.com.
First USA and MBNA, the biggest issuers of Visa and MasterCard credit cards, respectively, both declined to comment on recent trends.
Nonetheless, Mr. Gross expected consumers to respond more to mortgage rates than to credit card rates. "The house represents such a large fraction of people's net worth that any change in their payment is going to have a big impact," he said. "There is no doubt that the mortgage interest rate is, for most people, the most significant interest rate that they face."
Though incomes as a whole remained unchanged in July, disposable income -- what consumers have left to spend after taxes -- rose 0.2 percent. Mr. Wiegand attributed about half the gains in disposable income, which has ballooned more than 5 percent in the last 12 months, to the cut last year in the federal income tax. "For all the political heat that the tax cut is taking," he said, "it's helping steady consumer demand right now."
Mr. Wiegand recommended accelerating the tax rate reductions scheduled for 2004 as an extra stimulus for the economy. Mr. Roach disagreed. "The last thing we need is a tax cut aimed at upper-income investors," he said. "If we do want to provide some support to consumer demand, it should be for lower- to middle-income households."
Judging by the Census Bureau's most recent figures on the distribution of income, the rate reductions would probably benefit fewer than half of Americans who receive any income.
Mr. Roach acknowledged that the strong spending by consumers in July did not support his earlier prediction of a return to recession this year. But he warned against ignoring the burden of consumers' debts merely because of their current behavior.
"I haven't slept well in a couple of years," he said, "and I'm not going to sleep any better tonight."

HEADLINE: Professors Offer A Reality Check For Politicians 

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
When Leonard Wantchekon set out to investigate what kind of campaign messages are most effective, he could have done the standard review of past political advertisements or interviewed candidates, consultants and voters. But Professor Wantchekon, who teaches politics at New York University and is an expert in game theory, wanted a more scientific approach. 
 So he chose a novel but controversial approach: instead of observing an election, he participated in one. 
 Born and reared in Benin, Professor Wantchekon decided to use the 2001 presidential primary in his small West African home country as his case study. As a younger man, he had helped found the Democratic Front of Benin, in the early 1980's the only opposition group to military rule in that country, and in 1988immigrated to Canada as a political refugee. With his previous political ties, he was able to convince Benin's four primary candidates to allow him and his researchers to write and disseminate campaign messages for each of them and then test them on villagers. 
Working hand in hand with the two opposition and two pro-government parties, Professor Wantchekon and his team created two types of messages. One used specific promises -- to build schools, clinics and roads in a particular village, for example; the other invoked a much broader appeal to improve the nation's general welfare. The team enlisted tribal leaders, soccer stars, popular musicians and local officials to help deliver their messages. From December 2000 to the primary in March 2001, they campaigned in about 20 villages, each with some 700 inhabitants. Each village was randomly assigned to receive either the specific promise or the broad appeal. Some 4.1 million voters in other villages who received the candidates' regular campaign messages, and not ones prepared for the experiment, served as a control group. 
The research, known as a field experiment, was unusual, Professor Wantchekon said, because "it involved real candidates in real elections."
But intervening in real elections creates problems, say some political scientists, who argue that potentially tampering with election results is unethical, as is having people unknowingly participate in an experiment. 
"There are some major ethical concerns with field experiments in that they can affect election results and bring up important considerations of informed consent," said Rebecca B. Morton, who also teaches politics at New York University. 
F. Christopher Arterton, dean of the Graduate School of Political Management at George Washington University, said he was not familiar with the study but cautioned that in general with field experiments, "one has to be careful not to cross the line between being a researcher and being an advocate."
Professor Wantchekon, who still counts himself among the pro-democracy advocates in Benin, said such concerns were overblown. Villages were carefully screened to help ensure that the experiment would not influence the results, he said. Only villages where the votes were not close in the previous election were selected. (As it turned out, the incumbent, Mathieu Kerekou, a Marxist former military ruler, won). Professor Wantchekon also argued that it was perfectly reasonable not to inform villagers that they were participating in his experiment because doing so would have skewed the study's results. In the end, he emphasized, it would be the villagers who might eventually benefit from his findings.
Professor Wantchekon said his results, which are under peer review, showed that specific promises worked well for incumbents, but not for challengers or underdogs, who won more votes when they used broad appeals. Women also preferred broad appeals. The findings, he added, could sharpen the political debate: "There are clear benefits to voters from this experiment." Candidates courting women, he said, might be motivated to work for more lasting changes in children's health care and education. 
To Professor Wantchekon and other proponents of field experiments, that method has a scientific rigor that is lacking in other types of political analysis. It is well accepted in medical research, for example: when scientists test new medical treatments, they compare a new drug to an existing one or to a placebo by testing it on people who are randomly chosen and who do not know which drug they are getting. Random selection gives researchers confidence that any difference in results between the two groups is due to the treatment. Similarly, field experiments, supporters say, promise to shed light on important political questions, from why people vote to what makes for successful welfare reform.
"We see experiments in medicine and say, 'We can do that,' " said Donald P. Green, who heads the Institute for Social and Policy Studies at Yale University, a research center that sponsors field experiments, including Professor Wantchekon's. 
Professor Green concedes that critics of the method raise important questions. But in his view, designing social programs around untested theories or allowing problems to go unfixed is worse than staging randomized experiments that can produce important findings. 
Some scholars point out that because the method takes the researcher into the real world with all its complexities, it offers less control over what is being measured, which makes the results less verifiable. Unlike the messy real world and all its hard-to-control variables, the laboratory is "refreshingly free of confounding influences," argues James E. Alt, director of the Center for Basic Research in the Social Sciences at Harvard University, who says he personally favors statistical analyses.
But Professor Alt also acknowledges that the artificial environment of the laboratory can distort results. He said that while some researchers in recent years have sought to make laboratory experiments more realistic -- setting up television sets in shopping malls, for example, where participants can view campaign commercials in a natural setting -- laboratory experiments still lack the context and realism of the field.
Field experiments began in the 1920's with agronomists, who wanted to improve crop yields -- hence the method's name. An early experiment in politics, in 1927, looked at voter turnout in Chicago. 
Although a handful of political scientists tried the technique, their efforts were almost completely forgotten by the 1960's, as the statistical revolution swept through the social sciences, including political science and economics.
A small but influential group of academics, including Professor Green, began resurrecting field experiments in the late 1990's in an effort to put the "science" back in political science. 
He began in his own backyard. He and Alan S. Gerber, another political scientist at Yale, wanted to find out which type of campaign was most effective in getting voters to the polls: mailings, telephone or door-to-door canvassing. During the 1998 local elections in New Haven, Professors Green and Gerber randomly surveyed 30,000 registered voters. They found that canvassing in person increased turnout by 9 percentage points. Telephone appeals had no effect. Mailings increased turnout by up to several percentage points, depending on how frequently they were sent out. The results, they said, could be used to create programs that promoted greater voter turnout.
There are huge questions that field experimentation cannot answer, for obvious ethical and logistical reasons. For example, what conditions make for a successful coup d'etat and what causes genocide? And while scholars might find it useful to identify the reason people don't bother to vote, most would consider it unethical to stage an experiment that kept voters away from the polls.
Kathleen McGraw, who teaches political science at Ohio State University, said that while field experiments provided more rigorous findings that could be used to improve democracy, the ethics of a particular experiment must be considered on a case-by-case basis. "It all comes down," she said, "to whether in specific experiments, the potential benefits outweigh the potential harm" to participants.
One place likely to feel the impact of field experiments, if they become more widely used, is the multimillion-dollar political-consulting industry, which thrives on creating campaign messages of unproven and untested value, said Professor Arterton of George Washington University. "It's an industry that is very skilled at talking about the factors that produce a result," he said, "but it's not very effective. Field experiments could make some political consulting firms out there very uncomfortable."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Not the Only Nation Resisting a Strong Pact at the Summit Meeting on Global Warming 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
The photograph appears in a full-page advertisement in The International Herald Tribune under the headline "Put a Face on Global Warming and Forest Destruction." 
 It is a picture of President Bush, whose country is accused by protesters and some delegates at an international conference here of derailing any hope of progress at the talks to reduce poverty and protect the environment. 
 "Corporate criminals!" the protesters shout as they assail American officials for opposing targets and deadlines intended to promote development while preserving the environment.
But in the private negotiating rooms at the United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development here, the United States is far from the only country balking at approving a strong, ambitious agreement. 
Saudi Arabia, Canada, Japan and Australia, for instance, also oppose deadlines for the conversion from oil and gas power to windmills, solar panels and other forms of renewable energy. The European Union objects to eliminating subsidies for activities that threaten natural resources, like commercial fishing.
Developing countries have joined the United States in pressing to water down language that would have committed nations to significantly reducing the threat that dangerous chemicals pose to health and the environment.
The large number of countries opposed to various targets and time frames is the main reason why negotiators have struggled this week to complete the summit meeting's plan, which is meant to be an ambitious blueprint for the world.
On one hand, the United States has been almost alone in refusing to support an agreement to reduce the number of people who lack sanitation by half by 2015. Australia also opposes that time frame. 
But on the other hand, the American decision to accept timetables for restoring depleted fisheries and for reducing the risk of hazardous chemicals has been nearly lost in the storm of criticism.
"The situation has been very polarized, but it's not a matter of singling out one country," said Gustavo Ainchil, the diplomat from Argentina who is leading the negotiations on energy. "You cannot simplify a problem that is very complex."
Everyone here supports the summit meeting's overall goals of protecting plants and wildlife, reducing pollution and bringing water, electricity and housing to the poor. But poor nations object to environmental targets or strong language that would require costly intervention on their part. Wealthy nations refuse to budge on subsidies that protect their industries. 
Oil producers are reluctant to embrace commitments that promote alternative energy sources. Other countries, in many cases, view the deadlines as unnecessary regulation.
The result is that the plan, which officials hoped would be completed tonight, is still incomplete, with deadlocks on issues ranging from subsidies to renewable energy and from corporate accountability to globalization.
Washington has borne the brunt of the blame for the delay. The United States has the world's largest economy and is one of its largest polluters. Many leaders complain that it has been reluctant to eliminate the agricultural subsidies that make it difficult for poor nations to export to the American market. Other officials complain that it has failed to acknowledge and accept its obligations for cleaning up the environment.
Last year, Mr. Bush angered many leaders when he rejected a treaty negotiated in Kyoto, Japan, that set targets for reducing emissions of gases that trap heat in the atmosphere. Mr. Bush said such accords should also bind developing nations, especially China and India, that are also major emitters of such gases. Developing nations have refused, saying wealthy countries are among the largest polluters and should clean up first.
The European Union, which wants to set deadlines for resolving environmental problems, has been sharply critical of Washington's reluctance to make commitments to such agreements.
"On targets and timetables on the environmental issues, we haven't seen a concrete proposal, nothing at all except watering down the text, avoiding anything concrete," said Jos Delbeke, a senior member of the European delegation. "We cannot understand why the United States, being a world leader, is taking such a harsh stance."
Environmentalists agreed, saying the United States deserved the criticism because it had objected to so many critical aspects of the summit meeting's plan, including time frames for converting to renewable energy and for reversing the decline of endangered plants and animals. 
Among the critics is the Rainforest Action Network, the advocacy group that placed the advertisement in The International Herald Tribune.
"Any progress is welcome," Paul L. Joffe, the director of international affairs for the National Wildlife Federation, said of the American agreement on fisheries and chemicals. "But what we've seen so far is very minimal compared to the enormous challenges here and the enormous lack of commitment to goals, timetables and funding."
But United Nations officials described the American concessions on fisheries and chemicals as significant. The Americans have agreed to restore depleted fisheries, where possible, by 2015, and to make commitments for sound management of chemicals with the goal of minimizing their adverse effects on health and nature by 2020.
Environmental groups complain that the wording is weak. But some officials warn that the intense criticism of the Americans has given a distorted picture of the negotiations, as if the rest of world were eager to embrace difficult decisions.
"They're always the focus because they have so much power," said Jon Pronk, the United Nations special envoy to the meeting.
"But it's necessary not only to be critical of the Americans," Mr. Pronk said. "You have to be also critical of the Europeans. Agricultural subsidies are outrageously high in Europe. It's complex. It's not only a north-south dispute."

HEADLINE: Trees Fall in Canada's Forests, but U.S. Isn't Buying 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: VALEMOUNT, British Columbia 

 BODY:
In this tiny lumber village in the Canadian Rockies, people are more likely to take their vacations in Las Vegas or Disney World, retire in Arizona, drive Chevrolets and live in mobile homes imported from the United States.
 With the ties to the United States here so tight, disruptions in relations with the United States can hit as hard as a family squabble. And relations now are pretty raw. 
 The squabble is over a 27 percent American tariff levied in May on Canadian softwood lumber -- wood from any conifer, like spruce, fir or pine. People here blame the levy for the shutting down of their only lumber mill in September, causing one in three local workers to lose their jobs. 
"The United States is acting like a bully," said Valemount's mayor, Jeannette Townsend, an otherwise soft-spoken official. "Our military went over to Afghanistan even though it was not our war. That was a neighborly act, and in response the U.S. government and lumber barons are devastating our communities."
A look at the dispute from both sides of the border, however, shows that this trade issue is a lot more complex than it may look to the parties involved. The tariffs have not stopped American mills from closing or curtailed Canadian exports or bolstered slumping lumber prices. The finger-pointing may be as much a measure of a troubled industry on both sides of the border as anything else. The underlying reason, analysts say, is that despite a housing boom in the United States and Canada the last few years, the world is awash in lumber, thanks largely to the enduring recession in Japan and a marked increase in exports from Russia. 
Months of trade negotiations have been fruitless, making the lumber issue the greatest irritant between the two countries in years. The dispute is so bitter it appears to have hardened Canadian government views on other issues, including the Bush administration's policies toward Iraq and American pressure to strengthen the Canadian military in the campaign against terrorism.
Annual Canadian softwood lumber sales to the United States amount to between $6 billion and $12 billion, depending on highly volatile prices, and supply about a third of American needs. In June, a month after the tariffs were imposed, Canadian softwood sales to the United States plunged 40 percent, shrinking the country's trade surplus and signaling that a deep recession may have descended on the lumber sector.
There are 70,000 Canadian jobs directly involved in softwood production, half of which is destined for the United States. The Canadian Forest Service predicts a loss of 25,000 jobs if the dispute goes on for more than two years, which seems possible.
The signs of hard times are already visible in this village of 1,300 people, where 40 percent of the households have at least one member who works in the lumber industry. Outside the Slocan Forest Products Ltd. plant, 30,000 trees lie like piles of matchsticks, open to weathering by the sun and rain. The local food bank, founded during a previous slump in the early 1990's, is gearing up again, and the Slocan mill has hired a social worker to counsel the newly unemployed. 
"When the U.S. goes to war they always have to have Canada on their tail, and is this the thanks Canada gets?" asked Shirley Gonyou, who has worked in the mill for 27 years. "Do Americans want to know if Canadians are on their knees yet?"
But the same rage expressed in lumber towns across British Columbia, Quebec and Ontario can be heard south of the border as well, where even more lumber mills have been closing down in recent years. In the 13 months before the tariffs were put in place, 93 American mills and 53 Canadian mills temporarily or permanently shut down production. (In the four months after the tariffs, 42 Canadian mills and 28 American mills sharply reduced production or shut down.) 
"The Canadians want to access our markets at the expense of our workers," said Robert Lockwood, president of TreeSource Industries Inc. His company, which had 12 mills employing 1,500 people in 1998, was already down to four mills employing 400 and another was scheduled to close at the end of August. 
At the core of the dispute is a divergence in lumber economies. 
In the United States, most timberlands are privately owned, with harvesting rights auctioned off or sold at market rates. But in Canada, more than 90 percent of timberlands are owned by provincial governments that set cutting fees. The governments adjust the fees and otherwise regulate cutting and manufacturing in such a way as to guarantee employment in remote rural areas.
American companies say Canadian timber fees are so low they amount to a hefty subsidy. The Commerce Department has estimated that the margin of cutting costs between the countries is 27 percent -- hence the size of the tariffs. Canadian officials say that figure is based on old data, and that their fees more or less match market forces.
Canadian government officials and lumber executives say their older forests are superior to those in the United States, producing a better product favored by American carpenters. And they maintain that their American competitors are suffering more from their own inefficiency than from unfair competition. In the southern United States, analysts note, costs of logs have risen more than sixfold over the last 30 years for lumber producers while the selling price of lumber has increased only by a factor of 2.6.
Stephen G. Atkinson, a forest-products analyst at the Bank of Montreal, wrote in a recent report that when American officials speak of Canadian "stumpage fees" they are merely stating the average cost paid to the government for timber. He noted that harvesting costs also include fees for forest management, road building, replanting and environmental remediation.
"Canadian companies are responsible for forest management and the U.S. companies are not," Mr. Atkinson wrote. "An honest comparison looks at total costs and profitability."
But according to Cheri Burda, a forestry analyst at the David Suzuki Foundation, a Canadian environmental group, Canadian companies do not have to abide by the kind of strict endangered-species legislation that restricts operations in the United States and raises costs substantially. 
Lumber prices for American mills have remained low despite the tariffs because Canadian companies stepped up production in the weeks before the duties took effect and because Russian, Scandinavian and Eastern European producers have increased their exports to the United States. Currently, 1,000 board feet of green Douglas fir fetches around $285, well below the $400 average since January 1995 and the $305 required for the average mill to break even, according to American industry sources.
Talks between the two countries broke off in March, but are expected to resume in the next few weeks. Meanwhile, Canada is appealing to panels of the World Trade Organization and the North American Free Trade Association. 
"The tariff policy has backfired," Canada's trade minister, Pierre Pettigrew, said in an interview. "We will win before the W.T.O. and Nafta, but that will take time, and in the meantime Canadian communities are suffering and American consumers are being deprived of Canadian lumber."
In a separate interview, Peter Allgeier, the deputy United States trade representative, said he saw no likelihood of a quick solution. "If the Canadian provinces were to sell their timber through a market mechanism like an auction we would say that would be a good way to solve the problem," he said.
Just south of Tacoma, Wash., at a TreeSource mill that closed in mid-August, there was little argument over who is to blame for the industry's troubles.
"Free trade and the Canadians bringing their lumber in have brought the lumber prices down to nothing," said Ted Smith, a 36-year-old mill operator. "There's a bitterness, but we don't have a whole lot of control. I just hope the tariff will help."

COMPANY: SLOCAN FOREST PRODUCTS LTD (60%)

HEADLINE: TRADE PANEL SAYS EUROPE CAN IMPOSE PENALTIES ON U.S. 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization, the international arbiter in global trade disputes, ruled today that the European Union can impose $4 billion in penalties on the United States because an American tax break that promotes exports is illegal.
 The penalty is the biggest handed down against a country since the trade organization based in Geneva came into being in 1995, and it could hurt companies like Boeing, General Electric and Caterpillar Inc. that have been heavy users of the tax break. 
 But the ruling is probably less important for the actual money involved than for the diplomatic and political repercussions.
European leaders have made it clear they will give the United States time to change its law and will not impose the penalties, which would be in the form of retaliatory tariffs on American exports, anytime soon. 
But trade experts said the Europeans would now have what amounts to a Damoclean sword they can hold over the United States on bitterly disputed issues ranging from steel tariffs to farm subsidies.
"This gives the European Union a $4 billion club against us," said Gary Hufbauer, an international trade analyst at the Institute for International Economics, a policy research group in Washington. "It can keep the club in the closet, but it will be a presence that surrounds all the negotiations at the World Trade Organization."
The trade organization had already ruled twice that the tax break violates international trade treaties, and lawmakers in Congress have already been making their second effort to pass a new version of the law that would pass muster under the international rules.
Today's decision, which had been anxiously awaited for months, was simply about the size of the penalty that the European Union could impose. The United States contended that the penalty should not be more than $1 billion, but the trade panel accepted the European claim that the damage it has suffered from the American tax breaks was $4 billion.
In Washington, the Bush administration played down the significance of today's decision, predicting that the offending American law will soon be rewritten.
"I am confident that today's findings regarding damages will be rendered moot by our coming into compliance," said Kenneth Dam, deputy secretary of the Treasury, in a written statement.
Today's verdict could also have a profound impact on American political attitudes toward the World Trade Organization, providing ammunition to critics who see the group as a threat to national sovereignty.
Though it has been hailed as a major force in lowering trade barriers around the world, the trade organization is frequently attacked by trade unions and other critics as a faceless and secretive agent of "globalization."
The actual dispute centers on what are called "foreign sales corporations," which are offshore subsidiaries of American corporations used to export American-made products. These subsidiaries are exempt from normal United States taxes, but the European Union has argued for years that the tax breaks amount to illegal export subsidies.
The ruling's biggest effect is likely to be on a handful of major American manufacturers who have used the disputed tax break most heavily. Boeing and General Electric are both believed to have received tax benefits from the provision of more than $100 million a year. Motorola, Honeywell, Caterpillar and Cisco Systems have been among the other biggest beneficiaries.
Pascal Lamy, the European Commission's chief trade negotiator, made it clear today that he would give the United States time to rewrite its laws before imposing any penalties.
But he also said Europe's patience would not last forever. The verdict, he said, "makes the cost of noncompliance with the W.T.O. crystal clear." Another European trade official who works below Mr. Lamy put the matter more bluntly. "We are patient," he said. "But patience has its limits."
Despite the Bush administration's optimism on fixing the problem, trade experts, including lobbyists who are pushing for a rewritten law, say the task is harder than it looks.
Congress passed one new version of the tax break in 2000, but the trade organization ruled in February that the law was no better than the previous one because it still gave a selective tax break to exporters.
Lawmakers on the House Ways and Means Committee drafted another law this summer, but the measure became ensnarled in feuding about other more explosive issues. One of them is a proposal to cut back on the ability of American companies to avoid almost all taxes by incorporating in offshore tax havens.
European officials are reluctant to press their case to the limits, in part because they want to avoid a trade war with the United States but also because new tariffs would raise prices for European consumers.
"What this does is give Europe the legal right to retaliate against us, but this is a legal right that will prove difficult and self-damaging to exercise," said Susan Esserman, a trade lawyer who was deputy trade representative in the Clinton administration. "It would be a self-inflicted wound."
The bigger issue is whether European leaders will try to use their new authority to exert pressure over other contentious issues.
European leaders are still furious about the steep tariffs on imported steel that President Bush imposed this year. The administration has diluted those tariffs by making exceptions for hundreds of products, but European leaders are still threatening to impose retaliatory tariffs on American products like orange juice.
"They can pull the $4 billion sanctions trigger whenever they want," said Christoph Feddersen, a trade lawyer in Brussels with the law firm of Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton. 
"Even if there is no legal link" between the foreign sales corporations case "and the other disputes, such as the one over steel tariffs, there is obviously going to be a connection," he added. "The W.T.O. is not just about the law. It is also about politics and diplomacy."

HEADLINE: Nassau Budget Deficit Is Worse Than Had Been Predicted 

BYLINE:  By MARC SANTORA

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Aug. 30 

 BODY:
Nassau County's financial outlook is worse than officials had previously thought, with a possible deficit of $268 million next year, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today.
 The county, which needed state help to pay its bills last year and to balance this year's budget, projected in April that its deficit could be $185 million in 2003. 
 Mr. Suozzi said that Nassau, like counties across the state that have suffered during the economic downturn, has suffered, too. Mr. Suozzi, who took office in January, said that Nassau's problems were compounded by what he called a decade of fiscal mismanagement and unresolved labor disputes. 
In April, Mr. Suozzi outlined a plan to deal with the budget crisis. Today, in a presentation to the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, which was created in 2000 to oversee county finances, he said, "There is no one big dramatic solution to the problems." His plan, though, is still the best way to deal with the problems, he said.
The plan consists of resolving labor disputes over wages and benefits, restructuring debt, increasing property taxes and reducing the size of the work force.
"I don't want to do layoffs," Mr. Suozzi said, noting that he could not rule them out. He said he had basically frozen departmental budgets for next year in an attempt to reduce the work force by at least 1,200 people by the end of 2003, which he thought would be sufficient to help balance the budget.
On property taxes, Mr. Suozzi said he would not raise them next year above the 19.4 percent that he had previously projected. He has committed to using the extra revenue solely to pay down the debt.
Mr. Suozzi is required to submit a budget proposal to the County Legislature before Sept. 16.
Stressing that Nassau's predicament is partly a function of the downturn in the economy, Mr. Suozzi said, "Every county in New York State is facing increased pension costs."
He said $15 million was initially budgeted to meet pension costs but that the fall in the prices of some stocks, where the pension funds were invested, meant that the county would have to pay more than $60 million.
Another problem common in counties was reduced sales tax revenue, he said. "People are not buying as many clothes or cars or shoes," Mr. Suozzi said. "These are tough times for the entire state."

HEADLINE: Despite Slump, Cities See Drop In Welfare Rolls 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
During the boom years of the late 1990's, when the 1996 welfare law was still sending public assistance rolls plummeting nationwide and more recipients were leaving for jobs than anyone had expected, critics of the law had one big warning: wait until the economy sours, the poor will come back.
 But despite the economic downturn, it has not happened in New York City, which has the largest number of public assistance cases of any city in the nation. Nor has it happened in many other large urban areas. 
 Although unemployment in New York City has risen more than 20 percent from its low in March and the numbers of families calling themselves homeless have jumped to record levels, the number of people who get public assistance has tumbled to 418,277, down 9.5 percent since the start of the year.
No one really knows the reasons for the decline, though given the passionate welfare debate, theories abound. All sides agree that factors such as how the city has chosen to administer the national mandate and the culture of the local bureaucracy have so far trumped cycles in the economy in affecting the rolls. Harmony ends there. 
On one side of the debate, advocates for the poor say they see the decline as yet more proof that the system is callous by design. Pointing to swelling lines at food pantries and housing shelters, they say there is overwhelming anecdotal evidence that the city is discouraging needy people from getting aid.
For proponents and administrators of changes in welfare, the continued downward march is evidence that their policies have had a long-lasting impact on improving the self-reliance of former welfare recipients. Independent researchers have also pointed to other factors, like quirks in the types of employment that single mothers are most likely to find in New York and the fact that welfare rolls in the city are disproportionately high.
Most important, proponents of change say, New York City's experience is not particularly anomalous when viewed against national data. Because of how the 1996 law was written, the Administration for Families and Children in Washington collects data on caseloads by state instead of city.
For 2001, the most recent period for which data is available, 26 states had rising caseloads, but the overall number of people receiving federal welfare benefits fell by 5.6 percent.
"There is great variability, but the overall trend continues to be down," said Wade F. Horn, assistant secretary for children and families. Despite economic contractions across the country, he added, "we are not seeing increases in caseloads which would bring us back to anything close to the level we saw in 1996."
An informal survey of counties with major urban centers done by New York City itself, while not a perfect apples-to-apples comparison, suggests that many other cities continue to see steady declines.
From January through May of this year, New York City public assistance caseloads dropped 4.1 percent. In the same time period, Chicago's Cook County saw the number of recipients of federal aid decline 6.9 percent while Detroit's Wayne County dropped 1.3 percent and Los Angeles County lost 2.9 percent.
The main reason the downward trend continues nationally even in these times of economic frailty is that welfare and the state of the economy, surprisingly, have historically had weak statistical correlation. Verna Eggleston, the city's commissioner of Human Resources, says the rolls are going down and may continue to decline in the near future because "there are still people on our caseload who are engageable" in the work process.
Lawrence Mead, a professor at New York University who has been studying welfare nationally, is more blunt. "It continues to go down because the levels of dependence in New York City are still well above those that would be dictated by economic conditions," he said.
Professor Mead points out the percentage of New Yorkers who get public assistance is still several points above the national average.
Another possible explanation for the continued exodus is that former welfare recipients have been shielded from the economic downturn because of the kinds of work they have tended to go into.
"Single mothers have kind of dodged the recession bullet," said Mark K. Levitan at the Community Service Society of New York. "They are particularly well represented in health care, education and social services," industries that grew strongly through 2001.
For example, 17.9 percent of single mothers in New York are employed in education and social services jobs, a field that grew 15 percent in the last two years, Mr. Levitan said.
The city's peculiar employment pattern may also help to explain why federal assistance caseloads here have declined rapidly while caseloads in 26 states, including California, Massachusetts and Michigan, increased in 2001, the most recent period for which the federal government collected data.
"Expansion in those particular industries in New York City help explain why it is not increasing as much as in other states," said Margy Waller, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington who studies welfare and poverty. In other localities, Ms. Waller said, single mothers were more heavily employed in travel-related industries like hotels, which were crushed after the Sept. 11 attack.
Demetra Nightingale, director of welfare and training research at the Urban Institute, said many states seeing sharp increases in their rolls also had shorter time limits for public assistance than New York and cut back on their benefit amounts more drastically. Since they were quicker to shed dependents, she said, they have seen quicker rebounds. 
That means, she added, that New York should not congratulate itself too heartily yet. Unemployment payments and temporary job programs took some of the edge off the displacement caused by the events of Sept. 11, but adverse consequences of that economic shock have been delayed, not avoided.
"You might not see its effects until about now or in the next few months," she said.
In fact, applications for public assistance in New York rose to 19,083 in July from 15,395 a month earlier, according to the city's Human Resources Administration. Average monthly applications for 2002 are also up by about 800 people over the monthly average in 2001, indicating that the decline in rolls may be on the verge of slowing.
Advocates for the poor, however, insist that regional differences and economic quirks cannot explain the demand increases they are seeing at food kitchens and housing shelters. Instead, they insist, the city is so focused on shedding people that it is scaring away the truly needy.
"Because the whole program under the previous administration was driven by punitive action, clients don't feel they can turn to the benefits when they really need it, " said Carlos Rodriguez, director of food stamp programs and policy at the Community Food Resource Center, an advocacy group that also runs a soup kitchen in Harlem.
"The picture is painted perfectly by the long list at the E.A.U.," he said, referring to the Emergency Assistance Unit, the city's intake center for homeless families, "and even longer lines at emergency food providers."
Two recent reports bolster claims by advocates for the poor that the decline in welfare numbers conflicts with other indicators that show the poor in increasing distress. More than three-quarters of the food pantries in New York City faced an increased demand for food in the six months after Sept. 11, according to a study conducted by Hunter College for the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. Food pantries give provisions to needy families as opposed to single homeless individuals.
In addition, the report surveyed food pantry directors on the causes of the increase and 76 percent said the loss of welfare benefits was a key reason. "The people running nonprofit, community-based feeding agencies overwhelmingly indicate that people kicked off welfare are coming to them for help because they do not have jobs," said Joel Berg, the group's executive director.
And a report to be released next week by the Public Advocate's Office compared food stamp use in 10 major urban areas in the period from June 2001 to June 2002 and found participation in programs increased in every city but New York, where it fell 2 percent. The report concludes, "New York City's previous administration's opposition to public assistance may also contribute to the city's low participation levels."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
W.T.O. Rules Penalties Can Be Imposed on U.S.
The World Trade Organization, the international arbiter in global trade disputes, ruled that the European Union can impose $4 billion in penalties on the United States because an American tax break that promotes exports is illegal.
 The verdict is the biggest penalty ever handed down against a country since the Geneva-based trade organization came into being in 1995, and it could hurt companies like Boeing and General Electric that have been heavy users of the tax break. Page A1. 

5-Month Fall for Dow and Nasdaq
The Nasdaq composite index ended August in the red, its fifth consecutive monthly loss. It has not suffered a five-month fall since April 1984. The Dow Jones industrial average also had a five-month decline, for the first time since September 1981. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index just managed to avoid a fifth month of decline. C4.

Plans for an Ad-Less 2003 Masters
CBS Sports and the USA Network will televise the Masters without commercials next year from Citigroup, I.B.M. and Coca-Cola. The Augusta National Golf Club said it made the decision to protect its sponsors from being pressured by a campaign to add women to its membership rolls. A1.

Boeing Machinists to Vote Again
The machinists union at Boeing will vote again on management's latest contract proposal because of confusion among workers about the ballot, union officials said. Workers said they voted on Thursday without knowing what they were supposed to do after the contract expired midnight tomorrow. That prompted the union to seal the results and call a new vote. A16.

The F.A.A. ordered commercial airlines to check more than 1,400 planes manufactured by Boeing to see if they are equipped with an improperly wired fuel pump. A16.

Andersen Payout to Enron Creditors
Andersen Worldwide, the umbrella group for overseas accounting firms affiliated with Arthur Andersen, confirmed that it would pay nearly $60 million to creditors, employees and shareholders of Enron. C3.

Flight Attendants Criticize Plan
United Airlines flight attendants called the plan to reduce labor costs 15 percent too drastic and joined other unions in urging the airline to name a new chief executive to hasten financial recovery efforts. C4.

A July Surge in Consumer Spending
The Commerce Department reported that personal spending in July jumped 1 percent, to $7.35 trillion -- the biggest increase in nine months -- thanks largely to low interest rates. Consumers managed to spend more even though their total incomes did not change. Most of the increase in spending came from a 3.9 percent rise in purchases of big-ticket items like cars and appliances. C3.

Record Stock Fund Withdrawals
As the stock market declined, investors withdrew a record $52.6 billion from stock mutual funds in July and shifted a record $28.1 billion into bond funds, an industry report said. C4.

Regulators Investigate Airlines
The Japanese Fair Trade Commission will look into whether Japan Airlines and two other airlines violated the country's monopoly law by cutting fares on a route also operated by an upstart carrier, Skynet Asia Airways. C2.

U.S. Markets Are Closed on Monday
United States financial markets and banks will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. Most financial markets in other countries will be open.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
A Whiff of Failure Is Still in the Air

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
In the Mets' clubhouse, the television was showing the Cubbies, "the only game in the majors this afternoon," as Ernie Banks loves to enunciate. 
 There was the ivy on the wall. There was the brick wall that has been behind home plate since time immemorial. It all looked so sweet and normal, but it will take more than the Friendly Confines of Wrigley Field in the middle of the afternoon to bring baseball back to anything approximating sweet and normal. 
 The Mets drifted in, seeming to relish the routine of slipping into uniform. 
"Contentissimo!" shouted Armando Benitez, sounding very happy to be there, playing ball, earning a paycheck, and a big paycheck at that.
But for all the ritual, there was a hangdog air over all the players and the people who own the teams. They had gone to the last possible moment with their labor negotiations, only to discover that a small percentage of people care anymore, and some of those are angry. Fans had demonstrated in Anaheim the night before, protesting the potential wreck of a winning season. 
"There will be some fan fallout," admitted Vance Wilson, the backup catcher who worked his way out of the minors and became the Mets' assistant player representative. "We need to spend time with the fans to let them know they are important."
But even the sincere impulses may not be enough. The players and the owners cannot merely open the gates and tell America that everything is just the way it was.
After the last sour month of labor discussions, the baseball nation saw the furry-tongued Bud Selig and Donald Fehr trying to assure us that this was a wonderful and historic step for humankind, because baseball was spared a stoppage this time around.
For all their overnight negotiating, it does not sound as if anything has changed. The rich teams -- that is to say, the Yankees -- will continue to stockpile their cable riches in order to load up on Mussinas and Giambis, their Mondesis and Weavers. 
Not even a new luxury tax, which will cost the Yankees a few million dollars here and there, will stop them from putting their foot on the face of the American League, forever.
There was one clear development during a month of blather, and that was the immense distaste the public now has for baseball's posturing. This is new. It has never been this bad. Oh, there was an old guy here and a little kid there, holding up signs saying, "Please, don't go away," but mostly the reaction was, whatever. Prove it. Show us some moxie. Take a hike. Come back in a year.
In the end, the players could not walk because where else are they going to make an average of $2.4 million a year in salary?
Some words flickered across the screen in the Mets' clubhouse. Steve Kline, the Cardinals' player representative, was quoted as saying: "It came down to us playing baseball or having our reputations and life ripped by the fans. Baseball would have never been the same if we had walked out."
He was right about that, but coming to an agreement was hardly an act of statesmanship. Not much is different. Selig threatened to contract a few weak teams last winter, but contraction has now been put off for four years. 
A lot of economists have said that baseball is in a precarious position with advertisers and television, but nevertheless an owner like Jeffrey Loria trades up on franchises the way yuppies trade in S.U.V's. 
In the new settlement, baseball is going to work toward distributing about $250 million a year to the weaker teams -- with no guarantee that the owners won't do the Enron Shuffle with the books to build themselves a hacienda rather than a farm system. 
And the bogus steroid clause, letting the lads beef up all winter and take their drug tests in the friendly confines of spring training? Fehr and Selig insult our intelligence with that one. 
While the two sides pulled their all-nighter on how to divide the swag, I could not help but think about Pete Coscarart, the old Brooklyn Dodger second baseman, who used to send me a few handwritten letters reminding me that baseball had adamantly refused to include the pre-1946 players in the pension plan. 
"They are waiting for us to die," said the spunky Al Gionfriddo, another old Dodger who has been ignored. 
Well, Coscarart did die in late July at age 89, so now there are about 75 players left. Oddly enough, they were not mentioned in yesterday's settlement. 
Meanwhile, George Steinbrenner and the other big-market owners were more than willing to hold all the fans' money for playoff tickets during a potential layoff. But the working stiffs who waited outside the ballparks did not know whether they were going to make a decent pocketful of beery quarters and dollar bills from working as vendors and waitresses and ushers last night.
This is not their game. And at the new ticket prices, this is not the people's game anymore, either. 
The players got into their uniforms. They are good at what they do, and must prove it in public, over and over again. In general, they deserve their money, as well as the friendly applause from the tiny crowd when they took the field last night. 
"Nobody got hurt," Mo Vaughn said, meaning there was no labor stoppage. But something has been hurt. Baseball's image has been bruised, even disfigured. It has never been this bad.

HEADLINE: A City That's Down but Not Out 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Poverty in a Land of Plenty: Can Hartford Ever Recover?" HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
LAST-MINUTE DEAL IN BASEBALL TALKS PREVENTS A STRIKE

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
For the first time in 30 years, Major League Baseball and its players reached agreement on a new labor contract without a work stoppage yesterday, concluding the deal a few hours short of a strike.
 "This represents the first time in baseball history that we have reached a collective bargaining agreement without the loss of a single game," Commissioner Bud Selig said at a news conference in Manhattan announcing the agreement. 
 Selig's reading of history was off -- negotiations in the 1960's were completed without work stoppages -- but, given the contentious relationship that had produced five strikes and three lockouts in the eight negotiations since 1972, the development was surprising.
It not only ensures labor peace for four more years, but it also guarantees that the World Series will be played this year. The last time the players and the owners tried to negotiate a new agreement, in 1994, the World Series was canceled for the first time in 90 years. 
"All streaks come to an end, and this is one that was overdue to come to an end," Donald Fehr, the union's executive director, said.
The agreement includes greater sharing of local revenue among baseball's 30 clubs and a more serious penalty for high payrolls, called a luxury tax, than the previous agreement had employed. The agreement also ensures that no teams will be eliminated through the 2006 season and provides for testing of players for steroids for the first time. News analysis, Page D1. 
In this negotiation, the players union, the Major League Baseball Players Association, may have given up more than it ever had since winning free agency for players in 1975. Selig, however, had made a persuasive argument that some aspects of the game needed fixing and players concluded that the time was right to settle and not squabble. The agreement must be ratified by both sides, but they say that is a foregone conclusion.
"This was definitely a time that with the market and people's portfolios down and Enrons and Arthur Andersens, WorldComs, certainly the effect of Sept. 11 coming up, people being laid off, all of that whole gamut made the players realize that a strike's not good for anyone," said Al Leiter, the Mets' player representative.
The players had set yesterday as a strike date, fearing that if they ended the season without a new agreement the owners would declare an impasse and put a new economic system in place after the World Series.
A series of all-day and all-night bargaining sessions took the negotiators to a deal completed little more than three hours before the day's first game was scheduled to be played in Chicago. Without an agreement, players would not have gone to Wrigley Field or 14 other ballparks where games were scheduled for last night.
But they played the game knowing their sport had changed its economics with the alterations in revenue sharing and the luxury tax. The union had been concerned about the effect of the combination of those two elements on the higher-spending teams, like the Yankees, but its negotiators succeeded in getting the clubs' negotiators to accept a tax system that should not be as costly to as many teams as they had wanted to affect.
"Obviously, that's a subject that we're very sensitive to," Fehr said. "We believe this is an agreement we can live with. Otherwise we wouldn't have made it."
Selig and the clubs have cited the disparity between teams' payrolls and competitive imbalance as serious problems. They point to the dominance of the Yankees in recent seasons as the epitome of their problems.
But in their economic proposals management did not want to affect only the Yankees; it was also going after six other big-spending teams, including the Mets. In the end, though, Selig settled for a plan that, if in effect this year, would tax the Yankees $9.5 million, the Texas Rangers $2.5 million and the Los Angeles Dodgers $315,000.
Management's preference would be for every team to be under the threshold and pay no tax. But when players hear that, they think the clubs want the tax to serve as a payroll cap. The money will be combined with the revenue-sharing proceeds.
Clubs that exceed the designated threshold will pay the tax on the portions of payrolls over the threshold. The threshold will be $117 million in 2003, $120.5 million in 2004, $128 million in 2005 and $136.5 million in 2006. The tax rates will range from 17.5 percent the first time a team exceeds the threshold to 40 percent the third and fourth times it goes beyond.
The two sides compromised on thresholds and rates.
But in a tradeoff, the players accepted a tax in the fourth year, which they initially opposed, in return for the clubs' acceptance of returning the termination date of the agreement from Oct. 31 to December. The union had wanted Dec. 31, which was the date before the last agreement, but settled for Dec. 19. The difference in dates deals with control over player contracts after the final season of the agreement, 2006.
Compromise was also present in the revenue-sharing plan. The union wanted part of the total amount phased in over four years, with the revenue sharing fully reached in the fourth year. The clubs wanted no phase-in. They agreed to a partial phase-in, with full revenue sharing in the final two years.
That full annual revenue-sharing sum will be $258 million, and the four-year total will be $988.68 million.
The bulk of the money, representing 34 percent of net local revenue, comes from the richer clubs and goes to the poorer clubs.
The idea of transferring money is for the poorer clubs to use it to improve their teams and become more competitive. Because the money will be divided equally among all recipients, as opposed to a different distribution system under the old agreement, middle-revenue clubs will benefit most from the plan.
Negotiators had basically completed their work on revenue sharing first, but it was contingent on reaching agreement on the luxury tax. It took four bargaining sessions through Thursday night and yesterday morning to get there.
Working primarily with two negotiators from each camp, Bob DuPuy and Rob Manfred for the clubs and Steve Fehr and Michael Weiner for the players, the two sides met for the better part of four hours between 9:30 p.m. and close to 2 a.m. Then at a 4 a.m. meeting, the players' two negotiators gave the clubs' pair a proposal. Two and a half hours later it was the clubs' negotiators who were offering a proposal.
With management officials growing impatient because there were travel plans to carry out if games were to be played yesterday, the union representatives went to the commissioner's office at 9:15 a.m. Fehr, who had not been at the smaller sessions, attended that meeting, which Selig also joined for his first appearance at the bargaining table.
The Boston Red Sox, meanwhile, were at Fenway Park, having delayed their 7:30 a.m. departure for Logan Airport and their flight to Cleveland. They waited more than an hour.
Other teams and players waited, too, to find out if their games and maybe the season were in jeopardy. Finally, shortly before noon, the agreement was concluded.
"It goes without saying we're really excited and happy we got this done," said Tom Glavine, the Atlanta Braves pitcher who is the National League player representative and a veteran of the 1994-95 strike. "We don't have to go through the uncertainties of another work stoppage and what it does to the game."
Selig remained euphoric. "I think there were a lot of people," he said, "who never believed they'd live long enough to see these two parties come together, make a very meaningful deal and do it without one game of work stoppage."

W.T.O. Allows Penalties Of $4 Billion Against U.S.
The World Trade Organization ruled that the European Union can impose $4 billion in penalties on the United States because an American tax break that promotes exports is illegal. The verdict is the biggest penalty handed down by the W.T.O., but European leaders have made it clear they will give the United States time to change its law. A1
